                                                  Books by the Author
1.  The Race of Grace—introductory book in which performance-related themes (such as perseverance) are considered
    essential for rewards in heaven. Entrance into heaven, in contrast, is regarded as free. A strong defense of unconditional
    security derived from believers being given to Jesus is a particular strength of this book.
2. Is Heaven a Gift or a Reward?—while some assert that heaven is a reward in some sense, this book maintains that regarding
    heaven itself as a gift is best.
3. Breaking the Rocking Horse—introductory book regarding the distinction between having eternal life as a gift versus
    obtaining it as a reward. An overview of the outer darkness and an exegetical treatment of the parable of the soils are this
    book’s primary strengths.
4. Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity—a more comprehensive discussion regarding perseverance (and other
    performance-related themes) as being needed for rewards in heaven rather than for entrance into heaven. This book
    provides both introductory material and advanced treatments.
5. Woolly Wolves and Woolless Sheep—a rejection of the notion that profession of salvation is proven genuine by the way a
    person lives. This book focuses on the parable of the sheep and the goats and shows the inadequacy of conditional security
    in interpreting this parable.
6. Sheep and Goats—an advanced discussion of the parable of the sheep and goats that evaluates four interpretations that are
    compatible with unconditional security.
7. Sealed and Secure—a thorough defense of a popular argument for unconditional security that also defends the premise of
    unconditional promises.
8. Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection—an advanced defense of unconditional security which affirms that believers
    can fall from grace but not fall from perfection.
9. Salvation—a study of how the verb save (sozo) and the noun salvation (soteria) are used in the NT. A comprehensive chart
    of NT usage is provided.
10. Believe—an aspectual defense of unconditional security that examines how the verb believe is used in the Gospel of John.
    A comprehensive chart of metaphors for believe in the Gospel of John is provided also.
11. Carnal Corinth—an affirmation of the categorical existence of carnal Christians within the Corinthian epistles.
12. John in Living Color—a color-coded translation and reference manual of the Gospel of John that focuses on the
    grammatical and aspectual indications of unconditional security.
13. Dad, can I be sure I am saved?—an intermediate discussion of assurance.
14. Trichotomy—an advanced holistic dichotomous discussion of trichotomy with an integration of nikology.
15. Ordo Salutis—a Free Grace order of salvation.
16. Soteric and Mistholic Faith—an advanced discussion of the nature of faith.
17. Karpology—a discussion of the soteriological implications of singular versus plural fruit.
18. Predestination and the Open View—a discussion of predestination that focuses on free will and the book of life from an
    open view.
19. Logic Tables and Diagrams—illustrations of logic with scriptural implications pertaining primarily to the soteriological
    and misthological arenas.
20. Drawing and Appointment—an examination of Calvinistic claims regarding drawing and appointment as found principally
    in Jn 6:44 and Acts 13:48.
21. The Outer Darkness—a magnum opus that ties together the author’s arguments for unconditional security and conditional
    rewards.


                            For books by the author, see http://misthology.org/?page_id=35.
                             For additional material, see www.UnconditionalSecurity.org.

                                                  Acknowledgments
        First and foremost, I want to thank my Lord Jesus Christ for giving me a Proverbs 31 wife, Dianne (pictured on
the front cover), and then giving me justifiable reason to believe that in eternity future she will be my Song of Solomon
lover. Throughout the years I have thought it was rather peculiar that the Lord would give me such a wonderful woman
as a tangible expression of His love only to remove that intimacy when I reach Heaven. Deep down, in my heart of hearts,
I had hoped that somehow, someway that sexual intimacy might continue even in Heaven, but I attributed that desire to
wishful thinking. After all, the Lord makes it very clear that those who rise from the dead will not be married in Heaven.
However, last year (2015), the Lord worked in a providential manner so that I came across a book by Barrow Morrow,
Heaven Observed, in which he poses the possibility that sexual intimacy might continue in Heaven, even though
procreational marriage would not. He only spent five pages on the topic, not nearly enough to convince me, but enough
to give me glimmer of hope. For further discussion, he defers to a book by Peter Kreeft, Everything You Ever Wanted to
Know About Heaven. Indeed, Kreeft devotes an excellent chapter to the question, “Is there sex in Heaven?”
        As the Lord would time things, I discovered these books at the same time that Dianne and I learned that she had
breast cancer, which led to her mastectomy. My therapy, to console myself, was to pour myself into research on the
possibility that our sexual intimacy might continue eternally. If that were true, I could view the cancer as little more than
a speedbump, a molehill rather than a mountain. Realistically, cancer would be nothing more than a temporary
inconvenience to our eternal intimacy. Just as coal has to be submitted to extreme pressure and heat to produce a diamond,
the Lord had to put me in a situation like that with a woman like this for me to write a book like the one you now have
in your hand, which endeavors to explore every possibility and calculate the logical implications. As a result, this book
will be more sexually explicit and venturesome than I otherwise would have planned. Doing so was necessary in order
to put forth the strongest argument possible and thereby convince myself as to the hope of such heavenly intimacy.
        Along the way, I discussed my research with friends and even presented a two-hour presentation of my preliminary
findings at a Westside Baptist Church.1 I am especially appreciative of the pastor, David Pearson, and the people of
Westside in giving me such a warm reception at that very trying time. The Lord used my wife’s cancer for good—to
produce this book as a therapeutic hope to those who, like myself, would find encouragement in the fact that the biblical
case for sexual intimacy is much stronger than many have heretofore considered. Whereas Kreeft devoted an entire
chapter to this thesis, I have devoted an entire book.
        As I discussed this research with my friends, Keith Call recommended that I consult Michael Heiser’s book, The
Unseen Realm, which had just come out. This book proved to be a very valuable tool in aiding my research. His discussion
provided collaboration for a direction that my research already had taken and the literary foil by which to engage and
pursue that avenue more thoroughly. Adopting Kreeft’s thesis and applying Heiser’s antithesis allowed me to produce a
much stronger synthesis, the missing link, so to speak, in Kreeft’s presentation. As I discovered during the course of my
research, I was not the first to take such an approach. My conclusions tend to be more conservative at times, though, than
some other researchers in this field, in that my book defends monogamy rather than polygamy. Kreeft had been open to
the possibility of polygamous sex in Heaven. Other groups and writers have advocated polygamous views as well.
        Frankly, to a considerable degree, I would find their polygamous arguments discouraging. The impetus for my
book has been to (1) first deal with the data in a scientific manner by examining the factual information on the subject
and (2) secondly deal with the problem in a loving manner that would allow me to formulate honest hypotheses that
would provide a reasonable consolation that my monogamous relation with my wife will be even better in Heaven. This
book is therefore intended as a comfort for Christian monogamists. Polygamists can look elsewhere for their comfort.
The biblical data is much more conducive to monogamous hypotheses than polygamous ones.
        Dianne and I are very grateful for the friends, churches, and family members who have prayed for us during this
time. We are thankful for our children—Jeremy, Lindsi, and Jonathan—who threw Dianne a surprise survivor party after
she had finished all her treatments. As always, I am thankful for my mother, Gladys J. Cauley, for assisting in the
proofreading, though I am sure some of the arguments in this book will come as a surprise! My friend, Scott Crawford,
must be thanked, as usual, for proofreading. The men of our Bible study group have been an encouragement in their
feedback and discussion over the past year as I shared tidbits of my research. But most of all, thank you Lord Jesus for a
monogamous intimacy that is desirable enough that the anticipation of its continuance is worth fighting for in defending
the hope that the best is yet to come. Cancer will not have the last word. It will not be allowed to say that the best years
of our lives sexually are behind us. No, this book proves otherwise. For faithful believers who—because of sickness, old
age, or the death of a spouse—are afraid that the best years are sexually behind them, read on—the best is yet to come.

                                      Chapter 1.
                             Primary Biblical Confirmation
                                                        Introduction
       Sterling has written an excellent three-part series of articles discussing the possibility of two modes of humanity
in the eternal state.2 Mode one pertains to the possibility of physical sex, within the confines of procreative marriage,
continuing in the eternal state for those who inhabit the kingdom during eternal state in natural (yet sinless, thus
transformed) flesh and blood bodies (cp. 1Cor. 15:50), so that procreation can continue in the eternal state. My hypothesis
in The Outer Darkness (TOD) was that those believers who live to the end of the millennial kingdom will be allowed to
enter the eternal state in sinless flesh and blood bodies and reproduce. Procreation thereby would continue in the eternal
state. Certain biblical considerations necessitated that conclusion. Thus one mode of humanity, existing in non-
resurrected, flesh and blood bodies, would procreate.
                           Illustration 1. Eternal Modes of Humanity as understood in TOD
            Mode                        Sex                              Mode                             Procreation
    Mode-1 Humanity (M1H                           versus       Mode-1 Humanity (M1H)                        
    Mode-2 Humanity (M2H)                                       Mode-2 Humanity (M2H)                        

       The other mode of humanity pertains to those in resurrected (thus translated) flesh and bone bodies (Lk 24:39)
who are animated by the spirit and who inherit the kingdom. Those existing in resurrected flesh and bone bodies would
not procreate. In TOD, I believed that those in this second mode of existence would not have sexual intimacy. Therefore,
in Illustration 1, both sex and procreation are crossed out as applicable to the second mode of humanity, namely,
resurrected believers. In short, like the other authors surveyed by Sterling who take the two-mode view, I had argued,
basically, that sexual intimacy would continue on Earth during the eternal state, but not in the Heavenly City. More
precisely, I had argued that sexual intimacy would continue for mode-1 humanity (M1H) but necessarily cease for all
those in mode-2 humanity (M2H). As a result of the present study, however, I have now revised that original assessment.
The revised thesis of the present book is that marriage and procreation will indeed cease for those who are resurrected,
thus for M2H, just as was maintained before in TOD, but the new proposal is that sexual activity will not necessarily
cease for those who are resurrected. Thus the chart on the left needs revision. Sex should not have been automatically
crossed out as applicable to those in resurrected bodies.
       In response to Sterling’s articles, which pitted Dillow and me against one another as advocates of the M1H versus
M2H models respectively, I emailed Sterling a copy of my book, Rewards are Eternal (RAE), with this explanation:

              I enjoyed your articles in JOTGES. As you noted, Dillow rejects the two-mode view of humanity in
       the eternal state. As you suggested, perhaps Platonic views lay behind his objection. Nevertheless, the heart
       of his argument, as he has stated it, is that procreation cannot occur in the eternal state because there is no
       form of death in the eternal state. Although Dillow affirms that rewards are eternal, his no-death position
       necessarily leads to a rejection of rewards altogether in the eternal state. He is not aware of this
       inconsistency. But others have used this same argument to deny that rewards are eternal. Therefore, I had
       to refute Dillow’s argument in my book, Rewards are Eternal.3

       Repeating my arguments herein for the two-mode view or for the eternality of rewards is unnecessary since those
arguments can be found within TOD and RAE. Those aspects of my previous arguments remain completely intact. On
the basis of that research and the arguments in those books, I will consider the two-mode view as proven and Dillow’s
no-death argument to be soundly defeated.4 Consequently, in the present study we can move beyond these earlier
assessments and build upon the two-mode argument. In TOD, I argued that mode-1 humanity (M1H), that is, humans

who enter the eternal state in flesh and blood bodies, will be able to have sex and procreate. Mode-2 humanity (M2H),
that is, humans who enter the eternal state in resurrected bodies, were presumed not to have sex and thus not procreate.
                                  Illustration 2. Subgrouping for Modes of Humanity
                      Original Model                                                   New Model




        Over the years I have thought that this arrangement was a little unfair—alright, to be honest, more than a little
unfair! Why would the faithful believers who inherit the kingdom in glorified bodies be rewarded with no sex, while
sexual intimacy is granted freely to unrewarded believers who simply enter the kingdom in physical bodies? Too bad I
was not born in the millennial kingdom and thus had a shot at eternal sex, was a thought in the back of my mind.
Nevertheless, theology is a science that requires that one follows the data, not one’s heart, so as to conclude that faithful
believers will be rewarded with no sex in Heaven—or so I thought at the time. Sure, we would still be male and female,
and thus have sex in the sense of having gender, but physical sexual intimacy would be ruled out for the resurrected
kingdom rulers. This was my original assessment in TOD and RAE. I was wrong.
        Subsequent to my release of TOD and the second edition of RAE, I came across logical and typological evidence
which lead me to conclude that my exegetical inquiry into the total range of possibilities for both mode-1 and mode-2
humanity had failed to penetrate the full depth of the material. The timing of the discovery was not coincidental.
Collaborating circumstantial evidence, such as my wife being diagnosed with cancer at the same time that I was reading
this alternative viewpoint, compelled me to study this matter much more thoroughly. My new model postulates that M2H
actually needs to be broken up into two different groups. Cancer need not have the last word on sexual intimacy.
                                           Illustration 3. Mediation in Mode 2

                                       Mode           Sex Kids
                              Mode-1 Humanity (M1H)       
                              Mode-2A Humanity (M2AH)     
                              Mode-2B Humanity (M2BH)     
       In accord with the original model, the new model still affirms both sex and procreation for those in natural bodies
and denies both sex and procreation for the unfaithful in resurrected bodies. The new proposition takes a mediating
position between these two previous affirmations, however. The new proposal is that for exegetical, typological, and
misthological (reward-related) reasons, M2H must be broken up into two groups so that faithful believers compose the
inner mode-2A (M2A) ring while unfaithful believers comprise the outer mode-2B (M2B) ring. Whereas the older models
either affirm both sex and children or deny both sex and children, the new model denies one and affirms the other. The
primary point of contention will be, of course, over whether those in mode-2 bodies have sexual intimacy.
Chapter 1. Primary Biblical Confirmation                                                                           Page 3
        Does Jesus’ statement that there is no marriage in Heaven for those who have been resurrected necessarily imply
that the resurrected will not have sexual intimacy in Heaven (Mt 22:29; Mk 12:25; Lk 20:36)? No, but most people think
so. Jesus’ response in Luke is the most detailed: “Those who are considered worthy to attain to that age and the
resurrection from the dead, neither marry, nor are given in marriage; for neither can they die anymore, for they are like
angels, and are sons of God, being sons of the resurrection” (Lk 20:35-36). The first thing to be noted is that Jesus does
not rule out sexuality or sexual intimacy, only marriage.5 If sexual intimacy is not confined to earthly matrimonial laws,
then the passage is silent about the possibility of sexual intimacy in Heaven. The Lord only ruled out sex being a
stumbling block to the resurrection. What we learn from Jesus’ encounter with the Sadducees has been summed up at the
popular level by the turn of a phrase: Do not let Sadducees make you sad you see because they do not believe that there
is a resurrection. As a corollary, we should also learn, from the present study: Do not let today’s Sadducees make you
sad you see because they do not believe that there is sex in Heaven. Affirming sex in Heaven means more than merely
affirming sexual gender in Heaven. Gender is a given, even among those who deny that sexual intimacy will exist in
Heaven. Consequently, what is being affirmed in the present study is more than the mere eternality of sexual gender.
Rather, what is being argued herein is that sexual intimacy in Heaven continues only for Mode-2A Humanity (M2AH).
                                  Illustration 4. Summation Regarding Resurrection
•   Mode-1 Humanity (M1H) is composed of married, unresurrected believers who have sexual procreation.
•   Mode-2A Humanity (M2AH) is composed of unmarried, faithful, resurrected believers who have sexual intimacy.
•   Mode-2B Humanity (M2BH) is composed of unmarried, unfaithful, resurrected believers who lack sexual intimacy.

       M1H will have sexual procreation on Earth. This perspective is shared by all advocates of the two-modes of
humanity. Moreover, those adopting this perspective acknowledge that such sexual procreation by M1H will result in
ever increasing numbers of procreating humans so that humanity spreads throughout the universe. Indeed, the logical
implication is that humanity will spread throughout the multiverse. (See my TOD and Misthological Models). The present
study is affirming more than this expanding population by sexual procreation among M1H throughout the multiverse,
however. That postulation only affirms sex in the multiverse by M1H. What is being affirmed herein by the expression,
sex in Heaven, is that M2AH will have compatible sexual intimacy even in the Heavenly City.

       Lk 20:35-36 is one of several texts dealing with the out-resurrection (see TOD). Those believers who were worthy
to be called sons of God in a misthological manner would be granted (1) rulership of the kingdom and (2) citizenship in
the Reward City. The present study will argue that they will also be given something else—(3) sexual companionship.
                                               Illustration 6. Sex versus No Sex




       My postulation is that those who live in the Reward City, namely overcomers, will be rewarded with sexual
companionship, while those unfaithful believers in the outer darkness will not. We might liken living in the Heavenly
City to living with your mate in a luxury penthouse with an ocean view. Living in the outer darkness would be like living
alone at street level in an economy room with an alley view. Other people would be living on your floor also, to be sure,
but no one else will be living with you in your room. Sexually, you would be alone. There will be no sexual intimacy for
those in the outer darkness.
                                                       Barry Marrow
       A number of writers have proposed that sexual communion may continue in Heaven, even among those who are
raised from the dead, and some of these writers have even speculated that a form of marriage may still exist. Marrow, for
example, anticipates that marriage will still exist, though not as we know it. His comments would be applicable to M2H:

         The point of Jesus’ words is that in the resurrection, in the world to come, there will no longer be any need
         for the institution of marriage to bring children into the world, to fulfill the levirate law, because in Heaven
         there is no death. His comparison of angels is simply that they are both alive and cannot die.
                 Therefore, while this passage does suggest that marriage as we know it will not exist in Heaven
         for procreational purposes, the passage does not teach that earthly marital relationships will cease to exist.
         In fact to say that marital relationships will cease to exist would be to ignore some of the most important
         purposes of marriage given in the Bible. Some of the purposes behind God’s design for marriage include
         the fact that (1) in the covenant of marriage we see a spiritual manifestation of the image and personality
         of God (see Genesis 1:27), and consequently, our sexuality and gender are an intrinsic part of our human
         nature; (2) marriage is intended to help meet the personal, relational needs of man and woman, because we
         are not intended to live solitary lives but rather with companionship (see Genesis 2:18).6

6
    Barry Morrow, Heaven Observed: Glimpses of Transcendence in Everyday Life (Colorado Springs: NavPress, 2001),
Chapter 1. Primary Biblical Confirmation                                                                                 Page 5

       Well said. Moreover, Marrow poses that sex in Heaven will continue to exist in this heavenly marriage and quotes
Kreeft in support. (We will turn to Kreeft in a moment.) Unfortunately, Marrow speculates, “If sexual relations should
for some reason not be a part of the glorified life, it is only because there is something much better to do” (emphasis his,
331). Marrow then supplies a popular quote from C. S. Lewis’ book, Miracles, in that regard.
C. S. Lewis
        Lewis’ fuller quote, which is found easily on the internet, is provided below. Marrow only quoted the part placed
in italics:

       The letter and spirit of scripture, and of all Christianity, forbid us to suppose that life in the New Creation
       will be a sexual life; and this reduces our imagination to the withering alternative either of bodies which
       are hardly recognizable as human bodies at all or else of a perpetual fast. As regards the fast, I think our
       present outlook might be like that of a small boy who, on being told that the sexual act was the highest
       bodily pleasure should immediately ask whether you ate chocolates at the same time. On receiving the
       answer ‘No,’ he might regard absence of chocolates as the chief characteristic of sexuality. In vain would
       you tell him that the reason why lovers in their carnal raptures don’t bother about chocolates is that they
       have something better to think of. The boy knows chocolate: he does not know the positive thing that
       excludes it. We are in the same position. We know the sexual life; we do not know, except in glimpses, the
       other thing which, in Heaven, will leave no room for it. Hence where fullness awaits us we anticipate
       fasting. In denying that sexual life, as we now understand it, makes any part of the final beatitude, it is not
       of course necessary to suppose that the distinction of sexes will disappear. What is no longer needed
       for biological purposes may be expected to survive for splendor. (Emphasis added.)

       As to Lewis’ remark that life in the New Creation will not be a sexual life, he seems to have missed the mark by
a mile. Life in the New Creation may be largely sexual if sex is not limited to the physical sex arena. But I will leave it
up to the reader to consider Peter Kreeft’s discussion on the subject. In any case, Lewis is clearly wrong. Sexual life will
definitely continue in Heaven for M1H. And since Lewis missed that observation, why think that his comments are
accurate in regard to M2H? At least Lewis recognizes that the biological distinctions (thus sex organs) between the sexes
may remain, which in itself is enough to derail his objection to sex in Heaven.
Randy Alcorn
      Alcorn shares Lewis’ perspective that sex will continue in terms of sexuality, including gender differences and
even sexual organs:

              I think that the components of our sexuality that make us distinctly male and distinctly female are
       things that we have every reason to believe would carry over to our new bodies. The very fact that we are
       eating and drinking suggests stomachs and digestive systems strongly, I would think. And so just as we
       would have our organs that help our bodies function in the distinct ways that they do, we could still have
       our sexual organs without having the sexual desires but having still the sexuality that defines us as male
       and female.7

       Alcorn draws a connection between having stomachs and sexual organs. The presence of one suggests the other,
he reasons. Following this line of reasoning, one might well ask, “If the presence of a stomach suggests an appetite, will
we have an appetite for the food we eat?” One would think so. The presence of an appetite would certainly increase the
enjoyment of eating. In that case, though, one might suggest, with equal logical consistency: “If the presence of a stomach
suggests a physical appetite, then the presence of sexual organs suggests a sexual appetite, that is, sexual desires.” The
objection by Lewis and Alcorn to sexual activity in Heaven is inconsistent with their allowance of sexual organs in
Heaven. A more robust model is necessary. The presence of sex organs is reasonable, as is the anticipation of a


329. I do not agree with Marrow’s assessment that Jesus’ “comparison of angels is simply that they are both alive and
cannot die.” Much more to this analogy is implied, as discussed herein. Nevertheless, if Marrow can make a satisfactory
defense for sex in Heaven from such a weak position, then my Marrowistic position is even stronger in that I am making
a case for taking the analogy of angels as being proof-positive that sex exists in Heaven.

                                            Transcendent Desires and Realities
       Before leaving Marrow, though, one would do well to pause and consider the fact that Marrow failed to note that
the entire thesis of his book supports his corollary that marital and sexual relationships continue in Heaven. The basic
thrust of Marrow’s book is that transcendent desires give evidence of transcendent realities. He references C. S. Lewis
in support: “If I find in myself a desire that no experience in this world can satisfy, the most probable explanation is that
these longings intimate that I was made for another world” (emphasis his, 17). Beulah Land by Squire Parson is a popular
song, which I thoroughly enjoy, that expresses this heavenly longing as a form of nostalgia:

                                       I’m kind of homesick for a country
                                       To which I’ve never been before
                                       No sad goodbyes up there will be spoken
                                       Time won’t matter anymore
                                       Beulah Land, I’m longing for you
                                       And some day on thee I’ll stand
                                       And there my home shall be eternal
                                       Beulah Land, sweet Beulah Land

       If we are homesick for Heaven, this is reasonable evidence that Heaven is our home. Our desire for this
transcendental country is in fact proof of its existence. The newborn baby desires food. This desire for food is in fact
proof that the food exists. The newborn would not desire food if food did not exist. Babies were created to desire food
because food exists to satisfy that desire. Their Creator created them with such physical desires. Our physical appetite

intimacy with our own personal pets, then why can we not have a special degree of intimacy with our own spouse? And

physical intimacy? If such writers can allow the possibility of pets in Heaven, then why can they not allow petting?

more pleasurable in Heaven than on the current Earth. If sexual pleasures follow suit, then physical sex should be more
pleasurable in Heaven than on Earth. Does Rhodes need to be reminded that sensual pleasure is not sinful? God is the
one who created sensual pleasure. Sensual pleasure is certainly going to still exist for those who enter the eternal state in
redeemed physical bodies. Why not allow it for those who enter the eternal state in resurrected physical bodies? Ron

indicates that there is a physical reality that is designed to meet that desire. The desires of our hearts for Heaven are
likewise a reliable indicator as to the reality of Heaven, which is the argument of Marrow’s book: “Using Blaise Pascal’s
famous dictum, ‘The heart has its reasons, of which reason knows nothing,’ we suggest that the heart is a reliable guide
to teach and instruct us about Heaven” (p. 17). For instance, we know that eternal, thus transcendental, reality exists
because God has set eternity in our hearts (Ecc 3:11). Our hearts lead us to believe that our lives have transcendental
value that stretches into eternity. Our hearts can be trusted in that intuition because God placed that intuition in our hearts.
“Paul refers to the ‘eyes of the heart’ as the intuitive organ of spiritual enlightenment that allows Christians to understand
God’s gracious provision for them in this life and the life to come” (Eph 1:18-19).11 The Bible says that we can find God
if we seek Him with all of our hearts (Jer 29:13). Is this seeking God not a form of following our hearts? God has written
His moral law in our hearts (Rom 2:15), and this moral law can be useful in bringing us to God. Our Creator created us
with transcendental desires, and these desires are proof that corresponding transcendental fulfillment is available. We
were designed to feel both physical and spiritual needs, so we have every right to believe that our Designer has designed
the means for fulfilling those needs.
        Since saltwater fish do not complain about being wet in the sea, our complaining about our environment and
longing for a different environment, as aliens in a foreign land, suggests that we are like fish out of water, or more like
freshwater fish trying to live in saltwater.12 A fish in saltwater longing for freshwater would indicate that freshwater
exists. The fish is out of its native environment. Similarly, the God-shaped vacuum in our heart that causes us to long for
God is proof that God exists. Our longing for Heaven is proof that Heaven exists. Marrow quotes C. S. Lewis to conclude:
“If I find in myself a desire which no experience in this world can satisfy, the most probable explanation is that I was
made for another world....Probably earthly pleasures were never meant to satisfy it, but only to arouse it, to suggest the
real thing” (p. 339). Beulah Land expresses a transcendental longing. We have every right to anticipate that such longing
points to a transcendental reality that can satisfy that longing. The transcendental longing is, in and of itself, proof of the
transcendental reality. The New Heaven and New Earth will fulfill that longing. They will be very much like the present
reality, but the saltwater will have become fresh. What about sexuality? Is it done away with? Does it move to a higher
reality that is so different that we cannot imagine it, as Lewis claims, or that is so different that it would be like comparing
chocolate with the beach? I doubt it.
        The parallel to sexuality should be obvious. Still, in case it is not, I will spell it out with another song. The song I
sang to my wife at our wedding was, I Could Never Promise You, by Don Francisco. The lyrics express a transcendental
longing:

                              I could never promise you on just my strength alone
                              That all my life I’d care for you, and love you as my own
                              I’ve never known the future, I only see today
                              Words that last a lifetime would be more than I could say

                              But the love inside my heart today is more than mine alone
                              It never changes, it never fails, never seeks its own
                              And by the God who gives it, and who lives in me and you
                              I know the words I speak today are words I’m going to do

                              And so I stand before you now for all to hear and see
                              I promise you in Jesus’ name the love He’s given me
                              And through the years on earth and as eternity goes by
                              The life and love He’s given us are never going to die.

        This marital life and love is promised to never die, even as eternity goes by. Did Francisco fail to read Jesus’ words
that the marital status would be annulled in the hereafter? Surely not! More likely, like myself and many others, Francisco
was expressing a transcendental expectation fully in accord with a regenerate heart that transcends the limits of our
reason. As a young man singing this song from my heart many years ago, I would not have been able to give a logical
explanation that would have satisfied my reason. That was then. Thirty-two years later, as it just so happens, if one
believes in coincidence, I was reading Marrow’s book and then Kreeft’s books affirming that marital love can transcend
earthly limitation at the same time that my wife was diagnosed with stage-three breast cancer. I had to face the possibility
that I might be losing my wife. I designed the following logo for a caner T-shirt for us to wear at the time.

                                                  Illustration 7. Chemo




       I do not think that it is accidental that the Lord led me to read these books at the exact time my wife was diagnosed
with breast cancer. The first book I read supporting this proposal was that by Marrow. What are the chances that thirty-
two years after I sang the transcendental song, I Could Never Promise You, to my wife at our wedding and had developed
a misthology called Marrowism that I would read a book demonstrating that we would not lose our sexual experiences
with our spouse by an author called Marrow, at the exact same time that I learned that my wife had cancer and was
concerned about losing my wife!?! Moreover, at this same time, my older son emailed me about his struggle to look
forward to the rapture since he was newly married. The thoughts of losing that marital intimacy was impeding his ability
to look forward to the rapture. My youngest son, on the other hand, was struggling with looking forward to the rapture
since he is not yet married and would like to experience marital intimacy before the rapture since the opportunity would
be lost after the rapture. The Lord synchronistically allowed all these factors to come together at the same time to cause
me to formulate a model that would be comforting both to me and them. Scripture mandates that I share this comfort
with others: “Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of mercies and God of all comfort; who
comforts us in all our affliction so that we may be able to comfort those who are in any affliction with the comfort with
which we ourselves are comforted by God” (2Cor 1:3-4). As if that was not enough, as I finished the rough draft of this
section and shared the results at our monthly Bible study, Lk 8:16 was at the heart of our study: “Now no one after
lighting a lamp covers it over with a container, or puts it under a bed; but he puts it on a lampstand, in order that those
who come in may see the light.” The conclusion of the study was that we should not hide the insights that we get from
God’s word but share them with others. Then, as if that was not enough, the next day I found an online presentation
defending this thesis that was presented back in 2007, by Kreeft no less, at the very seminary I had attended years before,
Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary!13 Even I can take a hint when I am given that many taps on the shoulder. So
I am sharing this model with others. Working on this material during the time my wife has been undergoing chemotherapy
and breast surgery has been therapeutic for me. I am sharing this material with others in order that it may help them also.
       The first thing I am going to do is grab the proverbial bull by the horns and examine Jesus’ statement in depth that
many superficially take as proving that sexual intimacy ceases in the resurrected state. Jesus’ statement is found in
Matthew, Mark, and Luke. But the Lukan form is the fuller account.

                                                    Lk 20:35-36
               Those who are considered worthy to attain to that age and the resurrection from the dead,
     1. neither marry, nor are given in marriage;
        a) for neither can they die anymore,
        b) for they are like (equal to) angels
     2. and (that is) are sons of God, being sons of the resurrection.

                  1) Number 1 is applicable to all believers who are resurrected.
                     • All resurrected believers will be:
                        a) equal to angels in terms of immortality and
                        b) like angles in terms of being unmarried (Mt 22:30; Mk 12:25)
                  2) Number 2 is only applicable to worthy resurrected believers.
                     • Like angles in terms of their sexual companionship (Mt 22:30; Mk 12:25)
                  3) Number 1b has dual applicability
                  4) Number 2 uses kai dualistically:
                     • Additionally in relation to marriage
                     • Epexegetically in relation to angels.

        My thesis is supported by treating the kai in Lk 12:36 dualistically, but my thesis is not dependent upon this
perception. For example, TOD argues for an epexegetical use of kai for Rev 2:26, but it does not require that vantage
point: “And he who overcomes (that is, he who keeps My works until the end) I will reward Him with authority over the
nations.”14 TOD advocates a dualistic view of kai in which it was both epexegetical and parenthetical. Likewise, in the
present case, the duality of the analogy to angels in statement 1b is not dependent upon adopting a duality regarding kai
in statement 2. Nevertheless, adopting the duality proposed regarding kai is very reasonable.
        Luke makes explicit what Matthew and Mark only made implicit: Being like angels is not limited to being like
angels in terms of immortality but encompasses their sexuality. Matthew and Mark leave it up to the reader to infer in
what sense(s) resurrected believers will be like angels. Luke specifies that they will be immortal but also adds that these
angelic believers are sons of God. Using kai to pair the word angels back-to-back with the expression sons of God
suggests an explanatory relationship. Per Matthew and Mark, we know that all resurrected believers will be like angels.
Per Luke, we know that being like angels has special applicability to worthy believers. This special applicability is
explained by an explanatory usage of kai. The but (alla) of Matthew and Mark is an epexegetical kai in Luke insofar as
it pertains to worthy believers.
                                         Illustration 9. Dualistic Usage of Kai




14
  BDAG (1.c) notes, kai is “often explicative; that is, a word or clause is connected by means of kai, with another word
or clause, for the purpose of explaining what goes before it and so, that is, namely” (bold added).
Page 10                                                                                        Mongamous Sex in Heaven!
       In conveying additional information, kai says that worthy believers will be (1) unmarried plus (2) sons of God.
In conveying clarifying information, kai says that worthy believers will be like angels in terms of being sons of God.
What about unworthy believers? Neither the additional nor clarifying sense of kai would be applicable to them. They will
not be sons of God or like angels in that sense. Kai is being used from the overall vantage point to show simple addition:
Those who are misthologically worthy will be like angels in terms of being unmarried and also be sons of God
misthologically. Even so, a dualistic effect is further intended grammatically:

       Those who are misthologically worthy will be like angels in terms of being unmarried and also like angels
       in terms of sexually. Yet kai is probably also being used dualistically (in a grammatical capacity) to
       underscore the additional vantage point: Those who are misthologically worthy will be like angels that is
       like angels in terms of sexuality.

       Commentators, such as Lenski, say that this verse means that we will be like angels regarding sex and marriage.
To which I would say, “Fine, we will be having sex but not be married.” Such a deduction would follow naturally if the
sexual activity between male and female angels is not associated with procreative marriage. Granted, some commentators,
such as Stein, say that angels are asexual, I would respond that such commentators are clueless. Resurrected sons of God
will not marry for they will be like angels in terms of being able to find an appropriate sexual mate in contradistinction
to the fallen sons of God: “The sons of God saw that the daughters of men were beautiful; and they took wives for
themselves, whomever they chose” (Gen 6:2). This is the first time the phrase sons of God is used in the Bible, and it is
used of fallen angels leaving their earthly abode in order to have sex with earthly women. These fallen sons of God were
punished as a result: “And angels who did not keep their original state and estate, but abandoned their proper mode and
abode, He has kept in eternal bonds under darkness for the judgment of the great day” (Jude 1:6; TM).15 Obviously, these
angelic sons of God had a strong sex drive if they were willing to risk damnation for sex! Which came first, their sex
drive or their fall? Apparently, their strong sex drive led to their fall. Angels are to mate with angels, and humans with
humans. An unbridled sex drive is dangerous to both angels and humans. Either their unbridled sexual desire led to
their fall, or their fall led to a perversion of their sexual desire. Either way, as angels in Heaven, they had sexual
desires before their fall. The natural inference is that even unfallen angels in Heaven have a strong sex drive.
       Angels in Heaven must control their desires if they are to remain in Heaven. The nature supposition is that they
can fulfill their sex drive lawfully in Heaven if they mate with their own kind. After all, the Bible teaches that the things
on Earth are a shadow of what takes place in Heaven. In the opening chapters of Genesis, we on Earth are told to mate
according to our kind. Mating according to one’s kind on Earth is presumably a shadow of the heavenly reality. Given
this type-archetype expectation, biblically we would anticipate that angels in Heaven mate according to their kind. If
heavenly angels can mate with their own kind out of desire and compatibility, might we do the same in Heaven?
                                                    Peter Kreeft

I would suggest that the same observation pertains to sexuality. Thomas quotes William Sargent along these lines:

       children, or even erotic pleasure, but rather the sense of mingled identity that lovers briefly achieve, the
       acquisition of another human being who, if only monetarily, seems to become part of oneself.17

        We desire sexual intimacy to last eternally because we want to experience fully what we already have partially.
At times, holding my wife, I have almost felt like we really were one flesh, that our bodies could merge together into
one. Presently, that is a physical impossibility. Two objects cannot occupy the same space at the same time. However,
NDErs have described hugging each other and their arms going into each other, in an embrace that surpassed anything
that they had experienced on Earth. Listen how one NDEr describes such an embrace: “When he wrapped his arms around
me, they went all the way through me—we went into one another. This hug was so much deeper than hugs on earth.”18
If that type of experience could be added to sexual intimacy, which is something my heart has longed for concerning my
wife, then it would be something my heart rightfully tells me to anticipate in Heaven. This is the natural outworking of
the arguments employed by Marrow, Lewis, and Kreeft.
        Chapter eight of Kreeft’s book is entitled, Is there sex in Heaven? I highly recommend his entire chapter. His
opening premise is that sex is something you are, not something you do (p. 118). Basically, this is a commonsense
proposition: Even if you are not actively having sex, you are a sexual being. He appeals to commonsense for the eternality
of sex: “God may unmake what we make, but He does not unmake what He makes. God made sex, and God makes no
mistakes” (emphasis his, 121). A quotation might help strengthen his position: “Everything God does will remain forever”
(Ecc 3:14). Therefore, sexual differences are preserved in Heaven, as they are on Earth. As Kreeft points out, Paul’s
“statement that ‘in Christ...there is neither male nor female’ [Gal 3:28] does not mean there is no sex in Heaven. For it
refers not just to Heaven but also to earth: we are ‘in Christ’ now” (emphasis his).19 Because we retain our male-female
gender and roles in Christ now, this verse cannot be used to object to our doing so in the future. To this point in Kreeft’s
argument, he merely has asserted that gender differences are intrinsic to who we are as persons and will continue into
eternity. Even objectors like Lewis and Alcorn would agree. From this premise, he will proceed to argue that retention
of gender leads one to expect function of gender, thus sexual intimacy. Even so, we have not yet reached that part of his
argument. He is carefully laying a solid foundation upon which he can build such a conclusion.
        Kreeft’s third principle is that sex is spiritual. However, by this affirmation, he simply means that our sexual
identity is not limited to our physical body but encompasses our spirit and soul. Another way of saying this would be to
say that sex is holistic, innately applying in a psychosomatic unity to the whole person, to every cell of the body and
every dimension of our person. Sex is ontological not just functional. We are not asexual spirits trapped in sexual bodies:

       If you are a dualist, if you split the body and soul completely, if you see a ghost in a machine, then one half
       of the person can be totally different from the other: the body can be sexual without the soul being sexual.
       The machine is sexed, the ghost is not. (This is almost the exact opposite of the truth: ghosts, having once
       been persons, have sexual identity from their personalities, their souls. Machines do not.)20

       The truth of the matter is that the physical body derives its sexual identity from the soul, and sometimes does so
imperfectly. Kreeft notes that many people are opposed to the idea that we have sexual souls. For those who find the
proposition that our metaphysical makeup is sexual, let us pose the alternative, which hopefully they will find much more
repulsive than their objection to metaphysical gender. Suppose that our critics are correct, and sexual differentiation is
limited to the physical dimension. In that case, what about astral sex? Is the charge of homosexuality no longer applicable
when two people who have male bodies engage in astral sex since they are acting outside of their bodies and therefore
supposedly no longer males? Hardly! They are still sexual, as even proven by the presence of their sexual desire!
Consequently, they are still males. Being metaphysical does not make them asexual. Their sexual identity applies to their
entire being, not just their physical genitalia. The absence of genitalia in the astral state would not prove that sexual
identity is neutral. The expression and book title that men are from Mars and women from Venus is not just talking about

the differences of their bodies! The differences permeate our entire being. In fact, the metaphysical differences are even

         The soul is either masculine or feminine, but the body, the machine, sometimes fails to express this clearly, as in
the case of hermaphrodites. Humans born with both male and female genitalia are hermaphrodites in which sexual
abnormities in the machine, the physical area, fail to express the metaphysical sex of the individual accurately. Biological
deformities, such as intersex anomalies due to gender blurring and DNA mutations because of the fall and curse, need
not pose an obstacle to Kreeft’s hypothesis. We are either male or female, not both. Indeed, such deformities support his
contention that sex is not simply a matter of physical genitalia. Similarly, a man who claims to be trapped in a woman’s
body and who then has a sex change has not changed his metaphysical masculine makeup. To the contrary, now the
genitalia of his machine would falsely indicate a female sexual identity while his soul retains its masculine sexuality. The
resurrected body will remove ambiguities where the machine has physical breakdowns due to genetic abnormalities, and
it will reverse deviances where the machine has been changed due to moral breakdowns. “The resurrected body perfectly
expresses its soul, and since souls are innately sexual, that body will perfectly express its soul’s true identity.”21
         At this juncture Kreeft introduces what will lead to a sexual cosmic ladder: “Differences in general, and sexual
differences in particular, increase rather than decrease as you move up the cosmic hierarchy. (Yes, there is a cosmic
hierarchy, unless you honestly believe that oysters have as much right to eat you as you have to eat them.)”22 Certainly,
distinguishing male from female is a lot easier among human beings than among oysters! Sexual differentiation clearly
increases as one moves up the cosmic ladder from an oyster to a human.
         The next ring in his cosmic-ladder proposition is to assert that sex is cosmic: “Sex goes all the way up and all the
way down the cosmic ladder” (p. 126). His discussion seems to be more geared to the quantum level, and perhaps it does
apply at that level physically to the extent one is located on the cosmic ladder. However, for his proposition at this point
to be convincing, he would have to, at a minimum, explain asexual reproduction among plants and animals. Perhaps he
might allow that in such cases we are staying on the same rung of the ladder and not moving up the cosmic ladder.
Regardless, since this part of his discussion is lacking, I remained unconvinced concerning this particular aspect of his
argument, at least to the extent that I am not necessarily convinced that sexual differentiation is necessarily applicable to
everything at the bottom of the ladder. Languages do not only use masculine and feminine forms for inanimate objects.
Such languages also use neuter. Therefore, I am inclined to think that the concept of neuter must be permitted in the
cosmic makeup as well. My supposition has the advantage of sexually showing the fallacy of pantheism. God is male
and female, not neuter. Since parts of creation are neuter, God cannot be equated with the creation. Creation allows a
sexual neutrality not found in the Creator. Adam and Eve were not created neuter but in the image of God. That part of
creation which is neuter is not created in the image of God. Any attempt to make us neuter is to neuter the image of God
and thus God. Such attempts should be firmly rejected.
         In any case, sexual differentiation does in fact increase as one moves up the ladder, which is the point to which
Kreeft is building, as he proceeds to assert, regarding sex at the top of the ladder, “God is the most sexual of all beings.”
This part of his argument was surprising, but it logically follows: “Sexuality is ‘the image of God’ according to Scripture
(see Genesis 1:27), and for B to be in the image of A, A must in some way have all the qualities imaged by B. God
therefore is a sexual being.” This argument is straightforward in its syllogistic deduction and thus valid, allowing Kreeft
to deduce: “There is therefore sex in Heaven because in Heaven we are close to the source of all sex.” On a Trinitarian
as opposed to Unitarian basis, Kreeft is able to pose that God is a sexual being. God does not have male and female
genitalia. Such genitalia, nonetheless, provide us as creatures with a way to understand what God is like in terms of His
unity of persons. We are not God; we do not become Gods (note the capital G). We are forever the created-creators; God
is the Uncreated-Creator. Whatever we create is subsequent to and dependent upon His creating and sustaining us.
Nevertheless, so that we can understand the invisible attributes of our Creator, He has created us as sexual beings with
sexual genitalia so that we can understand Him, the invisible God.
         So let us go back to the beginning and consider the logical implications of the way we were created by asking this
question, “What is the principle reason we were created male and female?” So that we could procreate? No. The
primordial reason that we were created as male and female was so that we would be created in the image of God: “And
God created MAN in His own image, in the image of God He created HIM; male and female He created them” (Gen
1:27). Being created in the image of God necessitated that man be created as both male and female. God could not create
an asexual Adam if He was going to create man in His own image, nor could God just make a male Adam if He was
going to create MAN in the image of God. Creating an image bearer in His own image required that God make a plurality
and a sexual duality. The numerically-plural and sexually-dual nature of this singular image bearer is again restated: “In

the day when God created MAN, He made HIM in the likeness of God. He created them male and female, and He blessed
them and named them MAN in the day when they were created” (Gen 5:1-2; TM).23 To qualify as God’s image bearer,
MAN had to be both male and female. Eve was not an appendix. She was not optional. The ability of Adam and Eve to
procreate sexually was a secondary, not primary, aspect of their being created as a singular entity in the image of the
Creator. Animals can procreate, but animals were not created in the image of God. When God made the animals, such as
the rabbits, He did not make just one male and female rabbit. He made lots of male and female rabbits. The unique,
singular unity of Adam and Eve is an important part of their numerical role as God’s image bearer, superior even to
angels in that regard. Their complementary sexuality is no less important. If you do away with either the singular unity
or the complementary sexuality, you no longer have the Triune God as He has presented Himself in these foundational
passages. Then why did God not make a threesome? Because sexuality is a twosome. Polygamy is not a picture of the
Trinity. The Trinity is a twosome in terms of sexuality (pictured by Adam and Eve) and a singularity in terms of essence
(pictured by the two of them together being called MAN).
       Moses further highlights this unity by saying that they become one flesh in the sexual act (Gen 2:24). By sexual
union they functionally become what they already are by virtue of creation—a singularity composed of male and female
duality. Our human sexuality is but a lower rung on the cosmic ladder that helps us understand the triune God. The sexual
relationship that exists between the three members of the Trinity is at the top of the ladder. The sexuality between the
three members of the Trinity is a duality, demonstrated by the male-female image bearer. Both the male and female are
equally valuable and equally a part of the image. These sexual distinctions are an innate part of their nature as God’s
image bearer. Doing away with either their masculinity or femininity destroys their capacity to act as God’s image bearer.
Their sexual identity must be preserved in Heaven and in eternity future for them to remain created in the image of God.
I might also add that their ability to merge into one sexually must remain intact for them to be able to function as God’s
image bearers in the same capacity as that given in the original design. Take away either their sexual identity or their
sexual unity and you deface the image of God.

watchful participants—they got to watch; they were watchers—but God was the one who actually made man.25 This is a

        I have extrapolated Kreeft’s gender affirmation regarding angels so as to deduce that male and female angels have
some sort of sexual interaction between themselves even in Heaven. The spiritual intercourse I postulate among angels
would be devoid of physical intercourse. The type of spiritual intercourse I have in mind is reported as taking place
currently in the astral plane, where spiritual energies are exchanged in what is popularly termed astral sex. Some angels
have not been content with this spiritual intercourse among their own kind, however. We know for a fact that some angels
left Heaven to procreate with human women (Gen 6:2-4).26 Obviously, angels have sexual appetites and abilities. The sin
of these particular angels was in moving down the ladder to a lower rung in order to have physical intercourse with
earthly women. These heavenly angels should have remained on their own rung on the ladder and been content with
spiritual intercourse with spiritual beings of their own kind, namely, female angels. Likewise, humans are not to move
up the ladder to have sex with angels, nor are humans to move down the ladder to have sex with animals. Created beings
are to limit their sexual activities to members of their own kind in the plane of existence God intends. We should stay on
the rung of the ladder where God puts us.

       At this juncture some speculate that when marriage is done away with, sex is unlimited as long as it is a
heterosexual union between men and women. Ranganathan makes such a proposal:

              A question was given to Jesus concerning a woman who had several husbands in her lifetime (each

       Unfortunately, Kreeft allows the possibility that we promiscuously might have sex with multiple kindred souls.
To the contrary, the type-archetype pattern for the intimacy that we will have in Heaven has been clearly given in the
Adam-Eve monogamy. Typology favors monogamy over polygamy. The same primeval pattern to which Kreeft appeals
for continued sexuality is the same pattern that makes the case for sexual exclusivity. His allowing the possibility of
plural mates is thoroughly inconsistent with his own argument. His line of argument, that nothing will be exclusive, is
the same type of argument that one finds in the commentaries as arguments against sexual relationships. Exclusivity and
sexuality stand and fall together in that regard. Early in his book Kreeft laid the foundation for this mistaken argument
against exclusivity when he said, “Heaven is pure communism. There is no private property in Heaven....In Heaven there
is no ownership....Therefore no one can possess Heaven” (pp. 42-43). He is wrong on multiple accounts. For example, I
have written a book entitled, Is God a Communist?, which would refute his premise. Repeating such arguments here is
unnecessary.

formulate our theories.30 So I will allow Swedenborg’s comments to the degree that they are in accord with the proper
use of these three avenues of discernment.

“marriage as we know it will not exist in Heaven.” So why call it marriage? This communion will not be regulated by
rules revolving around death or the needs for procreation or protection. Such matters are no longer applicable to
overcomers. Instead, their sexual union would be like angels in Heaven. Jesus had every right to expect the Sadducees to
be able to figure this out for themselves. The Sadducees were sad you see, because they did not believe that there is sex
in Heaven. Many Christians are like modern day Sadducees. They get tripped up, unnecessarily, by earthly rules
pertaining to marriage as if such rules would be applicable to sex in Heaven, which is extremely foolish. A host of
logistical problems should have put the Sadducees on the right track to make the proper deduction. These logistical
problems would include questions such as: “What about those who never marry or who married an unbeliever? Are they
to be left spouseless in Heaven?” No. They will be free to find their perfect match in Heaven. To avoid confusion, this
postmortem union in Heaven should not be called marriage, even though, as Swedenborg rightly observes: “The delight
of real marriage love, though, not only lasts into old age on earth but even becomes heavenly delight after death, when it
is filled with a deeper delight that becomes better and better to eternity.”34 The exclusivity and growth sounds like
marriage, but it is not marriage per say, even though marriage can lead to it.35

                                          Illustration 15. Marriage is an Acorn




       Earthly marriage could be pictured as a seed that has the potential to die and bring forth eternal fruit in intimate
growth in this postmortem union (cp. Jn 12:24). Our earthly marriages must die at the occasion of physical death, but our
marriages have the potential to yield much more fruition in a metaphysical union, even during the intermediate state, as
we are rejoined with our soulmate, if our soulmate is likewise a resident of the Heaven City. Paul expects believers to be
able to reason along similar lines regarding the resurrected body: “But someone will say, ‘How are the dead raised? And
with what kind of body do they come?’ You fool! That which you sow does not come to life unless it dies; and that
which you sow, you do not sow the body which is to be, but a bare grain, perhaps of wheat or of something else. But God
gives it a body just as He wished, and to each of the seeds a body of its own” (1Cor 15:35-38).
       Using this same logic, let us paraphrase how this reasoning would apply to the current discussion: “But someone
will say, ‘How do marital relationships exist after death?’ You fool! That which you sow does not come to life unless it
dies; and that which you sow, you do not sow the relationship which is to be, but a bare grain, perhaps of wheat or of
something else. But God gives them a relationship just as He wished, and to each of the relationships partners of its own.”
The relationship that God wishes to give us is analogous to that of angels, a relation not defined by fear of death or by
needs for procreation or protection. Therefore, we need a much better descriptive term for this postmortem relationship
than marriage. To call this postmortem relationship marriage would be like calling a full grown plant a seed. How
foolish!
       An acorn dies and becomes an oak tree. You do not look at an oak tree and call it a seed. The seed dies and
becomes something different, yet related, a full blown tree, which is what it was intended to be all along. Marriage
likewise dies and becomes something different, yet related, a full blown relationship.36 God never intended for the sexual
relationship that Adam and Eve had before the fall to be the epitome of their sexual union. He did not intend for them to
be locked in at a lower rung than angels on the cosmic ladder for all eternity. Rather, the seed of their marital relationship
was to fall into the Earth and die and be resurrected into something much grander. To compare what Adam and Eve will
have in resurrected bodies to what they had in sinless bodies would be like comparing an oak tree with an acorn. If the
sex they experienced in the Garden of Eden was great, how much greater will be the sex they experience in resurrected
bodies? The better resurrection of Heb 11:35 logically entails, among other things, better sex than is experienced on
Earth. This better sex will be experienced in sinless flesh-and-blood bodies.
                                     Complementary Consensual Soulmate (CCS)
       The model I propose is that if we and our earthly spouse are overcomers living in the Heavenly City, we will have
the option for heavenly sexual union. Unlike Ranganathan and Kreeft, who pose that we are free to have many partners
in Heaven, I postulate that we would only desire one partner, our soulmate. Complementary Consensual Soulmate (CCS),
which is the term I am adopting for my model, purposefully uses the singular form of soulmate.37 CCS does not stand

for Complementary Consensual Soulmates. God took one rib out of Adam’s side to produce a singular partner, a sole

become one flesh, not separated by divorce or death or joined to additional partners (Mk 10:2-9). No man should try to
counter this original design or attempt to separate these two soulmates or add to them. The singular form of soulmate in
my model is intended to convey the idea of monogamous sole mate. To use a pun, a soulmate is one’s sole mate. A
polygamous CCS is rejected.
        The consensual nature of CCS presupposes that the desire is mutual. Both partners would have to desire to have
this union with each other since death in physical marriage allows one to marry whom one wishes within certain
parameters: “A wife is bound as long as her husband lives; but if her husband is dead, she is free to be married to whom
she wishes, only in the Lord” (1Cor 7:39). CCS likewise poses that upon death overcomers are free to be joined to
whomever they wish as a singular, complementary, heterosexual partner within the Heavenly City. If two overcomers
were married to each other in their earthly lives, then the reasonable expectation is that they would wish to have one
another as their mutually compatible sex partner in Heaven. Suppose, however, through death and remarriage for
example, that these overcomers had been married to multiple partners over the course of their earthly lives. What would
happen in that case? For instance, in the case of a widow and widower who remarry, both of whom are overcomers and
both of whom previously had spouses who were overcomers, would this result in a communal union, that is, multiple
partners? No. I propose complementary consensual soulmate communion (CCSC) but not communal sex in the form of
having multiple sexual partners. My postulation is that in such a case they would choose the partner that they were most
compatible with, and this single partner would be their sole soulmate.38 Otherwise, an alternate possibility would be that
the first qualified compatible partner would be the one selected.
        In the cases of those who are left without a corresponding CCS partner, as a carryover from a previous earthly
marriage, they would be free to seek a CCS partner within the Heavenly City. This proposition is applicable to various
situations. Faithful believers who prayed for a marriage partner on Earth, for example, but who never had their prayers
answered on Earth, will find their prayers answered by a CCS partner in Heaven. Kreeft’s own discussion regarding a
related matter would lead to that conclusion:

       All prayers for healing are answered. The puzzle of how to understand Christ’s oft-repeated promise in the
       New Testament, such as, “Whatever you ask Me, I will do it for you”, is easily solved. He means exactly
       what He says—no watering down, no evasion, no “nuancing”. But He has not yet fulfilled all His promises.
       Many prayers for good things like healings have not been answered—yet. The only understanding of
       these passages that does not make nonsense of the two facts of promises and nonfulfillments is that it is
       only a matter of time, and the timing is God’s, not ours....
       ....Heaven will be the answer to every prayer, every desire for healing, physical, emotional, mental, and
       spiritual. All healings on earth are previews of coming attractions.39

        Obviously, Kreeft is using healing as only an example, an excellent example at that, to be sure. Nevertheless,
given his discussion on kindred souls, many will certainly ask if the same logic does not apply to the desire to have a
Christian mate. Are prayers to have a Christian wife not prayers for a good thing? Of course, they are a good thing. After
all, the Bible says, “He who finds a wife finds a good thing, and obtains favor from the Lord” (Prov 18:22). Will the Lord
not answer our desire to a have a Christian soulmate in the next life if He does not in this life? Maybe I am like the child
whom Lewis would reprimand for holding on to his candy, but I am not easily impressed with the trite responses that he
and other objectors give to the effect that the Lord will give us something better than sex. Would you tell a cripple that
God will not heal him in Heaven but give him something better? No! Then why tell a single that God will not give him
a CCS sexual partner in Heaven but give him something better? Logical consistency would dictate that just as believers
who pray for healing, but do not necessarily find their prayers answered in this life, will certainly have their prayers


momentarily. They would not be sexually active as of yet. When they do find a CCS, presumably they might live in the
same mansion or, then again, they might simply visit each other in each other’s mansion. Rules of marriage do not apply.
Despite their sexual union, these soulmates do not necessarily have to live under the same roof. Nevertheless, in the
course of the passage of time at least, they eventually would probably prefer a shared cohabitation (Gen 2:24).

        When Jesus criticized the Sadducees on this matter, it was because they did not understand the power of God and
because they did not work out the logical implications of the Scripture (Mk 12:24-27). Let us not follow their example;
rather, let us use our regenerate minds and hearts to think through and anticipate the logical implications of the Scripture
and not be so quick to limit God’s power to work out those implications. Basically, Jesus is saying that the Sadducees
should have been able to figure it out for themselves via the information they had available. The logistical problems of
(1) multiple marriages and (2) people who die without qualifying marriage partners should have led them to conclude
that marriage, as we know it on Earth, will not continue in Heaven. Obviously, therefore, marriage dies with death.
Nevertheless, because a physical resurrection occurs, and with it the pre-existing sexual distinctions, they should have
been able to deduce that those resurrected will have sexual relations in a manner analogous to the angels, who surely
have sexual relations because they are sexual beings. These post-mortem human sexual relations will be in accord with
the original design of a human monogamous heterosexual communion. Presumably angelic relations are also
monogamous, following the same basic design, per even Jewish understanding of Gen 1:27. To be sure, these are just
logical inferences, but theology is a science and hence necessitates making logical inferences based on the available data.
Jesus faults those who fail to do so. Logical inferences from scriptural data lead me to postulate three levels of sexual
activity in the eternal state.

Level-One Sex
       As noted in the introduction of this discussion, Sterling has written an excellent, three-part series of articles
concerning the eternal state that pit Dillow and me against one another as advocates of the one-mode versus two-mode
models, respectively. I emailed Sterling my response to Dillow’s argument and thereby maintain, for the reasons given
therein, that the classic two-mode view is vastly superior to the one-mode view. Consequently, building upon the classic
two-mode argument, we can make the following two inferences.
Intermediate-Level Sex

                                                      Inference One
       Those who inhabit the kingdom during the eternal state in natural bodies will be able to procreate, and hence have
sexual relations, at the physical level. Level-one sexual intercourse, consequently, will be understood herein to refer to
physical sexual intercourse that is capable of sexual reproduction. Level-one sex in the eternal state has been explained
and defended in TOD and RAE. Mode-1 humanity (M1H) will certainly have level-one sex.

                                                      Inference Two
       Those who inhabit the kingdom during the eternal state in natural bodies will be restored to a sinless condition
and consequently have the abilities that Adam and Eve originally had restored to them. Hence, they will be able to have
level-one sex for procreation, and in my revised two-mode model they will also be able to have level-two sex (i.e., astral
sex at the metaphysical level) for spiritual communion. Nevertheless, because their spirits will still be tethered to their
bodies, my hypothesis is that their experience of spiritual sex will be at a slightly lower level than that of the angels, just
as it was for Adam and Eve before the fall. In the eternal state, the intermediate level will become the new level one.
Level-Two Sex
        The type of sex experienced by angels in Heaven is spiritual sex, a higher order of sex. They are spiritual beings.
They are sexual beings. They are in Heaven. Hence they engage in spiritual sex in Heaven. One does not have to be
rocket scientist to connect the logical inferences. Though they can take physical form, they are not physical beings and
by default would not take this lower form to have a lower form of sex. The spiritual intercourse occurring naturally among
angels would be devoid of physical intercourse. Their spiritual sex is untethered by physical bodies.
        Human beings are capable of having sex at this spiritual level via the astral plane, though they are still tethered to
their physical bodies. Some foolish human beings are currently leaving their physical bodies via their spiritual bodies
(though still attached by the silver cord) and engaging in sexual activity via their spiritual bodies in the astral plane
through this type of self-induced out of bodies experience (OBE). Russ Dizdar has a deliverance ministry for Christians
involved in astral sex.41 As fallen human beings we should not be currently engaging in activities in this fallen plane.
God purposefully closed these realms off for us in our present condition. Trying to circumvent these limitations is fraught
with danger in the present state of affairs. Not only do we open ourselves up to fallen entities who would take advantage
of us and to temptations too difficult for us to withstand in our fallen condition, we are traversing in forbidden areas that
have the potential to land us in the outer darkness. Why engage in substandard level-two sex when doing so jeopardizes
our having level-three sex for all eternity? But before we can discuss level-three sex, though, we must make a few more
observations about level-two sex.
        Since physical bodies are not involved in OBE sex, an exchange of physical bodies fluids is not involved either.
Instead, spiritual energies are exchanged in what is popularly termed astral sex. Presumably, Adam and Eve had this
ability as well before they fell. Astral projection and astral sex would not have been prohibited to them before the fall. In
their unfallen state they would have been able to do easily what we can only do with considerable difficulty. While
intermediate level-two sex for them would have been riskless, for us it would be reckless. Not only did they have physical
sex via their physical bodies, involving the exchange of bodily fluids for the purpose of procreation, but they also were
able to have metaphysical sex (via their unfallen spirits leaving their bodies), involving the exchange of spiritual energies
for the purpose of spiritual communion.
        Since physical sex is a level-one sex engaged in the physical body for the purpose of reproduction, while
metaphysical sex is a level-two sex engaged in outside of the physical bodies, the two forms of sex would have been
mutually exclusive. One form of sex may have led to the other, to be sure, but Adam and Eve could not have engaged in
both forms of sex at the same time. An out-of-body experience was not possible for them while they were in their bodies.
