in Job is not Satan, the fallen angel, but merely an angel doing his job, as the satan, reporting on what he observes on
Earth and giving his assessment. Perhaps the satan merely refers to a job description in Job, as Heiser asserts, not a
personal name, but Heiser says that this is true in Zech 3:2 as well, so that this passage does not refer to the devil (p. 59).
Three weaknesses in Heiser’s comments immediately come to mind. First, the LXX translates the satan as the devil in
these passages. Second, Jude 1:9 certainly gives the impression that the satan in Zech 3:2 is the devil known as Satan via
a personal name in the NT. Third, the Greek NT frequently refers to Satan as the Satan, but we do not translate the
personal article since it is being used with a personal name.79 I suspect, accordingly, that the satan is Satan in these
passages. Consequently, the typical translation for Job 1:6 is retained herein: “Now there was a day when the sons of
God came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan also came among them.”
        Moving back to Genesis, Heiser treats Gen 3:5 as parallel to Ps 82:1 in that the first elohim refers to God while
the second one refers to gods: “For God [elohim] knows that in the day you eat from it your eyes will be opened, and you
will become like gods [elohim], knowing good and evil” (Gen 3:5; TM). Various translations concur. The context, as
Heiser notes, indicates that this is the case: “Then the Lord God said, ‘Behold, the man has become like one of us,
knowing good and evil” (Gen 3:22; TM). Heiser asserts: “The phrase ‘one of us’ informs us that, as in Genesis 1:26,
God is speaking to his council members—the elohim” (emphasis his, 62). If Heiser is using council broadly to refer
simply to angels, that is, to both tiers of angels and not limiting it to the male archangels, then his point is well received.
He has failed to prove that the us in Gen 1:26 needs to be limited to the higher tier of male angels (aka, sons of God). In
fact, in the next paragraph (p. 62) he points out that when God created man, He made him “a little lower than the elohim
[Heb]” (Ps 8:5). While the NAS translates this occurrence as God, the NKJ translates it as angels. The latter is
undoubtedly correct, as proven by Heb 2:7, where the NT writer quotes the LXX, which in this verse translates elohim
into Greek as angels.
                                                      Biblical Goddesses
        The most natural conclusion is that God created humankind like the angels, not like the sons of God, in making
them male and female. In other words, God making humankind as male and female in Gen 1:26 cannot be limited to
making mankind like male archangels or even male angels in general; the verse must be inclusive of female angels. One
might reasonable ask, in that case, “Might God be speaking to higher ranking male and female angles rather than to all
angels? Might He be speaking to a divine council composed of male and female archangels?” Heiser does not address
such questions because he largely ignores the question of angelic sexuality. He does, however, acknowledge that elohim
is used of both “gods and goddesses of other nations (Judg 11:24; 1Kgs 11:33)” (p. 30). Heiser concludes that God Most
High is surrounded by a pantheon of inferior deities, so that no other gods are like God, no other god is like Yahweh
(pp. 31-32). His conclusion, in this regard, is all fine and good. Still, to be more complete and consistent, Heiser should
have concluded that God is surrounding by a pantheon of inferior gods and goddesses. The divine council is not only
composed of gods but also of goddesses.
        If in worshipping gods the Israelites were actually worshiping fallen male archangels, were they not worshiping
fallen female archangels in worshiping goddesses? Consistency would dictate that Heiser answer affirmatively. As it is,
he ignores such questions, despite the substantiating evidence for OT goddesses. For example, the goddess mentioned in
1Kgs 11:5,33 is Ashtoreth, the goddess of the Sidonians.80 The Hebrew word for goddess is elohim. If the biblical texts

are to be taken at face value, one cannot limit elohim to male divine beings. Female divine beings may also be intended,
depending on the context. Another example of this phenomenon occurs in 2Kgs 17:31, where they worshipped
“Adrammelech and Anammelech the god and goddess [elohim] of Sepharvaim” (TM). Adrammelech was a male god

        Surely, when the serpent told Eve, “You will become like gods,” he was not telling her that she would become
like a male god, as if she would undergo a sexual transformation. Rather, the serpent was using the plural form of eat,
open and become in conjunction with elohim (which is also plural) to assert that she and Adam would become like gods
and goddesses so that an expanded translation would be: “For God [Elohim] knows that in the day you and Adam eat
from it your and his eyes will be opened, and you and he will become like gods and goddesses [elohim], knowing good
and evil” (Gen 3:5; ETM). Those translations rendering the second elohim as gods would do better to translate it as gods
and goddesses in recognition that elohim can refer to both, and in this context it is clearly best to render it in this manner
since the serpent is talking of a human male-and-female couple becoming divine. Likewise, I would postulate that God
was speaking to elohim, gods and goddesses, when He said, “Let us make humanity in our image” (Gen 1:26; TM). God
is the supreme deity. These lesser deities, as well as humanity, were created like Him—as male and female. The us =
God plus the gods and goddesses.
        Surprisingly, Heiser ignores this perspective, even though it is rather apparent and is acknowledged by others who
adopt arguments similar to his. For example, an online article by Bokovoy states:

              The text’s inherent logic implies that the author held a similar view to other ancient Near Eastern
       people. The ’elohim or “gods” included both male and female deities. Eating the forbidden fruit made
       the man like the male divinities in Yahweh’s council and the woman like the female goddesses.
              Interestingly, a similar issue appears in the Priestly account of creation, when God speaks to the
       divinities in his council with the words, “Let us make man in our image according to our likeness” (Gen
       1:26). Hence, both the Priestly and Yahwistic versions of creation include a reference to Israel’s God
       addressing a group of non-specified deities. Even though references to a deity speaking in the plural in
       these types of accounts are confusing to many modern readers, they wouldn’t have been to the
       ancients who understood their God to have exercised dominion over the universe through a divine
       council of deities. Similar statements where a god appears speaking to a specified divine council of
       gods appear throughout the ancient Near East.
              The subsequent verse in the Priestly narrative, however, contains the same type of grammatical
       ambiguity concerning ’elohim witnessed in Genesis 3:5a. The text reads:

       Then God (‘elohim) created man in his image in the image of God/gods (‘elohim) he created them; male
       and female he created them (Gen 1:27).

              This passage, therefore, parallels Genesis 3:5. Both verses contain two references to the
       noun ’elohim. In both verses, the first ’elohim clearly means “God” singular since the corresponding verb
       (“created” in 1:27 and “knew” in 3:5a) is as a third person masculine singular form, i.e. “he,” in the singular,
       did X. Then, following a clearly marked reference to “God,” both verses present a second reference to the
       noun ’elohim that is grammatically ambiguous. Genesis 1:27 could mean “in the image of God” or “in the
       image of gods” he created them....
              Still, just as a careful reading of Genesis 3 clarified that the second ’elohim contextually means
       “gods” in the plural, the same is true for Genesis 1:27. The text should be read “in the image of gods he
       created them, male and female.” Thus, both biblical verses (3:5a and 1:27) follow the same grammatical
       pattern: reference to ‘elohim meaning “God” singular—together with a corresponding masculine singular
       verb—followed by a second ambiguous ’elohim that means “gods” in the plural.

   Unlike those writers, such as Godawa, who pose that these female goddesses were actually male angels posing as

              Though traditionally interpreted as “God (‘elohim) created man in his image, in the image of God
       (‘elohim) he created them,” this translation makes little sense. In addition to considering the parallel
       statement in 3:5a, readers should recognize that if the author had truly intended the second ’elohim to mean
       “God” singular, his text would have read that God created the man “in his image” not “in the image of
       ‘elohim.”
              In other words, the author could have clarified his meaning by simply writing the words: “Then God
       created man in his image; in his image he created them; male and female he created them.” In fact, it would
       have been most logical to simply omit the ambiguous clause altogether, i.e. “Then God created man in his
       image, male and female he created them.” The only reason to include the clause “in the image of
       ‘elohim he created them, male and female” is if the author meant what he said: Men and women were
       created in the image of gods, the first man in the image of male gods and the first woman in the image
       and likeness of female goddesses.82 (Italics his.)

        Neither the documentary hypothesis nor the Mormon theology espoused by Bokovoy are necessary for the
postulation being entertained—namely, that God created Adam and Eve in the image of gods and goddesses. In making
this proposition, Bokovoy has gone two steps further than Heiser, and both of these steps are reasonable. Whereas both
Heiser and Bokovoy use the same grammatical argument to pose that God is speaking to the council members in Gen
1:26 and both scholars acknowledge that God alone did the actual creating, a fact also proven by the grammar, Heiser
assumes the traditional understanding of Gen 1:27 (God created man in His own image, in the image of God He created
him), but Bokovoy much more coherently argues that the latter reference to elohim should be plural gods: in the image
of gods He created him. If Heiser is correct that God is speaking to His divine council in v. 26, when He says, “Let us
make man in our image,” meaning in the image of God and the council members, then it stands to reason that in the next
verse, when God creates man, He would make him in the image of God and the council members. Bokovoy’s deduction
follows naturally. And since God makes man in the image of the council members as male and female, it stands to reason
that the divine council is composed of both male and female deities—gods and goddesses. Bokovoy, in essence, astutely
follows the logical implication of the Heiser’s argument to its logical conclusion in making this deduction.
                                         Illustration 23. Structure of Gen 1:27
                    1                        2                     3                 4                    5
      A    Elohim created man      in His own image,
      B                            in the image of elohim     He created          him,
      C                                                                      male and female     He created them.

        Commentators point out the chiastic structure of clause A and B and merely treat clause C as explanatory. As a
result, B2 is considered a stylistic equivalent of A2, and thus of A1, so that the imager elohim are assumed to be the same
as the Creator Elohim. The English translations rendered the verse accordingly as: “God...God.” I would suggest, instead,
that an appositional stair-step structure be adopted.
        The Creator Elohim created man in His own image (A1-A2). Rather than simply repeating statement A2 in B2,
and thereby clearly asserting that the singular Creator Elohim is the exclusive reference in B2, the text uses an ambiguous
elohim in B2, which could refer to imager elohim, that is, to gods and goddesses. Plural elohim certainly seems to be the
intended reference when the similar construction from the broader context is consulted: “You will become like gods and
goddesses” (Gen 3:5, TM; cp. Gen 3:22). The historical context also suggests this understanding, as this perspective of a
divine council consisting of male and female deities was shared by other cultures. The immediate context thus leads to
this conclusion since God had enjoined these plural elohim in Gen 1:26, “Let us make man in our image,” which
accordingly would be in His image and the image of the divine council. The next verse shows that God did just that: He
created man (A2) in His own image and (B2) in the image of divine council. This is the heart of Bokovoy’s argument. I
might also add, for completeness sake, that just as the singular Elohim is imaged by the plural elohim, the singular man
is expressed in a male and female relationship. This male and female composite, in turn, informs us that the imager elohim
are male and female gods and goddesses. Heiser’s thesis regarding Gen 1:26 logically leads to Bokovoy’s thesis regarding
Gen 1:27. The former verse informs us that God intended to make man in His image and that of the council. The latter
verse tells us that He did just that, with the added clarification that doing so resulted in His creating humanity as male
and female, which in term has retrospective implications regarding the sexuality of the council and the Creator.

                                          Illustration 24. Stair Steps of Gen 1:27

                       Step A
      Elohim created man in His own image,                     Step B
                          in the image of elohim             He created           him,                  Step C
                                                                             male and female        He created them.

        The chiastic structure does not merely repeat but advances the thought. No doubt, a chiastic structure is
implemented in the advancement. Clause B does not read, “He created him in the image of elohim,” but inverts the word
order to achieve the chiastic effect. The inverse order is used purposefully, so the chiastic structure is self-apparent. Still,
the chiasm is part of a stair step in which clause B advances the thought of the previous clause, showing that the Creator
Elohim is imaged by plural elohim. Likewise, clause C clarifies its previous clause by showing that the singularity gives
way not merely to a plurality but to a male-female plurality. As clarified in clause C, the singular him of clause B is really
a male-female composite of two separate people. In the same way, the Creator Elohim is not the only elohim in whose
image MAN was created, as shown in the intermediate clause B. MAN was made in the image of both the singular
Creator Elohim and the plural imager elohim. In all three clauses, the Creator Elohim is singular. The singularity of this
Elohim as Creator is static, unchanging. Through the stair step, though, we learn that this Creator Elohim has two sets of
imagers—one divine, one human. Creator Elohim is imaged by imager elohim who, in turn, are imaged by male and
female humans. Possibly, this divine-human imaging foreshadows the divine-human Imager, Jesus, who is the “image
of the invisible God” (Col 1:15), the only imager worthy of worship because this Imager is Yahweh incarnate.
        In any case, the postulation that angels were created in the image of God is not uncommon. When I did a Google
search for, “Were angels created in the image of God?” the first link to come up was an article by that very title at
Answers in Genesis by Bodie Hodge, who considers it wise to be open to the possibility that angels were created in the
image of God.83 The second link to come up was an article by Tom Terry, entitled: “Man and Angels: Are Both in God’s
Image?”84 Terry does not believe that angels are created in the image of God, but he poses an interesting question: “How
can man, being lower than the angels be created in God’s image and the angels being higher than man not be in God’s
image?” Terry’s answer is functional rather than ontological. He, like myself, believes that man is more like God than
angels in terms of certain functions: being fruitful, multiplying, filling the Earth, subduing it, and ruling.
        Counter wise, even though Heiser adopts a functional approach, he moves beyond it to a definitional understanding
so that image refers to status (pp. 40-43). Nevertheless, Heiser has posed a false dichotomy when he seeks to limit the
image of God to functional aspects leading to definitional status devoid of abilities or potential abilities. Functions cannot
be divorced from abilities. Later, Heiser practically concedes this point: “These abilities are part of our being like God.
They are attributes we share with God, such as intelligence and creativity. The attributes God shared with us are the
means to imaging, not the image status itself. Imaging status and our attributes are related but not identical concepts”
(emphasis his, 59).
        You cannot function in a manner in which you do not have an ability. If you do not have the ability to function in
a certain capacity, then you cannot perform that function. Function presupposes ability. An additional weakness in
Heiser’s discussion is that he does not address the fact that an individual’s inability to function in a certain capacity does
not mean that the individual in question does not have the status associated with being classified as part of a species that
has the capacity. For example, humans have the ability to walk, but this does not mean that all humans are able to walk.
Humans have the ability to reproduce, but not all humans have the ability to reproduce. The inability to walk or reproduce
does not make them any less human. They still have the ontological status of being human beings. The abilities to walk
or reproduce do not need to be intrinsic to each individual within the species. In this manner, we may rightly make the
distinction between status and ability and thereby make explicit what Heiser only made implicit: “Humans who survive
birth without suffering severe impairment, however, are able to represent God as originally intended. They do so by
means of a spectrum of abilities we have as humans” (p. 59).
        My hypothesis is that being created in the image of God means that as a species we have certain abilities and
functions associated with our status, but these abilities and functions do not need to be inherent in each member of the
species for a particular member of that species to be classified as belonging to that species. This postulation is nothing
more than common sense. A newborn human baby does not have the ability to walk or reproduce, but he or she is still
properly considered a human being. The baby belongs to a species that has these abilities. Even if the baby has a birth
defect that will prevent him or her from ever having the ability to walk or reproduce, the baby is still a person who is

fully human. He or she has the status of being a human being even though he or she may never have all the abilities
normally associated with that status. The same argument pertaining to the newborn applies to the preborn. A person is
fully human before birth, not because of potential functions that he or she may or may not possess as an individual but
as a part of a species. A birth defect does not prevent a person from being considered human before birth or after birth.
It suffices that the species as a whole has the abilities and functions that enable everyone within the species, regardless
of their own particular abilities and functions, to be given the status of being imagers of God. Let us not make a false
dichotomy between abilities and status by forgetting that we are part of the human species. God would never have
conferred this status upon us as a species without creating us with these abilities. The status of being created in the image
of God presupposes the ability to function in a manner compatible with that status—as a species.
        Similarly, we should not make a false dichotomy in how to translate Gen 1:26. One way to translate the verse is,
“And God created man in His own image, in the image of God He created him.” Yet an equally appropriate alternate
way to translate the verse is: “And God created man in His own image, in the image of gods and goddesses He created
him” (TM). The verse should be understood in both capacities. A dichotomy need not be supposed. The verse should be
understood in a composite capacity: “And God created man in His own image, in the image of God, that is, as gods and
goddesses, He created him” (ETM). In creating man in the image of God, Elohim created him in the image of gods and
goddesses whom He previously had created in His image. Likewise, when the serpent tempted Eve, she would have
understood him as saying, “For God knows that in the day you eat from it your eyes will be opened, and you will become
like God, that is, like gods and goddesses, knowing good and evil” (Gen 3:5; ETM). God’s original image bearers were
the angels. Humans are derivate image bearers. The original imaging sequence was: God—gods and goddesses—humans.
                                                     Female Watchers
        In the book of Daniel, these angelic elohim are called watchers. In fact, the NAS calls them angelic watchers: “I
was looking in the visions in my mind as I lay on my bed, and behold, an angelic watcher, a holy one, descended from
heaven” (Dan 4:13). “This sentence is by the decree of the angelic watchers, and the decision is a command of the holy
ones, in order that the living may know that the Most High is ruler over the realm of mankind, and bestows it on whom
He wishes, and sets over it the lowliest of men” (Dan 4:17). “The king saw an angelic watcher, a holy one, descending
from heaven” (Dan 4:23). The Hebrew (or rather Aramaic) reads ir in each case, which in Greek is transliterated as ir
(TH) and translated as angel (OG).85
        As Heiser notes, the sons of God who transgressed in Gen 6:1-4 are called watchers in 1En 6:1-2 (enumerated by
some texts as 1En 7:1-2)—at least they are called watchers in the English translation Heiser provides: “And when the
sons of men had multiplied, in those days, beautiful and comely daughters were born to them. And the watchers, the
sons of heaven, saw them and desired them. And they said to one another, ‘Come, let us choose for ourselves wives from
the daughters of men, and let us beget for ourselves children” (p. 104). My minor disappointment with Heiser’s translation
is that the English translations and commentators of Enoch that I consulted render it as angels instead of watchers, as
does the Greek manuscript of Enoch.86 I would have preferred documentation and explanation from Heiser regarding the
discrepancy and the underlying text. Even so, at least Heiser explains that watcher in this passage is a translation of the
Aramaic ir. An online article supplies the documentation and confirms that although text is rendered angels: “An Aramaic
text reads ‘Watchers’ here” (emphasis original).87 Therefore, with this online supplementation and my own analysis
regarding the Danielic texts above (cp. Heiser, 53-54), I am content that these angels were indeed watchers.
Consequently, I would suggest that the NAS Danielic gloss of angelic watchers be employed for the Enochian text as
well: These sons of heaven were angelic watchers. After all, although most English translations of this passage render
watchers as angels, this section of Enoch (chs. 1-36) is called The Book of the Watchers.

                                                Winged Female Angels
        On the other hand, Judkins and McDaniel believe that the winged women in Zech 5:9 are “female demons” rather

sphinx...represents what the Bible calls the cherubim, a type of angel” (p. 85). “The sphinx as it has been stated was
actually a symbolic depiction of an angel” (emphasis theirs, 92). These types of angels, as even Judkins and McDaniel
acknowledge, definitely included female angels:

research, cherubim were both male and female angels.

                                                  Embracing Angels
       In Ex 25:20 the two cherubs face one another. Yet they seem to be the same in shape and only touching at their
wing tips. Nevertheless, according to Talmudic legend, the cherubs in Solomon’s temple were in in the form of male and
female angels interlocked in an erotic sexual embrace, or what Patai would call a marital embrace.

                 Rashi, the 11th-century commentator, explains the passage: “‘The Cherubim were joined together,
         and were clinging to, and embracing, each other, like a male who embraces the female.”
                 Whether the above tradition referred to the First or the Second Temple, was no longer clear to the
         Babylonian teachers. Some held that it must have referred to the First Temple, because in the Second there
         were no Cherubim; others, like Rabh Aha, son of Jacob (a contemporary of Hana bar Qetina), argued that
         it referred to the Second Temple and that the Cherubim discussed in it were those painted or engraved on
         the wall.
                 Yet another detail concerning the Cherubim is given by Rabbi Shimeon ben Laqish (ca. 200—275
         C.E.), an outstanding Palestinian teacher:

              When strangers entered the Sanctuary, they saw the Cherubim intertwined with each other;
              they took them out into the marketplace and said: “Israel, whose blessing is [reputedly] a
              blessing and whose curse is a curse, should occupy themselves with such things!” And they
              despised them, as it is written, “All that honored her, despise her, because they have seen her
              [shameful] nakedness.”

               The same tradition is contained in several Midrashim with a few added details:


93
     Ken Johnson, Fallen Angels (USA, 2013).
Chapter 3. Biblical and Extrabiblical Confirmation                                                               Page 51
            When the sins caused that the gentiles should enter Jerusalem, Ammonites and Moabites
            came together with them, and they entered the House of the Holy of Holies, and found there
            the two Cherubim, and they took them and put them in a cage and went around with them in
            all the streets of Jerusalem and said “You used to say that this nation was not serving idols.
            Now you see what we found and what they were worshiping!”

              As to the time when the Cherubim were shown to the people filling the courts of the Jerusalem
      Temple, the only statement we have is that of Rabh Qetina: the showing, and the accompanying
      explanation, were made “when Israel made the pilgrimage” to the Temple. According to Biblical command,
      every male Israelite was duty-bound to make the pilgrimage to the Temple three times a year: on Passover
      in the spring; on the Feast of Weeks, seven weeks later; and on the Feast of Booths (Sukkoth) which fell in
      autumn, two weeks after New Year. Of the three, the greatest and most enthusiastically celebrated was the
      last one, on which, more than on any other Hebrew holiday, the populace was commanded to rejoice. From
      descriptions contained in the Mishna and in Talmudic sources we know not only the ritual details of this
      joyous feast, but also the fact that both men and women participated in it, and that on the seventh day of
      the festival the two sexes used to mingle and commit what is euphemistically referred to as
      “lightheadedness.” We can only surmise that the showing of the Cherubim representing a male and a
      female figure in marital embrace, may have preceded, and, indeed, incited the crowds to, the commission
      of this “light-headedness,” which could have been nothing but an orgiastic outburst of sexual license.
              Such ritual license was in accordance with both old Hebrew practice and the religious customs of
      other ancient Near Eastern peoples. As to its Hebrew antecedents, we happen to know from the incident of
      the Golden Calf that sexual rioting was the traditional response to the exhibition of statuary symbolizing or
      representing the deity. When Aaron made the Golden Calf (as a representation of Yahweh) and showed it
      to the people, they “offered burnt-offerings and brought peace-offerings and...sat down to eat and to drink,”
      and then engaged in sexual intercourse.....
              However that may be, the Cherubim-in-embrace were regarded as a fitting symbolic expression of
      the relationship between God and Israel. Rabh Qetina was, of course, far from being the first to speak of
      this relationship as one like that between man and wife. God as the husband and Israel as His wife had
      become a prophetic commonplace, from Hosea to Ezekiel, that is for the last two centuries of the First
      Temple period. It was this relationship that the Cherubim visually depicted, according to the Talmudic
      quoted above.94

Rabbi Raymond Apple summarizes this interpretation:

      The “marital embrace” theory takes the cherubim as symbolic of the union between God and Israel,
      frequently represented as it is in terms of betrothal and marriage. Rabbi Kattina is quoted in the Talmud as
      asserting, “Whenever Israel came up to the festival (presumably any of the three pilgrim festivals) the
      curtain would be removed from them and the cherubim shown to them with bodies intertwined one with
      another, and they would be thus addressed: ‘Look! You are beloved before God as the love between man
      and woman!'” (Yoma 54a).95

The Jewish Encyclopedia underscores the miraculous nature of the legend:

      It is recorded as a miracle that when Israel was worshiping the Lord, the cherubim lovingly turned their
      faces toward each other (B. B. l.c.), and even embraced like a loving couple. On these occasions the curtain
      was raised so that the Jews who had come on pilgrimage might convince themselves how much God loved
      them (Yoma 54a). At the destruction of the Temple the heathen found the cherubim in this posture; and
      they mocked the Jews because of their obscene worship, thinking the cherubim to be the objects of it (Yoma
      54b).96

                                                 Baal and His Consort
        Heiser gives extended discussion regarding Baal in his book, but Asherah does not even get honorable mention in
his subject index (though she is at least mentioned on p. 156). Still, with Baal having 450 prophets and Asherah (Baal’s
consort) having 400 prophets (1Kgs 18:19), you would think that Asherah would be deserving of more discussion. After
all, vessels were made for both her and Baal (2Kgs 23:4). In an online article Heiser refutes the notion that the Asherah
was considered Yahweh’s wife by Yahweh’s faithful followers.97 Agreed. Yet if Baal was a really a fallen male angel,
then would not Asherah be a fallen female angel? Furthermore, if Asherah was considered the wife of Baal, then it stands
to reason that when some Israelites equated Yahweh with Baal, this would have led some of the idolatrous Israelites to
suppose that, like Baal, Yahweh must have had a wife also—Asherah perhaps. Behind the scenes, in the meantime,
Lucifer was masquerading as Baal, and Lucifer’s fallen soulmate would have been masquerading as Asherah.

       Also mentioned here [in 1En 19:2] are, ‘the women of the angels who went astray’, referring to them as

       once in scripture in Zechariah 5. So the Book of Enoch informs us and reaffirms that there are indeed female

       and female angels. Except that the one place where female angels do appear in scripture, they are described

Time of the First Incursion
       Fortson notes that the fall of these angels did not occur at the time of Lucifer’s rebellion. Jude is alluding to the
event that occurred in Gen 6:1-4, after humankind began to multiple on face of the Earth. Tradition says that it was in the
days of Jared (whose name means descend or come down). Therefore, it was hundreds of years after Adam was created.
Fortson computes it to be “about 460 years after Adam was created” (Noah, 170). He appropriately deduces:

              Lucifer may have learned his lesson when he directly confronted God’s creation in the garden and
       caused them to fall. Because he learned from his 2nd mistake, he may have sent other angels to directly
       interfere with God’s creation. According to the Bible and other sources, there are angels bound in chains
       of darkness for their actions in Genesis 6. These angels did something completely separate from the original
       rebellion because Lucifer and his army were not bound for rebelling against God. (Noah, 128)

        Very good. But then Fortson makes an unwarranted assumption: “Once we get to Genesis 6, Lucifer has learned
that he cannot attack God directly, and he has learned not to mess with God’s creation himself, so it makes sense that he
would convince other angels in his ranks to mess with God’s creation” (Noah, 129-130). The biblical text does not say
that these angels who fell these hundreds of years later were in Lucifer’s rank. Fortson himself acknowledges within that
discussion that those angels who fell with Lucifer previously were evicted from their first estate, the heavenly realm of
God. Jude seems to imply that it was not until this time that they abandoned their proper mode and abode: “And angels
who did not keep their original state and estate, but abandoned their proper mode and abode, He has kept in eternal
bonds under darkness for the judgment of the great day” (Jude 1:6; TM). They left their heavenly estate and changed
their spiritual state in such a way so as to incarnate themselves physically so that they could reproduce sexually with
human women with the result that they could not return to their original estate or state. The aorist tense in Jude and the
Enochian elaboration give the impression that this was a one-way trip, a decisive action from which there was no return,
but which did not take place until this point in time. Read 1En 15:1-7 above again and see if you do not discern this to
be the case. These angels had not been evicted yet. Up until this point, Heaven had been their home. This impression is
confirmed repeatedly by earlier statements: “Enoch, scribe of righteousness, go to the fallen heavenly Watchers who
have left the High Heaven, that is, the Holy Eternal Place, and have defiled themselves with women, and have done as
the children of Earth do, and have taken wives for themselves and greatly corrupted themselves on Earth” (1En 12:4).
“The decree is this: From this point on, you will not ascend into Heaven for all eternity, and you will be bound upon the
Earth for all the days of the world” (1En 14:5). Thus these angels were not part of the original Luciferian rebellion.
Fortson should have paid more attention to the implications of his citation from Jubilees:

              “The Sons of God were sent down to teach mankind truth and justice; and for three hundred years
       did indeed teach Cain’s son Enoch all the secrets of Heaven and Earth. Later, however, they lusted after
       mortal women and defiled themselves by sexual intercourse. Enoch has recorded not only their divine
       instructions, but also their subsequent fall from grace; before the end they were indiscriminately enjoying
       virgins, matrons, men, and beasts.” – Jubilees 4:15,22, 5:1 (Noah, 158)

        The biblical and extrabiblical texts lead to the conclusion that these angels did not fall until later—until the point
in time described by Gen 6:1-4, hundreds of years after the fall of Adam, and even longer after the fall of Lucifer. Why
did it take these angels hundreds of years to notice that human women were beautiful? Why did these immortal angels
not lust for these mortal women earlier? In criticism of the Sons-of-Seth theory, Fortson, among others, would astutely
ask such questions as, “Were the daughters of Seth ugly? Is this why the sons of Seth lusted after the daughters of Cain?”
Such questions are designed to show the ridiculous nature of the Sethite theory. However, someone might ask, in turn,
“Were the female angels ugly? Is this why the male angels lusted after the human females?” The position of the present
book, of course, is that female angels are indeed very beautiful. The reason that these angels lusted after female women

Mortal Impregnating Gods
      A similar fall from immortality to mortality happened to the gods in Ps 82:6-7, according to Tate (WBC):

               The judgment on the gods in v 7 strips them of their divine status and condemns them to “the human
       fate of death” (Kraus, 157). They will no longer have an exalted status, free from the ravages of disease and
       death. It is too much to say, however, that the sentence is that of capital punishment with immediate
       execution (cf. Cohen, 271; Ackerman, 398). The sentence is that of becoming mortal....They are to be
       deposed from their divine prerogatives.

        Heiser concurs: “Yahweh told these elohim that they would die like men (Psa. 82:6-8)—that he would strip them
of their immortality” (emphasis his, 322). “When they became corrupt, they were sentenced to mortality” (p. 376). Heiser
places their death at the climactic battle between them and Yahweh at the end of the ages (pp. 259-260). If this is the
case, then their becoming mortal does not necessarily mean subject to short life spans but capable of being killed
physically and subsequently subject to spiritual imprisonment.

physical death as a result.103 In Gen 6, the gods incarnated themselves in such a way that they would be able to procreate
with human women and produce angelic-human offspring with mixed DNA.104 They imposed this mortality upon

if Gilgamesh’s father was a hybrid, as Fortson proposes, then his father was a demigod, not a god.105 For technical
precision, I am using the term gods to refer to angels but demigods to refer to Nephilim, the hybrid offspring of the gods.

and Mortality (ISCM) may be helpful in providing a mediation between the Malone and Marzulli camps.

                                                 Wives of the Watchers
       Returning now to Enoch, obviously 1En 15:1-7 poses no problem whatsoever for the thesis of the present book.
The only tweak that needs to be made to my second option regarding 1En 19:1-2, to reconcile the two texts, is simply to
postulate that female watchers were not actually wives of the male watchers, since the word wife is associated contextually
with sexual reproduction. Granted, the Greek word thelus used here can simply mean mature female, as it does in
Gen 1:27. But it can also mean a woman with nursing breasts and thus be associated with reproduction and child rearing.
Female watchers would not qualify to be considered thelus of a male watcher in the latter sense, but they could in the
former sense. The context only rules out the latter, not the former. Angels do not reproduce with one another; therefore,
they do not have reproductive marriages. They are unmarried in that sense. Still, this does not mean that they cannot
engage in sex with one another for other purposes. Their being created male and female presupposes that they function
as male and female and thus engage with one another sexually.
       My hypothesis is that 1En 19:1-2 may be properly interpreted to allow the possibility that the male fallen watchers
took human wives, and the fallen female soulmates (who thus were fallen female watchers) of these fallen watchers
became sirens to seduce human males. The celestial soulmates of these male fallen watchers, that is, their female
counterparts, fell with them. This answers the question, “What happened to the female soulmates of the male watchers
who fell?” They fell with them. When the male watchers left Heaven to chase after human women for procreative
purposes, their female companions left Heaven to seduce human men since fallen female watchers could not procreate
with their heavenly soulmates. This should occasion no real surprise. According to the thesis of this present book, angels
were created male and female, as sexual partners for one another—one male angel for one female angel for all eternity.
Therefore, when the male angels left Heaven to procreate with human women, the female watchers they abandoned were
left without any male companions in Heaven. So these female angels likewise left Heaven to pursue sexual relations on
Earth with human men. These female angels preferred to risk an eternal Hell rather than to live in, what would be for
them, a sexless Heaven for all eternity. These female watchers were left without sexual partners when their male partners

sexual bond for those created in God’s image was too strong for one to stand without the other. If the male fell, so did
the female, as in the case of the watchers. If the female fell, so did the male, as in the case of the humans. In Heaven we
will not have marital bonds, but we will still have sexual bonds, just as the angels do. The strength of those bonds are
attested by both the biblical and extrabiblical texts. I strongly suspect that Berg, and other likeminded interpreters, may
be correct regarding this Enochian text.117
                                                     Additional Watchers
        When their male soulmates left them to mate with human women for procreative purposes, the forsaken female
angels followed suit. Thus, in addition to the male watchers who left their heavenly posts in Gen 6:2, we have strong
grounds for concluding that their female counterparts departed from their heavenly realm as well. So in addition to the
gods monkeying with men, we find goddesses involved in monkey business of their own, a point indicated by both the
OT and Enoch. But this episode is not the only occasion in the OT in which we find watchers not performing properly.
There are additional watchers.
        Heiser’s thesis is that the episode at the Tower of Babel is at the heart of the OT worldview (p. 112). In Gen 11:7,
Yahweh again uses a plural exhortation to address the divine council: “Let us go down there and confuse their language”
(TM). Then God alone performs the action: “The Lord confused the language” (Gen 11:9). Even so, afterward, the Lord
divides the nations “according to the number of the sons of God” (Dt 32:8; ESV, RSV). The Dead Sea Scrolls confirm
that this is the correct reading (p. 113). The NRS renders it, “According to the number of the gods.” The LXE says,
“According to the number of the angels of God.” The NET reads, “According to the number of the heavenly assembly.”
The NLT has, “According to the number in his heavenly court.” These latter translations are not gender specific. Perhaps
the phrase sons of God is generic. Could God be speaking to both gods and goddesses on this historic occasion?
        Heiser notes the interesting parallel between “the number of the nations listed in Gen 10” and “the number of the
sons of El [God] in the divine council in Ugarit.” The number in both cases is seventy. “The rest of the nations were
placed under the authority of the members of Yahweh’s divine council. The other nations were assigned to lesser elohim
as a judgment from the Most High, Yahweh” (p. 114). These seventy sons of god prove to be unfaithful, so God
pronounces a judgment against them (Ps 82:6). Gen 6:2 might be misunderstood as implying in the minds of some that
all the sons of God took human wives before the flood when, in fact, the text only says that the sons of God took human
wives.118 According to Enoch, exactly two hundred watchers fell. We know that all the sons of God were not involved
because those who did so were confined to darkness (Jude 1:6). Then, a few chapters later in Genesis, we find God
dividing the world up after the flood among the sons of God. Consequently, not all the sons of God were involved in the
rebellion of Gen 6. Perhaps only two hundred fell at that time, as Enoch specifies. Similarly, in Gen 10, we should not
think that God divided up the nations among all the remaining sons of God, only some of them, seventy to be exact.
Therefore, when we encounter the phrase, the sons of God, we certainly cannot assume that it means, all the sons of God.
Mathematically, more sons of God exist than those being discussed. Sexually, one might likewise suspect that the term
is being used generically. Sons of God might be used to refer to their status rather than necessarily to their sex, a point
that Heiser seems to miss. In Gen 6:2, both status and sex were intended, to be sure. Even so, without additional
confirmation, it might not be safe to assume that the seventy sons of God were necessarily male angels, even in Ps 82.
Notwithstanding, even if the seventy sons of God are male angels, one is left to speculate as to what became of their
female soulmates.
                                                   Female Cherubim
       The postulation of female watchers in light of extrabiblical material, such as Enoch, seems plausible in view of
the extrabiblical material confirming the existence of male and female cherubim. Josh Peck points out: “The Lamassu is

                                                 Fallen Angels
      Scholarly discussion unfortunately sometimes has the tendency to regard the belief in fallen angels as a later
development: Commenting on Job 4:18, Clines (WBC) says,

              It may then be asked from where Eliphaz derives his idea of the untrustworthiness and “folly” of the
      “messengers” or angels, if not from some divine revelation. Certainly, it is agreed by commentators, there
      is no reference here to the fully developed idea of “fallen angels” as found in the intertestamental literature
      (e.g., 1 Enoch 6–9; 15; 64; Adam and Eve 12–16; see J. A. Sanders, “Dissenting Deities and Philippians
      2:1-11,” JBL 88 [1969] 279–90 [284–88]; P. D. Hanson, “Rebellion in Heaven, Azazel, and Euhemeristic
      Heroes in 1 Enoch 6–11,” JBL 96 [1977] 195–233). But the story of the union of the “sons of God” with
      the daughters of men in Gen 6:1-4 is adequate traditional background for this assessment of angels’
      reliability. It should be noted that a similar indictment is made by Bildad (25:5) without reference either to
      Eliphaz or to supernatural revelation. Pope mentions a case in the Ugaritic Baal myth where some such
      (female) servants of the gods are reproached for gross misbehavior.

        Since the flood motif is widespread in ancient cultures and associated with the gods coming down and comingling
with human women, as recounted for us briefly in the Gen 6:1-4 narrative, as Clines points out, it is imprudent to regard
the belief in fallen gods/angels to be a later development.120 As to the background cited by Pope, it is “in reference to
some shameful misdeed committed by the slave girls at a divine feast, an act so repulsive that Baal himself stood up and
spat in the midst of the assembly of the gods!” (Job, ABC, 231). One is left to wonder: If these lewd slave girls were in
the midst of the assembly of the gods, were they not low-ranking goddesses? Perhaps here we have an ancient allusion
to fallen goddesses. In any case, goddesses were certainly part of the Ugaritic divine council:

            Ugaritic mythological tablets describe the activities of the main gods and goddesses of the Canaanite
      pantheon. Although there existed no single state theology, the major gods reflect local geographical

119

       god, Baal, surrounded by a council of deities and a lower level of attendant gods. The divine council

       Athirat (Asherah), Anat, and Astarte are well known goddesses of the Ugaritic pantheon, or what we would call
female archangels. This pantheon had other goddesses, however. Darby cites scholars who would divide the Ugaritic
“pantheon into three or four hierarchical levels” so that “the Ugaritic pantheon is more complex than what the Anat,
Asherah, Astarte triad implies.” Further, he says that it is important to note that “many goddesses are attested at Ugarit.”122
Additional known deities among this list of Canaanite goddess would possibly include Eshmun, Kathirat, Nikkal,
Qadeshtu, Shapash, and Shemesh. Ancient cultures make explicit what the Bible makes implicit: The divine council
included goddesses in their hierarchy (thus female archangels).
       Whereas liberal scholarship seeks to explain Israel’s monotheism as an evolution from the surrounding pantheism,
Heiser’s book is valuable as a conservative counter argument, arguing for polemical assimilation instead (pp. 76, 111,
116). Yet he acknowledges that the material regarding Eden in general and the divine council in particular

       can only be properly understood in light of the worldview the biblical writers shared with other people of
       the ancient Near East. Like Israel, the people of ancient Egypt and Mesopotamia, for example, also believed
       in an unseen spiritual world that was governed by a divine council. The divine abodes of gods—the places
       they lived and where they met for governing the affairs of the human world. (Realm, 44)

        He then launches into a discussion of the Ugaritic council as being “particular relevant” (p. 45), especially since
the “Old Testament has a three-tiered council structure like that at Ugarit” (p. 46), with the necessary implication that
“an ancient Israelite would have thought of Eden as the dwelling of God and the place from which God and his council
direct the affairs of humanity” (p. 47). Heiser’s discussion is a refreshing conservative assessment of this historical
background and context. Yet woefully absent is the acknowledgement that the Egyptian, Mesopotamian, and Ugaritic
cultures all pictured this council as composed not only of gods but goddesses. The fuller implication is that an ancient
Israelite would have thought of goddesses being a part of this council also—a point Heiser should have made and factored
into his discussion. After all, he insists: “The inspired New Testament writers were perfectly comfortable referencing
content found in 1 Enoch and other Jewish books to articulate their theology.” “For the person who considers the Old
and New Testament to be equally inspired, interpreting Genesis 6:1-4 ‘in context’ means analyzing it in light of its
Mesopotamian background as well as 2 Peter and Jude, whose content utilizes supernatural interpretations from Jewish
theology of their own day” (pp. 98-100). Mesopotamia was the cradle of civilization. The Tower of Babel was located
there, and Abram was called from there (Gen 24:10). Yet these cultures not only believed in gods but goddesses. The OT
not only discusses gods but goddesses. If we are to accept Heiser’s conclusion that these gods were fallen male angels,
should we not conclude, on the same basis, that these goddesses were fallen female angels?
                                                          Conclusion
        The presumption that certain types of male angels are euphemistically described by the Bible as covering their
genitals is common. If they have female counterparts, then the reasonable deduction would be that these female angels
cover their genitals with their wings as well. Extrabiblical material confirms that female angels exist. In both biblical and
extrabiblical texts they are described as goddesses. Some extrabiblical texts also describe some of the watchers as female,
with goddesses in the highest levels of the pantheon, the top of the hierarchy, thus corresponding to what we call
archangels. The sexual activity of angels is explicitly confirmed by both biblical and extrabiblical texts as well. Although
the biblical text only explicitly affirms the sexual activity of a certain group of fallen male angels called the sons of God,
within the scope of Scripture the phrase certainly refers to more angels than were involved in this initial sexual escapade
with human women. Trying to determine if the phrase is occasionally used generically in Scripture, to include female
angels, is problematic. Still, even if the phrase refers exclusively to a certain class of male angels, it stands to reason that
they had angelic female counterparts. In all likelihood, these male and female couples either stood or fell together because
of their sexual union. As to the primary thesis of this book, if male and female angels copulate in Heaven, then, of course,
we have every reason to believe that resurrected believers will also. Sexual activity in Heaven is affirmed.

                            Secondary Biblical Confirmation
                                                       Introduction
       As noted, Berg has made an interesting proposal concerning fallen female watchers who went astray sexually.
Naturally, if male and female angels coexist, this supports the thesis herein. Furthermore, if angels are sexually active,
as Berg believes, then it further supports my thesis: Our being like angels would mean that we will be sexually active.
Berg has another contribution to make to the current discussion that would also support the thesis of this present book
even more directly. He believes that he has biblical reason to pose that sex in the new heavens and new Earth will be
heavenly, that is, better than what we earthly beings experience presently. Does the Bible actually teach that sex will be
better in the future? In order to answer this question as thoroughly as possible and to interpret the key passages as
accurately as possible, this chapter will necessarily be sexually explicit. It is not intended for younger readers.
                                                     Jer 31:22
       Berg’s comment on Jer 31:22 regarding sex in the eternal state is worthy of serious consideration:

              In Jeremiah 31:22 we are told that in the future, God will “create a new thing in the earth: a
       woman will encompass a man.” Just from what it says, it appears that this “new thing” involves
       Intimacy between the sexes. Perhaps this takes place after the Lord re-creates All Things (Rev. 21:4-
       5)? In this regard, God invented pleasure, intimacy, and sex, so why would He not re-invent it and make it
       even better (Acts 11:9; I Tim. 4:4-5)?

Although I agree with Berg’s conclusion, I was initially hesitant to put very much weight on his statement regarding
Jer 31:22 in deriving that conclusion. Speculations abound as to what Jeremiah means when he says that in the latter
days (cp. 30:24 and 31:1) a woman will encompass a man. Is Jeremiah affirming that the woman will encompass the man
sexually in eternity future, as Bergs believes? Perhaps, but this word for woman does not necessarily mean wife but is
used more comprehensively for female. The same Hebrew word is used for female (neqebah) in Gen 1:27, for example.
Some have speculated that, in this passage from Jeremiah, it pertains to the virgin birth of the Messiah. Keli and Delitzsch
dismiss this interpretation as the intended meaning here, along with other speculations, such as a woman becoming a man
or protecting a man. Keli and Delitzsch conclude: “The new thing that God creates consists in this, that the woman, the
weaker nature that needs help, will lovingly and solicitously surround the man, the stronger.”123 Contextually, this
principle has application to Israel and the Lord. Whereas the Lord has been lovingly seeking to embrace Israel, at last
Israel will lovingly seek to embrace the Lord. Whereas before Israel was a wayward wife, she will be the enchanted and
enchanting lover of her Husband—after His law of love rules in her heart, of course. Yet this contextual understanding
does not necessarily rule out a deeper principle: The one who previously had the stronger drive to embrace lovingly will
now be the object of the desire to be lovingly embraced. The passage uses sexual imagery to apply this principle to Israel
and the Lord. Nevertheless, the sexual imagery also applies to human sexuality. Jeremiah does indeed seem to be talking
about a woman sexually encompassing a man in the latter days.
                                                  Stronger Female Sex Drive
        Sexually, this expression in Jer 31:22 could mean that whereas today the male normally has the stronger sex drive,
in the future his female soulmate will have the stronger sex drive. The verse is promising a role reversal in sexual relations.
Some commentators suggest something similar: The woman will woo the man; the woman will court the man; the woman
will seek the man; the woman will eagerly embrace the man; the female will enamor the male. An online article by
McDaniel, for instance, adopts the latter rendition—enamor—as it pertains to Israel: “Jeremiah’s expectation was that
Lady Israel—who was loved by her God with an everlasting love—would rapturously reciprocate vocally and
unequivocally with paeans of love, thereby creating the role reversal between the Lover and the Beloved.”124
        Why limit this role reversal to Israel, though? Israel is only the specific application of the underlying interpretation:
The seeker will become the sought. The sexual role-reversal that will occur in the future would not only apply to Israel
but also to sexual roles in general, thereby allowing extrapolation of that proposition to heavenly soulmates. This proposal

would explain why the word female rather than wife is used: The female will encompass the male. Similarly, Word Bible
Commentary (WBC) says that a wordplay connects the word daughter with the word female via a pun. The faithless
daughter becomes the encompassing female. To be sure, WBC applies this assessment to the sexually faithless Israel as
a wife (cp. Jer 3:1-2,11-14,20) becoming transformed into the faithful Virgin Israel (Jer 31:4). Nevertheless, the enjoining
of woman (neqebah) with daughter (bath) suggests that we not limit neqebah to wife, and thus to Israel, but allow it a
more comprehensive sweeping application to females in general, and thus to sexuality in particular. WBC practically
concedes this point, unwittingly, in correctly advocating the reading of female rather than wife: The female will encompass
the male. Why not allow this phrase, whatever it means, to have a full sexual import as many commentators suggest?
After all, the context is talking about the Jewish people coming back as a remnant to Israel from the remotest parts of the
Earth and experiencing millennial blessings, such as new wine and oil, flocks and herds, lush vegetation, dances and
merrymaking, so that “then the virgin [Heb. bethulah; Gr. parthenos] shall rejoice in the dance” (Jer 31:13). Virgin means
human female in this verse, not the nation of Israel. Contextually, these female virgins will encompass the males.
                                                         Half-Virgin
       Textually, we need not limit the text in Jer 31:22 to a wife encompassing her husband, much less to Israel
encompassing the Lord. Nor should we limit the text to mean virgin. Feinberg argues rightly against the text being
interpreted as dealing with the virgin birth of the Messiah. The virgin birth of the Messiah is found in other texts, certainly,
such as Is 7:14, which says that the virgin (Heb. almah; Gr. parthenos) will conceive a child. The heart of Feinberg’s
argument is simple: “The word for woman [neqebah] cannot be twisted to mean a virgin. Etymology, usage, and modern
practice of the language are all opposed to it. The verb is susceptible of some wide nuances, but in no place can it mean
conceive by a virgin or otherwise.”125 The text is not talking about the virgin birth, but it might be talking about some
type of virgin sex, a possibility entertained by WBC and overlooked by Feinberg. Sexually, the text applies to mature
females. It cannot be limited to wives; it cannot exclude virgins. This text is enigmatic. My hypothesis is that it alludes
to mature females encompassing males sexually in such a way to encourage a partial association with female virginity.
These females are performing this sex act in such a way that they can neither be identified as wives or virgins. The text
suggests a virgin daughter who is sexually active, some type of a half-virgin.
                                                      Woman-on-Top
         In the resurrection, humans will not be married, but they will still be male and female. Thus the role reversal will
apply inclusively to resurrected human soulmates. Remarkably, one of the most seemingly farfetched interpretations of
this phrase might be closer to the truth than those offered by many scholars. Some interpreters have entertained the
possibility that encompass should be taken very literally and sexually, that is, vaginally. Put bluntly, in vaginal intercourse
the woman’s vagina encompasses the male penis. So some interpreters will at least mention this possible interpretation,
if for no other reason than to dismiss it immediately because the text states that what occurs will be a new thing, and
vaginal intercourse is certainly not new. So something else must be inferred—it is immediately assumed.
Notwithstanding, a few online interpreters have maintained that vaginal intercourse is very much the intention of the text
and have deduced that what is new is the sexual position: The woman will be on top! Some of those holding this
interpretation have even gone so far as to conclude that the woman-on-top sexual position is the only sexual position
biblically allowed by this text, so the woman-on-top sexual position must be used exclusively!
         Naturally, this woman-on-top exclusivity is not seriously entertained by hardly anyone, and rightly so. The woman-
on-top position is already common today and is not used exclusively. Therefore, this sexual position cannot be new in
the millennial state. And the present age cannot be the new age intended because this sexual position is not used
exclusively in the present age. Therefore, the woman-on-top-exclusivity proposition is logically ruled out by both
considerations. Such an interpretation is too restrictive, too narrow, and too poorly developed to be entertained herein.
Still, the synthesis being created herein, which adopts the strengths of various models, can be strengthened by providing
a defense for a more sensible variation of this model.
                                              Encompass as a Euphemism
       Encompass can be reasonably taken as a euphemism for sexual intercourse, without limiting it to the woman-on-
top position. As noted above, the working hypothesis being developed herein, in regard to this particular text, is that
whereas today the male normally has the stronger sex drive, in the future his female soulmate will have the stronger sex
drive. As part of that more aggressive sex drive, the female may prefer the woman-superior position, but she need not be
limited to that position, even though her more intensive sex drive may express itself more routinely in this position.
Whereas the male-on-top position may be the dominant sexual position before the millennial kingdom starts, the female-
on-top position could become the dominant sexual position during the millennial kingdom and on into the eternal state.

        A variety of euphemisms for sex are employed in the OT. For example, “Adam knew Eve his wife; and she

with her as one does with a prostitute. In this way they had sex with Oholah and Oholibah” (Eze 23:44). Of course, this
is what the passage is talking about, but one does miss the fact that the passage is using a euphemism to convey that
meaning when it is translated in this manner. A couple of the passages in the list combine the euphemism go in to with
lay with (Gen 30:16; 2Sam 12:24). The male is the initiator of the sex act in the above list of passages. The man-above
position would be the natural expectation in this list of passages, though one should not necessarily insist upon that
particular sexual position in every case. Naturally, the male is the imitator for the euphemism go in to. The male goes
into the woman; the woman does not go into the man. This euphemism naturally puts the man in the more dominant role
of the sex act. He is the subject performing the action; she is the object of the action. The man goes into the woman.
        What would be a good euphemism for the reverse, for placing the woman in the dominant role so that her vagina
encircles him? Is it any accident that Jer 31:22 supplies the perfect euphemism for the female dominant sex role? The
female encompasses the male. The Hebrew and Greek words for encompass mean to go around, encircle. Her vagina
literally encircles his penis. Just as he literally goes into her, she literally goes around him. These expressions are
euphemisms for the role of the penis and vagina during the sex act. Whereas the description of him going into her places
him in the driver’s seat, so to speak, the description of her going around him places her in the driver’s seat.

       arose and lay with him; and he did not know when she lay down or when she arose. 36 Thus both the
       daughters of Lot were with child by their father. (Gen 19:31-36)

        This passage also combines the euphemisms come in to and lie/lay with. These women did not have a man to
initiate the action of coming into them, so they took the aggressive role and lay with a drunken man. Perhaps, after
witnessing the destruction of Sodom and Gomora by fire, they thought that the Earth had been destroyed by fire so that
they were the last three humans on Earth, so they took upon themselves to replenish the human race.126 In any event,
these females encompassed this male. They were the female perpetrators who deliberately used alcohol to facilitate a sex
act to which the male would not have submitted had he been sober. Today we would call this incapacitated rape. This
incapacitated rape could just as easily be described by the word encompass:
       31
         Then the firstborn said to the younger, “Our father is old, and there is not a man on earth to come in to
       us after the manner of the earth. 32 “Come, let us make our father drink wine, and let us encompass him,
       that we may preserve our family through our father.” 33 So they made their father drink wine that night,

       arose. 34 And it came about on the morrow, that the firstborn said to the younger, “Behold, I lay last night

       preserve our family through our father.” 35 So they made their father drink wine that night also, and the
       younger arose and encompassed him; and he did not know when she lay down or when she arose. 36 Thus
       both the daughters of Lot were with child by their father. (Gen 19:31-36; TM)

        Obviously, Jer 31:22 is not condoning rape as such. The text is not saying that the female will rape the male in a
morally reprehensible manner in the eschatological future. However, it might be reasonably interpreted as saying that the
female will lay with the male, meaning she will take initiative and be more aggressive than the male. Yet the euphemism
of choice in Jer 31:22 is more graphic than lay with. The euphemism used in this particular passage is new, which is
fitting since the text is describing a new thing. Encompasses is the female counterpart of go in to. Whereas the latter
means to enter, the former means to encircle. The one euphemism is just as graphic for the female action as the other is
for the male action. Jeremiah’s using the word encompass in this context to describe sexual intercourse thus has several
advantages: (1) newness, (2) vividness, (3) symmetricalness, and (4) comprehensiveness.
        Unlike the old euphemism, lay with, which could be used of either a male or female taking the initiative, even to
the point of describing a sexual predator (i.e., male-on-female rape or female-on-male rape), this new euphemism,
encompass, would definitely put the female in the predominant role, just as go in to cast the male in the dominant role.
Encompass is the symmetrical counterpart to go in to. This new euphemism also has the advantage of not being too
narrow in scope. It is more comprehensive than what is suggested by those who opt for a woman-on-top position. That
woman-on-top suggestion is much too nearsighted. For one thing, the woman does not necessarily have to be on top in
order to assume the initiator role in the sex act. For another thing, the sex act need not be limited to sexual intercourse as
the singular type of sex act envisioned.

Oral Sex in Ruth

                                                   Incapacitated Rape
       Quite probably, Gen 19:31-36 is not the only OT passage in which the female takes the assertive role in
encompassing an incapacitated male. In a highly debatable text, it appears that Ruth might have engaged in what could
have been considered, by today’s standards, as incapacitated rape of a sleeping male—had the male not consented upon
awakening. In this understanding of the story, Naomi told Ruth to wash, perfume, and dress herself in the sexiest manner
possible and then hide herself until Boaz was intoxicated and asleep, at which time Ruth was to make her move on Boaz
sexually in the middle of the night (Ruth 3:1-5). The euphemism used by the text is that Ruth was to uncover his feet and
then lie down at his feet (Ruth 3:8). One popular interpretation is that she was being instructed to uncover his penis and
then go down on him, that is, give him oral sex.

                                                  Feet as a Euphemism
      Critical to this interpretation is the euphemistic understanding of the word feet in this context. Like many others,
Aaron provides cross references for various passages that use the word feet in a euphemistic sense:

              Referring to an unmentionable part of the body, by naming another part in the same vicinity, is
      known as the Rule of the Displaced Referent. We have seen this usage in the words “lions” and “thigh.”
      Even the more unlikely word “feet” has been so used. When a woman gives birth, the baby “cometh out
      from between her feet [regel]” (Deuteronomy 28:57). Jacob, referring to the offspring of Judah, said: “The
      scepter shall not depart from Judah, nor a lawgiver from between his feet [regel]” (Genesis 49:10).
              Today, if we wanted to say testicles, we would probably just say testicles. Or if we were speaking
      of one’s descendants, we would not feel a need to explain what part of the body they came from. Even
      Clarke seemed a bit embarrassed by this primitive way of speaking: “I am sufficiently aware that the literal
      meaning of the original ‘mibbeyn raglaiv’ is from between his feet, and I am as fully satisfied that it should
      never be so translated ... for reasons which surely need not be mentioned.”
              In a reference in which our King James translators put the word “piss” (which was not an offensive
      word in 1611 A.D.), the original actually used a euphemism for urine, as given in the margin: “the water of
      their feet [regel]” (2 Kings 18:27). Since the “water” here is urine, there can be no doubt that “feet” is a
      euphemism for the sexual organs.
              Israel, destined to suffer the loss of all things, was likened to a man from whom all hair was shaved
      - not only the hair of the head and beard, but even the pubic hair, euphemized as the hair of the feet: “In the
      same day shall the Lord shave with a razor that is hired, namely, by them beyond the river, by the king of
      Assyria, the head, and the hair of the feet [regel], and it shall also consume the beard” (Isaiah 7:20).
              Even the expression “wash the feet,” used as a euphemism, could have a sexual meaning: When
      David told Urah [sic.] to go to his house and “wash thy feet [regel; 2Sam 11:8],” his feet had doubtless just
      been washed before coming into the presence of the king. It would not be necessary to wash them again
      upon entering his own house (which was close - 2 Samuel 11:2), nor would such be necessary for David to
      mention. The setting makes it clear what David wanted Uriah to do. Apparently Uriah understood these
      words in a sexual sense, for he later explained why he did not go to his house to “lie with my wife”
      (2 Samuel 11:1-11).
              “Foot” is a very ancient and established euphemism for the male organ. “Shoe,” consequently,
      because a natural euphemism for a man’s sexual partner. This may help us better understand a Jewish
      custom about removing a shoe. If a man refused to marry his brother’s widow, as prescribed by the law of
      Moses. [sic]

             then shall his brother’s wife come unto him in the presence of the elders, and loose his shoe
             from off his foot, and spit in his face ... and his name shall be called in Israel, The house of him
             that hash [sic.] his shoe loosed (Deuteronomy 25:5-10).

             Since a foot going into a shoe was emblematic of sexual intercourse, the REVERSE - the act of
      taking a shoe from the foot - apparently symbolized that sexual intercourse between these two people would
      not occur.127 (Italics mine.)

euphemisms.html. Accessed on 1/23/2016.

              So, “water of the feet” means urine; “hair of the feet [regel]” (Isa. 7:20) means “pubic hair.”
       Dt. 28:57 speaks of a formerly pampered woman as being reduced by famine to eating the afterbith [sic.]
       that comes out from between her “feet [regel].” Ezek. 16:25 personifies Jerusalem as a wanton
       nymphomaniac, who spreads her “feet [regel]” to every passerby. In Isa. 6 the six wings of the seraphim
       come in three pairs: one to fly with, one to cover the face (for reverence) and one to cover the “feet [regel]”
       (for modesty). David urges Uriah the Hittite, called home on furlough, to go and wash his “feet [regel]”;
       Uriah replies that while his comrades are at arms he would not go home to eat and drink and “lie with his

       [regel]” (possibly gout, I suppose; more likely urinary tract problems, which are very common in old
       men).128

      In Eze 16:25, the nymphomaniac’s whoredom is frequently translated along the lines of opening her feet to
everyone who passes by, while other translations are a little more graphic, rendering it as the spreading of her legs. Even
more explicitly, her feet mean her vulva.

                                                   Legs as a Euphemism
       One potential problem, however, with applying the above discussion to the passage in the book of Ruth is that the
above euphemistic passages use regel for feet while the references in Ruth use margelot instead. Block (NAC) tries to
use this difference to deflect from the probability that the word feet is being used as a sexual euphemism in the Ruth:

              Naomi may have deliberately used the word margelot to exclude the genital interpretation that is
       occasionally intended with regel/raglayim. On the analogy of meraashoth, “place of the head, head
       support,” in Gen 28:11, 18, some interpret margelot as “place of the feet, footing.”26 However, a better clue
       to its meaning is found in Dan 10:6, the only place outside this context (here it occurs four times:
       vv.4, 7, 8, 14) where the word appears. There, juxtaposed with zeroa, “arms,” the word means “lower
       limbs,” inclusive of feet, legs, and thighs. Accordingly, it seems Naomi is advising Ruth to uncover Boaz’s
       lower limbs, probably exclusive of his genitals, and then go and lie down herself. Naomi says nothing about
       lying next to him or even lying at his feet. She is simply to lie down and watch what happens. Although the
       action is suggestive, by either of these last two interpretations the choice of margelot actually draws the
       reader’s attention away from the genitals and diffuses it over the limbs as a whole.129

       Block’s logic and exegesis are woefully unconvincing at this point, however. For starters, one could just as easily
suggest that Naomi may have deliberately used the word margelot to include rather than exclude Boaz’s genitals,
something that might not have been as clear if she had used regel, which is only occasionally understood as a euphemism
for genitals. If so, the narrator is calling the reader’s attention to the genitals as part of the whole. Because regel might
have left the matter in doubt, Naomi used margelot to indicate more explicitly that she wanted Ruth to uncover much
more than Boaz’s literal feet! To aid our understanding of margelot, Block (NAC) does well to draw our attention to
Dan 10:6, which is the only other place the word occurs outside of Ruth. In Daniel this word is used in connection with
the appearance of a glorious angel, who is described very vividly. When we turn over to that passage and again consult
the NAC, we find that Miller, the NAC commentator there, instructs us to consult Eze 1:27 also. So let us do so.
                                                 Illustration 28. Margelot
                            Dan 10:6                                                  Eze 1:27
      His body also was like beryl, his face had the           Then I noticed from the appearance of His loins and
      appearance of lightning, his eyes were like flaming      upward something like glowing metal that looked like
