        Ezekiel describes the upper half as his loins and upward and the lower half as his loins and downward. Evidently,
the angel’s upper loin (i.e., his upper abdomen) is associated with the upper half of his body, and his lower loin (i.e., his
lower abdomen) is associated with the lower half of his body. This makes sense. Daniel likewise describes his upper half
as (1) body (i.e., torso), (2) face, (3) eyes, and (4) arms. The arms are described in juxtaposition with margelot. Block
says that margelot includes his feet, legs, and thighs, as assuredly it does. But what about the loins? Did Daniel bypass
this part of his body? Not likely. Much more reasonably, the angel’s upper loin was considered part of his body (i.e., his
torso), while his lower loin was considered part of his margelot. Accordingly, margelot is not only used for his legs in
juxtaposition with his arms but as a summation for the lower half of his body, thus his waist down. Accordingly, margelot
is at least inclusive of the genital area. Consequently, Block is wrong when he suggests that a comparison with Dan 10:6
probably excludes his genitals. To the contrary, margelot probably means from the waist down and certainly would
include the genitals. When Naomi tells Ruth to uncover his legs, she euphemistically means to uncover his genitals.
        This is not the only context is which legs are used euphemistically, at least as it appears in some English
translations. For example, the NAS translates regel as legs in the five passages below:

        According to TWOT, “in a rare usage (Isa 7:20) it is used of the pubic hair (i.e. hair of the legs).” Other euphemistic
examples are cited also (e.g., Ex 4:25; Is 6:2; 7:20). BDB likewise lists several passages where it is used euphemistically
(e.g., Dt 28:57; Jdg 3:24; 2Kgs 18:27; Eze 16:25; Is 7:20). Concerning Is 7:20, BDB says that it means “hair of the private
parts.” In other words, in three of the five passages listed above, the NAS legs are actually widely recognized euphemisms
for sexual organs (Dt 28:57; Is 7:20; Eze 16:25). BDB concurs with NAS that it actually refers to legs in 1Sam 17:6. One
may reasonably conclude that the same is true in Eze 1:7. TWOT would give foot/leg as one common range of meaning
for regel. In summary, regel frequently means one’s actual feet, but at times it could refer to one’s legs or be used
euphemistically to refer to one’s sex organs. Therefore, regel tends to refer to part of one’s lower body: whether it be
one’s sex organs, legs, or feet. But margelot seems to refer to the entire lower half of one’s body: one’s sex organs, legs,
and feet. Naomi was thus telling Ruth to uncover the lower half of his body, to strip him from the waist down.
        Block seems to give a nonsensical impression of Ruth 3:4—that Naomi told Ruth to go lie down somewhere
nearby where she could merely watch what happened. To the contrary, the next verse (3:5) records Ruth as promising to
do as Naomi had instructed. Then, in the next verse (v. 6), the narrator confirms that Ruth “did according to all that”
Naomi commended her. What exactly was that? The narrator tells us. Ruth “uncovered his feet and lay down” (v. 7). So
where do we find Ruth lying? At his feet in the very next verse (v. 8)! More specifically, at his margelot, that is, the
lower half of his body, the very part of his body that she had just uncovered. Block’s attempt to put distance between
Ruth and Boaz via Ruth’s directions crashes against the details of the text. All Block can do is lamely admit in v. 8 that
Boaz awoke surprised “to find someone lying by his legs.” Contrary to Block’s previous reconstruction of the events,
Ruth is not lying at a distance to see what happens! She is lying right there at his legs. Block had said that “she is simply
to lie down and watch what happens.” It sounds more like she was lying down in such a way to invoke a reaction!
        Block is not oblivious to this interpretation, of course. He describes it reasonably well:
              Ruth is to uncover his “feet” and go and lie down herself. Few texts in the book have generated as
       much discussion as this command. There is a line of interpretation that treats it as a command to engage in
       risque and seductive behavior. It seems that in this cultural context, at winnowing time the threshing floor
       often became a place of illicit sexual behavior. Realizing that the men would spend the night in the fields
       next to the piles of grain, prostitutes would go out to them and offer their services. As a Moabite Ruth might
       not have had scruples about feigning the role of a prostitute to secure a sexual favor from a “near relative”
       any more than Tamar did in Genesis 38.
              This interpretation is rendered all the more attractive by the fact that each of the three Hebrew words
       that make up this sentence is capable of more than one meaning, and each is capable of bearing an overtly
       sexual meaning. First, the root glh, “to uncover,” is often used in sexual contexts of “uncovering someone’s
       nakedness” (a euphemism for exposing the genitals130) or of “uncovering someone’s skirt.”131 Second, the
       final verb, sakab [shakab], “to lie,” is often used to denote sexual relations.132 Third, the noun between
       these verbs, margelot, derives from regel, “foot,” the dual and plural of which may be used euphemistically
       for the genitalia.133 Not surprisingly, therefore, some interpret Naomi’s scheme as delicate and dangerous,
       charged with sexual overtones.134

       One might be reasonably skeptical regarding the proposition of possible prostitution; nevertheless, Block (NAC)
overstates his skepticism in denying the sexual nature of the encounter:

                The ambiguities in the words and the circumstances chosen by Naomi are indeed provocative. What
         is one to think of a woman who bathes, puts on perfume, and then in the dark of night goes out to the field
         where the man is sleeping and uncovers his legs? Under ordinary circumstances these look like the actions
         of a prostitute. On the other hand, this overtly sexual interpretation of Naomi’s directions seems to read far
         more into the text than is intended. Each of the three words probably is misinterpreted. First, there is no
         suggestion in Naomi’s tone or intention that either verb is to be interpreted sexually. The verb gilla [galah]
         need not be interpreted along the lines of “uncovering someone’s nakedness,” and it is unlikely that Naomi
         would have encouraged her daughter-in-law to immoral action by using sakab [shakab] sexually. Although
         Naomi may show signs of compromising theologically, especially at the beginning, unlike Lot’s daughters,
         who do use sakab, after chap. 1 the picture the narrator paints of Naomi is consistently virtuous.

       According to Block, the narrator is attempting to draw the reader’s attention away from the genitals. Actually,
Block, not the narrator, is the one seeking to draw the reader’s attention away from the genitals. Contrary to Block, by
using margelot the biblical narrator gives the impression that the directions are to strip Boaz from the waist down (v. 4),
and the narrator then confirms that Ruth was following these directions (v. 5) in lying down at that part of Boaz’s body
that she had just exposed (v. 8). The narrator is implicitly calling the reader’s attention to the genitals.
       In contradistinction to Block, Dennis believes that the key word is uncover [galah] and that it certainly must be
interpreted sexually in this context:

               The Scripture says that Ruth was to “uncover his feet.” The key word in this passage of Scripture is
         “uncover.” There are a number of words in Hebrew that are translated “to uncover;” however, [1] the one
         used here means “to denude.” [2] This word, when relating to bodily disrobing, is always used in one
         way or another, to describe a sexual uncovering. [3] It “always denotes ‘to uncover’ something which
         otherwise is normally concealed.”135

        As already noted, Block (NAC) says that uncover [galah] “need not be interpreted along the lines of “uncovering
someone’s nakedness,” even though it is “often” used in this sense. Lexically, Block is correct that uncover is used in a
variety of ways: to uncover nakedness is only one of those uses. But what about contexts in which uncover refers to
bodily disrobing, which is the case in this context, where, as even Block would admit, she is disrobing the lower part of
his body? Who is closer to the truth, Block or Dennis? I have broken up Dennis’ lexical argument into three numerically
noted claims in the quote above. If Dennis’s second claim is correct, that galah always describes a sexual uncovering
when related to any type of bodily disrobing, then the sexual interpretation of Ruth’s actions is strongly supported.
Dennis’ claims are thus worthy of careful scrutiny.
        As to his first claim, he cites Strong’s concordance for meaning denude. Granted, this is the first meaning given
by Strong’s concordance, and the concordance gives this same meaning for the captives led into exile. Still, it is debatable
that this is the meaning in the context of Ruth and whether the captives were completely naked. So this first part of
Dennis’ lexical argument is not particularly persuasive. As to his second claim, he provides no citation to support his
claim. Thus the only way to verify this part of his claim is to look for ourselves—a task we will undertake momentarily.
As for his third claim, I was not particularly impressed when I first read it. Of course, to uncover something would suggest
that it otherwise was concealed, was my initial reaction. So what is the big deal? But being inquisitive, I checked out the
resource Dennis quoted, which was TWOT. Since Dennis was not writing at a technical level, he left out the technical
details. However, the pay dirt comes from digging in the details provided by TWOT:

                In the Piel it always denotes “to uncover” something which otherwise is normally concealed.
         Thus it means “to open” the eyes—to see an angel (Num 22:31) or wonderful things in the law (Psa 119:18);
         “to make known, revealed, manifest”: of Jeremiah in his complaint to the LORD (Jer 11:20; Jer 20:12), of
         the LORD in his revelation of peace and truth to Israel (Jer 33:6) and his righteousness to them (Psa 98:2);
         “to betray”: of fugitives (Isa 16:3), of secrets (Prov 11:13; Prov 25:9); “to uncover, expose”: of Esau's
         hiding place (Jer 49:10), the mysteries of darkness (Job 12:22), foundations (Mic 1:6), sin (Job 20:27;
         Lam 2:14; Lam 4:22), and feet (Ruth 3:4, 7).

135
      C. Thomas Dennis, Women, Sex and the Bible: The Secret to Sexual Happiness (USA, 2003), 44.
Page 74                                                                                       Mongamous Sex in Heaven!
              But it is used most frequently in this stem for designating proscribed sexual activity. It occurs
       twenty-four times in Lev 18 and Lev 20 in the expression “to uncover the shame” which denotes sexual
       intercourse in proscribed situations, usually incest, also Deut 22:30 [H 23.1]; Deut 27:20. It is also used of
       uncovering or removing that which covers: the woman’s skirt (Isa 47:3; Nahum 3:5), of Judah’s protective
       covering (Isa 22:8), and Leviathan's outer armor (Job 41:13 [H 5]). In many passages, then, it has the
       connotation “to shame.”
              Alongside of Lev 18 and Lev 20 it occurs in the prophetic complaint that Israel has “uncovered her
       nakedness,” a metaphor denoting that she threw off her loyalty to the LORD. Against this, the Lord or her
       former lovers will “expose the nakedness” = “to shame” of the faithless nation (Hos 2:12; Ezek 16:36); cf.
       the threat against Nineveh (Nah 3:5) and against Babylon (Isa 47:3). (S.v. galah, TWOT.)

        At this point, it occurred to me why TWOT’s definition was a big deal. When galah is used in the Piel (which is
an intensive form), per TWOT “it ALWAYS denotes ‘to uncover’ something which otherwise is normally
concealed.” After giving this definition, TWOT unwittingly cites Ruth uncovering Boaz’s “feet” in Ruth 3:4,7 as an
example. But are feet normally concealed? No, especially not in a culture that wears sandals! Therefore, translating
margelot as feet clashes with the very definition that TWOT has just supplied for galah in this very context! TWOT shot
itself in the foot, lexically speaking, when it defined margelot as feet. The resolution is simple. Just read the very next
sentence in TWOT’s definition, where TWOT gives the answer. After erroneously claiming that the Piel stem of galah
refers to uncovering feet in Ruth 3:4,7, TWOT immediately goes on to state: “But it is used most frequently in this
stem for designating proscribed sexual activity.” Instead of treating Ruth 3:4,7 as an exception to the rule, according
to which galah always would refer to uncovering something that otherwise is normally concealed, TWOT should have
acknowledged that her uncovering his margelot was used of sexual activity. In other words, Ruth uncovered his genitals:
Something which otherwise is normally concealed. As TWOT goes on to illustrate, the Piel of galah most frequently
refers to sexual activity and therefore is frequently translated as nakedness. Stated another way, Ruth uncovered his
nakedness. If we are to allow galah to have its normal meaning in this type of construction and context, then this would
be the meaning: She uncovered his nakedness.
        Are there any exceptions? Not if always means always, which is what TWOT said. This observation is close to
Dennis’ second proposition: “When relating to bodily disrobing, [it] is always used in one way or another, to
describe a sexual uncovering.” If TWOT is correct about always, then Dennis may be correct also. At this point, I was
willing to lift the hood, so to speak, and take a look for myself. So let’s roll up our sleeves and do the work necessary to
see if the Piel of galah always refers to a sexual uncovering when used of removing bodily clothing. Since Dennis did
not limit his statement to the Piel, though, perhaps some Berean-minded readers might like to do an even more thorough
examination for themselves and examine all the references for themselves and see if these things are so. It is easy to do
so and would not take long to verify. Strong’s number for galah is 01540. Just go to an online search engine that allows
you to search by Strong’s numbers, such as http://www.eliyah.com/lexicon.html, enter the number and do a search. As
an added bonus, you can select the version in which you want to display the results, such as the NASB, which is the one
I normally use by default. You can then look at all 271 occurrences in 167 verses. The disparity in the numbers is
attributable to the fact that sometimes galah will occur more than once within a single verse.
        When I read these references, my overall impression was that only two texts might realistically be used to question
Dennis’ claim that galah always refers to a sexual uncovering when used of removing bodily clothing. My reaction was
to raise two questions: What about (1) uncover the leg (Is 47:2) and (2) removing skirts so as to expose heels (Jer 13:22)?
Do these two texts necessitate that we tone down Dennis’ claim just a bit? Apparently not. As to the first text, uncovering
the leg is associated with nakedness in the context: “Remove your veil, strip off the skirt, uncover [galah] the leg, cross
the rivers. Your nakedness will be uncovered [galah]” (Is 47:2-3). Uncovering one’s leg is associated or equated with
uncovering one’s nakedness. Both expressions are clearly linked by using the verb galah for uncover. Apparently,
uncovering the legs is a euphemism for exposing one’s genitals in this passage.136 This text strongly supports the sexual
interpretation of Ruth’s actions. Her uncovering Boaz’s legs was a euphemism for exposing his genitals. If Dennis is
guilty of anything in relation to this text, it is of understating his argument rather than overstating it!
        Dennis makes a strong argument that Ruth denuded Boaz. Even so, his argument is even stronger than he has
acknowledged. The same is true of the second text: “Because of the magnitude of your iniquity your skirts have been
removed [galah], and your heels have been exposed” (Jer 13:22). Does this mean that when Ruth raised Boaz skirt, it

       For those who prefer a milder rendition, F. B. Huey (Jeremiah, NAC) is content with the euphemistic explanation:
“‘Heels’ is [1] generally understood as a euphemism for the public exposure of the nakedness of a harlot. [2] It has also
been interpreted as a picture of the woman being driven barefoot into exile as a prisoner of war.” As to the second option
posed by NAC, does it really do justice to the context to suggest that God is merely threatening them with being barefoot?
Nonsense. MPC does better: “Probably these phrases are fetched from the usual practice of soldiers, when they have
conquered a place and taken prisoners, to strip them, and leave those of either sex, either no clothes to cover their
nakedness, or nothing but their own rags, not sufficient to cover their nakedness.” Yes, the text is describing forced
nakedness at the very least. Still, why the focus on the heels? Rendering it as merely euphemistically as barefoot does
not do justice to the focus on the heels of the euphemistic feet. Something more explicit than generic nakedness seems to
be entailed. TWOT hits the nail on the head in attributing the reference to heels as euphemistically depicting exposed
buttocks in Jer 13:22.
       Just as the backside of one’s feet are one’s heels, so the backside of one’s privates are the buttocks. But Ruth
exposed the feet rather than heels. That is to say, she exposed the front side of Boaz’s feet, that is, his privates, his genitals.
She then lay down (shakab) at his exposed genitals. She did not lay down at distance, nor did she sit down. Very explicitly,
she lay down at the very part of Boaz lower body that she exposed. This fact is easily deduced from the details of the
passage. She uncovered his feet and lay down (Ruth 3:4,7)—at his uncovered feet (Ruth 3:8,14). As to what she was
doing while lying there, the narrator leaves that up to the reader’s imagination. Yet practically nothing is left to the
imagination as to exactly what Ruth uncovered, as a survey of the usage of the Piel form of galah in relation to uncovering
clothing will reveal.

        When the Piel of galah is used in regard to clothing, the text is normally explicit, saying that the person’s
nakedness is uncovered. Occasionally, some other equivalent expression is used: skirt, feet, leg, yourself, or lewdness:
(1) Skirt is self-apparent in its context as a reference to nakedness. (2) Feet, judging from the normal usage of galah in
relation to clothing, is just one of the euphemisms describing uncovered genitals. (3) Leg has been discussed already in
this context as a euphemism for nakedness. (4) Yourself is self-apparent in its context as a reference to nakedness.
(5) Lewdness refers to female genitals (so HHL), likewise pudenda (so HALOT). Otherwise, if lewdness is not referring
to genitals, then it is not used in relation to the removal of clothing and is thus not within the range of the current
discussion. Therefore, unless the use of feet in Ruth is the sole exception to the rule, whenever the Piel of galah is used
in relation to removing clothing from part of the body, it always is used, in one way or another, to describe the sexual
uncovering of one’s nakedness so as to expose one’s genitals.
        Given the frequency, variety, and exclusivity of galah being used in this capacity in relation to the removal of
clothing, it is extremely unlikely that the uncovering of feet in Ruth 3:4 and in again in Ruth 3:7 would be exceptions.
Moreover, even when we move beyond the Piel to include all other uses of galah in relation to clothing, we encounter
no other exceptions to galah being used in relation to uncovering some form of nakedness. Most significantly, the closest
linguistic parallel occurs in Jer 13:22, where the uncovering of the heels of one’s feet refers to the exposing the
hindquarters of one’s privates. Consistency would dictate that the uncovering of one’s feet would refer to the exposing
of the front part of one’s privates. If this OT passage in Ruth is to be understood in the context of the OT, then Ruth
uncovered Boaz’s nakedness, and she then lay down at his exposed genitals. The narrator does everything but draw a

also the Niphal in Eze 23:29. The NAS uses these stems of galah in relation to uncovering nakedness for both the Piel

literal picture. Yet the word picture he has drawn suffices to make this the reasonable conclusion. Scholastic integrity
should lead one to interpret the passage in harmony with such details. For these reasons, those scholars favoring a sexual
understanding of what Ruth did must be preferred. Even though Hubbard (Ruth, NICOT) thinks margelot probably
means place of the feet, he acknowledges that the Piel of galah in such texts normally refers to illicit sexual activities:

              The verb glh [galah] in the Piel (“to uncover, make visible” something hidden) occurs primarily in
       expressions describing varieties of illicit sexual relations. Obliviously, such associations gave it an immoral
       ring in Israelite ear since such behavior was forbidden. The direct object here (margelot; “place of feet”)
       probably intensified that ring. As is well known, the term “feet” could be used as a euphemism for sexual
       organs (male: Exod. 4:25; Judg. 3:24; 1 Sam. 24:4 [Eng. 3]; female: Deut. 28:57; Ezek. 16:25; etc.) though
       not demonstrable as a euphemism here, it may have been chosen to add to the sexual overtones. 1n any
       case, “place of feet” meant the place where his feet lay. Hence, Naomi instructed Ruth to lay bare Boaz’s
       feet by laying back the edge of the large mantle in which he slept. Then she herself was to lie down (another
       sexually suggestive word!), presumably at his feet. (Emphasis his.)

Edward Campbell (Ruth, ABC) is another such scholar:

              Margelot appears elsewhere in the OT only at Dan 10:6 where it is paired with “arms” must mean
       “legs.” This noun is etymologically related to the common noun regel, “foot,” which can serve as a
       euphemism for the penis or the vulva, either as sexual organs or as the urinary opening (see Judg 3:24;
       1 Sam 24:3; II Kings 18:27 = Isa. 36:12; Isa 7:20; Eze 16:25; and in all probability, Exod 4:25; Deut 28:57;
       and Isa 6:2). The versions were clearly troubled as they sought to interpret correctly, doubtless they
       recognized the possible inference that Ruth uncovered the entire lower body of Boaz. Consider LXX “reveal
       the (place) at his feet....
              The question is whether the story-teller meant to be ambiguous and hence provocative. It seems to
       me that he did; therefore the intentional ambiguity of the translation “legs,” which leaves open the question
       of how much of his legs.

       Frankly, given the acknowledgement by ZEOTB (s.v., sex) that the Bible tends to tone down explicit references
to sex, it is amazing that the narrator of Ruth is as explicit as he is in dropping as many hints as he does. Younger,
nevertheless, thinks that the lack of explicitness makes any sexual uncovering improbable, even though he acknowledges
the sexual overtones:

              When he lies down, Ruth is to note that place and then go and uncover his feet (or legs) and lie down
       close beside him (probably not simply “at his feet,” as is often understood), so that “both lie beside one
       another as husband and wife.” That sexual overtones are present in the action of a woman uncovering a
       man’s legs in the dark of the night and lying down, there can be no doubt. But that our author intends the
       explicitly sexual sense of “uncover his genitals and lie down” is in my opinion utterly improbable. (Ruth,
       NIVAC).

        Younger hedges his statement by inserting the word explicitly. The argument may be readily conceded that the
biblical author does not explicitly say that she uncovered his genitals. What the biblical author is explicitly saying, though,
is that she uncovered his legs and implicitly that she did so from the waist down so as to uncover his genitals. The explicit
gives rise to the implicit. Such hints are justifiably convincing in the minds of some scholars to conclude that a sexual
exposure is indicated, as ZEOTB acknowledges:

               The Scriptures tend to avoid direct reference to the sex organs and to issues connected with sex. For
       example, when Gen. 17:11 refers to the rite of circumcision, the mention of the male sex organ is concealed
       by use of the expression...“the flesh of your foreskin.” The injunction that a wife should not seize her
       husband’s adversary by the male sex organs uses the term...“shame-provoking things” (cf. Latin pudenda).
       Again, reference is made to the desolation of Judah by the Assyrians as being as extensive as if one shaved
       “the hair of the feet” (Isa. 7:20; NIV, “the hair of your legs”); some believe that this usage of the word
       feet is an indirect reference to the lower parts of the body including the genitalia and pubic hair (cf
       Ruth 3:1-4,7-9; Deut. 28:57; perhaps Isa. 6:2). In a similar way, a circumlocution is used to refer to the
       testicles and the penis (Deut. 23:l). The word seed is used to refer to male semen, and a variety of injunctions
       are given in relation to this term (Gen. 3:15; Lev. 15:16-18; 22:4).
Page 78                                                                                         Mongamous Sex in Heaven!

       Notwithstanding Campbell’s acknowledgement that Ruth uncovered Boaz’s legs and his admission that many
sexual innuendos and double meanings are intended in the text, he does not believe that any sexual intercourse actually
occurred. His argument that no sexual intercourse actually occurred runs counter to his own analysis, however. His
argument is that since in 3:13 Boaz told Ruth “to lodge” (lun) there that night (i.e., stay the night) and since this Hebrew
word lun never has any sexual undertone, “there was no sexual intercourse at the threshing floor.” This argument is
woefully unconvincing. Campbell acknowledges that for Ruth to lie (shakab) at Boaz feet could easily have a sexual
undertone: “Surely the audience also recognizes that shakab in Hebrew (combined with the preposition ‘with’) means to
have sexual intercourse, an idiom which has become common parlance in English.” Ruth does not merely stay (lun) the
night; she lies (shakab) at his exposed legs.
       Campbell acknowledges that Ruth uncovers Boaz’s legs and that in 3:14 “Ruth is to resume the same place to
sleep as she had taken in verse 8,” but then he adds, “It is inescapable that this position is next to Boaz.” At this point
Campbell cheats. The same place is not merely next to him. Campbell seeks to evade the clear implications of his own
argument and the text. He turns she lay at his legs into she lay next to him (cp. vv. 8,14). That is not what the text says,
and Campbell knows it. The text does not say that she uncovered his legs and lay next to him. For that matter, the text
does not say that she uncovered him and lay next to him. The text says that she uncovered his legs and lay at his legs.
The very thing she uncovered is where she lay. In vv. 7 and 8, she uncovered the lower half of his body, and then she lay
at the lower half of his body. Moreover, in v. 14, she returned to that exact position after Boaz told her to stay the night.
She did not merely lay beside him. She lay at the lower half of his body. Campbell shoots his own argument in the foot
when he fails to own up to the fact that she lay at his legs. In a context specifying that she lay down at what she uncovered,
Campbell himself acknowledges that his legs are what she uncovered. Perhaps one must speak syllogistically for those
who are scholarly so that they will own up to what the text is saying explicitly:
                    1. She uncovered his legs (as Campbell acknowledges).
                    2. She lay at the part of his body that she uncovered (as the text explicitly states).
                    3. Therefore, she lay at his uncovered legs.

        If she merely lay beside him, this would suggest that her head was basically level with his. Evidently, this is what
Campbell imagines. Much to the contrary, however, she lay at his legs, as his own analysis would concede. Where would
that place her head? At his genitals of course. Little wonder, then, that those writing at a more popular level are doing a
better job of being true to the text than those writing at a scholastic level. Those writing at the popular level have the
audacity to acknowledge the obvious. Her lying at his legs would put her head level with his genitals and virtually spell
oral sex to anyone but a commentator.
        Even aside from all these lexical arguments, Tod Linafelt’s argument is persuasive as to the socially scandalous
nature of the encounter:

              All of these possible double entendres and sexual allusions are centered around the crucial
       instruction of Naomi’s that Ruth should “uncover his feet.” It is difficult to know exactly what to make of
       the Hebrew word margelot, commonly translated as “feet” or “the place at the feet.” The term is obviously
       related to the more commonly occurring word for foot, regel, which is a well-known euphemism in the
       Bible for genitalia (cf. Judg 3:24; 1 Sam 24:3; 2 Kgs 18:27; Isa 7:20; Ezek 16:25), but in the present form
       it occurs only in Dan 10:6 where it means “legs.” It is possible that it also means legs here, but one of the
       problems with the word is that it is used in 3:4 and 7 to indicate what Ruth uncovers, while in 3:8 and 14 it
       seems to refer to the place that Ruth spends the night (hence the translation “place at his feet”). Whether
       the word means “feet” in a quite literal sense,” or “feet” in a euphemistic sense, or “legs,” or even “the
       place at his feet/legs” hardly matters: any one or combination of the above meanings is equally
       scandalous (for Boaz) and dangerous (for Ruth). Any of the actions—done in the middle of the night,
       alone behind a pile of grain—would imply the offer of a sexual encounter. In a situation like this,
       Naomi’s final words of instruction, “he will tell you what to do” (v. 4), presume that Boaz will not refuse
       the offer. (Ruth, BO)

       Naomi’s instructions were thoroughly scandalous (at least in the minds of those who cannot give her the benefit
of the doubt in acting responsibly—given the motives, intentions, culture, circumstances, time, and typology), and Ruth
performed as instructed. Boaz could give Ruth the benefit of the doubt, but he knew that many could not, so he handled
the manner delicately. The narrator also could give her the benefit of the doubt but recorded the encounter ambiguously
for the sake of overly scrupulous readers who would treat the matter too scandalously so as to stumble in their faith if
matters were made too explicit. Ruth was not acting like a prostitute but making a marriage proposition with an informal
Chapter 4. Secondary Biblical Confirmation                                                                          Page 79
betrothal in such a manner that would be ill-advised as a role model for others seeking earthly marriage but unwittingly
useful in God’s hand for a typological foreshadowing of sex outside of normal boundaries of marriage, yet inside the
typological boundaries of consenting soulmate exclusivity. This text could foreshadow consensual soulmate exclusivity.

                                                Biblical Situational Ethics

       Black, White, and Gray
        In suggesting that the culture, circumstances, time, and typology might be factors that sufficiently justify Naomi’s
directives and Ruth’s actions, so as to acquit them of charges of acting immorally, I am adopting an argument from
biblical situational ethics, or more specifically a form of graded absolutism. Geisler, for example, states, “Everything is
not black or white. There are real moral conflicts.”138 Some people assume that if morality can be relative to such factors,
then morality is always relative, so there can be no such thing as moral absolutes. This makes as much sense as saying
that the presence of gray proves that black and white do not exist. Nonsense. In a similar fashion, we cannot automatically
assume that a limited moral relativity proves that absolute morality is impossible. Conversely, at the opposite end of the
spectrum, others assume that if morality is absolute, then moral relativity is impossible. This makes about as much sense
as saying that if black and white exist, then gray cannot exist. A more mature ethical perspective allows the possibility
of black, white, and gray.

       Villainize Ruth
       The field of ethics can be a minefield at times, blowing apart simplistic approaches to ethics. The book of Ruth is
one such example. This biblical book uses ambiguity regarding the sexual nature of the encounter as a literary device to
implement fuzzy logic in order to challenge simplistic binary morality. As a case in point, in order to defend the moral
virtue of the characters involved from a binary perspective, Block attempts to undercut the rather obvious sexual
overtones of the passage. Supposedly, in his reconstruction, Naomi only told Ruth to lie somewhere near Boaz and watch
his response. However, in that case, we are left, therefore, to deduce that Ruth went beyond Naomi’s directions and
actually lay at Boaz’s uncovered legs when Ruth only told her to lie nearby and watch. Block’s proposal thus backfires.
In attempting to exonerate Naomi, in the manner in which he does, he implicates Ruth. Block unwittingly winds up
throwing Ruth under the bus, so to speak, in his defense of Naomi.

       Villainize Naomi
        Taking the opposite approach, Deffinbaugh purposefully throws Naomi under the bus in order to save Ruth. He is
right when he says, “You will find that some scholars and Bible teachers tap dance all around the threshing floor, fervently
trying to sanctify Naomi’s actions. In my opinion, it is a futile effort.” He is correct. Block is one such example. I also
agree with Deffinbaugh when he says, “I take the text at face value. I do not believe that there is some unique cultural
interpretation here. Folks, when a woman bathes, puts on perfume and dons her best dress, and then secretively climbs
under the covers with a man who has had his fill of food and wine, I don’t think anyone in any culture would read this in
any way but what we all assume.”139 True. Posing that there was some unique custom pertaining to uncovering feet that
would sanitize this text so as to remove any scandalous associations is nothing more than scholastic speculation. My
invoking a cultural defense is drawn more broadly from the culture at the time, especially regarding the kinsman
redeemer. For instance, if her nearest kinsman redeemer was not fulfilling his moral obligations, as seems to be the case,
then does this justify her actions, at least to some extent? Apparently, it does.
        Deffinbaugh argues that Naomi gave ungodly council, but “somehow” Ruth and Boaz are able to navigate the
moral minefields of this situation and come out unscathed. Deffinbaugh performs a tap dance of his own in his attempt
to scandalize Naomi while sanctifying Ruth. He throws Naomi under the same bus as Tamar and Mordecai (Esther’s
uncle) in the book of Esther. Even poor Mordecai cannot escape being thrown under the bus by Deffinbaugh. Frankly, I
am not inclined to throw these biblical characters under the bus and regard them as godless. Nevertheless, Deffinbaugh’s
article is worth reading, at least as a partial corrective to Block, but I would see a number of matters differently, such as
when he says, “If Boaz is a prototype of Christ, our Redeemer, then should he not have been trusted to assume a leadership
role in redeeming the family property and marrying Ruth?” Not necessarily. For one thing, Boaz and Ruth may be serving
not only as prototypes for Christ and His Bride, respectively, but also for male and female soulmates in the eternal state.

The text is not only saturated with double entendres but also with double typology. The text is not two dimensional but
three dimensional. A key part of Deffinbaugh’s tap-dance routine occurs in his explanation of Ruth 3:6:

             Ruth “did according to all that her mother-in-law commanded her.” The way I read these words,
       Ruth did not do everything exactly as Naomi had instructed, but she acted consistently with what she was
       commanded. When we get to Ruth’s actions and choice of words, we find that she obeyed Naomi’s
       command in a way that was completely honorable and consistent with her noble character. (Black bold
       emphasis his.)

Then in a footnote he adds,
              Some scholars and translations leave us with the impression that Ruth uncovered more than the feet
       of Boaz, and that she lay beside him, rather than at his feet. This may be what Naomi had in mind, but I am
       convinced that it is not what Ruth did. She consistently took the moral high ground, as Boaz bears witness
       in 3:10-11.

       Stand or Fall Together
        Quite to the contrary, the text gives us the impression, contrary to Block, that Naomi was instructing Ruth to
uncover Boaz from the waist down, as Deffinbaugh himself would allow. Deffinbaugh comes up with over a dozen
reasons to claim that Naomi’s moral compass was broken. What Deffinbaugh is objecting to in the above quote is the
belief that Ruth followed through on the sexual implications of Naomi’s instructions. In this regard, his tap dancing is
just as bad, if not worse, than that of Block. Those scholars and translators who acknowledge that Ruth actually did as
Naomi instructed are being far truer to the text than those who do not. Naomi’s directions, as Deffinbaugh himself admits,
involve much more than just uncovering Boaz’s literal feet; they indicate on many levels that Naomi was directing Ruth
to act sexually. Deffinbaugh gives a list of reasons to believe that Naomi’s directions were intended to be sexually
explosive. Yet when it comes to Ruth’s follow-through, Deffinbaugh acts as though all Ruth did was uncover his literal
feet. His proposal runs counter to the flow of the passage.
        Similar to Deffinbaugh, Linafelt acknowledges that the word for all in Ruth 3:6 “is often taken to emphasize that
Ruth did exactly as Naomi had instructed” (emphasis his), but he believes it “often carries the connotation of
‘approximately’—as it does in 2:17...and it is likely that this is the sense of the preposition here.” He and Deffinbaugh
thus concur that it does not mean exactly in this passage. Yet, whereas Deffinbaugh believes that Ruth stops short of
doing what Naomi instructed, Linafelt believes that Ruth went beyond what Naomi instructed: “As we will see, Ruth
does not do all that Naomi instructs her, or perhaps it is better said that she does all that Naomi instructs her and more
as well” (Ruth, BO). This perspective is superior. Edward Campbell (Ruth, ABC) states that grammatically the expression
here is “an indication of exactitude....The translation would then be ‘and she did everything exactly as her mother-in-
law had commanded her.’ The impact would be particularly effective because Ruth does do exactly what Naomi told
her to do—up to a point. Then, where Naomi had said ‘he will tell you what you are to do,’ Ruth instead tells Boaz what
he is to do” (italics his). Hubbard (NICOT) makes the same point. In uncovering Boaz’s feet and lying at his feet, with
all the sexual implications that were involved, Ruth was following Naomi’s instructions exactly: “Ruth went to the
threshing floor and did exactly as her mother-in-law had directed her” (GWT). Then she went beyond those instructions
when she requested that Boaz spread his kanaph over her, whatever that means. If we are to interpret the text in its natural
historical-grammatical composition, within the flow of the details provided by the context, then the proper interpretation
is that Ruth performed sexually, exactly as instructed. She then went beyond what Naomi had instructed in that Ruth
instructed Boaz to spread his kanaph over her.140

140
    A plausible alternative is that even if Ruth did less than what Naomi instructed, as Deffinbaugh would insist, then
Ruth still may have performed oral sex, a possibility Deffinbaugh does not address. When Naomi commanded Ruth not
to be known by the man (yada) until after he had finished eating and drinking (Ruth 3:3), this can easily be interpreted as
an injunction not to have sexual intercourse with him until that point: “Here is almost the full range of nuances of the
Hebrew term ‘to know,’ but the audience will doubtless have supplied in their own minds one additional frequent
meaning, ‘to have intercourse with’” (Campbell, Ruth, ABC). Similarly, Naomi’s instructions to uncover his legs and lie
down can be interpreted to mean disrobe him and have sexual intercourse with him (Ruth 3:4). Naomi could easily be
understood as instructing this Moabitess to act like the daughters of Lot, from whom the Moabites derived their ancestry
(Gen 19:36-37), by having sexual intercourse with this intoxicated man who had called her daughter. Better
commentators contemplate such possibilities, even if, like Campbell, they eventually conclude that no sexual intercourse
Chapter 4. Secondary Biblical Confirmation                                                                         Page 81
       Kanaph
       Naomi did not tell Ruth to instruct Boaz to spread his kanaph over her. Ruth did this on her own. Even so, the idea
had been planted in her head by Boaz! Ruth undoubtedly intends a sexual understanding of the term. The real question
is, “Did Boaz also intend a sexual innuendo?” Although Linafelt (BO) does not really consider this possibility, even
though he should have, given his reading sexual intentions into everything else Boaz said, at least Linafelt does explain
the sexual understanding of kanaph intended by Ruth:

       Whether or not her instructions to Boaz are a proposal for marriage or an invitation to sexual intercourse is
       another of the central ambiguities on which the scene turns. By telling Boaz to “spread his ‘wing’ (kanaph)”
       over her, she [Ruth] may well be invoking a rite of betrothal that is perhaps alluded to also in Ezek 16:8.
       But as Fewell and Gunn point out, this is not simply a given. Nowhere is the term for “betrothal” (aras)
       used in either of these texts, while both present an atmosphere of highly charged sexuality. Moreover, the
       word kanaph, which literally means an “extension” or “extremity,” may itself, like “feet,” be a
       euphemism for male genitalia. It is Saul’s kanaph that David cuts off in a symbolic castration scene in
       1 Samuel 24, which as I noted above takes place while Saul is relieving himself in a cave, and when the
       book of Deuteronomy (23:1 [Dt 22:30; cp. Dt 27:20]) legislates against adulterous relationships it does so
       with the idiom “to uncover another man’s kanaph” in a way parallel to the idiom in Leviticus “to uncover
       another man’s nakedness [ervah]” (18:7, passim; 20:17). It may be, then, that Ruth is offering herself
       sexually to Boaz. Protestations to this interpretation based on the assumed morality of the characters (so
       Bush) are simply circular in their arguments. Moreover, Boaz’s relieved reaction to Ruth’s statement can
       be cited in support of either. An invitation to sex would indicate that such has not already taken p1ace,
       while an invitation to marriage would mean that even if it had he was being given the opportunity to cover
       the indiscretion in private rather than being accused later in public (as was his ancestor Judah in Genesis
       38).
               I would maintain, again, that the ambiguities present in the scene and reinforced by the author’s
       choice of so many words with potential double meaning should not be reduced to one meaning above all
       others. Rather, these ambiguities are part of the narrative art and are what makes the story more than a
       simple morality tale. Fewell and Gunn put it well: “Ruth allows Boaz freedom to make a choice. See her
       as but an ephemeral sexual object (‘extend your penis’), or see her as a person in need (‘spread your
       wing/skirt’), a person who offers an enduring relationship, in which sexuality will have its home.” Thus,
       it is not just that the reader must decide what to make of Ruth’s ambiguous invitation, but that Boaz must
       as well. In forcing Boaz to decide what to make of this woman lying at his feet, Ruth is also continuing to
       push him past his moral and theological platitudes, for we may recall that when they met in the field Boaz
       praised Ruth for seeking shelter under the LORD’s “wing” (kanaph). Her reply then was to address him
       as “my lord” (adon) and to wish for future “favor” in his eyes. By using the word kanaph here she makes
       even more explicit, via a shrewd wordplay, her resolve not to wait around for the Lord but to take a gamble
       on Boaz and his kanaph instead.141

       Qualified End Justifies Some Means
       Given Linafelt’s own analysis, he has failed to give due consideration to the possibility that the duality regarding
kanaph was not invented by Ruth in 3:9. Rather, my postulation is Boaz is the one who invested the word kanaph with
double meaning in 2:12, at least subconsciously, if not intentionally. Even there, in that first encounter, Ruth was seeking
to determine if a double meaning was intended. With Naomi’s help, she correctly deduced that Boaz was expressing
sexual interest in her—even if subconsciously. We will return to that discussion shortly. But for now let us note that Ruth
did not stop short of following Naomi’s sexual instructions. Not by a long shot! If anything, she probably went beyond
those instructions. Nevertheless, one of Deffinbaugh’s arguments still may be exegetically significant: “Nowhere in the
Book of Ruth is Naomi praised. Ruth is praised several times, and Boaz likewise is praised” (emphasis his). In interpreting
the immediate text within the book of Ruth in light of the broader context, I would allow that some type of subtle
differentiation might be intended between the relative virtue of Naomi and Ruth, similar to what Deffinbaugh suggests.


actually occurred. But an option not normally considered by commentators is that Ruth may have opted for oral sex—
instead of performing exactly as Naomi had instructed her, which was to perform vaginal intercourse—and then
afterwards, that is, after the oral sex, Ruth offered him vaginal intercourse, which was the only form of intercourse that
Naomi had envisioned.
141
    For sake of consistency, I have substituted my own transliterations for his.
Page 82                                                                                         Mongamous Sex in Heaven!
Still, before theorizing possible distinctions, an ethical objection raised by Deffinbaugh is worthy of discussion: “Naomi’s
plan seems to assume that the end justifies the means” (emphasis his).
        Basically, Block and Deffinbaugh draw justifiable attention to the fact that Ruth’s virtue is affirmed. Therefore, a
tension is apparent with the seeming ethicality that end-justifies-the-means (EJTM). In Christianity we do not normally
sanction an EJTM mentality. So if an EJTM morality is the backbone of one’s defense in justifying Naomi’s instructions
and Ruth’s complicit actions, then both women are automatically assumed to be performing in a genuinely scandalous
manner. A more mature understanding of Christian ethics, however, might allow a defense of their character that does
not conflict with the obvious sexual overtones of the passage.
        We might as well start by critically examining the EJTM approach to morality. In one of my favorite pieces of
Christian fiction, Carmical poses a discussion between Ben (an Innocent, i.e., an infant killed before reaching the age of
accountability) and Alcemene (a reporter):

               Ben and Alcemene floated downward....As they landed, Ben asked, “Any more questions about the
       Innocents?”
               Alcemene remembered something she had thought of earlier, but was afraid to ask. She said bluntly,
       “What you’re really saying, then, is that the end justified the means.’
               Ben responded instantly. “You may say that, but not with such a flippant tone of voice and not without
       qualifying your words.”
               Alcemene swallowed. “I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to offend you.”
               Ben shrugged. “You’re a reporter. They pay you to be offensive.” He and Alcemene laughed
       together.
               Then Ben became serious again. “Always be careful how you state such a proposition. A good end
       does not justify evil means.”
               “But isn’t that what you’re saying?” “Not at all. An infinite, eternal good justifies the use of finite,
       temporal evils. The evil means that the Father permitted were always limited in scope, influence, and
       intensity, and above all else, they were temporary.
               “Let me stress one last thing, Alcemene, or nothing else I’ve said will make sense. Although the
       Father permitted all that happened, he didn’t cause it. Wicked rebels persisted in their rebellion in spite of
       every effort to stop them. Simply because rebel men and nations became tools in a greater plan of good did
       not excuse their actions. “I think especially of those who killed the most helpless of all, the unborn. It would
       have been better for those murderers to have drowned in the seas that are no more than to suffer their present
       fate Outside. “Nor did those evils become good. The tiny graves, the silent cradles, the empty arms and
       bitter tears of mothers, were all real and terrible. They were just as real and terrible as the Father’s broken
       heart when his Son died to end those evils forever.”142

        Carmical allows a qualified-end-justifies-the-means (QEJTM) as an explanation for the problem of evil—a
solution that is not uncommon in Christian circles. Why did a good God create a world in which evil would come to
exist? Why does God not remove evil? Writing at a philosophical level, Plantinga considers various answers, some of
which sound like QEJTM.143 Did God cause the evil? Of course, not. But He did create a world in which He knew that
evil would come to exist. Then why did He do so? Some would say that He did so because it was the best possible world.
The greater good was to create the best possible world. Others would say that He had no choice if He was going to make
a world with significantly free moral agents. Regardless, creating a world with significantly free moral agents was the
greater good: The end that justified the means of creating a world in which a finite amount of sin would occur for a finite
amount of time. In a discussion of deontological versus teleological ethics in an online article, Geisler also allows that
“the end may justify the use of good means, but it does not justify the use of any means, certainly not evil ones” (emphasis
his).144 Again, this sounds like QEJTM, and all the more when one starts to unravel Geisler’s argument.145 At the very
beginning of the article, Geisler gives a summation of the ethical position he holds:

        And since His [God’s] moral nature does not change, it follows that moral obligations flowing from His

        conflict, the Christian is responsible for obeying the greater commandment. The Christian is not held
        guilty for not following the lesser of two (or more) conflicting commandments.

        Types of Absolutism
        In this case, the end that justifies the means is the greater commandment. One should at least read Geisler’s online
article to get an introductory feel for the complexity of ethicality. For a much more in-depth treatment, see his book.146
For present purposes, summarizing a few options will have to suffice. Let us limit ourselves to three forms of absolutism
and add my synthetic blend of the lesser-evil and greater-good absolutism:

        1.   Unqualified Absolutism (Anabaptist): absolute laws never conflict.
        2.   Conflicting Absolutism (Lutheran): when absolute laws conflict, choose the lesser evil.
        3.   Graded Absolutism (Reformed): when absolute laws conflict, choose the greater good.
        4.   Synthetic Absolutism (Marrowism): when absolute laws conflict, choose the greater good or lesser evil.147

       Number one is not realistic. Number three, which is the position taken by Geisler, is to be preferred over number
two. But at times, in my estimation, number two may be the best that one can do. Number four thus allows a synthesis in
which number three is preferred over number two when possible. Therefore, the type of situational ethics I am employing
in my defense of Naomi and Ruth is not situationism (which affirms that there is only one absolute law—love). In my
synthesis, I am not limiting graded absolutism to the positive end of the moral spectrum but allowing it to encompass the
negative end also, therefore running all the way from the positive end to the negative end. In other words, I am not
limiting my graded absolutism to various shades of white; instead, I am allowing a graded range of gray (i.e., shades of
gray) between black and white. Doing so seems better suited to the human condition and exegetical considerations. For
instance, this ethical model will allow me to entertain the possibility that Deffinbaugh is partially correct in sensing that
Ruth is more virtuous than Naomi, but it allows me the freedom of doing so without throwing Naomi under the bus,
morally speaking, so as to picture her as being morally in the black. Not having access to graded absolutism caused
Deffinbaugh to see everything in black and white, thus picturing Naomi in morally harsh terms and Ruth as morally
exemplary. His assessment turned out to be much too faultfinding concerning Naomi and too simple-minded regarding
Ruth.
       For sake of illustration, let us consider homicide. Depending on various factors, such as circumstances and
motives, homicide can run the gamut from being thoroughly condemnatory to highly praiseworthy.

1.    First degree murder— culpable, intentional, premediated murder
2.    Second degree murder— culpable, intentional, unpremeditated murder
3.    Voluntary Manslaughter— culpable, intentional, unpremeditated murder with limited circumstantial justification
4.    Involuntary manslaughter— culpable, unintentional killing
5.    Justifiable homicide—blameless killing
6.    Mandated homicide—prescribed killing
7.    Meritorious homicide—praiseworthy killing

        Levels 1-5 are well-known levels of homicide. An example of level 6 would be a police officer or solider killing
someone in the line of duty. An example of level 7 would be an officer or solider being awarded a medal for his action
in doing so. As to biblical counterparts for level 7, some biblical heroes are praised because of their success on the
battlefield. David killing Goliath would be the most famous example. Biblical examples are not limited to the military,
however. God commended and rewarded Phinehas for killing both a man and his wife by running them through with a
spear (Num 25:5-13)! Phinehas’ action was not only justified but praiseworthy under the circumstances. To put it mildly,
circumstances can play a major part in determining how one’s actions should be perceived. Other factors would include
motive and intent.

    Norman L. Geisler, Christian Ethics: Contemporary Issues & Options, second edition (Grand Rapids: Baker
Academic, 2010). Unless stated otherwise, all page citations herein will be from his book.

    Broadly speaking, SA = GA + CA. That is, (SA) synthetic absolutism is a combination of (GA) graded absolutism

into SA.

      Deffinbaugh’s binary black-and-white approach to the text paints Naomi in a very negative light while putting
Ruth and Boaz in a very positive light. Such a sharp dichotomy between the moral justification of Naomi’s directions
and Ruth’s action is rendered untenable by the narrator’s depicting Ruth’s actions as being completely in accord with
Naomi’s directions. Yet, with Deffinbaugh’s simplistic rejection of EJTM, he has painted himself into a corner where it
would be hard not to consider Naomi’s socially scandalous directions to be genuinely morally scandalous.

       With my QEJTM model and synthetic absolutism, I am free to explore other possibilities not available to
Deffinbaugh’s model. For simplicity’s sake, a five-level symmetrical chart will be used to evaluate the actions of the
three principle biblical characters in the narrative. Level 3 is amoral (i.e., morally neutral), and is placed in the center.
Two negative levels are listed above it, and two corresponding positive levels are listed below it. A very reasonable
depiction, which gives some weight to Deffinbaugh’s argument, would be to put the three characters at three different
levels. If you want to assign a higher value to Deffinbaugh’s argument than I have done, then you might wish to put
Naomi at level two and regard her directions as worthy of some criticism. For my part, though, in seeking to see Naomi
through the narrator’s eyes, I do not see Naomi in such a harsh light. The narrator does not criticize Naomi. So why
should I?

       Neutral is not Negative
       Observe that Deffinbaugh’s assessment, as stated above, is based on an argument from silence: “Nowhere in the
Book of Ruth is Naomi praised. Ruth is praised several times, and Boaz likewise is praised” (emphasis his). Deffinbaugh
seeks to turn the narrator’s lack of praise into a negative. But a lack of a positive affirmation would more readily be
regarded as a neutral position rather than a negative, especially when Naomi’s directions are so closely associated with
Ruth’s positive position. The narrator makes no explicit negative comment about Naomi. Deffinbaugh has painted a
much more negative picture of Naomi than does the narrator. Thus, for my part, I am assigning Naomi to a neutral level
3, not a negative level 2, much less a very negative level 1. As to Ruth, she is pictured in a positive light by the narrator,
but morally she seems to be a bridge between Naomi’s questionable position and Boaz’s highly commendable position.
Therefore, in accord with the narration, I am ranking these three characters morally like stair steps.

       Weighing Implies Degrees
       Not only must Naomi and Ruth’s actions and circumstances be considered, but their motives and intentions must
be part of the moral calculus. God judges our motives and intentions: “The Lord weighs the motives” (Prov 16:2); He
discloses our motives before deciding if we are worthy of praise (1Cor 4:5); He judges our intentions (Heb 4:12).
Unquestionably, our motives and intentions must play a part in determining whether our actions are right or wrong. God
rewards us with various degrees of rewards. Certainly, He uses our motives and intentions in grading/weighing how right
or wrong our actions are. The degree of negative rebuke or positive praise that we get will be dependent, in part, upon
the degree to which our motives and intentions are culpable or commendable. Because judgment evaluates according to
degrees and dispenses rewards by degrees and weighs motive and intentions, our ethical model must calculate these
considerations as well. Additionally, Geisler says that we must consider whether the source of the moral directive is from
God’s nature versus His will:

              Since God’s moral character does not change, it follows that moral obligations flowing from His
       nature are absolute. That is, they are always binding everywhere on everyone. Of course, not everything
Chapter 4. Secondary Biblical Confirmation                                                                          Page 85
         God wills flows necessarily from His unchanging nature. Some things are merely in accord with His nature
         but flow freely from His will.
                 For example, God chose to test Adam and Eve’s moral obedience by forbidding them to eat a specific
         fruit on a tree (Gen. 2:16-17). Although it was morally wrong for Adam and Eve to disobey that command
         (Rom. 5:12), we are no longer bound by it today. That command was in accord with God’s nature, but it
         did not flow necessarily from it.
                 On the other hand, God’s command not to murder applied before the Law was given to Moses
         (Gen. 9:6), under the Law of Moses (Exod. 20:13), and also since the time of Moses (Rom. 13:9). Murder,
         then, is wrong at all times and all places and for all people. This is true because humans are created in the
         “image and likeness of God” (Gen. 1:27; 9:6). This includes a moral likeness to God (Col. 3:10; James 3:9).
         And whatever is traceable to God’s unchanging moral character is a moral absolute. This includes moral
         obligations such as holiness, justice, love, truthfulness, and mercy.
                 Other commands flowing from God’s will, but not necessarily from His nature, are equally binding,
         but they are not absolute. That is, they must be obeyed because God prescribed them, but He did not
         prescribe them for all people, times, and places.148 (Italics his.)

         Justified Nakedness
        An ethicality that does not factor such complexities into consideration will be subject to considerable errors. Might
the passage in question pertaining to Ruth be one such example? Might the sexual actions taken by these particular people
at this particular time at this particular place be within God’s will? Before we automatically assume that Ruth privately
stripping Boaz could not be within God’s will, we should recall that Isaiah publicly stripped himself and walked about
naked for three years (Is 20:2-3). Micah stripped and walked about naked also (Micah 1:8). Saul did also as an act of
prophecy! (1Sam 19:24). The way some interpreters deal with these passages is to say that Boaz and the prophets were
not striped completely naked so as to expose their genitals. Even if that were the case, these examples would still be cases
where partial nakedness, which would have been prohibited under usual circumstances, became an expression of God’s
will in certain circumstances. Gary Smith (NAC) is noncommittal as to whether Isaiah was completely naked, but his
comments are very reasonable regardless:

                Since the purpose of this command was to send a message to the people who would see Isaiah in
         public, Isaiah followed God’s command. God did not say that he had to be naked 24 hours every day or
         even every day of the week, so he would not be viewed as disobeying the Lord if he wore a cloak in his
         home on a cold winter evenings [sic.] to keep warm or if he was clothed when he worshiped God in the
         temple on the Passover. He was not an exhibitionist who randomly flashed people to gain attention. He was
         trying to send God’s message to certain leaders in a very graphic way, so he probably chose appropriate
         times to go naked to influence them.

Regardless as to whether Isaiah was completely naked at specific times during those three years, he was sufficiently
naked so that his nakedness would not have been excusable had it not been prescribed by the Lord as part of his prophetic
role. Though Calvin does not believe that Isaiah was completely naked, he concedes the principle point:

                In order to confirm this prophecy by the use of a symbol, the Lord commanded Isaiah to walk naked.
         If Isaiah had done this of his own accord, he would have been justly ridiculed; but when he does it by
         the command of the Lord, we perceive nothing but what is fitted to excite admiration and to strike awe....
                Yet it must not be thought that the Prophet went entirely naked, or without covering those parts
         which would present a revolting aspect. It was enough that the people understood what the Lord was doing,
         and were affected by it as something extraordinary.149

       What if the Lord had commanded Isaiah to walk about completely naked on such occasions, would Isaiah have
been justly ridiculed? Despite Calvin finding such a prospect revolting, based on his own logic, Isaiah’s action would
have been justified in that case, even if he were totally naked. In either case, we have an example of QEJTM. Would not
the same argument hold true for Ruth? Would not her actions be justified if the Holy Spirit directed her to the course of
action she took via Naomi? Yes, according to both Calvin’s logic and graded absolutism, as well as synthetic absolutism.
For that matter, I suspect that Ruth unwittingly was acting typologically as a prophetess. That she typologically represents

the Bride of Christ is a widely held proposition. My conjecture is that she also serves typologically as a female overcomer

       Rating Ruth
       Even though Geisler holds to graded absolutism, he fails to discuss graded absolutism as a possible solution to the
ethical tension posed by Ruth and instead denies that the passage has sexual connotations:

               There is nothing in the text of Ruth that indicates any moral impropriety on the part of either Boaz
       or Ruth. First, Ruth did not come at night to hide an immoral relationship with Boaz. Rather, she came in
       the night so that Boaz would not feel the pressure of public scrutiny. Boaz would have the opportunity to
       decline the proposal to redeem Naomi and marry Ruth without facing any public embarrassment.
               Second, the uncovering of the feet is not a euphemism indicating that Ruth had intercourse with
       Boaz. Rather, it is a literal description of a customary practice to demonstrate subjection and submission.
       Ruth merely pulled back the covering from over the feet of Boaz as a symbol of her submission to Boaz
       and willingness to become his wife.
               Third, the passage states that after uncovering the feet of Boaz, Ruth lay down (v.7). However, this
       is not the normal way to indicate sexual intercourse. Sexual intercourse is usually indicated by the phrase,
       “he lay with her.” Without the accompanying indication of laying [sic] “with” someone, the word normally
       indicates merely that someone reclines.
               Fourth, it was also a symbolic act for Boaz to spread the corner of his garment over Ruth. This refers
       to the practice of a man spreading a covering over his wife as well as himself. Ruth reminds Boaz of his
       responsibility according to the law of levirate marriage (Deut. 25:5-10). The word translated “wing” in
       the NKJV recalls the earlier blessing which Boaz pronounced upon Ruth at their first encounter (2:12).
       Ruth had sought refuge under the wings of the God of Israel, now she seeks refuge under the wing of
       Boaz.150

        This is a classic defense of the G-rated version of the text. Many, understandably, do not find it very convincing.
A PG-rated interpretation of the text would acknowledge the sexual overtones of the passage but then deny that any form
of sexual intercourse actually transpired. An R-rated interpretation would allow that oral intercourse occurred but then
seek to defend the characters from any charge of immorality. (I am adopting this position and using synthetic absolutism
for my defense of their morality.) An X-rated interpretation would insist upon sexual intercourse and that Naomi and
Ruth acted immorally as gold diggers.
        The G-rated interpretation seems suitable enough for children’s Sunday School lessons, but probably not for much
else. The biblical narrator, I suppose, allows this level of understanding for those who must approach this text with sexual
naivety. But the sexual nature of the passage is readily recognized by all three of the latter interpretations and is better
suited for a mature discussion of the text. For Geisler to pose that what Ruth did was simply a customary practice at the
time is a matter of sheer conjecture, and not a very persuasive conjecture at that. The invitation for Boaz to spread his
wing (kanaph) over her was an invitation for a marital relation, to be sure, but this invitation was provided via a
euphemism for marital sex. As already noted, kanaph can refer to penis.
        As to the verb lay down [shakab], there is some truth to Geisler’s comment that lay with is the normal expression
for sexual encounters. I have already noted a number of texts in which lay with is used as a sexual euphemism for sexual
intercourse. Specifically, one would presume vaginal intercourse when the expression lie/lay with is used (cf. Gen 19:32-
33,35; 19:34; 30:15-16; 34:2; 35:22; 39:7,12,14; Dt 22:22, 29; 1Sam 2:22; 2Sam 11:4,11; 12:11,24; 13:14; Eze 32:28-
29).151 If the narrator had simply meant to say that Ruth had vaginal sex with Boaz, one would anticipate that he would
had said that she uncovered his feet and lay with him (Ruth 3:7). Doing so would have removed all reasonable doubt.
However, the narrator does not seem to want to remove all doubt—in either direction—and prefers to use ambiguity
instead. Moreover, the fact that he did not say that she lay with him but lay down at his feet (Ruth 3:14), meaning his
uncovered lower body, strongly suggests oral sex rather than vaginal sex.152

       Morally and Legally Justified
       A couple of comments by Hubbert can be used to build a hypothesis as to why Naomi and Ruth could be rated
differently as to their culpability. Commenting on Ruth 3:4, he says:

              Since Naomi had identified Boaz as a goel (2:20), the scheme probably aimed to get him to carry
       out that duty by marrying Ruth. Still, one wonders why none of the kinsman-redeemers (including Boaz)
       had yet stepped forward to fulfill that duty. Since it was optional, not obligatory, perhaps each was waiting
       for the other to act, or each hesitated because Ruth was a Moabitess. If so, Naomi’s ploy was simply an
       acceptable but unusual way to break the impasse. And certainly she had Ruth’s best interest at heart.
       Finally, one cannot exclude the possibility that the narrator wanted the audience to compare this plan with
       that of Tamar (Gen. 38). Is history about to repeat itself—and perhaps with similar historic results for
       Judah? (Italics his.)

       Yet commenting on Ruth 3:9, Hubbert adds: “Ruth clearly assumed that as a goel Boaz had a duty to marry
her. Though the OT nowhere explicitly attests such an obligation, there is good reason to list it among the broad duties
of a goel. Indeed, Boaz raised no objection to her assumption; on the contrary, he praised her for familial loyalty (v. 10).”
Linafelt poses a similar possibility:

               Ruth not only draws vocabulary from Boaz’s earlier speech, but from Naomi’s as well. Naomi
       informed her that Boaz was not only a “relative” of theirs, but a “redeemer” (goel) as well. There, Naomi
       left it unclear as to what she meant by the term goel. Ruth too leaves this unclear. Many interpreters
       have tried to link the duties of the goel to the duties of the levir, the one responsible for marrying a dead
       brother’s widow in order to continue the family line (see Deut 25:5). The institutions of the redemption and
       levitate [sic.] marriage are never elsewhere linked in the Bible, however, and if they are linked here it is a
       linkage proposed by Ruth herself and not by social custom or legislation. And the fact that Ruth and Naomi
       have to resort to a nighttime seduction to convince Boaz to marry Ruth indicates that there is no expectation
       that he will do so as a part of his duties as a goel. The question remains as to why Ruth links the two
       institutions here. It is possible that she does so by mistake, being a Moabite and not being fully aware
       of what being a goel entailed but recognizing that Naomi thought it would offer them some assistance.
       Or it is possible that she links them intentionally, using the notion of “redemption” in its larger sense and
       thereby challenging Boaz to do more than the law required or was expected by him. Moreover, by linking
       their relationship with the institution of the goel, Ruth has given Boaz the “cloak” he needs to pursue his
       interest in this Moabite woman and still maintain his public reputation. (BO, 56.)

        In accord with such comments, my working theory is that, as a Jewess, Naomi knew far more about the situation
than did Ruth, who was a Moabitess. Naomi did not fill Ruth in on all the familial and legal details. Naomi was the one
who implicitly linked the two institutions. Naomi did not lie about the details. She just took the attitude: “Ask me no
questions, and I’ll tell you no lies.”153 Deffinbaugh will use this type of argument to defend Esther—to a limited extent.
I will use it to defend Naomi—to a point. Naomi knew that Boaz was not the nearest goel, and she knew that Boaz was
not legally bound to marry Ruth. But Naomi left out these details in instructing Ruth to perform oral sex on Boaz as a
precursor to full marriage.
        Naomi simply could have given the impression to Ruth that if she were orally to capitulate to Boaz in the manner
that she was prescribing, then—given the broad goel legalities and the moral character of Boaz—Boaz certainly would
consider Ruth’s actions virtuous and virtually tantamount to a betrothal. Naomi could have painted the goel and levir
legalities in broad strokes without going too far into the specifics, letting Ruth draw her own conclusions. Thus, knowing
more fully the specifics of the situation, Naomi told Ruth to do just as Boaz instructed afterwards. So when Ruth
performed oral sex on Boaz as instructed, she thought that, despite the apparent socially scandalous nature of the

maneuver, she was acting in a legally permissible and morally binding way under the Jewish goel-levir arrangement and

        In requesting that Boaz marry her afterwards, though, Ruth was a little more aggressive than Naomi instructed.
The reason Ruth went beyond Naomi’s directives, however, in requesting that Boaz marry her, was because, in Ruth’s
