say that Boaz disapproved of Naomi’s maneuver. Indeed, he probably considered it a brilliant way to allow him a recourse
to marry this Moabitess with public approval.
        As to Ruth’s perception, imagine a society in which the law is such that if a woman performs fellation upon a man
who has expressed sexual interest in her, then they are considered betrothed, and thus legally married, as a result of the
fellation, even though the full sexual consummation is to await the public marriage ceremony. Would a woman who
performs fellation in that situation be guilty of premarital sex? No. The fellation would constitute a legally binding
marriage. To Ruth’s knowledge, she was in such a culture and circumstance.
        Indeed, Chitwood speculates that the culture at that time had gone beyond the Mosaic law to merge the two
requests into one:

                Ruth’s actions had their basis in the Mosaic Law, and they had to do with two things — a request
         for both redemption and marriage (cf. Deut. 25:5, 6; 27:20; Ezek. 16:8). And Boaz, seeing that which Ruth
         had done, would understand her actions in this respect.
                Redemption and marriage are not linked in this manner in the Mosaic Law; but over time, as seen
         in the Book of Ruth, they had evidently become closely associated with one another in Jewish life in
         instances of the nature seen in Ruth’s life. It is evident from the context (particularly from chapter four)
         that the complete request, seen through Ruth’s actions, clearly involved both.154 (Emphasis his.)

        Somebody, during the time of the judges, combined these two institutions into one. Whether it was the culture,
Naomi, or Ruth who combined these two institutions is subject to debate. My theory is that it was Naomi acting within
that culture and that she was also the mastermind who suggested the fellation as a means to facilitate the dualistic
modification. What was for Naomi a lesser-of-two-evils modification was for Ruth a greater-good submission. Ruth was
not privy to the finer details of Naomi’s calculations. Similarly, in Rom 14:22-23, we find that sometimes a particular
action may be sinful for one believer (who acts in doubt) but not for another believer (who acts in faith). Whatever degree
of doubts Naomi may have had about the legality and morality of her plan, she did not pass any of those doubts or details
along to Ruth. Thus, in God’s providence, Ruth was able to act in good faith. She did so sinlessly. Whatever misgivings
were involved were born exclusively by Naomi.
        This theory leads to the hypothesis that the circumstances were such that Ruth’s actions, which normally would
have been prohibited, were not only permissible but commendable. One may recall that God told Abraham to sacrifice
his son (Gen 22:2). Normally, such an action would have been strictly prohibited. Why would God command Abraham
to do something that otherwise would be wrong and that put Abraham in such a moral dilemma? Typology provides at
least a partial answer. Abraham’s action typologically foreshadowed the sacrifice that God would make in sacrificing His
Son. One may posit that typology also plays a significant factor in the suspension of the moral inhibitions that normally
would have been associated with Ruth’s action.
        Chitwood focuses on the typology concerning Ruth without going into the complexity of the implicit sexuality.
Going back to the original sexual design of Adam and Eve, though, he properly understands Boaz and Ruth to typify
Christ and His Bride:

               Since the woman was formed from a part of the man’s very being, the man, apart from the woman,
         was incomplete. But, once God had formed the woman from the man’s rib and had presented that which

       The sexuality of the original model requires that Christ rule with His Bride. He cannot rule without her. Chitwood’s
argument to that effect is fine insofar as it goes. Corporately, Ruth necessarily represents overcomers during the church
age. This aspect of his assessment is accurate. What Chitwood fails to consider, however, is that the same argument
would apply to male and female overcomers. Original design requires that male and female overcomers rule in
conjunction with one another in sexual union as one complete person on the throne. Ruth not only typifies all church-age
overcomers in conjunction with Christ; she also typifies female overcomers in conjunction with male overcomers.
Correspondingly, at one level Boaz typifies Christ; at another level Boaz typifies male overcomers. The typology thus
leads one to suspect that a female overcomer will overcome her male soulmate sexually and encompass him aggressively.

                                                       Esther
       Admittedly, this conclusion will be hard for many to swallow. But the typological parallels make it reasonable.
Consider Esther, for example, and her uncle Mordecai. As already mentioned, Deffinbaugh takes a dim view of these
biblical characters:

               There is nothing pious about Mordecai’s attitudes and actions. Neither he nor Esther are model
       saints. They are much more like Jonah than like Daniel. God does not spare His people because of Mordecai
       or Esther’s faith or faithfulness. He does so in spite of their willfulness and sin. To sanctify the actions of
       Mordecai and Esther, we must distort the text....
               She has become the queen of Persia on false pretenses. I do not think she lied; she seems rather to
       have taken the position, “Ask me no questions, and I’ll tell you no lies.” The king did not ask, as he surely
       should have (any husband would want to know who his wife’s relatives are), and she did not tell. Had the
       king known that Esther was a Jew, and that Haman’s proposed action was against all Jews, he surely would
       have done otherwise....
               But my focus is on Mordecai. I am especially interested in him because he seems to be the central
       figure of the entire Book of Esther. The book might be more properly called the Book of Mordecai: he is
       the one who seems to enter her in the contest for queen; he instructs her to keep her identity a secret; he
       still exercised authority over her rather than her husband, the king. But most of all, Mordecai brought the
       entire Jewish race into grave danger because of his stubborn pride and rebellion [in refusing to bow to
       Haman]—not because of his righteousness.156

Counter wise, I am inclined to cut Mordecai and Esther some slack, just as I would Naomi and Ruth. I believe God was
providentially at work in their actions. Geisler uses providential arrangement to justify Esther’s actions:

      ESTHER 2: 1-18 — How could Esther participate in a pagan beauty contest?
      PROBLEM: It is evident that Esther was selected by God as His instrument to deliver Israel from evil at
              the appointed time (Esther 4:14). However, as a devout Jew, how could Esther take part in a pagan
              pageant and then become part of the harem of King Xerxes?
      SOLUTION: First, it is not clear that Esther had a choice as far as being part of the display of beautiful
              women before the king. According to Esther 2:8, Esther was “taken to the king’s palace.” This seems
              to imply that Esther had no choice in the matter, but was drafted into the service of the king.
      Second, it is not clear that participants in the pageant had to do anything explicitly immoral to be in the
              contest. Knowing Esther’s character, we can be sure she would have refused to do anything contrary
              to God’s law.
      Finally, once she had been chosen by the king, she was compelled to belong to his court. It was the
              providence of God that brought Esther to this place at precisely the appropriate moment.

What did it mean for Esther to make herself totally available? Dennis provides a more through explanation:

              During the feast, Ahasuerus decided to send for his queen, Vashti, to join the party “and immodestly
      display herself.” The Scriptures do not say to what extent this would go, however, it was a “gross breach
      of Persian etiquette.” Vashti refused the king’s command. He was embarrassed in front of his friends by
      her disobedience and he became livid with anger. The result was that Vashti lost her crown and the king
      decreed that her royal throne was to go to another.
              It was a short time after this event that Ahasuerus went off to war against the Greeks. He not only
      lost a queen, but he also lost his battle with the Greeks. When Ahasuerus returned home (this was two years
      after Vashti had been banished), he offered a reward to the advisor who could come up with a scheme to
      allow him to indulge his sensuality. It was in this context that the selection of the new queen was to be
      decided.
              It was decreed that all of the beautiful young virgins in the kingdom would be summoned to the
      king’s palace in order for him to select his new queen. For one year they were to go through preparation
      for presentation to the king. Each young woman was to have one night with the king. The one he found
      most beautiful and desirable, the one who pleased him most, was to become his queen.

      Esther favor with Hegai, the royal keeper of the women. We can already see what kind of young woman

Even if oral sex was not involved, one would still not want to use this text as providing the prudent recourse for dating
or finding a husband, as Rochford explains:

              This isn’t good wisdom for dating. Not everything in the Bible that is described is
       necessarily prescribed. Not everything that the Bible contains is necessarily condoned. Naomi is a bitter,

Not only Naomi but also Ruth, living in the time of the Judges, did what was right in their own eyes, according to
Jdg 21:25. They were doing the best they could in time and circumstances in which they lived. Therefore, when Ruth
uncovered Boaz’s feet, which would have been the lower half of his body so as to expose his genitals, it stands to reason
that, when she then laid at his exposed genitals, she did what was right in her own eyes, not only in exposing him but in
everything she did afterwards to persuade him to marry her, and that everything probably included fellation.

                                                   Spread the Male Skirt
        Contextual indications make this understanding of feet in Ruth 3:4-8,14 highly probable, even more so when some
additional sexual euphemisms from the context are explained. After Boaz is aroused by finding a woman lying down at
his feet (i.e., his naked lower half), she asks him to spread his skirt over her (Ruth 3:9). He responds by telling her that
he will do everything he can to marry her and instructs her to “lie down until morning” (Ruth 3:13). After securing this
promise of marriage from him, “she lay at his feet until morning” (Ruth 3:14). Aaron explains this euphemism regarding
the covering: “In the marriage act, with the woman on her back, the man would open her robe—‘uncover her nakedness’
(Leviticus 18:7)—and open his robe to spread it over her. These actions provided the basis for the euphemistic way of
speaking: ‘I spread my skirt over thee’ (Ruth 3:9; Ezekiel 16:8).”160 Ruth invited Boaz to take her sexually in a manner
associated with vaginal intercourse and marriage. But he responded that he was not yet able to marry her legally until he
deals with her nearest kinsman. Therefore, instead of covering her, that is, instead of entering her vaginally, he instructs
her to continue to lie down until morning, and she continues to lie at his feet. Apparently, rather than enter her vaginally,
he instructs her to continue doing what she was doing orally, euphemistically stated as lying at his feet until morning.
        In summary, Ruth is (1) instructed by Naomi to perform this action on Boaz’s feet in stealth (2) during the middle
of the night (3) while he is incapacitated. After successfully arousing him via his feet, (4) Ruth invites him to enter her
vaginally, but (5) Boaz instructs her to continue what she was doing at his feet until morning instead, and (6) he
facilitates her leaving secretly in the morning, (7) with a contingent promise of marriage. Understandably, many readers
believe that this encounter is very sexual and that reference to feet is being used euphemistically.

                                                     Double Meanings
        In his attempt at thoroughness, EW shows a propensity to overstate his argument at times, so in the ellipsis above
I have removed the part of his argument regarding misthos (Gr., reward) that he derives from Lev 19:12-13, which he
interprets as dealing with “sex as the daily wage of marriage.”164 Notwithstanding, his article is easily available online
and may be consulted at length, and I appreciate the title of his article: “The Misthos and Dunamis of Ruth.” The passage
in Ruth 2:12, which EW quotes above, is where Boaz tells Ruth, “May the Lord reward your work, and a full reward
[misthos] become yours by the Lord, from whom you came to trust for refuge under His skirt” (TM). The Hebrew word
for skirt (kanaph) in this verse is almost always translated as wings in this verse. In Hebrew it denotes extremities. As it
pertains to birds, it would refer to the wings of the bird. As it pertains to garments, it would refer to the skirts of one’s
garment. As a euphemism for a man or the Lord spreading his/His extremity over a woman, it refers to his/His penis, in
taking the woman as his/His wife. This is how it is used of Boaz in the only other occasion it is used in the book of Ruth,
that is, in Ruth 3:9. Kanaph is used explicitly of the Lord in this capacity in Eze 16:8: “‘Then I passed by you and saw
you, and behold, you were at the time for love; so I spread My skirt over you and covered your nakedness. I also swore
to you and entered into a covenant with you so that you became Mine,’ declares the Lord God.”165 Here, the Lord uses
sexual imagery to describe His metaphorically taking Jerusalem as His wife. In the context of Ruth 2:12, Boaz is
expressing an obvious interest in Ruth, a sexual interest is reasonably supposed. Indeed, given the broader context, it
would seem that in 2:12 Boaz is using sexually suggestive language to imply that having a male skirt placed over her
sexually could be her reward for her work. As is noted by commentators, the repeated use of this very word in a similar
expression in both Ruth 2:12 and 3:9 is no accident!

        Ruth 3:9 is rendered variously by the translators as some form of: spread your skirt over (ASV, DBY, ERV, JPS,

spread the wings of your garment over (GNV), spread the corner of your garment over (GWN, NIV), spread the corner
of your cloak over (NAB), spread your covering over (NAS), spread the corner of your covering over (NLT).
        The gist is clear. She is inviting him to spread the skirt of his robe over her and take her as his wife in doing so,
and thus become her husband. Only a couple of translations shy away from this obvious meaning and instead picture her
as asking him to be her protective bird by spreading his wing over her. Granted, some passages use kanaph metaphorically
to speak of the Lord as a bird spreading out His protective wings over them (Ps 36:7; 57:1; 61:4, cp. Mt 23:37; Lk 13:24).
However, to picture Boaz as a protective bird in Ruth 3:9 is a birdbrain sanitation of the text, an attempt to sterilize the
text of its sexual connotations, which are apparent to practically all translators and many commentators.
        Conversely, in Ruth 2:12, which is the only other occurrence of kanaph in the book of Ruth, almost every
translation renders Ruth seeking refuge under God’s wings for refuge/shelter/protection. None of the translations suggest
a connection pertaining to the skirt/cloak/garment/covering in relation to Ruth 3:9, though the same word is used and
similar imagery! They all obscure the sexual connection. In doing so, they share part of the blame for those who villainize
Ruth and wrongly make her out to be a gold digger. What all such accusations against Ruth miss, due in part to misleading

       No one listening to this conversation would have been able to charge Boaz with doing or saying anything improper,
of course. Obviously, he is very interested in this young woman. Even so, he does nothing overt in expressing his sexual
interest.168 Moreover, his reference to her seeking refuge under the Lord’s kanaph could simply mean to find protection
under the Lord’s wings, using the imagery of a protective bird. On the other hand, in a context suggesting a sexual interest,
being under a male kanaph would refer to being under his skirt as his wife. Boaz’s apparent sexual interest in Ruth would
suggest the latter understanding. Yet his statement is couched in such a way so as not to be lewdly associated with his
crotch. Boaz has coded this couched expression with a double meaning, wishfully offering his own skirts as the Lord’s
wings. In a modest manner, Boaz is offering himself to her, to be the Lord’s means of blessing her, to be the Lord’s
instrument in fully rewarding her work. Boaz insinuates that the Lord’s full reward to her could encompass his own
extremities (skirt/penis). Ruth could well wonder if he is offering her misthological sex, a sexual relationship with him
in marriage as part of her full reward.
       Although Linafelt does not fully explore the double meaning intended by Boaz in v. 12, he does discuss it
throughout the context and implicitly acknowledges it even here, describing the double meaning perceived and conveyed
by Ruth:

                Ruth, by means of a pun on Boaz’s pious words, places the focus squarely back on him [by calling
         him her lord]. And while Ruth’s statement that he has “comforted” her and “spoken to her heart” may be
         read (or heard by those round about within the story) as an innocuous statement of Boaz’s altruism (thus
         the NRSV’s “spoken kindly”), it may also be Ruth’s tacit indication that she knows when someone is
         trying to sweet-talk her. While the idiom of speaking to someone’s heart occurs only nine times in the
         Bible, fully one-third of those occurrences (Gen 34:3; Judg 19:3; and Hos 2:16) clearly have the meaning
         “to woo” or “to entice” a woman.
                Ruth carries the potential double meanings through to her final statement of their first
         exchange....The term she uses to refer to herself, shiphchah, does indeed connote the lowest rung of the
         social world of servants and slaves and is associated with the most menial duties. Later, in 3:9, she refers
         to herself as an amah, a word indicating a servant of a bit higher status and more importantly one who had
         the prospect of marrying into the family for which she labored....But in keeping with the tendency of Ruth’s
         speech to have one meaning for the listeners in the field and another for Boaz and/or the attentive reader....
                ....Ruth seems to be drawing attention to his thinly disguised interest in her.

        Fewell and Gunn do well in their analysis, but they fall short of complete consistency when they fail to perceive
the sexual desire in Boaz’s original statement regarding Yahweh’s wing in Ruth 2:12. While struggling with his sexual
desires during the course of what he was saying, it is reasonable to propose that, at the very least, he made some Freudian
slips indicating his sexual desire even in this statement, just as he did in other statements within that original discourse,
as Fewell and Gunn acknowledge: “His immediate and abundant concern for her welfare is itself most touching if not,
indeed, just a touch surprising. We might be forgiven if we begin to wonder whether his solicitousness in the matter of
touching is to be construed, to put it anachronistically, as a classic case of a Freudian slip” (p. 85). Whether intentionally
or not, his peculiar remark about God’s cloak caused Ruth to think of finding protection beneath the lower part of Boaz’s
cloak, as Fewell and Gunn vividly portray. Plus, they acknowledge that “she hoped to heaven she had read right the looks
he had given her out in the field. Surely he desired more than just a night with her” (p. 53). She had sought to accurately
interpret Boaz’s actions and words and the way he looked at her. Had she misunderstood his intentions? Not at all. She
had correctly interpreted his words, actions, and looks at her as conveying his desire to have her for his wife, not merely
have a one-night stand. In his wishful thinking that he could take Ruth under his wings/skirt as his wife, he had
pronounced a blessing, hoping that she would find what she needed under Yahweh’s wings/skirt. Boaz could not take
Ruth as his wife, so the best he could do, in his own mind at that time, was wishfully offer Yahweh’s skirt as a surrogate
for his own. He was trapped by his own moral character and honor from doing anything more. To take this Moabitess as
his wife would be socially scandalous. So Boaz was resolved not to act upon his feelings. He would not do anything
scandalous. Sexually, he could do nothing more than offer the Lord’s kanaph as his own in an act of wishful thinking.
Naomi was astute to perceive both his desire and dilemma, as Fewell and Gunn convey through their portrayal of Naomi’s
thoughts:

               It really was a shame that she [Ruth] was a Moabite, though. If she’d been an Israelite, she might
       have received a marriage proposal by now from some eligible bachelor or widower—like the man Boaz for
       instance.
               Judging from the amount of grain Ruth brought home every day, Naomi suspected that the man Boaz
       rather liked her daughter-in-law. She knew, however, that a man of his standing wasn’t likely to risk his

        With the aid of Naomi, Ruth not only correctly deciphers the double meaning of Boaz’s coded message but takes
the corresponding action. Fewell and Gunn acknowledge that other parts of Boaz’s speaking to Ruth are coded: “What
we must notice is that just as Ruth never explicitly asks for marriage, neither does the cautious Boaz explicitly promise
it. Both the asking and the answering are in code” (p. 90). Why not perceive that this part about God’s skirt in Ruth 2:12
was coded as well?

means for an informal betrothal and, with Naomi’s advice, she does so. She removes Boaz’s skirt from him sexually,
during the middle of the night, in order to secure from him a promise to cover her with his skirt in marriage. In the end,
her oral fellation is rewarded with a marital relation. Contrary to Linafelt, I pose that her resolve was not to take a gamble
on Boaz’s kanaph instead of waiting around for the Lord. Rather, she resolved to act in faith, trusting the Lord that the

act and Boaz the means by which to escape his trap so that he could take Ruth as his wife. Similarly, the purpose of my
synthesis is to give believers the means by which to escape the trap of thinking that the resurrection spells the death of
sexual fulfillment. The purpose of the resurrection is to destroy death, not kill sex. Death dies at the resurrection, not sex.
Whereas Boaz had given up all hope for sexual fulfillment, Ruth resurrected those hopes and gave him the courage to
take the appropriate action. May those believers who are encouraged by the present book find the courage to encourage
other believers with hope of sexual fulfilment in the resurrection as well.

Oral Sex in Song of Solomon

                                                            SSol 7:9
        According to EW, SSol 7:9 alludes to Ruth 3:5-7, where Solomon says that his skilled female fellatioist is able to
do the same thing that Ruth did: “And the roof of your mouth is like the best wine. It goes down smoothly for my beloved,
gliding gently over lips and teeth” (TM1). “To what does ‘it’ refer?” Joseph Dillow asks regarding 7:9b. He correctly
answers that it refers “back to the ‘wine,’” but then he equates this wine generically with “high sexual pleasure.” Actually,
the text is much more explicit: The “it” refers to the “wine,” and the “wine” refers to “her mouth.” After all, regarding
7:9a, Dillow acknowledges the obvious: “Her mouth is ‘like the best wine.” Longman says that it refers to her palate, her
inner mouth (Song, NICOT). A French kiss is one possibility. The other would be fellation. Read in conjunction with the
lips and teeth, the picture is that of the roof of her mouth flowing down gently over my beloved like wine, so that her lips
and teeth are pictured as part of this flowing wine. This is the source of this great pleasure. Her lips, teeth, and the inner
roof of her mouth are the wine flowing over her beloved. Fellation seems the most reasonable understanding. If the verse
is translated and understood in this manner, then in v. 9 my beloved would be a euphemism for her lover’s penis. Just as
today the male’s psyche is recognized by fellatioists to be so wrapped up with his penis that his penis can be treated as a
miniaturization of himself, an extension of who he really is, so it is in this verse and perhaps the following one: “I am my
beloved’s, and his desire is for me” (SSol 7:10). In belonging to her beloved’s penis, she belongs to her beloved. And in
causing his penis to desire her, she causes her beloved to desire her. As Dillow correctly surmises, “She is so focused on
him that she omits her possession of him. She is reveling in her ‘woman power’—her ability to satisfy her man
physically.”169
        Then again, I might be guilty of introducing a false dichotomy between fellation and deep kissing. Fellation is a
form of deep kissing. Indeed, although Dawson has multiple discussions about deep kissing in her commentary of the
Song of Solomon and first discusses kissing in relation to SSol 7:9, she then moves on to an interesting section in her
discussion of this verse entitled, “What About Oral Sex or Blow Jobs?” She proceeds to explain why blow jobs are not
forbidden by Scripture. For instance, Lev 18:22 and 20:13 forbid a male to lie with male as one lies with a male. What
makes this sexual activity unnatural is a male lying with a male. This would be true of any sexual activity between males,
such as kissing. Oral sex is not singled out. For a male to kiss another male in a sexual manner would be unnatural, and
thus a homosexual action, because the heterosexual-versus-homosexual nature of the action is determined by who does
it, not by what is done. Someone might object that a penis is not designed to be placed in the mouth and thus try to use
this as argument against regarding heterosexual fellation as natural. The shortsighted nature of this rejoinder can be easily
demonstrated by pointing out that such a narrowmindedness would have us believe that mouths are designed for eating
not for kissing, and most certainly not for deep kissing, so kissing is a homosexual act. The ludicrous nature of such an
argument is self-apparent. Our mouths, although designed for eating as their primary function, are also intended by our
Designer to be adapted to kissing as an appropriate form of oral sex between a man and woman. We see this repeatedly
in the Song of Solomon. Kissing is only one form of appropriate oral sex, however; a blow job would be another equally
valid form of oral sex. Indeed, one might well argue that both forms of oral sex—osculation and fellation—are not only
descriptive between heterosexual soulmates within the Song but also prescriptive. Our Creator seems to commend both
forms of oral sex within the Song, not only as being appropriate but also as being part of the behavior He enjoins between
male and female lovers.

                                                   Pleasure versus Reproduction
        Intended for Pleasure by Ed and Gaye Wheat is a classic book for Christian marital counseling. The basic thesis
of that book is that God designed sex to be pleasurable. Surprisingly, some Christians find it next to impossible to believe
that God designed sex to be fun. Sex is indeed intended for pleasure, not merely for reproduction! Song of Solomon is
proof—God’s thesis if you will—written in the form of exotic poetry, proving that He did not intend to limit sex to
reproduction. In the opening pages of his commentary on Song of Solomon, Dillow makes the same point: “Some writers
seem hesitant to believe sex was intended by God for any purpose other than procreation. Therefore, they refuse to accept
a normal interpretation of the book.” So they allegorize the book to cover up its obvious sexual meaning, but the book
“is simply a picture of idealized married love as God intended it.”182 Dillow’s statement may or may not need amending,
depending on how one defines being married. Given Dillow’s definition of being married, I can agree with his statement.
He defines marriage as a commitment (1) to leave one’s parents and (2) cleave to one mate for life, (3) consummated by
sexual intercourse, and (4) attested publicly by the legal authorities (pp. 69-70). Unwittingly, perhaps, he left out any
requirement about intending to procreate and raise a family in this definition of marriage. Yet this latter aspect seems to
be a basic component of original design for biblical marriage (Gen 1:28).
        On the other hand, if the Song of Solomon is about sexual love devoid of any discussion of reproduction, perhaps
it was not on accident that Dillow left procreation out of his definition. My point is that, given the absence of procreation
in the Song, one might contend that the Song pictures idealized sexual love, not necessarily marital love, when marital
love is defined more broadly in terms of being joined together in the first four senses described by Dillow for the fifth
reason—reproduction. When Jesus said that those raised from the dead do not marry (Mt 22:30; Mk 12:25; Lk 20:35),
He was speaking of marriage in the broad sense, which included the fifth element, being joined together sexually for the
purpose of reproduction. Indeed, the context of Jesus’ statement is focused on this fifth aspect. But if marriage is defined
more narrowly, as the sexual union of a man and woman for life in accordance with the laws of the land, then one may
postulate that the Song of Solomon is describing heavenly sex. Earthly sex should be in accordance with the laws of this
earthly land. Heavenly sex will be in accordance with the laws of that heavenly land. What we experience of this sexual
union here on Earth is but a foretaste of what is potentially available in Heaven, idealized in the Song because this
idealization of the sexual union can only be realized in Heaven.
        Granted, the historical occasion that served as the inspiration for this idealized sexual experience may have been
Shulamith’s wedding night with Solomon, but this is an inference that Dillow is making, which is by no means an overt
declaration by the text. These lovers are experiencing a degree of sexual intimacy that has been idealized so as to not tie
it so closely with its historical reality that it could not prefigure a heavenly realization. Just as the fall of Satan is pictured
by intertwining it with an earthly king, the king of Tyre in Eze 28:1-19, so the Song prefigures heavenly sex by
intertwining it with an earthly king, the king of Israel, Solomon, in the Song of Solomon.
        In any case, even if none of the passages of the Song were interpreted as advocating oral sex, it is still apparent
that the book is intended to showcase the pleasures of sex and not limit that sexual pleasure to reproduction. In fact, the
first part of the Song of Solomon presents the ideal sexual relationship between a man and women.183 Now, certainly,
given the broader biblical context, we are to understand that sexual exclusivity within the context of marriage is inferred,
at least as this sexual pleasure applies to us currently in our earthly relationships, and this association with marriage has
a link with reproduction in the broader biblical landscape. Notwithstanding, the focus of the Song is exclusively on sexual
pleasure, not on sexual reproduction. God enjoins these lovers to enjoy each other sexually for the pure pleasure of doing
so. He designed them to enjoy sex and enjoys their enjoying it. Sexual pleasure is not limited to, nor even linked with,
sexual reproduction within the covers of the Song. The allusions to oral sex within the Song only reinforce this basic
thesis: God never intended for sexual pleasure to be limited to sexual reproduction. That is a broad statement regarding
anticipated sexual pleasure in the eternal state. In science, though, one prefers a theory that can make precise, predictive
claims. I will venture four interrelated predictions regarding fellation after discussing the predictive value of typology.

book, a series of seven reflections portray the reality of married love” (Dillow, Solomon, 98). My postulation is that the
first half of the Song uses this youthful, romantic love to foreshadow heavenly love—love between heavenly soulmates—
not married love in the sense of love experienced here on Earth in which problems require that adjustments be made. The
idealized love of the first section serves a dual purpose to picture both (1) the foundation for marital love, and (2) the
foreshadowing of heavenly love. She is referred to as “O Shulamite” (SSol 6:13). “Without doubt the word is the feminine
form of ‘Solomon.’ It suggests that she is the ‘other part of’ Solomon. She is one flesh with him” (Ibid., 125). Shulamith
is the idealized sexual counterpart of Solomon. She serves as the aggressive typological model for the eschatological
realization anticipated in Jer 31:22, where the woman will encompass the male both vaginally and orally.
Chapter 4. Secondary Biblical Confirmation                                                                          Page 105
                                                 Erotic Typological Prophecy
        God created us as male and female to enjoy each other sexually. Any attempt to limit this sexual enjoyment to
sexual reproduction fails biblical analysis. Ideally, we should enjoy our sexual relationships with our marriage partner
just as much as these ideal lovers do with each other. But since this sexual enjoyment is not confined to sexual
reproduction, we have every reason to suspect that this ideal will be realized in the eternal state. My anticipation is that
Son of Solomon is not only erotic poetry but also erotic prophecy. It describes what sex will look like between heavenly
lovers in their resurrected bodies when the ideal becomes real, when the ideal is realized in the eschatological future.
This deduction is thus based on several inferences.
        The Song of Solomon does not limit sexual pleasure to sexual reproduction. Far from it! There is no association
with marriage, at least not in the sense of producing offspring and raising a family, even though he calls her his bride. I
would theorize that calling her his sister, his bride (SSol 4:9) would be compatible with my soulmate hypothesis. God
did not intend for sexual pleasure to be limited to purpose of reproduction for me and my earthly bride. Nevertheless, He
does intend for us to reproduce and raise a family as part of our earthly sexual relationship. Even so, when we are reunited
in Heaven, we will still be male and female and thus still be designed by God to experience sexual pleasure, though in
that heavenly context we are to experience that sexual pleasure apart from sexual reproduction, as is the case in Song of
Solomon. My earthly bride will become my heavenly bride when we are joined together in Heaven. She will be my bride
(in the sense of being recently enjoined sexually and legally) since our sexual union in Heaven will be a new union. We
will not be newlyweds, to be sure; we will not be wed; she will not be my bride in that matrimonial sense. We will not
be married; we will not be sexually enjoined for the dual purposes of (1) enjoying sex and (2) procreating. Sexual
reproduction will not be part of the equation. Instead, she will be my bride in a new sense and capacity in which we
mutually enjoy sexual pleasure as a form of living water apart from any thoughts of sexual reproduction, much like we
find in the Song of Solomon.184 Oral sex is only the icing on the cake, so to speak, in demonstrating that God intends for
us to be able to enjoy sex without necessarily linking it to reproduction. The multiple allusions to oral sex in the Song of
Solomon are proof that God does not intend to limit sexual pleasure to sexual reproduction. Oral sex has nothing to do
with reproduction! Rather, God intends for sexual pleasure to be a normal part of the male-female experience, even apart
from sexual reproduction. In a context highly suggestive of oral sex (SSol 4:16-5:1a), God tells these lovers to eat and
drink deeply (SSol 5:1b).185 Oral sex in the Song of Solomon would therefore foreshadow the heaven reality.
        Dillow hypothesizes that the historical background for the Song of Solomon is Shulamith’s wedding night with
Solomon. I am adopting his perspective, but proving it would be difficult because the Song has lifted sex above its
historical context to provide an idealized picture of sexual pleasure between the king and his queen.186 Shulamith’s name
is a feminized form of Solomon. So this is not her real name. Even her name has been idealized, and thus lifted above its
historical context, to serve a typological function. For such reasons, a variety of other interpretations have been provided
by others over the course of history for this Song. My hypothesis is that the Song has lifted sex above its historical context
to provide an exotic prophecy of what heavenly sex will look like among resurrected overcomers. Just as Melchizedek
may have been a historical person (such as Shem) who typifies Christ, so Shulamith is a historical figure who typifies a
resurrected overcomer having sex with her soulmate.
        One avenue of traditional Protestant interpretation is that Melchizedek was a historical person who serves as an
archetype of Christ. Literarily, rather than literally, he is “without father, without mother, without genealogy, having
neither beginning of days nor end of life,” and thus in terms of the literary record contained within Scripture, he is
topologically “made like the Son of God, he abides a priest perpetually” (Heb 7:3). In this case, what is not recorded is
just as important as what is recorded. His father and mother and genealogical records are purposely omitted from the
biblical record so that he might serve as a typological prototype. My hypothesis is that this is true of Shulamith as well.
(1) The absence of Shulamith’s historical name and (2) lack of any explicit limitation of her sexual experience to
marriage, (3) the complete lack of any association of her sexual experience with reproduction, and (4) the idealized focus
on sexual pleasure throughout the first section of the book are not by accident but rather are intended by God to signify
her typological function so that the recorded sexual aggressiveness on her part and the recorded strong emphasis on
sexual pleasure, especially of an oral nature, foreshadow the female encompassing the male in the resurrected state, as
anticipated in Jer 31:22. If my typological hypothesis is correct, and it certainly seems to be, then the Song of Solomon
is a conclusive typological confirmation of my thesis that overcomers will experience heavenly sex in the eternal state.
If that is the case, as seems to be the case, then the Song is a virtual slam dunk, hermeneutically speaking, for my thesis.

    The first section of the Song (i.e., 1:1-5:1) portrays “the ideal—the beauties of youthful and romantic love....the second

Page 106                                                                                         Mongamous Sex in Heaven!
        Overcomers will be kings and queens in the kingdom. Per Jesus, their sexual experience will have nothing to do
with marriage; their sexual identity will not be tied to sexual reproduction. Their sexual function will be exclusively for
intimate sexual pleasure in a sexually exclusive relationship of one man for one woman and, conversely, one woman for
one man. My typological hypothesis explains why the sexual pleasure within the Song is best understood in a context of
sexual exclusivity but is not linked, ball and chain, to earthly marriage. The only people for whom sex could be pictured
exclusively for pleasure with no tie to reproduction would be the resurrected kings and queens of the eternal state. All
other human sexual relationships—past, present, and future—are associated via the original biblical mandate with
reproduction, even though sex was never intended to be limited to reproduction. Since the sexual pleasure in the Song
transcends the biblical mandate to reproduce, even to the point that the Song leaves behind reproduction to focus
exclusively on sexual pleasure, it should be interpreted as an idealization that finds typological realization only in the
sexual experiences of resurrected overcomers.
        Given this typological association, a possible explanation may be suggested as to why the woman will encompass
the male in the heavenly state. This idealized woman makes a poetic claim that, on the face of it, does not seem to match
the physical reality: “Like an apple tree among the trees of the forest, so is my beloved among the young men. In his
shade I took great delight and sat down, and his fruit was sweet to my taste” (SSol 2:3). Is semen sweet? No. Even
though the taste of semen can be altered and sweetened to some extent by one’s diet, to describe semen as being sweet
like an apple is to take poetic license with the physical reality, so as to see it though the rose-tinted glass of romantic love
which finds the semen sweet psychologically. Perhaps that is all there is to it. But if my conjecture is correct, that the text
foreshadows a heavenly reality, then there is much more to the text than poetic license distorting the physical reality. My
theory is that in the resurrected state the masculine ejaculation will indeed be as sweet as apple juice to the feminine taste,
if not sweeter. Several lines of reasoning make this a reasonable conclusion.
        First, if the Song is foreshadowing the heavenly reality, then one would expect the reality to be greater than the
shadow. This is how prophetic foreshadowing works. Second, one would anticipate that heavenly sex would be better
than earthly sex, so one would expect heavenly fellatio to be better than earthy fellatio. So a sweeter taste is to be expected
in the heavenly state. This logical inference finds confirmation in the Song but could have been anticipated even apart
from the Song just by sheer logical deduction. Third, the sexual fluids of these lovers is described as living water in the
Song, and living water is sweet to the taste, as attested by NDEs. Thus one would anticipate that the male ejaculation, as
a form of living water, would be sweet to the taste. Fourth, the function of this male ejaculation will be changed from
procreation to recreation. One can make this deduction even apart from the Song. The Song is merely experiential data,
albeit expressed in erotic typological poetry, which confirms this deduction. As to pure logical deduction, when he
climaxes, the resurrected male will no longer ejaculate semen, which is seed for reproduction. Rather, he will ejaculate a
fluid that is intended to impart sexual pleasure for his soulmate. His ejaculation will no longer be designed for sexual
reproduction but for sexual pleasure. Hence, one would deduce that the taste of his ejaculation would be pleasurable.
        The four predictions above of what this oral sexual intimacy will look like in the eternal state are based on nothing
more than Scripture and logic. My next prediction, on the other hand, is an extrapolation that adds a bit of sanctified
imagination and mathematical calculation. I conjecture that the female vaginal fluid arising from her sexual arousal, and
described as living water and sweet to the smell, will indeed be sweet to both the taste and smell and also serve as an
aphrodisiac to her male lover—her heavenly soulmate—arousing his sexual desire for her, just as anticipated by the
biblical texts so describing it. Furthermore, his ejaculation, as living water, will not impart life (since it is no longer
semen) but rather enhance life, just as anticipated by biblical texts describing the more rewarding aspects of living
water.187 His ejaculation will be a type of ambrosia. Before giving the calculations for this predictive extrapolation,
however, a word needs to be said about the reasonableness of aphrodisiacal interpretations.

the contextual sexual imagery. The comments also include a couple of verses that use aphrodisiacs, such as SSol 2:5:
“Sustain me with raisin cakes, refresh me with apples, because I am lovesick” (SSol 2:5). As the article mentions, “Along
with apples, raisin cakes came to be viewed as an aphrodisiac.”188 Commentators provide more details. Dawson surmises
that the “aphrodisiac attributes of apples are well known. They increase libido and symbolize fertility in nature. They

       As already noted, Kreeft reminds us that all truth is God’s truth, and that we should use Scripture, logic, and our
imagination to formulate our theories. We must use our imagination if we are to formulate a theory as to how to properly
interpret this verse, and I am doing just that. Some, like Deffinbaugh, might question using the extrabiblical information,
like that provided by Pope, to aid in formulating one’s theories as to the probable meaning of the text. My contention is
that good science requires using all the relevant facts. Deffinbaugh likewise appeals to science, but his second premise
is questionable:

                  You might rightly ask why I hold confidently to my position, when others (some of whom are highly
         respected) see the text quite differently. It all comes down to one’s hermeneutics (the science of interpreting
         Scripture). I can boil the essence of my hermeneutics down to a couple of points. First, I believe that the
         text is to be understood as it appears. Second, I believe that the Scriptures provide me with all the supporting
         information I need to understand what I find in any biblical text. I do not believe that the interpretation of
         any text hangs upon information (alleged or true) that has been discovered outside the Bible. External
         information may supplement and illustrate biblical truth, but the interpretation of a biblical text does not
         hang on something outside of Scripture.

       Contrary to Deffinbaugh’s second premise, Geisler’s comments about hapax legomena would be sufficient to
demonstrate the fallacy of limiting our understanding to what is found in the biblical text. Indeed, Geisler’s extended
rebuttal to those who decry the use of extrabiblical material to aid in interpreting Scripture is worthy of note:

                In response, several important things should be observed. First, nowhere in the Bible does it spell
         out the law of noncontradiction, and yet all valid reasoning, including that about the Bible, is based on this
         law.
                Second, a commonly accepted principle of interpreting the Bible does depend on understanding
         things about the biblical language that are not explicitly taught anywhere in the Bible. For example, some
         words occur only once in the Bible (called hapax legomena). Thus, in figuring out the meaning of these
         words, it is necessary to understand how they were used in the language of the time outside the Bible. For
         example, the Greek for “daily” (epiousios) in the Lord’s Prayer (Matt. 6:11; Luke 11 :3) occurs only here
         in the New Testament. If it were not for extrabiblical sources, we would not know that it means the
         sustaining (bread) “necessary for existence.” Also, the Greek word apolytrosis, meaning “redemption”
         (Eph. 1:7), was used outside the Bible to mean “buy back from the marketplace,” which helps us to
         understand the significance of Christ’s buying sinners back from the marketplace of sin.
                Third, practices alluded to in the Bible—such as a “holy kiss” (I Thess. 5:26), women wearing a veil
         (1 Cor. 11), foot washing (John 13), reclining at a meal (rather than sitting in a chair; Luke 12:37)—are not
         explained in the Bible. Hence, our understanding of them is dependent on knowing the culture outside the
         Bible. This is true of numerous other customs.
                Fourth, it is fallacious to argue that all premises of a sound biblical argument must come from the
         Bible. God has two sources of revelation: general revelation in nature and special revelation in Scripture.189

       Using extrabiblical literature to help us understand biblical literature is biblical. NT writers use extrabiblical
sources, such as Epimenides (Tit 1:12) and Enoch (Jude 1:14), for example. Looking at how apples were used in the
culture at that time as aphrodisiacs is certainly appropriate to understand how they would have been regarded in this text.
Shulamith has just pictured her beloved as an apple tree with her sitting in the shade of this apple tree, where she is eating

two sources—God and Solomon—this would explain her plural injunction. This verse is as much a prayer to God as an

a natural interpretation so that God is understood as the one who will sustain the female lover’s sexual passion in the
eternal state by changing the composition and function of her male lover’s ejaculation so that it increases her sexual
desire and enhances her sexual response. If the Song of Solomon has any prophetic value, then this is a reasonable
expectation. After all, as noted by Pope, apples were used as an aphrodisiac to increase one’s sexual desire and ability so
as to make love repeatedly, even in a marathon copulation.
        Her sexual desire is so strong that it is like being sick with fever. Her sexual desire is fever pitch. If Solomon is to
sustain her with his apples, what would that mean in a context in which his apples are poetically referencing his genitals
and in which she is drinking his apple juice? The self-apparent deduction of the imagery is that she is performing fellation
to the point of drinking his ejaculation and wants the drinking of his ejaculation to act as a sexual stimulant. As she drinks
the juice from his apples, she is expressing a hopeful request that this will not be the end of the story on their wedding
night. She wants more than the oral satisfaction of drinking his ejaculation. She wants his ejaculation to act like well-
known aphrodisiacs: apples and raisin cakes. She is not satisfied with bringing him to orgasm but wants to be brought to
orgasm herself, as she proceeds to describe his fondling her in the next verse (SSol 2:6). She wants the sexual excitement
of drinking him to increase her desire as she responds to his fondling. Since their lovemaking does not end with her
fellation or with his manual stimulation of her vulva, a reasonable deduction is that she wants the orgasm that he has just
experienced from her oral stimulation, and which she is about to experience from his manual stimulation, not to be the
end of their festivities that night but only the beginning. She wants them to experience multiple orgasms during the course
of their lovemaking that night. She wants the marathon copulation read about in myths to be their reality. Granted, to
have seventy-seven or eighty-eight orgasms would be far beyond the realms of physical possibility, but for her and her
lover to each have several orgasms on their wedding night would not be beyond the realm of possibility. Evidently this
is her hope, as confirmed by the sexual actives that continue in the ensuing context (SSol 4:16-5:1).

        A stimulating kiss is much more likely the reference than a stimulating conversation in 4:11. The imagery of honey
and milk being under her tongue describes the aphrodisiacal nature of her open-mouth kiss; her deep kiss arouses him
sexually. Similarly, Dawson has a good discussion on the aphrodisiacal nature of the pomegranate in 4:13: “Researchers

testosterone level in both men and women. This helps preserve the health of their sexual organs and increases their

context is dealing with sexual pleasure, not sexual reproduction! The thoughts are of their mutual sexual arousal during
their wedding night, not of bearing children. Dillow correctly understands the aphrodisiacal nature of these other spices
and herbs as well: “When a woman is sexually aroused, there is faint and very stimulating odor associated with the

the most precious of aromatic herbs.”193 This context uses honey, milk, fruit, spices, and herbs as aphrodisiacs to describe
what her sexually aroused, feminine body produces to stimulate his passion.
        Although Dawson is normally an excellent resource in describing the aphrodisiacs within the Song, perhaps the
reason that Dillow is more perceptive to the aphrodisiacal nature of these spices at this particular juncture is because he
and Dawson take two different approaches to identifying the Shulamite’s lover in the Song. Dillow believes that Solomon
is the lover and that Solomon is, at times, described as a shepherd. Dawson believes that the shepherd, in contradiction
to Solomon, is the lover. The commentaries by both of these writers are excellent resources since they both agree on the
overall sexual nature of the Song, and both give excellent therapeutic interaction with this type of interpretation. For
instance, even though Dawson at times thinks that there is some anticipation in the book concerning future children, she
emphatically and correctly emphasizes that the Song describes sexual pleasure within marriage. For thesis of the present
book, it probably makes little difference as to whether Dillow is correct in associating the shepherd imagery with Solomon
or Dawson is correct in disassociating the supposed literal shepherd from Solomon. Nevertheless, for the sake of
expediency, the Dillowian approach has been adopted herein.
        That said, there is much to be said about the repeated discussion that Dawson gives to testosterone that is imparted
by the male to the female via deep kissing. The orally ingested testosterone acts like an aphrodisiac upon the female. In
fact, as Dawson documents, prostitutes typically avoid kissing in order to avoid the emotional bonding that takes place
in such action (KL 768). The injecting of testosterone into the female palate in the act of deep kissing may be “even more
effective than if he used a hypodermic needle to inject his drug of choice” (KL 759). There are several important points
to be gleaned from Dawson’s analysis of testosterone acting as an aphrodisiac in the act of deep kissing. First, this
aphrodisiac is produced naturally. Unlike the aphrodisiacs that come from spices or aromas foreign to the body, the male
lover’s body naturally produces this love drug. Second, this aphrodisiac is literal. Scientific evidence confirms the
aphrodisiacal properties of testosterone imparted via deep kissing. Third, this male hormone is shared with the female as
a sexual stimulant during sexual activity. In summary, God has designed the male body to produce testosterone to act
naturally as a chemical aphrodisiac produced by his body and sexually transmitted to his female soulmate. This being the
case, one is left to wonder if God might have similar designs in mind for the other fluids produced by the male and female
bodies when, after the resurrection, their bodies no longer produce these fluids for the purpose of procreation but
exclusively for the purpose of sexual pleasure. We will return to this conjecture in the discussion of ambrosia and nectar
after we survey some of the other aphrodisiacs described in the Song.

       SSol 5:1
        After being invited to enter her garden full of spices in SSol 4:12-16, the passage next describes her male lover
partaking of all her feminine aphrodisiacs, which are presented as three pairings of two each for a total of six (3 x 2 = 6):
“[1] I have gathered my myrrh along with my balsam. [2] I have eaten my honeycomb and my honey; [3] I have drunk
my wine and my milk” (SSol 5:1). When Dawson explains the male lover’s sexual response, Dawson appropriately
understands all these terms listed in this verse as describing aphrodisiacs: “Then six aphrodisiacs cement their emotional
love for each other” (KL 3369). Since in SSol 5:1 Shulamith’s lover is partaking of what her body is producing in

SSol 4:12-16, all the spices and herbs her body produced in SSol 4:13-14 should be understood as aphrodisiacs as well.
       As to aphrodisiacs 1 and 2 (myrrh and balsam), Dawson notes that this pairing is associated with olfaction: “A
wife radiating the smell of love, or myrrh, and a husband high on her balsam love to truly ravish each other” (KL 3417).

        Unfortunately, Dawson then allegorizes this second pairing to mean that “their lovemaking will never grow stale,
even as the events of life change their circumstances.” Given that Dawson correctly rejects allegorization of the Song as
being a castration of the text and given that Dawson properly interpreted aphrodisiacs 1 and 2 as dealing with the literal
sense of smell, a much more consistent interpretation would be to allow the text “to be understood as it appears” (to quote
Deffinbaugh) and thus take the second pairing literally as well. In the first pairing, her lover literally smells her. In the
second paring, he literally eats her. That is, he tastes her vaginal fluids as he performs cunnilingus.
        What about the third pairing, in which he drinks her wine and milk? It might simply be a continuation of the
description of cunnilingus: He drinks her vaginal fluids as he eats her honey. On the other hand, just a few verses earlier
he was describing her breasts: “Your two breasts are like two fawns, twins of a gazelle, which feed among the lilies”
(SSol 4:5). Garrett says that her lover coming into her garden and partaking of these six luxuries “imply that he has
partaken of her pleasures to the full” (NAC). Commenting similarly, Longman says, “He has possessed her completely,
a fitting image of sexual intercourse” (NICOT). These superficial summary statements, which are typical of
commentators, leave several questions unanswered.
        Why are these oral-genital sexual imageries used if vaginal intercourse is the only fitting image? One might
respond that oral-genital allusions are euphemisms to avoid vulgarity. Ok, but why suppose that oral sex is vulgar? Also,
what about her breasts? Describing her breasts, handling her breasts, and even sucking her breasts—in the poetic language
of this Song—are not considered vulgar by the biblical writer. Why think that describing oral sex with similar imagery
would be considered vulgar? If SSol 5:1 is her lover’s way of saying that he possessed her fully, that is, every part of her
in every way desired, then why think that her breasts are excluded and that the verse is limited to vaginal intercourse.
Obviously, limiting this verse to vaginal intercourse is a very short-sighted response. Surely, something among her
aphrodisiacal luxuries that he has partaken would refer to her breasts. He has already described the effect of her eyes
(4:9) and lips (v. 4:11) upon him. I would venture a tentative proposal that the third pairing in 5:1 refers to his sucking
her breasts, a proposition that even Garrett would allow in 8:2. After all, since sucking is associated with drinking, it
would make sense to associate this action in 5:1 and 8:2 with sucking her breasts, which her lover finds sexually
stimulating and thus describes it metaphorically as drinking an aphrodisiac. Granted, the verbs in 5:1 probably show a
“logical sequence” (Pope, ABC):

       1.   I have entered my garden, my sister, my bride
       2.   I have gathered my myrrh along with my balsam.
       3.   I have eaten my honeycomb and my honey;
       4.   I have drunk my wine and my milk.

He enters, gathers, eats, and drinks. The sequence of these four actions makes sense in terms of the poetic imagery of
coming into locked garden (cp. 4:12) to partake of its treasures. But the logical progression, used for poetic reasons, need
not be supposed to show temporal progression. A more likely temporal sequence would be that (#4) sucking her breasts
arouses her and him. Next, (#2) the smell of her arousal further arouses him as (#3) he performs cunnilingus. He finishes
by (#1) coming into her via vaginal intercourse. Accordingly, oral sex is performed on both her breasts and vagina,
which, in turn, become aphrodisiacs that increase his desire. This will be working theory adopted herein.

       SSol 7:2
       Other data in the Song would seem to confirm that oral sex is part of the imagery. SSol 7:2 is another verse thought
by some to describe cunnilingus: “Your navel is like a round goblet which never lacks mixed wine.” Pope (ABC) believes
that naval should be translated as vulva. Longman is open to that suggestion but gives additional argumentation for
simply taking the naval as a euphemism for vulva. He may be correct. In that case, naval is the proper translation, but
vulva is the proper interpretation. Poetically, Solomon is referring to her aroused vagina producing mixed wine that
Page 112                                                                                           Mongamous Sex in Heaven!
stimulates him as he drinks it—if one adopts the oral sex interpretation. Dillow insists that vulva is the correct translation
but thinks that vagina intercourse is alluded to and cites the mixing wine and milk in 5:1. One problem with this
interpretation is that 5:1 uses both terms as referring to her wine and milk. It is not as if Solomon is mixing the milk of
his semen with the wine of her vagina in 5:1. Plus, in 7:2 the mixed wine seems to be something he gets from her, not
something that he mixes for her. Additionally, the metaphor suggests something that one drinks, thus cunnilingus, not
vaginal intercourse. Pope is correct to reject the semen theory as having “no legitimation.” Alluding to her vaginal
moisture, love water (so Pope), as mixed wine is fitting with the immediate goblet imagery and need not distract from
my theory that drinking her wine and milk earlier was used as euphemism for sucking her breasts in conjunction with
eating her vaginal honey from her honeycomb. The imagery is fluid for the sake of the poetry. Nevertheless, in both
places, the wine is an oral aphrodisiac that stirs up his desire.

       SSol 8:2
        The next passage that alludes to aphrodisiacal oral sex is SSol 8:2: “I would give you spiced wine to drink from
the nectar [asis] of my pomegranates” (TM). Asis is normally translated as juice. It means sweet wine and is rendered
accordingly by NLT. Several translations opt for nectar (NET; NIV). Garret thinks that it may be “a euphemism for her
breasts” (NAC, p. 425, n. 182). Of course, pomegranates are an extremely well-known aphrodisiac. Garrett adds this
detail in WBC: “Keel ([1994] 263) illustrates a relief from the time of Ramses III in which nude women of the harem
give a man pomegranates and mandrakes, a fairly clear display of the sexual significance of these items.” Perhaps the
reason that Garrett thinks that pomegranates refer to her breasts rather than her genitals is that he believes the earlier part
of the verse refers to her genitals:

             The “house of my mother” occurs elsewhere in the Song only at 3:4. There, I suggested that the
       house of her mother and the chamber of the woman who conceived her can only be the womb. Here the
       meaning is even clearer. In Song 8:1-2 she self-evidently is taking him to a night of lovemaking, and no
       explanation for doing this in her mother’s literal house is satisfactory. The “mother’s house” is thus here a
       euphemism for the female genitals, and it is appropriate as a designation of the place of procreation. (WBC)

       The Shulamite is saying that she would bring him into her mother’s house and give him this spiced wine to drink
from the nectar of her pomegranates. If the reference to her mother’s house is a euphemism for her genitals, as WBC
poses, then this verse could very easily be referring to be given this spiced wine in her mother’s house and thus a reference
to oral sex, specifically in the form of cunnilingus. Indeed, the spiced wine here would seem to recall the mixed wine
from SSol 7:2, which was definitely related to her vulva rather than her breasts. In any event, I will allow Garret the
benefit of a doubt and take 8:2 as most likely, or at least most prominently, describing her breasts as the source of
aphrodisiacal nectar. The thought being that, in addition to being brought into her genitals, he will be given sucker from
her breasts, which is described as nectar.194

                                                Theoretical Levels of Orgasm
       Earlier I referred to my fifth predictive theory but postponed the calculations until we discussed prophetic typology
and the reasonableness of aphrodisiacal interpretations. Having now done so, I will proceed with highly conjectural
computations. As noted previously, my basic premise for this projection is that the female vaginal love water—biblically
described as arising from her sexual arousal and as living water that is sweet to the smell and taste—will literally be
sweet to the taste and smell in the eschatological future and serve as an aphrodisiac to her heavenly soulmate, thereby
arousing his sexual desire for her, just as anticipated by the biblical texts so describing it. Furthermore, his ejaculation,
although living water, will not impart life (since it is no longer semen) but rather, like hers, enhance life, just as anticipated
by biblical texts describing the more rewarding aspects of living water.195 His ejaculation will be a type of ambrosia. We
already have observed that his testosterone is a naturally produced aphrodisiac that is imparted to his female soulmate
via one form of oral sex, namely deep kissing. My theory is that the chemical composition of his ejaculation will be
transformed at the resurrection so as to impart a similar, but more potent, sexual reaction so that in drinking his ambrosia,
his female lover will experience a level-two orgasm. His male fountain will literally become a fountain of pleasure and
passion for her, even more so physically for her than for him, even though he will psychologically enjoy being the source
of her pleasure and the object of her passion.

       For sake of illustration and computation, let her having a level-one orgasm be defined in this context as the orgasm
she would receive through manual stimulation, whether it be by her lover using his fingers on her vulva or his penis in
her vagina to bring her to orgasm. She would experience a level-two orgasm as a result of drinking his ambrosia in oral
intercourse, which might possibly be twice as long and strong as a level-one orgasm. She could experience a level-three
orgasm as a result of receiving his ambrosia vaginally in vaginal intercourse, which might possibly be three times as long
and strong as her level-one orgasm. 196 For the sake of theoretical calculations, let the following estimations, therefore,
be entertained:

        1. Her level-one orgasm is manually induced.
        2. Her level-two orgasm is orally induced and is two times as powerful as her level-one orgasm.
        3. Her level-three orgasm is vaginally induced and is three times as powerful as her level-one orgasm.

       Her resulting level of orgasm is dependent upon two factors: the amount of his ambrosia that she takes and the
manner in which she takes it. If she takes his ambrosia orally, her resulting orgasm is doubled (orally then doubled). If
she takes his ambrosia vaginally, her resulting orgasm is tripled (vaginally then tripled). If the amount of ambrosia he
ejaculates during an orgasm were increased, it would have to be multiplied by these factors (x 2 for oral, x 3 for vaginal)
to compute her resulting orgasm. Therefore, these theoretical computations can be used as a basis to produce
extrapolations for the rest of the chart.197

receiving his ambrosia orally would be better than not receiving it at all, so level two is better than level one. Indeed, she

level-two or level-three orgasm to satisfy her sexual desire. These predictions are thus based on the prophetic implications
of the Song of Solomon, plus reasonable logical inferences, and assigning mathematical increments to those implications
and inferences.

reasonable presumption that his ambrosia would invoke a higher orgasm for her than mere manual stimulation.

drink her milk before having his orgasm, then this would cause him to have a stronger orgasm in response and move him

        Combing my mathematical inclination with exegetical speculation leads me to interject at least into the above

His ejaculation will be living water for the female. By the same token, the breasts of a resurrected female will no longer

provide sexual pleasure for her soulmate? If the above deduction is correct regarding the reconstitution of the male sexual
fluid to provide sexual pleasure to the female, and it certainly seems to be, then symmetry demands that the same be true
for the female. Her sexual fluids would provide sexual pleasure for the male. She would be living water for him sexually.
        Scientists love providing labels and making theoretical calculations. So for labeling purposes, I will refer to her
sexually reconstituted breastmilk as a form of nectar. Her nectar might do more than simply act as an aphrodisiac in
increasing his desire, however. It might also increase his sexual response in terms of raising his orgasmic potential. Let
us suppose that it also increases his sexual ability, specifically in the form of causing him to have a stronger orgasm. For
the sake of theoretical computation, suppose that he normally would only have a level-one orgasm when she manually
stimulated his penis either orally or vaginally, but drinking her nectar beforehand causes him to have a chemically
enhanced, level-two orgasm instead. If so, for the sake of simple calculation, let us suppose that he would ejaculate twice
as much ambrosia if he first drunk her nectar before he had an orgasm. In turn, she would be drinking twice as much of
his ambrosia when she fellated him in that case, that is, if he had drunk her nectar first, because her nectar would have
caused him to ejaculate twice the amount of ejaculation, thus ejaculating twice the amount of ambrosia. Because fellation
is normally a level-two orgasm for her, however, her response would now be raised to a level-four orgasm. As already
noted, if the amount of ambrosia he ejaculates during an orgasm is increased, it has to be multiplied by the appropriate
factors to compute her resulting orgasm. The computation is simple arithmetic:

    My synthetical sexual-typological hypothesis might be seen by some as a synthesis of two common antithetical ways
of interpreting Song of Solomon. The Song is frequently interpreted as a human love poem celebrating sexual intimacy
(which Christian interpreters would understand as celebrating marital intimacy and thus having nothing to do with
allegory), or as an allegory depicting Christ and His Bride (thus having nothing to do with literal human sexual intimacy).
A synthetic typological approach that combines the other two approaches is certainly nothing new. And, to be sure, in
my sexual typology, I am combing (1) human sexuality with (2) typology in such a way to avoid immorality. Moreover,
one of the reasons some interpreters prefer the allegorical method is to avoid any semblance of immorality in the Song.
Nevertheless, the typological-synthesis approach normally combines sexuality with allegory so as to make the surface
meaning the pretext to the deeper meaning of the text so that the human sexual love points to the love between Christ
and His Bride. My typological approach is different in that I am not using typology allegorically but eschatologically.
The use of typology in eschatology is a widely acknowledged biblical phenomenon. Accordingly, my approach
fundamentally falls well within the realms of scholastic possibility.

            His amount of ejaculated ambrosia x her normal response level = her resulting response level.
        Her drinking twice the amount of his ambrosia, at what would normally have been a level-two response for her,
would result in a level-four orgasm for her (2 x 2 = 4). She normally would only have a level-two orgasm by drinking
his ambrosia. But that calculation assumes that she is only drinking the normal amount of ambrosia. Yet if he drunk her
nectar first, it would cause him to ejaculate twice the amount of ambrosia when she fellated him, thus causing her to have

virginally instead of orally. In this case, her taking twice the amount of his ambrosia vaginally would result in a level six

result. She would have an orgasm that is four levels higher than his in this case. That is, in this scenario his level 2 yields
a level 6 for her, which is four levels higher than his level 2.
       Theoretically, the disparity might even rise higher if his drinking her vaginal honey has a similar effect on him as
his drinking her nectar. This seems to be a reasonable postulation, given the sexual information provided by the Song and
Proverbs. If he drinks her nectar beforehand, he has a stronger orgasm, or if he drinks her honey beforehand, he has a
stronger orgasm. If he drinks either, he would have a stronger orgasm. So if he drinks both beforehand, he would have
an orgasm that is two levels higher than his normal level-one orgasm. He thus has a level-three orgasm (1 + 2 = 3).
Accordingly, if his drinking both her milk and honey raises him to a level-three orgasm, then we would have to recalculate
his amount of ejaculated ambrosia times her natural level of response to derive her resulting response level. In this
case, she would have a level six orgasm orally (3 x 2 = 6) or a level nine orgasm vaginally (3 x 3 = 9). Whereas he would
max out at a level-three orgasm, she would max out at level nine. She would experience an orgasm that is six levels
higher than his in this case.

                             Historical Confirmation of Increased Penis Size and Ejaculation
        This conjecture regarding increased masculine ejaculatory output and matching feminine desire for such output
might raise an objection in the minds of some since Eze 23:20 portrays this desire for increased output as being abnormal
and immoral: “She lusted after male lovers, whose genitals were as big as donkeys, and whose ejaculation was as much
as that of horses” (Eze 23:20; TM). Speculations as to what this verse means run from simply metaphorical to completely
literal. In fact, one pastor and church use images from 3,000 years ago that were reported on the History Channel to
explain this passage and to assert that history proves that Egyptian men had unusually large penises.199 For a scholarly
assessment along the same lines, one might also consult Moshe Greenberg: “The oversize genitals of Egyptians figure as
well in 16:26 (evidently a commonplace, expressing a popular notion of their lewdness), and are here compared in size
and seminal discharge to those of equines [horses], proverbially lascivious, Jer 5:8” (Ezekiel, ABC, s.v. 23:20).
        Some translations try to tone down what some describe as the dirtiest verse in the Bible: “She lusted after male
lovers, whose genitals [basar] were as big as donkeys, and whose ejaculation [zirmah] was as much as that of horses”
(Eze 23:20; TM). But zirmah is certainly referring to issue of semen (BDB, TWOT), thus ejaculation from the penis,
which is why HHL simply defines it as phallus (i.e., penis). Some translations are frank about what the verse is saying,
“Who ejaculate like stallions” (CJB); “their seminal emission was as strong as that of stallions” (NET); “ejaculating as
violently as stallions” (NJB). As to basar, HHL notes that it is used as a euphemism for penis in Gen 17:11 and as penis
in Lev 15:2, where it is again used in regards to ejaculation. HALOT simply defines it as penis in Lev 15:2; Eze 16:26;
23:20. BDB says that it is used as a euphemism for the penis in Gen 17:14; Lev 15:2-19; Eze 16:26; 23:20; 44:7,9. In
any event, some translations make the issue clear: “Whose sexual members were like those of donkeys” (CSB); “whose
genitals were like those of donkeys” (GWN); “she lusted after their genitals—as large as those of donkeys” (NET);
“whose genitals were like those of donkeys” (NIV); “with genitals as large as a donkey’s” (NLT). Thus my translation
is in accord with these: “She lusted after male lovers, whose genitals were as big as donkeys, and whose ejaculation was
as much as that of horses” (TM). Obviously, she lusted after them because of their sexually enhanced penises. So the
NET is justified in cutting out the middle man and saying that she lusted directly after their sexually enhanced penises.
Similarly, great (gadel) flesh (bazar) in Eze 16:26 is properly rendered as “big-membered” (CJB; NJB); “well-endowed”
(CSB), “large genitals” (online edition of NIV). I will simply use the latter: “You engaged in prostitution with the
Egyptians, your neighbors with large genitals” (Eze 16:26; NIV).

based in literality because it is tied with the fertility gods and national gods of Egypt who were associated, biblically and
historically, with males that actually had large penises and voluminous ejaculation. The passages in Ezekiel call to mind
similar passages from Enoch where the fallen angels are described as letting out their penises like horses to impregnate
human women. These fallen angels are described as “great stars whose sexual members were like those of horses”
