resulting male offspring had abnormally intense sexual desires and abilities and large sexual organs, resulting in some
human females desiring to have sex with these sexually enhanced offspring. This illicit sex resulted in enhanced sex.
These half-angel-half-human offspring were sexually enhanced as a result of becoming like angels in that regard.

       Moreover, SSol 5:1 might suggest something similar: “I have eaten my honeycomb with my honey; I have drunk
my wine with my milk.” This passage describes him eating her fruits (SSol 4:16). Perhaps the multiple images

though very unlikely, is that the honey is described as wine in the second stanza, and sucking her breasts is associated

ideal becomes the eschatological real, one is left to speculate as to what that realization might look like. Could her breasts
actually produce an aphrodisiacal breastmilk that would cause her male lover to have a higher level orgasm that, in turn,
would cause her to have a higher level orgasm when she partook more abundantly of his fruit?
        For the sake of computational completeness, one more theoretical permutation might be considered. The paring
of honeycomb with honey under the verb eat in contraposition to the pairing of wine with milk under the verb drink
suggests that two different parts of her body are in view. Emphasis is called to her two breasts (SSol 4:5; 7:3,7). If eating
honey from her honeycomb is vaginal in SSol 5:1, then possibly drinking wine and milk refers to partaking orally of her
two breasts: one described as drinking wine, the other as drinking milk. This might open up another series of theoretical
computations. Suppose that each means of consumption—(1) drinking her breast wine or (2) drinking her breast milk or
(3) eating her vaginal honey from her honeycomb—causes an increase by one level in the computation, so that doing all
three causes him to move up three levels to a level-four response (1 + 3 = 4). Then, following the same computational
procedures, his level-four response would cause her to have a level-eight orgasm orally (4 x 2 = 8) and a level-twelve
orgasm vaginally (4 x 3 = 12). His maximum orgasmic level would be four and hers twelve. Her maximum level
would be eight levels higher than his in this case.

that she would attain a higher level of sexual pleasure than he does as a result, it is possible that she might arouse him
even in his sleep with erotic dreams and cause him to have an involuntary erection so that she can exercise her womanly
power over him and fellate him while he sleeps. Thus, she might have the power to take his ambrosia even while he is in

orgasm than he does, it would make sense that she might, on occasion at least, have to take advantage of him while he is

Oral Sex in Proverbs
        The case for oral sex is strong in Song of Solomon and provides reasonable support for the working theory being
developed herein that sexual pleasure will continue in the eternal state even apart from association with reproduction.
Nevertheless, some online interpreters overstate the case for fellatio and think that Prov 5:15 is instructing a wife to
perform fellatio on her husband, as if the injunction were addressed to her: “Drink water from your own cistern, flowing
water from your own well.” They think that the verse is saying that the wife is to drink her husband’s semen and that she
is the only women entitled to do so. Some taking this approach press this verse, along with a few other passages (e.g.,
Gen 38:8-10, Lev 15:16-17; 1Cor 7:4), to insist that the wife must swallow his semen rather than spitting it out, which is
likened to spilling it on the ground, making it unclean, a matter displeasing to God. Counter wise, most Christian marriage
counselors would say that this is pressing the text too far. Better arguments for swallowing are normally linked with her
meeting her husband’s physiological needs rather than the exegetical demands of the text.
        Prov 5:15 should not be translated or interpreted as dealing specifically with fellation, and thus not used to insist
upon swallowing during fellation. To be sure, Prov 5:15 is applicable to oral sex, at least inclusively; nevertheless, the
verse is not picturing fellatio but cunnilingus. Solomon is saying that the only vaginal lubrication that the husband should
partake of is that of his wife, whether through vaginal intercourse or cunnilingus. The next verse, Prov 5:16, on the other
hand, would apply to fellation but not be limited to fellation. In this verse, the husband is instructed to share his seminal
fluid only with his wife, whether through vaginal intercourse or fellatio. The man is to be content with the refreshing
sexual relationship he has with his wife as his well of living waters (cp. SSol 4:15). Likewise, he is instructed in the next
verse: “Don’t be like a stream from which just any woman may take a drink” (CEV). His seminal fluid is to be shared
only with his wife. She is the only one allowed to drink it. Drinking his seminal fluid certainly suggests oral sex, but the
imagery should not be limited to oral sex. More inclusively, his wife is the only woman permitted to drink, take, or
partake of his seminal fluid, whether it be orally or vaginally. Still, since what is good for the goose is good for the gander
and since the man is enjoined to drink from his wife’s well, it is reasonable to conclude that she is expected to drink from
his fountain, and drinking includes swallowing. (In any case, that same argument could be made from SSol 5:1.) If
swallowing is a problem, let it be noted that fellatirxes would recommend that she drink something with her husband’s
ejaculation if necessary to make it more palatable.
        Another passage in Proverbs is reasonably thought by some to denounce oral sex outside of marriage: “This is the
way of an adulterous woman: She eats and wipes her mouth, and says, ‘I have done no wrong’” (Prov 30:20; cp.
Prov 9:17). As Aaron notes, “Since no one links adultery with the normal eating of food or wiping the mouth, the terms
are clearly euphemistic for sexual activity.” The adulterous woman drinks the semen of another woman’s husband (i.e.,
the living water of his well according to this imagery) and wipes her mouth, claiming that she has not done anything
wrong. She is wrong. Oral sex outside of marriage is adulterous. This passage, like a variety of others in Proverbs, argues
for sexual exclusivity. The living water of both the male and female is to be limited to one’s singular sexual mate.
Living Water taken Orally
       A comprehensive survey of living water in the biblical texts would suggest that we define living water as flowing
water that (1) imparts life or (2) enhances life with pleasure. Various types of living water are discernable: physical,
soteriological, misthological, misthopological, interpersonal, pneumatological, paternal, terrestrial, celestial, and sexual.
The most famous text regarding living water contrasts it with physical water:

       Jesus answered and said to her, “If you knew the gift of God, and who it is who says to you, ‘Give Me a
       drink,’ you would have asked Him, and He would have given you living [zao] water [hudor].” 11 She said
       to Him, “Sir, You have nothing to draw with and the well [phrear] is deep; where then do You get that
       living [zao] water [hudor]? 12 “You are not greater than our father Jacob, are You, who gave us the well,

       In this passage internal living water is a soteriological gift. It imparts spiritual life in the form of regeneration,
which eternally quenches the believer’s thirst. Even the form of physical water that is properly called living water would
not qualify to quench spiritual water: “But when Isaac’s servants dug in the valley and found there a well [phrear] of
flowing [zao] water [hudor]” (Gen 26:19).204 The spring water (ESV) is living water (LXX). Physical living water must
be distinguished from spiritual living water. Nevertheless, at the physical level, note the difference between a cistern and
spring: “The water of running streams and fountains, as opposed to that of stagnant cisterns...is called living water”
(UBD, s.v., “water”).
       Living water can also refer to the Holy Spirit:

       Now on the last day, the great day of the feast, Jesus stood and cried out, saying, “If any man is thirsty, let

        Believers can have such an abundant experience of the Spirit that the Spirit flows through them to others. A well
can be hidden or made private; not so with a river. This river flows to others. The research in the present book has been

water to those thirsty enough to drink it, so that they can find this consolation refreshing as well, as it flows from my

                                                     Restoration
      The Lord delights in restoration (Job 33:25-26; 42:10; Ps 23:3; 51:12; 103:1-5; Joel 2:25-26; Jer 29:11; Is 40:31;
Mt 17:11; Acts 3:21). In Ps 103:5 is the well-known statement about the Lord renewing our youth like the eagle. In
commenting on this verse, Joseph Prince deduces that this literally has happened:

              Remember the Bible accounts of two different kings who wanted Sarah, Abraham’s wife, for their
       harems? Can you recall how old she was then? She was 65 when Pharaoh desired her, and 90 when
       Abimelech wanted her! My friend, these were heathen kings. I am sure that it was not because they were
       captivated by her inner or spiritual beauty. God must have literally renewed her youth physically! Beloved,
       God’s Word promises a literal and physical renewal of your youth and strength.208

       He is not the only one who has made this deduction. My projection is that just as Abraham offering up his son
foreshadowed the death of the Messiah, so this age reversal of Abraham’s wife foreshadows the age reversal that we will
experience upon the return of the Messiah. But before this eschatological renewed-like-an-eagle experience, we may
have to go through some difficult experiences like an eagle:

              The eagle has the longest life-span of its species. It can live up to 70 years. But to reach this age, the
       eagle must make a hard decision. In its 40’s its long and flexible talons can no longer grab prey which
       serves as food. Its long and sharp beak becomes bent. Its old-aged and heavy wings, due to their thick
       feathers, become stuck to its chest and make it difficult to fly. Then, the eagle is left with only two options:
       die or go through a painful process of change which lasts 150 days. The process requires that the eagle fly
       to a mountaintop and sit on its nest. There the eagle knocks its beak against a rock until it plucks it out.
       After plucking it out, the eagle will wait for a new beak to grow back and then it will pluck out its talons.
       When its new talons grow back, the eagle starts plucking its old-aged feathers. And after five months, the
       eagle takes its famous flight of rebirth and lives for 30 more years.209

        As I write this note, my wife has just finished her last chemotherapy treatment for her breast cancer. She will be
having her mastectomy next week. We have just met with the plastic surgeon to discuss the breast reconstruction surgery
she will have. He has said that we will have to wait six months after we finish the radiation treatment following the
surgery. He said that he preferred to call it breast restoration rather than breast reconstruction. Fine. But at most all he
can do is restore the breast aesthetically, not functionally. Dillow said that the reason Solomon described his wife’s
breasts like clusters of grapes in SSol 7:7 is because “grapes swell and become increasingly round and elastic as they
ripen, similar to the female breasts when sexually aroused” (p. 136). Those days will be gone for us, at least in relation
to one breast, after next week. A humanly restored breast is numb, so it would be dumb to think that the plastic surgeon
is going to be able to restore her breast to its previous function. We chose not to have a double mastectomy so that at
least one of her breasts would be sexually functional after the surgery. Frankly, I am not thrilled about that prospect, but
it is the lesser of two evils. Even so, what about those couples who have to have a double mastectomy? The Bible
commands, “Take pleasure in the wife of your youth....let her breasts satisfy you at all times” (Prov 5:18-19; TM). How
about after mastectomy? How are numb breasts supposed to be satisfying? How can husbands be commanded by God’s
word to take pleasure in breasts than can no longer experience pleasure? Does mastectomy not make a mockery out of
God’s word? Yes, it certainly does—but only for a limited time.

         Duane Garrett (Proverbs, NAC) rightly notes that the passage in Proverbs is not warning against wasting semen
by fathering illegitimate children, nor is it promising a blessing of fathering many legitimate children. Pleasure rather
than procreation is the subject matter: “The passage emphasizes the sexual pleasure of marriage and not having offspring
(v. 19). The command [is] to ‘take pleasure’ [v. 18] in your first wife...positively that marriage should include sexual joy
and fulfillment.” In this context take pleasure is a better translation than rejoice in Prov 5:18.210 “Take pleasure in the
wife of your youth” (CSB). Several translations render it as have joy, but GWN is closer to the mark when it renders it
as enjoy. Ironically, BBE translates the Prov 5:19 as, “Let her breasts ever give you rapture.” The irony is that I believe
that it is at the rapture that my wife’s breasts will be restored so that they can give me rapture.
         In Galatians the Bible promises: “Do not be deceived, God is not mocked; for whatever a man sows, this he will
also reap” (Gal 6:7). Can God be mocked by cancer? Sure, He can be mocked by cancer—but only for a time. This verse
is saying that you cannot mock God and get away with it in the long run. Will cancer be able to get away with it? No!
Many people today mock God. Cancer mocks God. But they will only be able to mock God for a brief period of time.
Judgment is coming. But what about those Christian couples who look to God for an answer as to how to apply His
promises to Prov 5:18-19? They should look at the next verse in Galatians: “For the one who sows to his own flesh shall
from the flesh reap corruption, but the one who sows to the Spirit shall from the Spirit reap eternal life” (Gal 6:7).
Christian couples can sow this Galatian promise, in relation to Prov 5:18-19, to the Spirit and trust the Spirit that they
will reap eternal life even in relation to the very thing that they have suffered the loss of—sexually responsive breasts.
When God does His restoration, He is not going to do so as a plastic surgeon.
                                       Illustration 38. Kick Cancer’s Butt T-shirts!


                      A                                        B                                       C




        Many T-shirts have been designed for women to wear saying that they have kicked cancer’s butt. Christian T-
shirts give the credit to God by saying, “God has kicked cancer’s butt!” But is it true? No. Not for us. When our surgeon
came in to give us the results of the chemotherapy, as confirmed by the MRI, she said, “I have good news and bad news.”
The good news was that the chemotherapy was completely successful! The cancer had been eradicated. Did that mean
that God had kicked cancer’s butt? No. Kick butt is an idiom that means to defeat someone completely.211 God had used
the chemotherapy to eradicate the cancer. Praise the Lord! But then it was time for the bad news. Cancer was still going
to get the last laugh—at least for now. Its butt had not been kicked because it had left behind a string of buts.
        The cancer was gone, as best the surgeon could tell, but we still needed to have the mastectomy. Not only did we
still need to have the mastectomy, and a numb breast for the rest of our lives as a result, but the surgeon was still going
to take out a large number of axillary lymph nodes. I was not pleased with this bit of news in the least. I had thought,
from what had been said from the first surgeon that we had seen, that they would inject a tracer (a radioactive liquid) into
the sentinel lymph node and use that to determine which nodes were cancerous and just remove the sentinel lymph nodes,
if possible, thus vastly reducing the risk lymphedema. But no! This second surgeon, after the chemotherapy had done its
work successfully, insisted that we still need to take out the axillary lymph nodes anyway. “Why?” I demanded. The
surgeon said that the chemotherapy had done its job so effectively that it had obliterated the swollen sentinel lymph node,
which the biopsy had confirmed as cancerous. So now injecting a tracer into the sentinel lymph node was no longer
possible. “So what you are saying,” I clarified very coldly, “is that doing the chemotherapy before the surgery has burned
the bridge making it impossible to use the tracer to take out only the infected lymph nodes?” The surgeon confirmed this
to be the case. To put the matter very mildly, I was very inquisitive at this point as to why the surgeon did not do the
surgery first and then do the chemotherapy afterwards (which is the protocol many surgeons take!) so that she could have

youth....let her numb breasts satisfy you at all times” (Prov 5:18-19). To think that God has kicked cancer’s butt when
cancer is able to make a mockery of this text in this way is just plain dumb.
        The standard Christian response would be to say that in the resurrection we will have new bodies, so cancer’s
mockery would be silenced then. Again, not true, at least not in the manner the resurrection is typically interpreted. Most
Christians believe that she will have new breasts, to be sure, but (there is that but again!) her breasts will no longer
experience satisfaction or give it. They will no longer be satisfying. Is this a satisfactory way to leave the matter? No!
        If I were to design such a T-shirt, I would have it emphatically say, with an eye toward the eschatological future,
“God will kick cancer’s butt!!!” Why? Because the biblical view of the resurrection leads one to believe that God will
not only restore the breasts but also restore their function! Not only will these restored breasts not be numb, they will
experience and give sexual satisfaction just as before, only at a much greater level of pleasure for those who are
overcomers. One of these days, I’m going to be able to thumb my nose at breast cancer. God is going to kick cancer’s
butt! I remind myself of that fact every day, especially when contemplating Prov 5:18-19, because I am looking beyond
these days just ahead, and the plastic restoration at the end of this year (2016), to the complete restoration to come when
our youth is renewed in the Heavenly City.
        My wife and I have the same birthday. We were born the same day of the same year. Guess what day she had her
mastectomy. Our birthday! What a birthday present! But I don’t mind because God has given me a new perspective, and
a therapeutic one at that, as a result of the research I have invested in this book. Seen from my perspective, cancer will
prove to be nothing more than a temporary inconvenience. God will get the last laugh. And we will be able to share in
His laughter and look back on the timing of this surgery in eternity future and laugh about it.
        These three things—original design, restoration, and God not being mocked—lead me to conclude that those
guided to the springs of the water of life misthologically will become springs of the water of life sexually. To express it
vividly, God is going to kick cancer’s butt by restoring not just my wife’s ability via sensitivity but her function via
stimulation. God has promised to give use the desires of our heart (Ps 37:4). His word will not be mocked. Cancer will
not have the last word. God will!
        This same line of reasoning would apply to testicular cancer, of course. Surgery for this type of cancer removes
the testicle or testicles containing the cancer. A man and his wife who are overcomers can look forward to his testicles
being restored in the resurrected state. His testicles will no longer function for sexual reproduction, but they will function
at unsurpassed levels for sexual pleasure. While his wife’s breasts are producing living water in the form of nectar, his
restored testicles will be producing living water in the form of ambrosia.

        The proverbial wife is living water for her husband, and the idealized Shulamith is the living water for her husband
(see pink highlighted text above). Surely, Solomon, who wrote both accounts, would count both women (the proverbial
wife and the idealized Shulamith) as being a picture of the virtuous wife who satisfies her husband. And he is living water
for her (see blue text above). Not only her vagina (Prov 5:15) but also her breasts (Prov 5:19) are sources of living water
for him. His testicles and penis are likewise living water for her. His fountain is to be a source of pleasure and passion
for her. God commands them to eat and drink each other and to be intoxicated by each other as a result (SSol 5:1). Their
drinking deeply/freely/abundantly of one another (so various translations) is rendered as being drunk or intoxicated (by
other translations). I particularly like the BBE: “Be overcome with love.” These translations blend together of course. If
you drink abundantly, then you will be drunk or intoxicated and thus overcome by the strong drink. Even so, I favor the
translation overcome for two reasons. For one thing, overcomers will be overcome by each other’s love. Secondly, the
female overcomer/lover will be so totally overcome by the level of pleasure that she derives from his ambrosia that she
will be eaten alive by the desire to overcome him and take his ambrosia even in his sleep. Her honey and nectar will
overcome him, and his ambrosia will overcome her. Some interpreters think that the verse is telling them to get drink
literally by drinking literal wine. Not so! Frankly, I am a teetotaler. Geisler has a good argument for completely abstaining
from wine and beer in our current age (pp. 359-373) and, even in the past, excessive drinking was biblically denounced
(Eph 5:18). Notwithstanding, I suspect that this passage will find literal fulfillment when overcoming soulmates are able
to be intoxicated sexually with one another’s ambrosia, nectar, and honey.

                                                        Exalted Horn
        I am theorizing that the male overcomer’s penis and testicles will be blessed so as to become a literal fountain of
living water for the sexual pleasure of his soulmate in the eternal state. Nevertheless, in developing this thesis, I have not
appealed to the horn/penis conjecture by Aaron: “Animal horns have long been considered a symbol of the erect male
organ....Since men do not have horns in the literal sense, there is strong reason to believe the word ‘horn’ is euphemistic
[in Ps 75:10; 92:10; 132:17]. Though the male organ may not be meant specifically, because the idea of fertility is
commonly present in such passages, there is a distinct linkage.” Critics respond that a euphemistic sense of horn makes
no sense in a variety of passages. For example, they would exclaim that the exalted horn in Ps 112:9-10 does not mean
that the wicked will see the exalted penises of the righteous (cp. Ps 112:6) and be grieved! Notwithstanding, even here,
one might respond that the wicked will be grieved when they see the righteous rewarded with a sexual experience to
which they are not privy.
        Similarly, could the wicked having their horns cut off while the righteous are having their horns exalted in Ps 75:10
contrast one group being deprived of heavenly sex while the other is free to enjoy it, perhaps typified by Dt 23:1?212
Likewise, in Ps 92:10 one may reasonably pose that righteous having their horn exalted is part of their having their youth
renewed so that they bear fruit in their old age and are full of sap (Ps 92:14). Could a sexual restoration not be part of the
euphemism? Would not the doctrine of eschatological restoration, in which our youth is restored in the resurrected state,
suggest such a possibility? In Ps 132:17, the Lord promises that He will “cause the horn of David to spring forth.” This
promise has personal application to David: “Upon himself his crown will shine” (Ps 132:18). The horn is associated with
his crown so as to be considered a euphemism for restored rulership. A sexual component may not be intended in this
latter passage, but the important point is that it has personal application to David. Would this not mean that Ps 92:10,14
has personal application to David also (cp. Ps 89:17-24)? But if so, would it not mean that David’s sexual abilities would
be restored? We simply may pose that his sexual ability will be restored so that his horn bears fruit and is full of sap.
Could this be a picture of his erect penis producing ambrosia?

        Quayle thinks that the horn mentioned in Ps 92:10 might the horn of a chimeric unicorn because the creature “is
said to have only one horn. Since there are few animals having a single horn, it is understandable why translators would
call this animal a unicorn, especially given that it is found in both Greek and Roman mythology” (p. 176). Granted, a
number of older English translations render the Hebrew reem as unicorn (DRA; GNV; KJV; RWB; WEB). Newer
translations render it as wild ox or bull or buffalo, however. Yet these newer translations are not suitable for this verse in
that the ox, bull, and buffalo have two horns while this verse is talking about one horn. The LXE renders the LXX
monokerotos as: “But my horn shall be exalted as the horn of a unicorn.”213 Monokerotos literally means one (mono)
horn (kerotos). So many would say that the Greek LXX mistranslates the Hebrew reem. More likely though, the LXX is
correct, but it is not talking about a one-horned horse, but a one-horned rhinoceros (so also ACC). Even today, the Big
Horned Rhinoceros (elasmotherium) pictured above¸ which lived at that time, is still referred to as The Giant Unicorn.214
It takes little imagination to make a euphemistic association with an erection when looking at its exalted horn. As already
noted, Solomon used tusk euphemistically: “His erect penis is a carved ivory tusk overlaid with blue sapphires”
(SSol 5:14; TM). David, his father, may have used the imagery of the big horned rhino euphemistically as well.
        David, like other OT saints, believed in the physical resurrection (Job 19:25-26; Ps 16:10-11; 49:15; 73:24; Is 25:8;
26:19; Dan 12:2,13). The Nephilim were excluded from the resurrection (Is 26:14), but this is understandable since they
were not truly human, being half human and half angel. The desire of many Jewish women for genetically enlarged
Nephilim penises was also common knowledge (Eze 16:26; 23:20). If David believed that resurrected believers would
be like angels, as Jesus did (Mt 22:30), then it would have been a simple deduction for David to conclude that he would
have an enlarged penis like the Nephilim, which were the closest thing he knew to humans becoming like angels.
Deducing that he would be like an angel upon resurrecting was not that hard of a deduction either, given that he already
knew that we were originally created to be like angels (Gen 1:26). David would have, or at least should have, expected
to be sexually active with an enhanced human-angel sexual ability when resurrected. His statement in Ps 92:10, even if
invoking a double entendre, gives reason to suspect that he made the proper deduction. Jeremiah made this deduction
and correspondingly made the easy deduction that when this occurs the women will encompass these sexually enhanced
men (Jer 31:22). The only thing that Jesus added to this OT anticipation was that this enhanced sexual activity would not
be associated with reproduction (i.e., marriage). But David might have even figured this out in that he would be like
angels in Heaven, who did not reproduce since they did not leave their heavenly estate to mate with human women, rather
than be like fallen angels, who left their heavenly realm and bodies to come to this realm and take on physical bodies so
that they might be able to have sex with human women so that they might reproduce. After all, Jude and Peter are just
citing a widely held OT belief in this regard (Jude 1:6; 2Pet 2:4). To be sure, Ezekiel was disgusted with the women of
Israel wanting to encompass the sexually enhanced males of Egypt, and he depicted it negatively as sex with human-
horses (i.e., satyrs). Still, his consternation is completely understandable in that this enhancement was a result of fallen
angels causing men to become like them. This indictment would not be applicable to women wanting to encompass men
who have become like unfallen angels in their enhanced sexual ability.

sexually prostituting themselves with satyrs imply that they were actually having sex with literal satyrs? When the
Israelites worshipped the golden calf, they “sat down to eat and to drink, and rose up to play” (Ex 32:6). They did not
rise up to play a game of badminton! They were indulging in a sexual orgy. Their playing the harlot with the foreign gods
might, at least on occasion, take a very literal sexual expression (Ex 34:16). On some occasions, it would entail sexual
orgies amongst themselves; on other occasions, it would be sexual orgies with the women who worshipped these foreign
gods (Num 25:1). Yet on some occasions, it would be with the fallen gods and demigods themselves who, in some cases,
were in satyr form. History will repeat itself during the tribulation. Watch the CERN video if you want to see a modern

                                                        Literal Lilith

       Lilith in Translation
        What about the goddesses? Will they be sitting on the sidelines during the tribulation while the male gods are
taking the form of satyrs and raping and seducing human women? Not likely. As a matter of fact, Isaiah might have
included fallen goddesses and/or demonesses along with his description of the satyrs. The LXE renders Is 34:14 as: “And
devils [lit. demons; daimonia] shall meet with satyrs [lit. donkey-centaurs; onocentaurious], and they shall cry one to the
other: there shall satyrs [lit. donkey-centaurs; onocentaurious] rest, having found for themselves a place of rest.”225 The
LXE is a translation of the LXX, and the LXX is the Bible that, for the most part, Jesus and the apostles used. Frankly,
when it comes to translating this verse, I am more inclined to trust their Bible than the naturalistic translation found in
some of our Bibles. Some of our translations want to translate this verse in strictly natural terms, as if it were simply
talking about wild animals and owls. The Bible that Jesus and the Jews used, however, did not understand this verse in
naturalistic terms. Neither should we. Seen through that biblical lens, the underlying Hebrew text is even more
supernaturally explicit: “The demons [tsi; HHL] will meet with the goblins [HHL], and the satyr [sair; he-goat shaped
demon] will cry to its companions, and lilith [name of sexual night-demoness/goddess haunting desolate Edom, similar
to the Babylonian and Gilgamesh accounts; cp. BDB; HHL; TWOT] will settle there and find a resting place for herself”
(TM). Even though some translators and lexicographers tend to demythologize this verse, I am inclined to follow the
LXX in allowing a supernatural rendition. Many of our translations concur with this supernatural understanding of the
verse. Lilith would basically be the feminine counterpart of the satyr in the LXX summation. The male and female
demons and demonesses will find rest there. Those translations that recognize the supernatural motif of the verse render
the Hebrew word lilith as: night-monster (ASV; ERV; JPS; NAS; NAU), night-spirit (BBE), Lilit the night monster
(CJB), lilith (DBY; NAB; TNK); and Lilith (NJB). Lilith is a hapax legomenon (a word that occurs only once in the
Bible), so lexicographers have to look outside of the Bible to determine its meaning. Part of that examination is to look
at how it was used in extrabiblical legends.

       Lilith in Legend
        Although Fortson acknowledges that “there are some students of the Bible that point to the verse in Isaiah as proof
of Lilith, whom they believe was Adam’s first wife,” he rejects the Lilith legend but upholds the possibility that such an
evil female goddess (or goddesses) will be active during the tribulation (Beyond, 25-28). Even though Biggs has written
a book defending the historical reliability of the Lilith account, even from what he considers a trustworthy biblical
perspective, and thus a relatively conservative position,226 I share Fortson’s more traditional conservative assessment.
My opinion is that Isaiah is affirming the historical reality behind the Lilith legend, without necessarily affirming what
would generally be considered erroneousness embellishments of the legend, and he is prophesying that the feminine evil
spirits associated with this legend will have visible manifestation during the tribulation at this location.227 Before

attempting to demythologize the legend, a brief overview of the legend will be helpful.
       The basic gist of the legends is that Lilith was Adam’s first wife (the so-called “first Eve”). According to the so-
called first creation account (Gen 1:26-29), Adam’s first wife, Lilith, was co-created at the same time as Adam and
directly out of the ground just like Adam. Thus Lilith is referred to as Adamah: “A mist rose up from the ground and
watered Adamah’s face” (Gen 2:6).228 Consequently, Adamah considered herself equal to Adam and refused to be
subservient to Adam. Specifically, according to legend, Lilith quarreled with Adam about always having to take the
inferior, subservient, woman-on-bottom position when having sex. She wanted to have her turn at the dominant position,
thereby taking the woman-on-top position. Adam refused. So Lilith uttered God’s unutterable magical name to grow
demonic wings and fly away from Eden and leave Adam.229 She refused to return to Adam and Eden to submit to Adam
as his wife, even though God sent angels instructing her to do so.
       According to the so-called second creation account (Gen 2:21-25), Adam’s second wife, the biblical Eve, was not
created until later. Adam had “become alone” after Lilith left him (Gen 2:18). God said that this was not good. So God
created the biblical Eve (aka the “second Eve”), who was subservient to Adam because, unlike Lilith, the biblical Eve
was created (1) after Adam, (2) from his side, and (3) named by him. Nevertheless, Adam was distraught after the death
of Abel and separated himself from Eve for 130 years.
       During that 130-year period of separation, before Adam was reconciled to Eve, Lilith would come to Adam in his
sleep, mounting him in his sleep, taking the woman-on-top position she had been denied, thereby raping him in his sleep,
and stealing his sperm in nocturnal emissions to produce her children—male and female demons. Lilith also had sex with
the archangel Samael—Satan—producing a race of demonic offspring by him, further transforming her into a
succubus.230 It was not until Adam returned to coupling with Eve, a 130 years later, that he had a son in his own human
image (Gen 4:25; 5:3).
       In the Talmud and Middle Ages, Lilith was considered a succubus, and her female offspring (the Lilim/Lithu) were
associated with succubi, who would copulate with men in their sleep, sexually overpowering and seducing them in their
sleep, causing them to have nocturnal emissions, so that these succubi could spawn their race of demonic children in
opposition to the race of children spawned by Adam’s second wife—the biblical Eve. This nocturnal seduction and rape
was the only way for them to continue to spawn their demonic race since God had castrated Samael. Lilith might also be
associated or identified with Alukah, the blood-sucking leech (nigh-spirit; BBE) that feeds on the throats of animals in
Prov 30:15. Alukah is a bloodsucking monster, a vampire, thought to be either one of Lilith’s direct descendants or
another name for Lilith herself. Alukah was the mother of female vampires called estries, the epitome of “those whose
teeth are swords, whose fangs are knives” (Prov 30:14). Thus goes the legends.

       Lilith in Prophecy
       My hypothesis is that Isaiah is using his readers’ familiarity with the Lilith folklore to affirm that the phenomena
associated with that legend will have visible realization in the prophetic future during the tribulation when the goddesses
and demonesses are again very much active in another Nephilim incursion: “Lilith will settle there and find a resting
place for herself” (Is 34:14; TM). Since Isaiah does not clarify how much of the legend in regard to the past is factual,
speculation in that regard is highly debatable. Quayle surmises well:


Isaiah would not give any historical validity to some of the truth shrouded in the Lilith myth and legend in that he would
have believed that (1) Nephilim had been created in the past through the union of fallen angels and human women, and
(2) he would have concurred with Solomon that there is nothing new under the son (Ecc 1:9). It would be simple deduction
for Isaiah to deduce from his prophecy that just as satyrs and liliths will exist in the last days, they must have existed in
former days. Given my belief, along with a number of other conservative writers, that succubi have been a prominent
factor in the past and will be a prominent factor again in the future, I am inclined to think that Isaiah believed so as well.
I would anticipate that he would have given at least this level of credibility to the Lilith legend.

        For myself, I do not subscribe to the two-creation-accounts theory in Genesis chs. 1-2 associated with the Lilith
legend, so as to think that Lilith was Adam’s first wife. Rather, in my conservative estimation, the account in ch. 2 is a
more detailed retelling of the summary account in ch. 1. My speculative inclination, however, is to favor the Jewish
legend that Lilith was Lucifer’s angelic mate. Since angels in Heaven do not marry nor have wives in the reproductive
sense, I technically would call her Lucifer’s soulmate rather than his wife. In any event, she was the so-called wife of
Lucifer, and he was the shinning one, the light-bearer, the god of light. Consequently, she was the wife of this angelic
god of light. This confusion led some to mistakenly consider her God’s wife. Actually, she was not God’s wife, but
Lucifer’s wife, if we use the term wife. When Lucifer fell, she fell. This proposal is in accord with my theory that each
angel in Heaven had a soulmate and they stood or fell together. According to one version of the Jewish theory, Lilith
seduced Adam, and Lucifer seduced Eve—sexually. I would pose, instead, that Lilith attempted to seduce Adam sexually,
but he was not seduced, even if Lilith did shape-shift into the form of a beautiful woman, as some would pose, which
would add to the confusion in the legends. However, Lucifer succeeded in tempting Eve with the forbidden fruit. Even
though this temptation was not a sexual seduction, many assume that it was, confusing it with the sexual seduction
attempted by Lilith.231 This is my conservative reconstruction to explain the legends in a manner consistent with my
analysis of the biblical data and hypotheses concerning sexual soulmates in Heaven. In any case, Lilith is a fallen goddess
who seeks to produce lilith demonesses. For present purposes, it suffices to summarize that just as goddesses and
demonesses have been active in the past in seducing men in order to steal their sperm to produce demonic hybrids, so
they will again be active in the future during the tribulation. The most plausible interpretation of Is 34:14 yields this result
and also suggests a conceptual link with Jer 31:22.
       Jeremiah is also familiar with this Lilith legend. Since he wrote after Isaiah, we may reasonably hold that Jeremiah
shares Isaiah’s prophetic perspective as well. Yet Jeremiah extrapolates and moves beyond the tribulation to the
millennium to foresee a time when human women, who have been faithful, will gain the sexual equality and even
superiority that the legendary Lilith sought. Feminists love the story of Lilith. She wanted to be on top, and feminists
want to be on top also, in every sense of the word. But in making Lilith their heroine, they will fail to achieve their
objective. Ironically, the woman who submits to her husband in a biblical manner is the woman who in the end will
encompass the male. Jeremiah prophetically foresaw this irony (Jer 31:22).
       Lilith was the first Sotah, the archetype of the adulterous woman in Proverbs 30:15-20, the Alukah who wipes her
mouth saying, “I have done no wrong,” when she steals the sperm of a human male. In the end, the virtuous woman of
Proverbs 31 will prevail over the sperm-stealing Lilith of Proverbs 30. The virtuous woman of Proverbs 31 will become
the Shulamith of the Song of Solomon, the eschatological realization of the idealized female lover. This sexually
aggressive Shulamith is anticipated in Jer 31:22, where the woman will encompass the male both vaginally and orally.
Shulamith, the idealized Song-of-Solomon-soulmate, will achieve, through godly means, what Lilith, the legendary
succubus, stole through ungodly means. The morally virtuous and sexually aggressive Shulamith will (1) predominantly
take the woman-on-top position during vaginal intercourse, even experiencing a superior orgasmic response over her
male lover, (2) wipe her mouth and legitimately be able say that she has done no wrong when she drinks her lover’s
ejaculation during oral intercourse, and (3) be able to rape her lover during his sleep, taking more of his ejaculation than
he otherwise would desire but as much as she desires. Yes, the virtuous woman will encompass the male, just as Jeremiah
foretells. Rather than being a bloodsucking vampire draining his vitality, though, she will be a life-giving fountain of
living water increasing his vitality. Shulamith will trump Alukah. I have every reason to conclude that my wife, who is a
Proverbs 31 woman, will become my Shulamith, that is, the misthological realization of the idealized Song-of-Solomon-
soulmate when God finally kicks cancer’s butt.
                                                       Conclusion
       This chapter has been lengthy, but I have not broken it up into multiple chapters because it is dealing
comprehensively with a plausible interpretation of a single verse—Jer 31:22. We may reasonably predict the
eschatological trajectory of this verse from its typological forerunners. The actions of Ruth and the Shulamite, when
taken as examples of erotic typological prophecy, suggest that in the eschatological future some women will encompass
some men in a new way already anticipated, to a limited extent, by the actions of these typological females. While
developing an argument for the validity of oral sex was by no means indispensable for the primary thesis of this book,

231
      Possibly, this led to the Jewish midrash which taught that God originally created a male and female leviathan.
Chapter 4. Secondary Biblical Confirmation                                                                        Page 133
which is that sexual pleasure between resurrected soulmates will continue in the eternal state, due diligence has been
given to this auxiliary argument because it supplies considerable artillery for a preliminary thesis of this book: Sex was
never intended to be limited to procreation. The abundant oral-genital sexual imagery certainly suggests oral-genital
sexual activity. The living water presently experienced sexually is only a foretaste of the eschatological living water that
we will drank sexually. These are deductions made from special revelation.
        In a section entitled, “Procreation Is Not the Only Purpose for Sex” (pp. 400-401), Geisler points out that sex is
intended for unification and recreation, not just procreation. One of his arguments is derived from general revelation: It
would be strange that God has designed women to be able to conceive only about 1,000 days of her entire married life.
God designed women to have strong sex drives for several decades, not just during the 3 days a month of their fertile
years. Geisler does well to draw inferences regarding the purpose of sex from general revelation. Consequently, then,
should we not also be able to draw valid inferences regarding the duration of sex from general revelation as well?
        To Geisler’s excellent designer argument, I would add a typological projection. In the very act of designing the
recreation and procreation of sex to last beyond the years of procreation, God has indicated that sex will not be limited
to marriage but be experienced beyond the resurrection. Marriage is associated with procreation. But sex between
soulmates lasts beyond the years associated with procreation and thus, typologically, beyond the years associated with
procreative marriage. The original designer argument proves that from the very beginning God never intended to limit
sex to procreation. In this derivative designer argument, in which we see what God has done with sex after the fall, we
find that God has communicated to us that sex is too fundamentally important, to what it means to us to function as His
human image bearers, to be limited to procreative marriage. Sex, by God’s derivate design, extends beyond the
procreative years. Thus, through general revelation, God has revealed to us something about the durability of sex.
Menopause spells the death of a woman’s procreative years, the death of her marriage from a purely procreative
standpoint. Yet sexual companionship with her soulmate survives such death. Should we not draw some inferences
between sex in relation to this form of death and the final form of death?
        Special revelation teaches us that general revelation has a lot to teach us about sex (Rom 1:19-27; 2:14-15).
Strangely enough, though, when it comes to what general revelation teaches us about sex outliving the death of
procreative marriage, no one is listening! Jesus said that procreative marriage will not last into the resurrected state for
the resurrected. General revelation already revealed as much! Procreative marriage does not survive menopause, as
general revelation teaches us, but sexual unification and recreation is not paused, as general revelation makes equally
clear. Sex does not even miss a beat. General revelation would teach us to expect sex between soulmates to continue after
the death of procreative marriage. Hence, general revelation would lead us to expect sex beyond the resurrection. The
typological analysis herein is in accord with the message that God has communicated to us through general revelation:
Sexual unification and recreation between soulmates will continue after the death of their procreative marriage. In other
words, sexual union will continue in Heaven.
        Gleaning from the more detailed information provided by special revelation, however, the interpretation advocated
herein goes on to postulate that male and female bodies will be transformed at the rapture and thus restored so that their
bodies are sexually capable of enrapturing their soulmates at the unprecedented levels hinted at by Scripture. In short,
sex will be better in Heaven. When restored female breasts are once again capable of enrapturing their lovers after the
rapture, the overcoming female will encompass her overcoming male in sexual passion, both orally and vaginally, at
levels previously attainable only in erotic biblical poetry. She will be overcome by passion and overcome him in passion
to such degrees that are presently only calculable at theoretical levels. Overcomers will be overcome by each other’s
love. Nonetheless, the female sex drive will tend to be stronger than the male sex drive. She will enamor her lover, even
in his sleep, bringing him to orgasm, just as Ruth did to Boaz, which probably foreshadows the action taken in the Song
of Solomon. In any case, the typological hypothesis for the Song is probable and, if correct, is a conclusive typological
confirmation of heavenly sex in the eternal state.
        What about subcomers? The thesis of the present book has been that they will be excluded from sexual intimacy.
Ruth and Boaz have been taken to foreshadow faithful believers. The Song of Solomon has been interpreted as idealizing
sexual intimacy so that it might typologically foreshadow such intimacy in Heaven for faithful believers, who will be the
kings and queens of Heaven. In juxtaposition, sexual intimacy has been denied for those in Hell and the outer darkness.
If there is any sex in Hell, it will be perverted and hellish, not pleasurable. Sex was intended for pleasure, but not for
perversion. Unbelievers who pervert it will not find it pleasurable in Hell. What about unfaithful believers who pervert
sex? Does it not seem counterintuitive to think that those who perverted sex on Earth—perhaps through adultery,
fornication, or homosexuality—will be able to still enjoy some degree of sexual pleasure in Heaven? The outer darkness
is not Hell, to be sure; nevertheless, as argued in my book TOD, there are certainly correspondences that can be made.
The rule that no one in Hell will experience sexual pleasure is not limited to those who abused sex. Correlatively, one
would expect that the lack of sexual pleasure in the outer darkness is not limited to those who abused sex. Rather, just as
anyone cast into Hell would be devoid of sexual pleasure, so anyone cast into the outer darkness would be denied sexual
Page 134                                                                                         Mongamous Sex in Heaven!
pleasure also. Accordingly, the analogy implemented herein is that being cast into the outer darkness may be likened to
being locked in a chastity belt. No sexual pleasure whatsoever is to be anticipated for those within its confines.
        When I posed this conclusion at our monthly men’s Bible study, my friend, Clint Parker, insisted that I needed to
address the question of masturbation. Specifically, he asked, if those cast into the outer darkness might not derive sexual
pleasure through masturbation. Will believers who perverted sex while on Earth be able to find at least some measure of
sexual satisfaction through masturbation while in Heaven?
        Those who believe that masturbation is necessarily sinful have recourse to an easy deduction. (1) There is no sin
in Heaven. (2) Masturbation is sin. (3) Therefore, there is no masturbation in Heaven. For those not making that
improbable premise, however, more rigorous thought is in order. Expecting to find sexual relief through masturbation
while in the outer darkness seems no more likely, correlatively, than expecting sexual relief through masturbation in Hell.
Surely those who abused their sexual liberty will not be given sexual liberty regarding masturbation, regardless as to
whether they are in the outer darkness or Hell. Moreover, Jesus associated being cast into the outer darkness with being
bound hand and foot (Mt 22:13). Granted, metaphorical language is employed. Notwithstanding, metaphorically picturing
the man cast into the outer darkness as having bound hands is certainly counterintuitive to imaging him performing a
hand job upon himself! Several possibilities might be posed as to why masturbation would not be feasible.
        First, the sexual organs of those cast into the outer darkness might not be fully functional. Male subcomers might
simply be impotent and female subcomers frigid. I find this explanation sufficient. Males who are confined to the outer
darkness could find themselves suffering from an eternal erectile dysfunction. They might have the desire to experience
sexual release through masturbation but be unable to bring themselves to this point of release for either psychological
and/or physiological reasons. Their psychological or physiological state might prevent them from being able to achieve
or maintain an erection sufficient for orgasm. Having an erection while weeping and gnashing one’s teeth over one’s
rejection is certainly not a reasonable expectation. One could not have an erection while suffering severe depression from
that state of rejection. Even after the initial shock of being cast into the outer darkness has subsided, the state of rejection
may in and of itself be enough psychologically to prevent an erection. Half in jest, Clint had asked if those in the outer
darkness could not take some form of Viagra. While it might be granted that those in the outer darkness would need some
form of heavenly Viagra to overcome their impotence, my supposition is that they would find that no such heavenly drug
is available or permissible for those in the outer darkness. Likewise, women who live in the outer darkness might simply
have no interest in self-stimulation or find it ineffective.232
        A second possibility would be to pose that those in the outer darkness will have fully functional sexual organs and
desires but be forbidden to use them. There will be no sin in Heaven. Believers will be unable to sin. If God simply were
to forbid them to engage in sexual activity, then they would be unable to do so. Perhaps a combination of the two models
will be in place. They will be unable to engage in solo sex because of the eternal regret of not having a soulmate. And
they will be unable to take a soulmate because they are prevented from doing so by divine decree. Their being forbidden
to find sexual pleasure in a soulmate will result in their having a state of mind that makes them sexually impotent and
frigid, making self-sex impossible.
        A third possibility might be posed in which they would be lacking the necessary sex organs. Males in the outer
darkness might be missing a penis and females a vagina. The Bible warns that those in the outer darkness will walk about
naked with the result that others see their shame (Rev 16:15). If taken at face value, this might mean that their sexual
organs would be exposed. Or, perhaps worse, their lack of sex organs might be exposed (see Dt 23:1 in footnote 212).
This theory would allow a limited concession to those who think that resurrected believers will be asexual in terms of
having no sex organs. This somewhat androgynous possibility might be entertained for those cast into the outer darkness.
        Regardless as to which model might prove to be correct—(1) dysfunctional sex organs or (2) prohibited functional
sex organs or (3) no sex organs—those cast into the other darkness will wish that they had fully authorized functional
sexual organs and a soulmate with which to engage sexually. They will weep and gnash their teeth at their loss. They
will have the desire but not the means to fulfil that desire. My assessment that there will be no sex for those in the outer
darkness is meant to rule out all forms of sexual pleasure, masturbation included. It is not meant to rule out sexual gender
or desire. Even if the sex organs necessary for orgasm were missing for those trapped in the outer darkness, a male would
still be a male trapped in a neutered body and a female would still be a female trapped in a neutered body.

232
    Even though the aphrodisiacs associated with heavenly sexual honey and nectar might be considered some form of
heavenly Viagra, it would be unreasonable to suppose that a male overcomer would actually need such stimulants simply
to have an erection or level-one orgasm. Nevertheless, since masturbation falls short of the ideal, male overcomers would
have no need for such a release. The sexual desires for both male and female overcomers will be fully met by their
soulmates. Masturbation, even if not a sin, would simply no longer be needed or even desirable for overcomers. Ideally,
one’s sexual desires and needs should be fully met by one’s soulmate. In Heaven this ideal will be fully realized for
overcomers.
                    Excursus on Swedenborg and Mormons
       As already mentioned, it was only after developing the thesis of this book that I became aware of the writings of
Swedenborg advocating a similar position. During the course of subsequent research, I became aware that the Mormons
also affirm marriage in Heaven. Some critics of the thesis being developed herein may try to poison the well by noting
the similarities between these groups and the argument being employed herein in regard to sex in Heaven. The fallacies
of such a criticism, other than involving a well-known logical fallacy, are several: (1) my thesis was developed before I
was aware of this questionable supporting material; (2) all truth is God’s truth, even when taught by someone with whom
we disagree on other issues; (3) the genesis of the position goes back to Genesis, not to Swedenborg or Mormons;
(4) some of the church fathers might have held somewhat analogous positions long before Swedenborg or the Mormons.
                                          Frederica Mathewes-Green
      In counseling a man who had recently lost his godly wife via death and who wanted to know if their marriage
might continue in Heaven, Frederica Mathewes-Green notes:

              Most Protestant commentators since the Reformation have not been comfortable going that far.
       However, there is an earlier strand of interpretation, from the first centuries of the church, that some
       find intriguing. It suggests that there is a special meaning to the marriage bond that continues in
       heaven, though we can’t know what it will be like. It is based on Paul’s description of marriage
       in Ephesians 5:21-33, which concludes: “This mystery is a profound one, and I am saying that it refers to
       Christ and the church.”
              Scriptures like the Ephesians passage, and Jesus’ well-known teaching that “the two will become
       one flesh” (Mark 10:8), suggest that the marriage bond has a spiritual meaning different from that of most
       earthly relationships. If so, God may preserve that mysterious quality in heaven just as he seeks to do on
       earth. But we’ll have to wait and see what form this relationship will take in eternity.233
                                                     Douglas M. Taylor
       Taylor has an article on the internet, The Ideal of Marriage to Eternity, in which he cites Swedenborg, for example,
in support. Notwithstanding, his arguments, for the most part, are well-reasoned. For example, consider this statement:

              Yet the error of supposing that there are no married partners in heaven, while very serious, is
       nonetheless understandable. If once it is supposed, as is often done, that a human being is a human being
       from his body rather than from his mind or spirit, then it is fatally easy to fall further into error, the error of
       thinking that with bodily differences erased by death, those in the other world will be neither male nor
       female. (Emphasis his.)234

Basically, this statement is a rebuttal of the ghost-in-a-machine argument debunked very well by Kreeft. Taylor
immediately continues:

       If, further, it is thought that the married state is something less than perfect, a kind of natural permission
       for the sake of the propagation of the human race on earth—if, in other words, marriage is held to be inferior
       to the state of celibacy, as has been taught for centuries and is still being taught—then it is only to be

       false and twisted ideas concerning life’s most precious jewel, a marriage of love truly conjugial,235 such

       heaven” (text). Such false assumptions distort the vision of many readers of these words, causing them to
       see things there that were never written.

       Whatever else one might say about the gift of celibacy as being preferable under certain circumstances (e.g.,

1Cor 7:7-9), it is certainly not the ideal situation or design that God had in mind before sin entered the world. One may

the physical body and spiritual body:

       Let us recall the familiar teaching that there is a spiritual body as well as a natural body, and that when the
       natural body is put off by death, we live in the spiritual body, and this is an exact replica of the mind, a
       beautiful mind being represented or manifested by a beautiful spiritual body, a masculine mind being
       manifested in a male spiritual body, a feminine mind in a female spiritual body. So it is that in the heavens
       also the conjunction of minds resulting from the conjunction of good and truth descends into the body, the
       spiritual body, the only difference being that there is, in the nature of the case, no propagation of physical
       offspring, but instead the propagation of spiritual offspring, that is, of new affections and delights belonging
       to good and truth.

        Do spiritual bodies desire food? NDErs frequently describe the pleasure they get from the food in Paradise. For
that matter, Jesus apparently confirms this to be case when He describes Lazarus being comforted in Paradise (Lk 16:25).
How was he comforted? Probably by being given food and drink in Paradise. Lazarus was being comforted by living in
comfort, having his desires for food and drink satisfied. Contextually, the contrast is between the rich man who used to
feast while in his physical body while Lazarus starved. Now, in their spiritual bodies, their roles have been reversed. The
rich man is now craving a drop of water to sooth his thirst by at least a fraction (Lk 16:24). The rich man’s spiritual body
was thirsty. His spiritual body was experiencing what we normally would consider a physical desire—something to drink.
His desire was intense even though it was a desire previously associated with his physical body. We may reasonably
suppose that Lazarus’ spiritual body was likewise subject to the desire to eat and drink. The difference was that Lazarus
was now the one feasting. The supposition is that those in spiritual bodies have the same physical desires that they did in
their physical bodies. Physical bodies are an extension of our spiritual bodies, and physical desires are an extension of
our spiritual desires.
         Why would this logical extension not also apply to our sexual desires? Since we are spiritually sexual beings who
retain our sexual gender while in our spiritual bodies, the reasonable deduction is that we also have corresponding sexual
desires while in our spiritual bodies. Those denying that we have corresponding sexual desires in Heaven certainly seem
to be inconstant when they allow that we have the other physical desires in Heaven. According to NDErs, they enjoy the
sights, sounds, tastes, and smells of their heavenly experiences. Since the desires pertaining to seeing, hearing, eating,
and smelling wonderful things in Heaven are finding fulfilment there, the natural inference is that our sexual desires will
be met as well. We were created as physical-spiritual beings with physical-spiritual desires in all these areas: sight, sound,
taste, and smell, with sex as the epitome fulfilling the sense of touch at the physical-spiritual level. Why think that these
first four desires will be granted but that we will be castrated in regard to our sexual desires? Is Heaven eternal castration?
Why suppose that God will allow us to keep our sexual gender eternally but castrate us by desexing us in regard to the
corresponding desires? So it is with a sympathetic ear that I hear Taylor go on to conclude:

              So the conclusion is that it is the general denial of anything eternal in any marriage that destroys
       conjugial love. With regard to one’s own married partner in this life, the thought that he or she is internally
       dissimilar and will not be one’s eternal partner puts an end to any conjugial love in that particular marriage.
       However, if there remains the general acknowledgment that there is marriage in the heavens, a suitable
       partner can be provided in the other life; but under no circumstances can this be done if there is a
       confirmed denial of the eternity of conjugial love; for to deny this is to deny the inmost bliss of heaven.

        Theoretically, at least in part, I believe that Taylor has overstated his case to some extent. Yes, I concur that a
suitable partner will be provided in the other life—if one has been an overcomer. But surely he is going too far to say
that anyone who disagrees with this proposition will be denied such a partner. My thesis is that all overcomers will have,
or at least can have, a complementary sexual partner. Every human being who lives in the Reward City will be qualified
to have a suitable sexual partner. Nevertheless, I do not believe that one has to agree with my thesis in order to derive the
benefit envisioned by this thesis. On the other hand, what about those who, after listening to this argument, then reject it
and insist upon eternal castration instead? Will God give them the eternal castration they insist upon in that case? Taylor
affirms that yes, in all circumstances, such believers would be deprived of a complementary sexual partner because such
rejection would be a case of “confirmed denial.” “Not so fast,” would be my response, “there may be circumstances in
which God will show them mercy.” Judgment can be merciful to those who have shown mercy, for example (Jam 2:13).
        Even so, Taylor could be correct in many cases. Regrettably, over the past few years I have become aware of some
Excurses on Swedenborg and Mormons                                                                                   Page 137
sincere believers who basically teach incipient antinomianism. They teach that everyone will be treated pretty much the
same in Heaven, if not initially, at least in eternity. Ultimately, in their opinion rewards do not really matter. To reject so

for many of the rewards that they hold in relative contempt. Sex is one such reward. Many of those who reject the thesis
of eternal sex may be deprived of sex for eternity because they have refused to follow through on the logical implications
of Scripture. If so, they will be misthological Sadducees. They will be sad you see because they will have disqualified
themselves from the experience by having denied the experience. Those who insist upon castration may be given the
castration they insist to be true. Those who transgress the doctrine of rewards too stringently could find themselves
deprived of those very rewards eternally. Those who deny that the outer darkness is a misthological consequence devoid
of sexual intimacy might find themselves cast into that very darkness because they denied what they should have affirmed.
To those whom have been given much will much be required (Lk 12:48). Those who have been given the massive amount
of data confirming misthology in my writings and yet have rejected it may find out the hard way that what has been
written is indeed true.
       The objection will be raised, “But if we will have sexual partners in Heaven, then why did Jesus not explain this
to the Sadducees or at least to His disciples?” Taylor responds to this objection at length:

               But why did not the Lord explain this to the Sadducees when they tried to trap Him with their
       question about marriage in the afterlife? Why did not the Lord explain plainly that there is certainly a
       heavenly marriage, though it differs from an earthly one? Why did He allow the Christian Church, founded
       upon the words of His Gospel, to remain in such obscurity with regard to marriage? Could He not have
       given (at that time) the unambiguous explanation He has now given in the Writings?
               No. That would have been worse than useless. The Lord in His infinite wisdom and mercy could
       perceive that mankind in general was incapable at that time of seeing such interior truths. Even the disciples,
       who were allowed to see more than the multitude, were unable to see the heavenly meaning of the parable
       of the sower, and needed to have it explained to them (see Luke 8:9). There were many things that they
       could not bear, including the doctrine about the spiritual marriage of good and truth, and the idea of a happy
       marriage to eternity. This was simply over the heads of the disciples.
               Still less could the bodily-minded Sadducees have grasped even an introductory idea of a spiritual
       marriage. They were renowned for their complete denial of the afterlife. Concerning the nature of such
       people, we read: “When a man is such that he does not believe that he will live after death, he also
       disbelieves that there is anything internal which is spiritual and celestial; and such are those who live in
       mere lusts, because they live a mere life of the body and of the world, especially those who are immersed
       in loathsome avarice” (AC 1201).
               These Sadducees were like that, and because their idea of marriage was manifestly restricted to the
       plane of the body, the concept of conjugial love, a love pure and clean above any other love of which
       mankind is capable, the concept of a spiritual kind of marriage, was quite beyond them. Even the Lord’s
       Divine wisdom itself on this subject would have been like thick darkness to their carnal minds. It was better,
       then, to let them think that there was no marriage in heaven than to have them defile the idea of a heavenly
       marriage with their gross, bodily ideas. For certain it is that there is no such thing in heaven as the kind of
       marriage the Sadducees had in mind. There is no such thing in heaven as marriage simply and solely for
       the sake of the propagation of physical offspring. The Lord’s words were literally true when applied to the
       Sadducees’ concept of marriage, and that is another reason for His speaking in the way He did. (Emphasis
       his.)

       In short, Jesus had taught: “Do not give what is holy to dogs, and do not throw your pearls before swine, lest they
trample them under their feet, and turn and tear you to pieces” (Mt 7:6). Jesus was practicing what He preached in not
casting the pearls of this truth about sexual partnership in Heaven before the Sadducees. They had rejected what light
they had, and thus they were not given more light, which is a commonly recognized consequence. As to not informing
the disciples about this truth either, Jesus and the apostles taught that they sometimes had to limit their teaching to milk
because their believing listeners were not yet ready for meat (Jn 16:12; 1Cor 3:2; Heb 5:13-14). At that point in time in
which Jesus was conducting His earthly ministry, some of Jesus’ disciples were even thinking that it was “better not to
marry” than to be stuck with a wife for the course of their physical life (Mt 19:9-10). Trying to tell His disciples that
there was a form of sexual companionship in which they would be delighted to be bound to their soulmate for all eternity
would have been like trying to explain calculus to math students who had not yet learned algebra! They were having
trouble enough picturing sexual companionship as being desirable even during the course of their earthly lives, much less
for eternity!

        Certainly, Jesus’ disciples were acquainted with the biblical proverb that teaches: “He who finds a wife finds a

better to live in a corner of a roof, than in a house shared with a contentious woman” (Prov 21:9). This proverb is even
repeated and thus stressed (Prov 25:24). Proverbs also warns: “It is better to live in a desert land, than with a contentious
and vexing woman” (Prov 21:19). In the mind of Jesus’ disciples, being bound to the same woman for eternity would
seem more like bondage than blessing: Hell rather than Heaven. They were not ready for the theological calculus being
undertaken in the present study. Notwithstanding their limited understanding and the concession that Jesus made to it at
