                            Excursus on Graded Absolutism
                                              Lying is Sometimes Justified
        A brief survey of some of the arguments for graded absolutism in Geisler’s book, Christian Ethics, may help some
readers to be more open to the possibility that the actions taken by such women as Ruth and Tamar may not be as black
and white as some people, including Geisler, would make them out to be. Recall that even Geisler admits, “Everything
is not black or white. There are real moral conflicts” (p. 88). My contention is that Ruth and Tamar fall into that category.
Geisler surveys six major ethic views in his opening chapter and takes the sixth view: graded absolutism. He gives this
summary of this view:

              Lying is sometimes right: there are higher laws. Graded absolutism holds that there are many moral
       absolutes, and they sometimes conflict. However, some laws are higher than others, so when there is an
       unavoidable conflict, it is our duty to follow the higher moral law. God does not blame us for what we
       could not avoid. Thus he exempts us from responsibility to follow the lower law in view of the overriding
       obligation to obey the higher law. Many graded absolutists believe that mercy to the innocent is a greater
       moral duty than telling truth to the guilty. Hence, they are convinced that it is right in such cases to lie
       in order to save a life. (Italics his, 20.)

        After all, “mercy triumphs over judgment” (Jam 2:13), the supreme example being the triumph of God’s mercy
over justice at the cross (p. 94).236 Therefore, the view that Geisler has presented most favorably, and holds himself, is
the one that lying is sometimes right, which apparently means sometimes justified, when it conflicts with a higher moral
law, such as showing mercy to the innocent versus telling the truth to the guilty, so that in such cases lying is a justified
means to save a life. Lying, even to saving a life, is not always right, only in certain cases. I take this as an example of
QEJTM. The means—lying—must be qualified by the particular case to determine if it is justified. The end does not
justify the means independent of its context. “The ethical context must be thought of as a whole....it is the moral context
as a whole that gives meaning to the act” (p. 91). An unquailed EJTM (UEJTM) is ruled out. EJTM must be qualified by
the specifics of the case involved to determine if a higher moral law and greater moral duty justifies lying in a particular
case. Thus, from the onset, Geisler has adopted what appears to be a QEJTM.
                                       Absolutists Often Overstate Their Case
       One strength of Geisler’s book is that he recognizes that “few positions are without any merit” (p. 27), so he seeks
to survey the strength’s and weakness of each position and be open to the positive contributions of the various positions.
I am seeking to do the same with my synthetic absolutism and in applying it to the biblical women discussed herein. For
on this very page, Geisler concedes, “Absolutists often overstate their case, acting as though they have an absolute
understanding of absolutes,” when in fact, they only “‘know in part’ (1 Cor. 3:12).” I suspect that some absolutists have
too quickly assumed that their presumed infallible understanding of absolutes absolutely rules out the possibility (1) that
Ruth could have engaged Boaz in oral sex, (2) that Tamar might have been relatively righteous in her prostitution, and
(3) that Rahab might have been justified in lying.
                                                 Geisler Overstates His Case
       After all, as an absolutist, Geisler is not immune to the shortcomings that he acknowledges are inherent within
absolutism. For he promptly proceeds to overstate his case: “The end does not justify the means; the means must justify
themselves” (p. 30). Nonsense. Lying does not justify itself! Yet lying is a means that absolutists would allow in certain
cases, if justified by certain caveats. His statement needs to be qualified: The end does not necessarily justify any and all
means in every context. Means that otherwise would be wrong must be justified by the end if those means are to be
considered right in a particular situation. Given what Geisler said about lying sometimes being justified, he should have
made some such qualification of his statement. In fact, a few pages later he will acknowledge the need for qualifications.
                                              Necessity of Qualification
       Although Geisler is opposed to situationism, he acknowledges

              it gives due value to differing circumstances...The circumstances do make a difference in the moral

236
   James gives a context to this statement. One cannot say that mercy always triumphs over judgment. James does not
make it a blanket statement, as James’ context makes clear (Jam 2:14-3:1). James does not say that mercy always triumphs
over judgment, for example. Hence, Geisler is justified to insert the word sometimes: “Mercy sometimes supersedes
justices (James 2:13)” (p. 106). The triumph of mercy over judgment is conditioned upon its context.
Page 140                                                                                         Mongamous Sex in Heaven!
       rightness or wrongness of the act....Without due stress on the conditioning influence of the moral situation,
       one’s ethics become legalistic and even inhuman.
              Indeed, as will be seen later, it is very difficult (if not impossible) to contend for a many-norm
       absolutism of any kind [as Geyser and I do], unless contextual qualifications become part of the definition
       of the norm....giving attention to the circumstances or context of ethical decisions is both unavoidable and
       desirable in elaborating a good ethical position. (Italics his, 46.)

Geisler’s argument has, therefore, led him apparently to a qualified end justifies the means (QEJTM). He concludes his
criticism of situationism, as really being a form of utilitarianism, because it ends up teaching that the end justifies the
means (p. 50). He then defers his reader to his next chapter which discusses utilitarianism. If he simply had intended to
reject an unqualified end justifies the means (UEJTM), then all would be fine and well.
                                              Absolute Rejection of EJTM
      Consistent with his criticism of competing ethical views but inconsistent with his positive description of graded
absolutism, Geisler expresses his criticism of EJTM in absolute terms when one turns to his next chapter on generalism:

               The end does not justify the means. Utilitarianism believes that the end justifies the means. But this
       is clearly wrong. Hitler’s goal to have a more perfect race was good, but his means of attaining it were evil.
       President Nixon’s goal of national security was a noble one, but the criminal and unethical activity of
       Watergate was not justified to reach it. The end never justifies the means; the means must justify
       themselves. Thus, an act is not automatically good simply because it has a good goal. The means to achieve
       it must be judged good by some objective standard of good. The road to destruction is paved with good
       intentions (Prov. 14:12). Something is not good because the intentions underlying it are good; it is good
       only if the actions are also good. (Italics his, 62.)

With such examples, however, Geisler has failed to prove his case. He has only proven that every end is not justified by
any means. He has not proven that the end never justifies means which otherwise would be unjustifiable. Lying does not
justify itself. Yet, as he has acknowledged in his opening remarks, many graded absolutists (such as himself) believe that
lying is sometimes right. But, as we know from the biblical text, to be right means to be justified, that is, declared right.237
Thus, by his own implicit admission, many within his camp would acknowledge that the end sometimes justifies the
means in that, in their assessment, the end (of showing mercy to the innocent) sometimes justifies the means (of lying).
His failure to own up to this obvious implication within his own position from the beginning hamstrings his criticism of
other positions throughout his discussion. For example, in his criticism of generalism, he will go on to state: “God wills
what is right because it is right. And it is right because it is in accord with his own unchangeable moral character” (p.
64). Granted, Geisler is rightly advocating divine essentialism over divine voluntarism with these comments.238
Nevertheless, a text like 1Kgs 22:22 certainly raises a red flag regarding Geisler’s unqualified assertion:
       19
          And Micaiah said, “Therefore, hear the word of the Lord. I saw the Lord sitting on His throne, and all
       the host of heaven standing by Him on His right and on His left. 20 And the Lord said, ‘Who will deceive
       [pathah] Ahab to go up and fall at Ramoth-gilead?’ And one said this while another said that. 21 Then a
       spirit came forward and stood before the Lord and said, ‘I will deceive [pathah] him.’ 22 And the Lord said
       to him, ‘How?’ And he said, ‘I will go out and be a lying [Heb., sheqer; Gr. pseudes] spirit in the mouth of
       all his prophets.’ Then He said, ‘You are to deceive [pathah] him and also prevail. Go and do so.’ 23 Now
       therefore, behold, the Lord has put a deceiving [Heb., sheqer; Gr. pseudes] spirit in the mouth of all these
       your prophets; and the Lord has proclaimed disaster against you.” (1Kgs 22:19-23; TM)

       The irony is that, through Micaiah, the Lord is telling the truth about using a lying/deceiving spirit, knowing full
well that He will not be believed. Some popular attempts to reconcile this text with God’s nature are woefully

237
    Dikaioo is the biblical word for justify and means to declare right/righteous (cp. Rom 3:4,20). Dikaios is the biblical

    Divine voluntarism asserts that something is right and good because God wills it. Divine Essentialism, in contrast,
asserts that God wills something because it is good and right, because it is in accordance with the essence of His
immutable good nature. If a strict dichotomy must be maintained, then I opt for divine essentialism over divine
voluntarism (cp. Geisler, 121). However, could it be that divine voluntarism is sometimes right? Could divine
essentialism be the end that sometimes justifies divine voluntarism as the appropriate means? After all, even Geisler
admits: “There is an element of truth within each view” (p. 121). “There is even some truth to voluntarism” (p. 122).

unconvincing. For instance, some would say that the text is merely anthropomorphic, not describing things as they really
are. God only seems responsible, but in reality He was not really responsible for what this lying spirit did because He did
not do it Himself. To be sure, God cannot lie (Tit 1:2; Heb 6:18) and, by logical extension, Scripture cannot lie because
it is God’s word (cp. Prov 30:5; Jn 17:17). Even so, this means that God has told the truth in this passage about using and
endorsing lying means through a secondary party. While some unqualified absolutists would point out that God can use
deception without necessarily using lying (p. 72), this explanation only suffices in a limited number of cases, such as
using troop maneuvers (e.g., Josh 8:1-22) or complexity and duality (e.g., Gog and Magog, discussed below). In the
present text, however, I have translated sheqer/pseudes as lying in v. 22 and deceiving in v. 23. Lying will be part of their
deception. Another equally vain attempt to evade the clear meaning of this text is to say that because the word pathah
means seduce, God uses seduction rather than deception. This explanation fails because, according to the passage, God
uses deception as His means for seduction on this occasion, not to mention that a number of translations render pathah
as some form of deception in this passage (DRA, GWN, LXE, NAB). Not believing that God uses deception can have
tragic consequences. Ahab refused to believe that God had used a lying spirit to deceive him—and it cost him his life!
God deceived these false prophets. Ezekiel makes this quite clear: “And if the prophet is deceived [pathah] and speaks a
word, I, the Lord, have deceived [pathah] that prophet, and I will stretch out my hand against him and will destroy him
from the midst of my people Israel” (Eze 14:9; ESV). God does not lie, but He can use a lie told by others in order to
deceive. “The Lord has sent among them a spirit of error” (Is 19:14; BBE). In the last days, “God will send upon them
the operation of deception, that they may believe a lie” (2Thess 2:11; MRD). “God will cause them to be greatly deceived”
(NLT). “God is sending them a deceiving power” (NAB). God is not the active agent in the deception, which is an
important point, to be sure, but He nevertheless does use intermediate agents and means to accomplish His objectives.
        In a scholastic article devoted to this passage, Harris observes: “For God to send some element of deception is not
exactly equivalent to God actively deceiving. He sends someone or something which deceives; He Himself is not named
as the deceiver.”239 God is not the active deceiver, but He employs deception. As for Ahab, Harris notes:

              God sent a spirit to counsel Ahab to take the wrong course of action Ahab had already decided to
       take. God did not lure Ahab into sin, nor did God entice him to change his intentions. Simply put, God did
       not lead Ahab into sin. Ahab had already determined what he intended do; he was simply looking for
       religious permission to pursue his own course of action, and even that permission came only because of the
       request of Jehoshaphat....
              ....Ahab did not believe God’s revealed truth but instead readily accepted multiple sources of
       falsehood. Ironically, God then used “other truth” Ahab had chosen as a means of judgment against him.
       (p. 81.)

Ahab already had determined to give himself over to falsehood. He was given more of the same. As in the case of God
hardening Pharaoh’s heart after Pharaoh already had repeatedly hardened himself, God gave Ahab over to falsehood after
he had already done so himself via multiple sources. In theological circles, we could call God’s hardening of Pharaoh a
judicial hardening, a hardening he brought upon himself as a righteous judgment from God.
       As to the prophets in Eze 14:9, Harris likewise observes:

              God not only set forth His truth of pending judgment, He also identified and denounced the false
       prophets of Israel whom the people foolishly respected and revered. God revealed that such false prophets
       prophesied from their own inspiration, even though they presented their message as originating with Him
       (13:2).... Whereas the false prophets may have previously deceived the nation by not being detected
       (although this is not certain), such an argument could no longer be made after Ezekiel 13. (p. 82.)

       These prophets and the people whom they duped were reaping what they sowed. Even though God deceived them,
He did so as a means of judicial deception: “When a false prophet is enticed into compromising with idolaters, the Lord
will deceive him as a means of judgment” (p. 83). Pertaining to a similar text in Rom 1:18-32, Harris reiterates the judicial
nature of the hardening: “The text presents the judicial standard according to which God turns over those who devolve
from blatant sin into an even deeper bondage of sin” (p. 84). In each case, the judicial nature of the deception is apparent:
“God’s use of deception is never capriciously wrought but rather is reserved for those who blatantly turn away from His
declared truth and replace it with something or someone they deem truthful. In each case an open rejection of God and
rebellion against Him occurs after He has revealed His truth” (pp. 84-85). In short, those who give themselves over to

       In fact, God deceives Satan, the master deceiver, within the passages of Scripture no less. Heiser makes this point

did not discern that the death of the messiah was the redemption plan [1Cor 2:8]” (p. 279, n. 5). “Jesus has baited them

hanging Jesus on the cross, they hung themselves. Gilbert likewise surmises: “Like a good military commander who does
not give his strategy to the enemy, God obscured the prophecies of Jesus’ first coming.”240
       Jesus caught Satan and his fallen forces by surprise in His first coming. He will do so again in His second coming,
as Berner explains: “Not only will the timing of the rapture catch the church and the world by surprise. It will catch Satan
by surprise” (p. 33). Even more remarkably, God purposefully has created a duality between the commencement and
climax of the Day of the Lord via similarities (p. 188) and double references in prophetic shortening (p. 192) so as to
intentionally confuse and con even Israel:

               The beginning and the ending of the Time of the End have many similarities that are designed by
       God to confuse Israel into accepting the beginning of the end as the fulfillment of prophecies which really

       brought back to the God of its fathers. Israel must be set up and forced to make a national decision regarding
       its Messiah. Israel failed to recognize Jesus as God’s Messiah when He came, exactly as scheduled, in
       fulfillment of the prophecy of Daniel 9. Israel will be presented with another Messiah. Will Israel recognize
       the falseness of his claim?241

               The similarities between Gog and Magog and Armageddon will actually foster the worldwide belief
       that the destruction of Gog and Magog by God will be the fulfillment of Armageddon. In a partial way Gog
       serves as a false antichrist—whose destruction by God makes it appear to Israel, to the apostate Christian
       church, and to the nations of the world, that the Antichrist has been defeated—Peace has come at last!
       The invasion of Gog and Magog will serve as a false Armageddon. Thus, Israel and the world will be
       primed for the coming of a false Messiah and a false Messianic Kingdom. (pp. 347-348.)

prophecy would play out as He planned it—God knew what obstacles and barriers to understanding Ezekiel’s prophecy

What purpose does it serve to have this paradox of word usage?”242 He goes on to explain at length:

        God will manipulate end-time events by defeating Gog in such a way so as to make Israel and the apostate church
think that the Antichrist has been defeated and that the time of peace associated with the millennial kingdom has
commenced and that the messiah who steps forward at that time is the true Messiah. They will be deceived by God into
thinking that the Antichrist is Christ. This deception by God is a righteous deception not merely because it is by God but
because it is a judicial deception. The end—which in this context is expressing a richly deserved judgment—justifies the
means of using deception. The means is qualified by contextual consideration and is considered justified for this reason.
In fact, Geisler admits, “Graded absolutism may be called qualified absolutism or contextual absolutism, as some
call it” (p. 107). Qualified absolutism is in reality QEJTM. Geisler, unfortunately, would reject this articulation of a
qualified EJTM because he never has anything good to say about EJTM. He denounces it repeatedly (see also pp. 85,181-
182, 185-186, 196). Nevertheless, he certainly seems to believe that the use of lying can be justified in certain
circumstances, such as in the case of Rahab:

         Augustine says that God blessed the mercy but not the lie. However, it was by means of the lie that
         Rahab’s mercy was expressed and the spies were saved. The same is true of the Hebrew midwives’ lie
         (Exod. 1:15-16). There was no actual separation between the lie and the act of mercy. And a mere
         formal distinction will not suffice as an explanation, since in actuality there was only one act (which
         included the lie) under consideration, and this act was praised by God. (p. 75)

       According to Geisler’s statement here, God praised Rahab’s act—of showing mercy via lying. God praised both
her end (showing mercy) and her means (lying). When Geisler reaches his chapter on graded absolutism (GA), he makes
his defense of Rahab’s lie even more explicit: “The Bible indicates that there are occasions when intentionally falsifying
(lying) is justifiable.....God blessed her [Rahab] because of the deception, not in spite of it. Hence, her ‘lie’ was an integral
part of her faith, for which God commended her (Heb. 11:31; Jam 2:25)” (p. 105). If this is not an example of the end
contextually justifying the means, then what is it? In my opinion, Geisler’s explanation fails to resolve the dilemma that
he put himself in with his opening arguments.

                In this respect, graded absolutism is similar to the principle of double effect, which states that when
         two results—a good result and an evil result—emerge from one act, the individual is held responsible only
         for the intended good result and not the evil result that necessarily resulted from the good intention. For
         example, a doctor who amputates to save a life is not morally culpable for maiming but is to be morally
         praised for saving a life. (p. 110.)

        Does a good end justify an evil means as long as one has good intentions? The answer would seem to be yes, from
this simple explanation and example. This would seem tantamount to utilitarianism’s claim, however, that a well-intended
good result justifies an evil result; in short the end justifies the means (EJTM). Geisler is quick to distance himself from
that conclusion. The gist of the distinction is that EJTM is an end-centered ethic but GA is a duty-centered ethic. One
might ethnically describe it as a duty-justifies-the-means (DJTM). Geisler’s distinction is useful, but it has its
shortcomings. God also operates in this manner. In sending His Son to die for us, for instance, the Father pitted His
mercy against His justice, we might say, so that there was a hierarchy in the way these two attributes were applied to


243
      Ibid., 335.
Page 144                                                                                         Mongamous Sex in Heaven!
           244
humanity. Yet God was not doing His duty in sending His Son! He was being true to His nature, but there is no
hierarchy in His nature (essence). God made a choice that was consistent with His nature.245 Geisler says that GA does
not appeal to “greater results but the higher rule” (p. 110). But what rule was God following in deciding to send His Son
to die for us? Was He really following a rule? Or was He really seeking a greater good in terms of results, namely that
we should love and adore Him all the more? Would not the latter be the case?
        Nonetheless, in deciding to create creatures that would fall so that He would redeem them and be glorified by
those so redeemed, this does not mean that God was implementing an UEJTM. He was not forced by His nature to create
such creatures. God has free will. He did not have to choose to create us or redeem us. Yet He did have to act in accord
with His nature in creating such creatures. Accordingly, there are moral boundaries as to what God can and cannot do,
but He has a range of freedom within those boundaries. Similarly, there are moral boundaries as to what we can and
cannot do, but we have a range of freedom within those boundaries—and somethings are amoral.246 We do not have a
rule, duty, or hierarchy that dictates our every move. In certain cases, we may have a range of freedom. Therefore, even
though a GA like Geisler might condemn the actions of Tamar or be unable to contemplate the possibility that Ruth acted
sexually yet righteously, my QEJTM model allows me the freedom to consider such possibilities. QEJTM would be
informed by DJTM, but not formed by it. DJTM is one factor to be considered in considering the context of a justifiable
EJTM, but it is not the only factor. Whereas Geisler seems to want an exclusively binary model in such cases, I am
willing to entertain the inclusion of a fuzzy range of possibilities even in such cases, so that what Ruth and Tamar did
might be exemptions to the normal binary rules.247
                                                 Logical Inconsistencies
        Geisler relates an example documented by Fletcher in which a mother imprisoned in a concentration camp could
escape by becoming pregnant. So she committed, in Fletcher’s words, “sacrificial adultery” with a prison guard so that
she might become impregnated. As a result, she released and returned to her husband and children who welcomed her
(pp. 42-43). Geisler denounces her “adultery to get out of prison” (p. 106). Is he consistent in doing so?
        Let us suppose that this was the only way that she could save her life. In a discussion devoted to justifying fighting
in just wars, Geisler concludes that “we are commanded to kill if necessary to protect the innocent” (p. 235). What if we
are the innocent party? Part of his argument in this section hinges on the fact that “killing in self-defense is sometimes
necessary with violent and aggressive people (Exod. 22:2).”248 Further, he uses this self-defense text and argument to
justify a mother terminating a tubal pregnancy in order to save her own life (p. 153).249 His argues, therefore, that a
mother may kill her child (via abortion) to save her own life but that she cannot to have a child (via adultery) to save her
own life.250 Which is worse, however, killing a child to save your life or committing adultery to save your life? Was the

                                                     More Righteous
Alleged Condemnation
       An examination of Tamar requires closer scrutiny than what is provided by Geisler, who simply condemns Tamar
by ripping Gen 38:24 out of its context. According to an isolated portion of the text, “About three months later Judah
was told, ‘Tamar your daughter-in-law has been immoral. Moreover, she is pregnant by immorality.’ And Judah said,
‘Bring her out, and let her be burned’” (ESV). According to Geisler, “Judah’s incest with Tamar was condemned by God
(Gen. 38). It was called ‘immorality’ (v. 24 ESV)” (p. 265). Is Geisler correct? No! In the context, God is not the one
who is condemning the sexual liaison; rather, the informants who did not have the full facts are the ones who condemn
her! When the full facts are disclosed in the next verse, however, Judah dismisses the charge of immorality against Tamar,
for which she would have been burned to death. Instead Judah concludes, “She is more righteous than I am” (Gen 38:21).
Geisler mispresents the conclusion drawn by the context. As you read this context, contemplate these five questions:

                                          • Why did Judah lie?
                                          • Was his lie justified?
                                          • Why did Tamar lie?
                                          • Was her lie justified?
                                          • What does it mean to be more righteous?

In his retailing of the story, Andy Stanley provides a concise commentary:
             With Joseph out of the picture, Judah moved on with his life. He relocated to a town several miles
      from home, married a local woman, settled down, and started having kids. He fathered three boys: Er, Onan,
      and Shelah. When Er grew to be a man, Judah arranged his marriage to a woman named Tamar.
      Unfortunately for her, Er proved to be such an evil man that the Lord ended his life early (Gen. 38:7).
      This left the young woman widowed and childless, a desperate situation in those days.
             Ancient cultures had a tradition called levirate marriage that protected childless widows from
      poverty and destitution. According to this custom, one of the dead man’s relatives could claim his estate,
      marry his widow, take care of her, and father children with her. Usually, this would be a brother, but in
      Canaanite law, any eligible relative could fulfill this duty. So, in keeping with custom, Tamar married
      Er’s brother Onan, but he also did what was displeasing in the sight of the Lord and died (Gen.
      38:10), which put Judah’s third son, Shelah, next in line.
             At this point, Judah saw a pattern. Two sons married Tamar and promptly died. According
      to the Bible, they died as a result of their own evil, not because of Tamar. Nevertheless, Judah wasn’t
      eager to send a third son to suffer the same fate as Er and Onan. He could have refused to fulfill his
      family’s obligation by forbidding the marriage, but he had a reputation to keep. His peers would never
      excuse such a huge break with custom, and his community would have labeled him an irresponsible,
      untrustworthy scoundrel. A man who would not care for his family could not be trusted to honor his business
      contracts, and he certainly couldn’t be trusted with public office.
             Judah surveyed the situation and found a convenient loophole in the custom. Shelah, the third son,
      was too young to marry. So Judah approached Tamar with a compromise. He said, in effect, “Until Shelah
      is old enough to marry, conduct yourself like a grieving widow. Live with your father, wear the
      customary widow’s garments, and reject all other proposals of marriage. Don’t worry, I’ll take care of
      you in due time.” It sounded reasonable on the surface and helped Judah maintain his honorable public
      persona, but it was a vow he never intended to fulfill. He hoped everyone would forget the agreement as
      the years passed.
             Eventually, Shelah grew to adulthood and became eligible for marriage. Meanwhile, Tamar had
      faithfully fulfilled her part of the agreement; but Judah showed no signs of honoring his promise. In fact,
      when Judah’s own wife died, he could have fulfilled his obligation to Tamar by marrying her himself,
      but he did nothing. And by this time, Tamar found herself in a very vulnerable position: older and with
      fewer childbearing years left. She would not have the same opportunities for marriage as before. If her
      father died, she would have no means of support. So she decided to take matters into her own hands.
             Each spring, wealthy men left their homes to personally oversee the harvest of wool and to enjoy a
      time of celebration. Wine, wool, and women put rich men in an agreeable mood, so if you were going to
      collect a debt or ask someone to fulfill an obligation, this was the time and place. But Tamar didn’t intend
      to ask Judah for anything. She knew better than to rely on his integrity. Instead, she planned to give
      Judah a dose of his own deception.
             She took off her widow’s garments and dressed herself like a temple prostitute. Canaanite sheep-
      shearing festivals often involved cultic prostitution and pagan rituals to enhance fertility for the coming
      year, and Tamar knew Judah’s habits. She sat in the gateway of the little town near the shearing festival,
      knowing Judah would be there. In those days, influential men of the community sat near the main gate of a
      city, where they made business deals and decided legal matters.
             Tamar’s veil prevented Judah from identifying her, and he certainly would not expect to find his
      daughter-in-law dressed like a temple prostitute. The fact that he didn’t recognize her during the
      conversation also says something about their interaction over the years. Clearly he had not stayed in touch
Excursus on Graded Absolutism                                                                                        Page 147

         to check on her welfare or to reassure her. Regardless, Judah solicited her services and they agreed that the
         price would be a goat. (Apparently, that was the going rate for that sort of thing three thousand years ago.)
                 Of course, Judah didn’t have the goat with him; he would have to send one back to her later.
         However, Tamar knew better than to trust Judah’s promise. Before agreeing to sleep with him, she
         demanded a deposit, something of value she could hold until he returned with payment. She asked for two
         items: signet, a bronze stamp worn around the neck and used to seal business transactions; and his staff, an
         ornately carved, utterly unique personal possession. In today’s terms, this would have been like asking
         someone to leave his driver’s license or social security card as a guarantee.
                 Judah agreed.
                 A few days later Judah fulfilled his promise and sent the goat by way of a servant. But the mysterious
         prostitute was nowhere to be found. Tamar had put on her widow’s garments and returned home, leaving
         Judah’s proxy no way to find her. He asked the men of the town where he might find the temple prostitute
         who sat by the gate, but they said, “There has been no temple prostitute here.”
                 When this was reported to Judah, rather than embarrass himself and risk becoming the butt of town
         jokes, he decided to let the matter go. He would return home after the festival, order a replacement signet,
         carve a new staff, and forget the whole thing happened.
                 Three months passed. Judah’s life returned to business as usual while Tamar kept to herself. But as
         spring blossomed into summer, Tamar’s tummy began to bulge. Before long, people began talking.
         Eventually local gossip reached Judah. His daughter-in-law had “played the harlot” and she was pregnant!
                 Judah responded exactly like someone hiding a secret sin, someone pretending to be someone he’s
         not. He burned with “righteous indignation” against the sin of another while conveniently forgetting his
         own wrongdoing. He became the quintessential self-righteous judge, taking the public downfall of Tamar
         as an opportunity to conceal his own hypocrisy. He said, “My daughter-in-law has shamed my family. Let
         her be tried publicly and burned alive for her sin!”
                 How righteous Judah must have felt. How his neighbors must have sympathized with this pillar of
         their community as he endured the disgrace brought upon his house by Tamar. How utterly proper for him
         to defend his good name against the shame of his daughter-in-law’s sin!
                 But the duplicity of his response would be laughable if it wasn’t so tragic. Isn’t this the same Judah
         who plotted to kill his brother? Isn’t this the same Judah who sold his brother into slavery because killing
         him didn’t yield a profit? Isn’t this the same Judah who broke his father’s heart and let him mourn the death
         of his son for years? Isn’t this the same Judah who promised to take care of his daughter-in-law, never
         intending to keep his word, and whose dereliction almost forced her into prostitution to avoid
         poverty?
                 Knowing the entire story, we see the irony. We know something Judah and his community didn’t.
         Tamar possessed irrefutable evidence of Judah’s secret sin. Meanwhile, Tamar remained silent.
                 On the day set for her execution, men arrived at her home. As these things went, someone would
         have bound her hands together and shaved her head, and then a mob would have dragged her through the
         streets to the place of execution. But before any of that could take place, she sent a messenger to Judah.
         The message was simple: “l am with child by the man to whom these things belong. Please examine and
         see who this signet ring and cords and staff belong to.”
                 Tamar’s plan worked perfectly. By waiting until the last moment, she left Judah nowhere to hide.
         By this time a crowd had gathered to see Tamar burned for her sin. Judah would be forced to call off the
         execution and dismiss the charges. In addition, he would be forced to explain his decision. A false allegation
         of this sort was not a casual matter.
                 They soon had their answer. Judah had promised to care for his widowed daughter-in-law, yet he
         never intended to follow through. Judah had used the body of a harlot in secret, yet he publicly condemned
         his daughter-in-law for behaving like one. To keep herself from becoming destitute, Tamar had to trick
         Judah into fulfilling his promise.
                 This whole episode, as strange as it is, finally brought Judah to a turning point in his life. He could
         no longer hide behind his pillar-of-the-community public persona. He had been exposed as a hypocrite, an
         idolater, a swindler, and a liar. And he admitted as much to the community who had gathered to burn Tamar
         as a harlot. His public confession was straight to the point: “She is more righteous than l, inasmuch as I did
         not give her to my son Shelah” (Gen. 38:26 NASB). Even the bizarre lengths to which his daughter-in-law
         went to secure her future didn’t diminish the fact that her actions were more righteous than his.251

Self-Preserving Prostitution
        As Stanley relates, Tamar is committing prostitution on this occasion to avoid a life of prostitution later. When
her father died, she would be in a desperate situation: starvation or prostitution. Stanley does well in his presentation of
her moral dilemma as recorded in the biblical drama. She was thus acting out of self-preservation. But Geisler had said
that in GA, “mercy to the innocent is a greater moral duty than telling truth to the guilty....it is right in such cases to lie
in order to save a life” (p. 20). Tamar was innocent; Judah was guilty. By Geisler’s own premise, showing mercy to save
her life was a greater moral duty than telling the truth to Judah, who was guilty of not following through with his
responsibilities to provide an offspring for her that would care for her in her old age.
        When I presented this material at our Sunday School class, I went on to point out, however, that Stanley leaves
out something that is obvious in the context: Judah lied to protect the life of his only remaining son. The negative reasons
that Stanley gives for Judah lying are undoubtedly correct. Still, according to the text, the primary reason Judah lies is to
protect the life of his only remaining son, Shelah. Since Shelah had not died, we may presume his relative innocence up
until this point in time. Judah is lying to protect the life of his son who, at least at this point in the narrative, is presumed
innocent. Thus Judah is lying to protect the life of his innocent son.
Righteous Prostitution
       During our Sunday School class, Douglas Berner suggested that there is even more to this story if we were to
consult the extrabiblical texts, and in an email after class he shared these citations.252 His suggestion is well received
herein. From the biblical account in Genesis, we know that Judah’s second son, Onan, committed colitis interruptus
because his offspring would belong legally to Judah’s first-born son, Er. He did not want to shire an heir for his brother.
From the biblical account, we also know that Judah lied because he was afraid that his third son would die like his
brothers. But we do not know what sin, Er, the first born committed that caused Judah to fear that Shelah would suffer
the same fate. We learn this from the parallel maternal found in the extrabiblical book of Jasher:
                23 And in those days Judah went to the house of Shem and took Tamar the daughter of Elam,

         the son of Shem, for a wife for his first born Er. 24 And Er came to his wife Tamar, and she became
         his wife, and when he came to her he outwardly destroyed his seed, and his work was evil in the sight
         of the Lord, and the Lord slew him. 25 And it was after the death of Er, Judah’s first born, that Judah
         said unto Onan, go to thy brother’s wife and marry her as the next of kin, and raise up seed to thy
         brother. 26 And Onan took Tamar for a wife and he came to her, and Onan also did like unto the
         work of his brother, and his work was evil in the sight of the Lord, and he slew him also. 27 And when
         Onan died, Judah said unto Tamar, Remain in thy father’s house until my son Shiloh shall have grown up,
         and Judah did no more delight in Tamar, to give her unto Shiloh, for he said, Peradventure he will also
         die like his brothers. 28 And Tamar rose up and went and remained in her father’s house, and Tamar was
         in her father’s house for some time. 29 And at the revolution of the year, Aliyath the wife of Judah died; and
         Judah was comforted for his wife, and after the death of Aliyath, Judah went up with his friend Hirah to
         Timnah to shear their sheep. 30 And Tamar heard that Judah had gone up to Timnah to shear the sheep, and
         that Shiloh was grown up, and Judah did not delight in her. 31 And Tamar rose up and put off the garments
         of her widowhood, and she put a vail upon her, and she entirely covered herself, and she went and sat in
         the public thoroughfare, which is upon the road to Timnah. 32 And Judah passed and saw her and took her
         and he came to her, and she conceived by him, and at the time of being delivered, behold, there were twins
         in her womb, and he called the name of the first Perez, and the name of the second Zarah. (Jasher 45:23-32)

       Judah was probably afraid that Shelah would follow in the steps of his older two bothers and practice colitis
interruptus like they did. This does not mean that colitis interruptus in and of itself is sinful, but when done for the reasons
they were doing it, it certainly was. Like Onan, Er was killed for practicing a sinful colitis interruptus. The two accounts
complement one another. From Jasher we know that both Er and Onan had both committed colitis interruptus to keep
from impregnating Tamar. But why did Er not want to impregnate Tamar? The legal heir would have been his own,
unlike the case of Onan. The parallel account in Jubilees answers this question:
                1
                  And in the forty-fifth jubilee, in the second week, (and) in the second year, [2165 A.M.] Judah
         took for his first-born Er, a wife from the daughters of Aram, named Tamar. 2 But he hated, and did
         not lie with her, because his mother was of the daughters of Canaan, and he wished to take him a
         wife of the kinsfolk of his mother, but Judah, his father, would not permit him. 3 And this Er, the
         first-born of Judah, was wicked, and the Lord slew him. 4 And Judah said unto Onan, his brother ‘Go

       in unto thy brother’s wife and perform the duty of a husband’s brother unto her, and raise up seed unto thy
       brother.’ 5 And Onan knew that the seed would not be his, (but) his brother’s only, and he went into the

        Judah married a Canaanite. Er wanted to marry a Canaanite, but Judah would not permit it. From the biblical
narrative, this makes sense. Judah’s father, Jacob, had also been instructed by his father, Isaac: “You shall not take a wife
from the daughters of Canaan” (Gen 28:1,6; cp. 28:8). He was instructed, “Take to yourself a wife from the daughters of
Laban, your mother’s brother” (Gen 28:2). This takes us back to the previous episode in Gen 24, where Abraham
solemnly instructed his servant: “You shall not take a wife for my son [Isaac] from the daughters of the Canaanites”
(Gen 24:3). Instead, Abraham instructed his servant to go back to his home country and take a wife for Isaac from among
Abraham’s relatives (Gen 24:4,37). This takes us further back in the biblical story to the blessing and curse placed on
Shem and Canaan, respectively, because of the sin involving Canaan: “Blessed be the Lord, the God of Shem; and let
Canaan be his servant” (Gen 9:26). Shem was the ancestor of Abraham (1Chron 1:24-27). Abraham had commanded that
his son Isaac not marry a Canaanite, and in turn Isaac had commanded that his son Jacob not marry a Canaanite. They
were not to marry a Canaanite, a descendent from Canaan, but to marry a descendent from Shem instead. Why? In part
the reason was because they had correctly deduced that the promised Messiah was to be a descendent of Shem from the
prophecy of Gen 9:26. Therefore, it makes perfect sense that Judah would want his first-born son, Er, to follow suite and
marry a Shemite, just as Jasher records. Judah wanted Er to take a wife from his mother’s kinsfolk. Judah’s mother was
Leah (Gen 29:35). Judah’s father, Jacob, had married her and her sister, Rachel. Eventually, Jacob would make a cryptic
prophecy that the Messiah would come from the linage of Judah (Gen 49:10), which is naturally much more compatible
with marrying a descendent of Shem rather than Canaan, of course.
        These men—Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and Judah—were descendants of Shem and wanted their sons to marry
descendants of Shem. Judah had faltered by marrying a Canaanite, who bore his three sons. The Messianic line would
be tainted by their Canaanite mother—if things had followed their natural course. But then the providence of God stepped
in, and Judah wound up fathering a child himself through a descendant of Shem; thereby, removing the Canaanite
interjection, and retaining a pure Messianic bloodline. Who would have thought of doing such a thing? Apparently, at
least two did—God and Tamar. Er did not want to father a child through Tamar because she was a descendant of Shem.
Conversely, God did not want Er to father Tamar’s child because he was a descendent of a Canaanite. God used Er’s
prejudice against him to accomplish His own objectives, just as He did with Onan. God was orchestrating the events so
that Judah would father a child through Tamar.253
        Surely Tamar figured this out and acted in accord with God’s plan. If the male dependents of Shem could figure
out the prophetic implications of Gen 9:26, then why could the female decedents of Shem not also figure it out? Indeed,
Rebekah probably used her disgust with Canaanite wives to have Isaac send Jacob away to find a wife from the
descendants of Shem and inherit the blessing of Abraham (Gen 27:46; cp. Gen 28:1-4). Tamar was not only seeking to
save her own life but the Messianic bloodline. To be sure, some descendants of Shem—like Esau and Er—despised their
birthright (cp. Gen 25:29). But there were also godly descendants of Shem—like Jacob and Tamar—who were
determined to do whatever they could in order to qualify for that birthright, to have the Messiah born of their lineage.
        Elder does not delve into the extrabiblical texts above or all the biblical deductions made above. Nevertheless, she
does cite Judah’s account regarding Tamar, which is found in the Testaments of the Twelve Patriarchs, and at least
preserves an early Jewish tradition as to what took place:

For the reasons above, I agree with Elder’s assessment:

             Judah had long since realized his mistake in marrying a woman of Canaan, and determined that his
      sons should have wives of his own race. A Hebrew lady with a Hebrew name, Tamar, the daughter of Aram
      (signifying palm tree), was chosen by Judah for his eldest son, Er, who was the nephew of Abraham.
             These sons appear to have been addicted to all the sins and wickednesses of the Canaanites. First, Er
      died shortly after his marriage, and the next eldest son, Onan, refused to obey the Hebrew Law of the next
      eldest son by marrying his brother’s widow.
             Judah became alarmed when Onan died; we are told that the Lord ‘slew him also’. Judah now feared
      to give Tamar to his youngest son, Shelah, ‘lest peradventure he die also, as his brethren did’. Judah returned
      Tamar to her father’s house, there to await his pleasure; in the meantime his Canaanite wife, Bathshua,
      died.
             Tamar, in the belief that her father-in-law, Judah, would marry a second time a woman of
      Canaan, determined to remedy the racial descent problem in her own person. A relative of the Jacob
      household, and well aware of the necessity for racial purity in that House, Tamar embarked upon a
      course which would prevent Judah’s immediate descendants being other than Hebrew, and a very
      self-sacrificing course it was.
             It was masterly strategy which brought about the meeting of Judah with his widowed daughter-in-
      law by the wayside, as recorded in the 38th chapter of Genesis, and the pledges given by Judah, with which
      he was later confronted, put all denial beyond peradventure.
             Thus, by Tamar’s self-sacrificing action, the royal enclosure within the House of Judah was saved
      from contamination by forbidden blood stock. Tamar was well aware that in taking the course she did to
      preserve the purity of her race in the House of Judah she ran the risk of being burnt by fire....
             In the family records which were handed down from father to son, Tamar would learn of the care
      exercised to preserve purity of race; she would learn that her great ancestor, Noah, ‘was a just man and
      perfect (tamim) in his generations’ from Seth. The word tamim means whole, flawless....
             Of the four women mentioned in connection with the ancestry of our Lord: Tamar, Rahab, Ruth and
      Bathsheba, Tamar is the first to have the honour of taking a definite step for racial purity, and it was indeed
      a great tribute which Judah paid her in his pronouncement, ‘She hath been more righteous than I’
      (Gen. 38:26).255 (Emphasis hers.)

       Judah was more right than he knew when he said that Tamar was more righteous than he was. Tamar was certainly
more righteous than Judah—a lot more righteous. Judah had some level of righteousness in wanting to save the life of
his only remaining son, but Tamar was much more righteous in that she was even willing to play the role of a prostitute
and have sex with Judah in order to persevere a pure Messianic bloodline. Frankly, and contrary to Geisler, what we have
here is a case of righteous prostitution.
Degrees of Righteousness
       The phrase more righteous occurs in five texts. We have examined the first occurrence in some depth. For sake of
expediency, I will simply quote and chart the remaining occurrences. Readers are encouraged to read these texts in their
contexts. For present purposes, it suffices to remark that relative righteousness runs the gamut morally from black to
white, with shades of gray in-between, thereby strongly supporting, if not outright proving, the case for synthetic
absolutism (SA). Biblical moral relativity includes black, white, and gray.256

given their circumstances and the stakes involved. Therefore, my using these women to support my thesis that such
women may be used typologically to foreshadow sexual aggressiveness in the heavenly state finds no insurmountable

        Many commentators note a possible connection between Tamar and Ruth, both of whom were very aggressive in
their seduction, and both of whom are blessed as a result. Moreover, the narrator of Ruth makes a connection with Tamar:
“Moreover, may your house be like the house of Perez whom Tamar bore to Judah, through the offspring which the Lord
shall give you by this young woman” (Ruth 4:12). Is it mere coincidence that the blessing extended to Boaz is associated
with Tamar who was accused of playing the role of a harlot (Gen 38:24) and who was then acknowledged to be more
righteous than her accuser (Gen 38:26). It is in this context that the birth of Perez is placed (Gen 38:29). As if that irony
was not enough, Boaz’s mother was Rahab the harlot!
        Some would argue that Rahab was a widow rather than a harlot. For example, Elder (p. 45) claims that the LXX
mistranslates widow as harlot in 1Kgs 11:26:

              It is a striking fact that in the Authorized Version of the Scriptures, Jeroboam’s mother, Zeruah, is
       recorded as ‘a widow woman’ (I Kings 11:26) while in the Septuagint the word used is ‘harlot’. If the
       translators had inserted ‘widow’ in the margin opposite Rahab’s name in Joshua, Chapter 2, it would at
       once have been clear to the reader that ‘harlot’ and ‘widow’ were interchangeable terms.

        Not true! The Hebrew word almanah (widow) is properly translated as chera (widow) in the LXX. In all three OT
occurrences describing Rahab as a harlot (Josh 2:1; 6:17,25), the Hebrew word zanah (harlot) is properly translated by
the Greek LXX porne (harlot). Perhaps Elder’s faulty accusation against the LXX is attributable to the way the Hebrew
reads in Josh 2:1: “The house of a woman, a harlot, whose name was Rahab” (TM). Because the Hebrew word woman
(ishshah) in this verse can be translated as widow, Elder assumes that it should be. Nevertheless, she wrongly accuses the
LXX of mistranslation in that it correctly renders the phrase as a woman (gune) a harlot (porne). Apparently, Elder
mistook the word woman as the word translated as harlot and then found a verse where this word would be translated as
widow (i.e., 1Kgs 11:26) and then assumed that this meaning was preferable in Josh 2:1. This string of errors is bad
enough. Even worse, these errors are compounded by the fact that Josh 6:17 and 6:25 use the simple phrase Rahab the
Harlot. The NT writers confirm this phraseology (Heb 11:31; Jam 2:25). Yet Elder sweeps this evidence under the rug
with ellipses (pp. 50-51)! Speculations that Rahab was just an innkeeper have no historical basis, as even Elder admits.
        Even though I give no credibility to Elder’s arguments that Rahab was anything more than a prostitute, the
possibility must still be allowed that Elder, among others, might be right to assert that Rahab was a Jewess living in
Canaan, therefore a Canaanite only in geographical sense, not in the racial sense. According to this theory, Rahab was a
descendent of Joseph’s younger son Ephraim, whom Jacob had blessed to be greater than the older son. Joshua was of
this lineage, as was Sheerah, who had built Jewish cities in the land of Canaan long before Joshua brought their Jewish
kinsman back from across the Jordan (1Chron 20-27). This intriguing theory would allow Rahab the harlot to be identified
as the Rahab in the genealogy of Jesus without violating the prohibitions of Dt 7:1-3 and Dt 17:15. Also, it would make
sense that Joshua would send the spies to find lodging in the abode of his kinswomen who lived in the land. Elder’s
arguments in this respect are well received herein.
        Similarly, Elder argues that Ruth was not a racial Moabitess but a geographical one, a Jewess living in the land
that had been taken by the Jews living on the other side of the Jordan River. This theory would harmonize with the
injunction for the Jews not to marry racial Moabites (Num 25:1-8). For the purpose of the present book, however, I have
adopted the more commonly held view that Ruth was a racial Moabitess. Nevertheless, I find Elder’s argument attractive.
Adopting Elder’s genealogical argument would result in only negligible amendments to the arguments employed herein.
For example, even though I would not claim, in that case, that Ruth was ignorant of the Jewish laws, I would still tend to
think that the logistical mastermind behind Ruth’s marriage to Boaz was Naomi, not Ruth. Elder takes the same position.
Naomi had Ruth take actions that would secure a marriage with Boaz.
     Second, even Elder acknowledges that those translations that render Boaz as complimenting Ruth on her morality
have missed the point:

               ‘All the city of my people doth know that thou art a virtuous woman.’ This word ‘virtuous’ in the
       Hebrew is ‘chayil’ and signifies force, strength of mind or body. The Septuagint reads, ‘Thou art a woman
       of strength or power’. Boaz was not referring to any moral characteristic regarding virtue or modesty, but
       telling Ruth that not only he, but all the townsfolk of Bethlehem knew her to be a woman of courage and
       strength of purpose which had enabled her to set aside age long custom and leave her own people on the
       other side of Jordan to take up residence amongst them. (p. 65)
Page 154                                                                                       Mongamous Sex in Heaven!
        Elder is correct. Yet in making that acknowledgement, Elder has opened the door to the point already made herein.
The “strength of purpose,” for which Boaz is praising Ruth, is not limited to her publicly known transition! A double
entendre is discernable in Ruth 3:11, much as EW suggests, so that Boaz may be understood as saying that Ruth is, what
we would call in the vernacular, a dynamite of a woman because of her astonishing sexual prowess. The LXX word for
virtuous is dunamis (power). The Hebrew word is chayil, and according to Fewell and Gunn, the phrase could mean
woman of worth, woman of character, or a woman of determination, but more importantly: “The phrase, like many others
in this story, does more than it says. What he intends, what she hears, and the nuances recognized by the reader make for
many possible levels of meaning” (pp. 127-128). Adding woman of sexual prowess to that nuanced semantic range is
contextually reasonable. Even so, the text should not be limited to that one level of understanding, in accordance with
the multiple levels intended by the biblical narrator for his readers. The verse might be best translated as: “For all my
people in the city know that you are a woman of prowess” (TM). Whereas, the people know Ruth to be a woman of
courageous determination for her allegiance to Naomi, Boaz has just discovered her prowess extends just as much, even
more so (cp. v. 10), to the sexual arena.
        My argumentation herein is thus not seriously impacted by whether Ruth was a racial Moabitess. For that matter,
it does not require that Naomi be perceived as the mastermind that joined the two institutions. Linafelt had posed two
possibilities: (1) Being a Moabitess and not fully aware of the differences in the two institutions of kinsman redeemer
and Levitical marriage, Ruth made a mistake in combining the two. (2) Or Ruth intentionally combined the two “and
thereby challenging Boaz to do more than the law required or was expected by him” (p. 56). I did not follow Linafelt in
either of these propositions but rather posed that Naomi was the one who led Ruth to combine the two institutions since
Naomi, as a Jewess, would be more familiar with the Jewish perspective concerning these institutions than Ruth who was
a Moabitess. If Elder is correct, however, that Ruth was actually a racial Jewess from the land previously inhabited by
the Moabites, that is, the land just across the Jordan river that had been taken by the Jews at the conquest of those lands
back in the days when the Jews crossed the Jordan river,258 then Linafelt’s preference for the second option is plausible,
even though Elder and I have both shown a preference for regarding Naomi as the mastermind.
        If Elder is correct that Ruth was a Jewess, then we may allow the possibility that Ruth rather than Naomi is the
one who initiated the plan to combine the two institutions in order to get Boaz to take action, just as Linafelt anticipates:
“Against Naomi’s expectations Ruth is the one who tells Boaz what to do, and against the reader’s expectations Ruth is
the one who drives the plot of the story rather than Boaz” (p. 58). “She presented the two together, and now Boaz agrees
that he will pursue both” (p. 59). Ruth was the mastermind who combined the two institutions of kinsman redeemer and
Levitical marriage and took the driver’s seat, so to speak, in bringing Boaz to the point of taking the desired action.
Naomi’s half-baked plan was made a full-baked plan in Ruth’s oven. Naomi had wanted Ruth to act sexually to move
Boaz to action, even with only one institution partially supporting Ruth’s action. With a keen Jewish intellect, Ruth
combined the two institutions and even surpassed Naomi’s expectations with the aggressiveness of her vocal instructions
to Boaz. Ruth used her mouth for more than fellation when she followed up with her vocal directions. Her prowess was
seen in both, and Boaz acknowledged it.
        Although she was a Jewess, Ruth acted like a Moabitess when it came to her sexual prowess in seducing this
Jewish man (Num 25:1) during his intoxicated sleep (Gen 19:30-37). Earlier in history and the biblical narrative, the
daughters of Lot had taken sexual advantage of their sleeping father in order to become pregnant. Moab, the father of the
Moabites, was born as a result of that incapacitated rape. Later, the daughters of Moab had played the harlot in seducing
Jewish men to worship their god. Ruth was willing to take actions that might make her look like a Moabitess harlot by
acting in a manner that was arguably common to prostitution, in seeming to seek what could be misconstrued as harlot’s
wages for sex performed on the threshing floor: “For you have played the harlot, forsaking your God. You have loved
harlots’ earnings on every threshing floor” (Hosea 9:10). Yet she was not a racial Moabitess and did not share the goals
of the Moabites. With unwavering determination, Ruth had expressed her devotion to Yahweh and His people (Ruth
1:16). One may reasonably suppose, then, that she saw her actions and directions as being compatible with that expressed
devotion.
        As to the historical account concerning Boaz’s mother, Rahab the harlot, she was blessed for hiding the spies
(Josh 2:3; 6:17,23,25; Heb 11:31; Jam 2:25). Afterward, she married Salmon and gave birth to Boaz (Mt 1:5). Boaz was
no stranger to the possibility that a woman who played the role of a prostitute in certain circumstances might actually be
a woman of great faith. His mother was such a woman. And now he had just discovered that Ruth was such a woman.
She had been willing to commit what some might consider an act of prostitution in order to get the Jewish men to do

what they should have done in the first place—fulfill the Jewish institutions of kinsman redeemer and Levitical marriage.

       Although I agree with Eldredge that Ruth did not have sex with Boaz that night, in the sense of full-blown vaginal

conclusion.

              In a list that is nearly all men, Matthew mentions four women: Tamar, Rahab, Ruth, and “Uriah’s
      wife” (1:3, 5-6). (And Mary in v. 16. ) That Bathsheba goes unnamed tells you of God’s disappointment
      with her, and of his delight in these three whom he takes a notable exception to name in an otherwise all-
      male cast. Tamar, Rahab and Ruth...whoa; this will open up new horizons of “biblical femininity” for you.
      Tamar we now know. Rahab is in the “hall of fame of faith” in Hebrews 11 for committing treason. That’s
      right—she hid the spies who were coming in to scope out Jericho before battle. I’ve never heard a woman’s
      group study Tamar or Rahab. But what about Ruth? She’s often held up as a model at women’s studies and
      retreats—but not in the way that God holds her up. The book of Ruth is devoted to one question: How
      does a good woman help her man to play the man? The answer: She inspires him. She uses all she
      has as a woman to arouse him to be a man. Ruth’ as you’ll remember, is the daughter-in-law of a woman
      from Judah named Naomi. Both women have lost their husbands and are in a pretty bad way; they have no
      man looking out for them, their financial status is below the poverty line, and they are vulnerable in many
      other ways as well. Things begin to look up when Ruth catches the eye of a wealthy single man named
      Boaz. Boaz is a good man, this we know. He offers her some protection and some food. But Boaz is not
      giving Ruth what she really needs—a ring.
              So what does Ruth do? She “inspires” him. Here’s the scene: the men have been working dawn till
      dusk to bring in the barley harvest; they’ve just finished and now it’s party time. Ruth takes a bubble bath
      and puts on a knockout dress; then she waits for the right moment. That moment happens to be late in the
      evening after Boaz has finished celebrating: ‘When Boaz had finished eating and drinking and was in good
      spirits, he went over to lie down at the far end of the grain pile. Ruth approached quietly, uncovered his
      feet and lay down” (Ruth 3:7). Note the gentle phrase “good spirits.” The King James describes it as “had
      a merry heart,” a result of the wine at the party.
              There is no possible reading of this passage that is “safe” or nice.” Yes, there are folks that’ll try to
      tell you that it’s perfectly common for a beautiful single woman “in that culture” to approach a single man
      (who’s had too much to drink) in the middle of the night with no one else around (the far side of the grain
      pile) and tuck herself under the covers. They’re the same folks who’ll tell you that the Song of Solomon is
      nothing more than a “theological metaphor referring to Christ and his bride.” Ask ‘em what they do with
      passages like ‘Your stature is like that of the palm, and your breasts like clusters of fruit. I said ‘l will climb
      the palm tree; I will take hold of its fruit” (Song 7:7-8). That’s a Bible study, right?
              No, I do not think Ruth and Boaz had sex that night; I do not think anything inappropriate happened
      at all. But this is no fellowship potluck, either. I’m telling you that the church has really crippled women
      when it tells them that their beauty is vain and they are at their feminine best when they are “serving others.”
      A woman is at her best when she is being a woman. Boaz needs a little help getting going and Ruth has
      some options. [1] She can badger him: All you do is work, work. Why don’t you stand up and be a man?
      [2] She can whine about it: Boaz, pleeease burry up and marry me. [3] She can emasculate him: I thought
      you were a real man; I guess I was wrong. [4] Or she can use all she is as a woman to get him to use all
      he’s got as a man. She can arouse, inspire, energize...seduce him. Ask your man what he’d prefer.259

259
    John Eldredge, Wild at Heart: Discovering the Secret of a Man’s Soul, revised and expanded (Nashville: Thomas
Nelson, 2010), 192-194. (Italics and ellipsis his.) Incidentally, Eldredge’s above assessment is much more astute than
Stanley’s assumption (pp. 135-137). Not only did Stanley fail to perceive that in the Matthean account God implicitly

statements to draw such a conclusion (pp. 83-87): “She risked her life.” “She explained why she had risked her life to

by his opening premise: “To say someone deserves grace is a contradiction in terms. You can no more deserve grace than
Page 156                                                                                         Mongamous Sex in Heaven!




you can plan your own surprise party” (p. xiii, emphasis his). His unqualified assumption is that grace “is: Unmerited.
Unearned. Undeserved” (p. xiv). This simplistic premise applies to soteriological grace, to be sure, but it does not apply
to all forms of grace. Misthological grace is at least partially merited, earned, and deserved. Rahab attained condign grace
temporally and misthological grace eschatologically. Contrary to Stanley, she expected to be shown grace because she
showed grace. In accord with the law of reaping and sowing, she expected to reap what she sowed—grace. This is an
example of condign merit in that it is a mixture of grace and merit wherein as an expression of unmerited grace the
recipient is given the opportunity to earn merited grace. Rahab did not deserve the opportunity so save her life by risking
her life for the Lord’s cause but, having been faithful to the unmerited opportunity she was given, she did have the right
to expect that she would be shown grace because of her faith and faithfulness. She did not merit the opportunity to merit
the grace of having her life saved, in other words, but she did merit having her life saved by risking her life. For discussion
of various forms of grace see TOD and MCMC.
                      Excurses on Ruth’s Seduction of Boaz
                                                        Introduction
       Even though I have deduced that in all probability Ruth seduced and fellated Boaz, I believe EW has overstated
his argument to that effect, so I will have to call attention to some of his errors. I do not wish to overstate my case, and
uncritically using EW’s material to support my case would make me complicit in that overstatement, so I will point out
some weakness in the case as he has presented it.
                                                       Word Studies
        As a rule, I am not impressed with EW’s word studies. For example, he mistakenly says that this Hebrew word
for feet (margeloth) is only used in Ruth. Not true! He has failed to note that this word also occurs in Dan 10:6, and thus
he fails to note that his argument could lead to the absurd notion that Daniel is saying that the legs and sex organ of the
man of his vison gleamed like polished bronze. EW’s etymological analysis is correspondingly in error. Etymology has
its place, but word usage is more important. Otherwise, you run the danger of thinking that butterfly means flying butter,
which would be an argument analogous to EW’s treatment of the etymological compound for margeloth.
        Even worse, in his discussion of Ruth 3:10-14, he says that ser refers to orgasm. Earlier, concerning Ruth 3:4, he
said that ser is the Hebrew word translated what in that verse: “He will tell you what you are to do.” EW believes that
Naomi is telling Ruth that Boaz will tell her how well she was doing (or did) in bringing him to orgasm. Yet EW fails to
present a convincing case lexically. For one thing, he misspelled the word. The Hebrew word is asher, not ser. Second,
he is having to read this meaning into the word from the context. His appeal to this word is therefore misleading in that
it would lead the uninformed reader to think that his argument is supported by the word when in fact it is not. His argument
regarding this word is derived from the context, not lexicography. He overstates his case.
        Still, to be fair, EW does acknowledge that he understands tremble (Heb. harad/charad) in Ruth 3:8 as meaning
that Boaz awoke trembling from having an orgasm and ejaculating, a point that I would concede is contextually possible
and perhaps even probable, if oral sex is involved as I suspect. Nevertheless, I would not build my case upon this word,
even though I would certainly acknowledge that in his analysis of this word, Linafelt (BO) gives a reasonable conclusion:
“Given the double entendres that fill the chapter, one also should not overlook the possible sexual connotations of
shuddering and involuntary physical reactions,” which is Linafelt’s scholastic way of saying that Boaz was awakened by
an involuntary orgasm induced by Ruth.
        Similarly, EW says that according to Webster philo-andros in Tit 2:4 means “to have casual or illicit sex.” I do
not see that word in my college edition of Webster. More importantly, this is not the meaning given for philandros by
BDAG, my Geek lexicon. Granted, Webster does define philander in terms of casual sex and says that it is derived from
Greek philandros. So perhaps EW can make such s point from Webster. Even so, it does not matter. The question is,
“How was the word used in the Greek NT?” Not how it might have come to be used or abused later. For example, we get
our word dynamite from the Greek dunamis. But dunamis does not mean dynamite. Dynamite did not even exist back
then. It was not invented until much, much later. So once again, I am left to question EW’s lexical information.
        Notwithstanding, once again I am not willing to toss the baby out with the bath water. His overstating his argument
does not mean that he does not have a valid argument. For that matter, I could even allow a double entendre in Ruth 3:11
and understand, much as EW suggests, that Boaz is saying that Ruth is a dynamite of a woman because of her astonishing
sexual prowess. The LXX word for virtuous is dunamis (power). The Hebrew word is chayil, and according to Fewell
and Gunn, the phrase could mean woman of worth, woman of character, or a woman of determination, but more
importantly: “The phrase, like many others in this story, does more than it says. What he intends, what she hears, and the
nuances recognized by the reader make for many possible levels of meaning” (pp. 127-128). Adding woman of sexual
prowess to that list seems plausible enough, though I would certainly not limit the text to that one level of understanding,
in accordance with the multiple levels intended by the biblical narrator for his readers.
       Therefore, I am not blindly following EW in accepting the plausible parts of his arguments for oral sex. Despite
my strong misgivings about some of his supporting argumentation, I agree with his overall position to a considerable
extent, especially since I am able to make up for some of the deficiencies in his argument. For example, given common
sense and the plausible biblical background in SSol 8:1-2 and Ruth 3:1-4, I would not rule out the possibility that Tit 2:4
includes the idea of older women teaching younger women how to love their husbands sexually: “It is important to note
that in that day and age young girls were prepared in the knowledge of sexual matters, so they would know how to relate
to their future husbands” (Dennis, 49). Also, despite EW having missed Dan 10:6, it does not really harm his overall
argument. In fact, judging from some scholastic discussions, Dan 10:6 may strengthen his argument.
       James Moffatt apparently understood Ruth 3:7 in a manner similar to EW because Moffatt translated the words,
“uncover his waist” (MNT). Leon Morris acknowledges this is a possibility and “that feet here is a euphemism for
pudenda” (Ruth, TOTC, 286). EW says that she stripped him from his waist down. This waist-down understanding would
Page 158                                                                                       Mongamous Sex in Heaven!
work for Dan 10:6, where the ESV translates margeloth as legs rather than merely feet. Likewise, because of Dan 10:6,
NET translates Ruth 3:4 as Naomi telling Ruth to “uncover his legs” and supplies this note:

         In Dan 10:6 the word refers to the legs, or “region of the legs.” For this reason “legs” or “lower body” is
         the preferred translation (see F. W. Bush, Ruth, Esther [WBC], 152). Because “foot” is sometimes used
         euphemistically for the genitals, some feel that Ruth uncovered Boaz’s genitals. For a critique of this view
         see Bush, 153. While Ruth and Boaz did not actually have a sexual encounter at the threshing floor, there
         is no doubt that Ruth’s actions are symbolic and constitute a marriage proposal.260

       To be sure, Bush (WBC) is worthy of consultation and adds that since margeloth coordinates with arms, it certainly
means legs. Even though the NET failed to be consistent, so as to render margeloth as legs in Dan 10:6, legs is certainly
correct there as well. Thus Bush (WBC, s.v. Ruth 3:4) concludes: “Consequently, Naomi most probably means that Ruth
should uncover the lower half of Boaz’s body and lie down there close beside him, not simply ‘at his feet’ as is often
understood (e.g., Morris, 286; Hubbard, 121), so that ‘both lie beside one another as husband and wife’ (Zenger, 67).”
Then Bush admits that the action and context are laden with sexual overtones and is sexually provocative, but Bush insists
that nothing in the context suggests that feet is used as a sexual euphemism and discounts the opinion of those who
believe that sex was involved, even though double entendre and ambiguity are used to shroud what exactly happened.
                                                          Conclusion
       As discussed at length in the present book, I believe Bush is half right. Sexual intercourse did not occur that night;
they did not have sex—when sex is defined as vaginal intercourse. Boaz could say, as Bill Clinton infamously claimed,
“I did not have sexual relations with that woman.” However, when the rest of the story is told, he did have sex with her,
when oral sex is considered a form of sex, which of course it is. For Ruth to lay at Boaz’s feet (a.k.a., uncovered legs)
until morning suggests the imagery of her laying her head at his genitals until morning, after bringing him to orgasm
orally. Perhaps, as some seem to suppose, she did so by positioning her body perpendicular rather than parallel to his
body. Whether she lay between his legs for the rest of the night (with her head on his genitals until morning) or beside
his legs in either a horizontal or vertical orientation (with her head on his genitals until morning), the text would, to put
it mildly, easily accommodate an oral-sex position.
