                   Excursus on Naamah’s Seduction of Noah
                                                       Introduction
        Speculations abound as to why Noah cursed Canaan in Gen 9:20-27 for the supposed sin of his father, Ham.
Explanations of the infraction fall broadly into two groups: nonsexual and sexual. Nicholas Odhiambo has countered the
sexual interpretations in favor of a nonsexual interpretation.261 Odhiambo seeks to limit our understanding of the passage
to the literal wording of the passage. Thus he concludes that Ham accidently saw Noah naked and was cursed for reporting
his father’s nakedness rather than covering it up. Yet the very fact that Noah curses Canaan rather than Ham undercuts
Odhiambo’s entire thesis. This cryptic curse is an obvious indicator of the cryptic nature of the passage. More is afoot
than the simplistic understanding advocated by Odhiambo.
                                                       Her Tent
       Hahn and Bergsma have written an excellent article that explains the four primary sexual interpretations. They
adopt the maternal heterosexual incest theory as the most plausible explanation, according to which Ham had sex with
Noah’s wife.262 Mark Biggs has upped the ante by contending for yet a fifth sexual interpretation that is even more likely,
the paternal heterosexual incest theory, according to which Noah had sex with Ham’s wife. In my online article, I have
provided a summation of these views with some of the technical details.263 For expediency in the present discussion,
summarization of some of the key points will suffice.
              18
                  Now the sons of Noah who came out of the ark were Shem and Ham and Japheth; and Ham was
       the father of Canaan. 19 These three were the sons of Noah; and from these the whole earth was populated.
       20
          Then Noah began farming and planted a vineyard. 21 And he drank of the wine and became drunk, and
       illicitly uncovered his nakedness [galah] inside her tent [ohel]. 22 And Ham, the father of Canaan, saw
       the nakedness [ervah] of his father, and told his two brothers outside. 23 But Shem and Japheth took a
       garment and laid it upon both their shoulders and walked backward and covered the nakedness of their
       father; and their faces were turned away, so that they did not see their father's nakedness. 24 When Noah
       awoke from his wine, he knew that he had fathered [asah] his youngest son. 25 So he said, “Cursed be
       Canaan; a servant of servants he will be to his brothers.” 26 He also said, “Blessed be the Lord, the God of
       Shem; and let Canaan be his servant. 27 May God enlarge Japheth, and let him dwell in the tents of Shem;
       and let Canaan be his servant.” 28 And Noah lived three hundred and fifty years after the flood. 29 So all
       the days of Noah were nine hundred and fifty years, and he died. (Gen 9:18-29; TM)

       The hithpael of galah (uncover, make naked) in Gen 9:21 does not mean that Noah simply was laying there
uncovered and naked, as some translations erroneously translate the verse. Rather, he uncovered himself and made
himself naked. Moreover, to uncover nakedness (galah ervah) is used exclusively for illicit sexual uncovering in the OT
(Lev 18:6-8,10-19; 20:11,17-21; Eze 16:37; 22:10; 23:10,18). The Hithpael of galah in Lam 4:21 is also a parallel: “You
will become drunk and make yourself naked.” Noah made himself naked for the purpose of illicit sex and thus shared
culpability for the copulation. This illicit actively is best understood as taking place in her tent, not his tent.

         What Moses wrote is called the Kethibh (what is written). He used what would normally be considered a feminine
possessive suffix (h), thereby denoting her tent. However, Jewish readers did not think this reading was the most plausible
one, so in the margin they added a Qere (to be read) in its place. This note in the margin read his tent. And when they
added the pointing to the Kethibh in 600 A.D., they pointed it with a Holem to read his tent. The LXX also reads his tent.
The problem with this replacement is that if Moses had meant his tent, he could have said so with Alha just as he did
numerous times elsewhere: Gen 13:3; 26:25; 31:25; 33:19; Ex 33:8,10; Num 11:10 (see also Josh 7:24; Jdg 4:11; Ps 27:5).
Instead, Moses uses an ambiguous form which suggests that it was her tent (hlha). He uses this seemingly feminine
suffice in three other places as well (Gen 12:8; 13:3; 35:21). These texts are not decisively referring to her tent on these
other occasions, though, so ambiguity with a hint of femininity is probably the most we can safely affirm.
         As to the articular form, Isaac’s consummation with Rebekah in Sarah’s tent (hlhah) has the article and is pointed
with a Qames (hl'hah) rather than Holem (hl{ha); nevertheless, sometimes this form means to her in the tent (Gen 18:6),
her tent (Gen 24:67), to her in her tent (Jdg 4:18), the tent (Ex 18:7; 33:8-9; Num 11:26), and sometimes this supposedly
feminine form is equated with his tent (Josh 7:22)! Given this flexibility regarding the articular form (hlhah), can we be
so certain that the anarthrous form (hlha) would be any less flexible? Moses appears to be using a purposeful ambiguity
that is highly suggestive of Noah disrobing in her tent. The various clues lead Biggs to conclude that since this was an
illicit sexual act, Noah did not disrobe in his wife’s tent; rather, he did so in Ham’s wife’s tent. Obviously, disrobing in
his own wife’s tent would not have been a shameful affair. Therefore, the illicit act must have taken place in the tent of
another woman—Ham’s wife’s tent.
                                                          His Son
        The other translational argument I have denoted in the red font in the biblical quote above is derived from Biggs’
literal translation of Gen 9:24: “And Noah awoke from his wine, and he knew what he had yielded to himself [asah]
was his youngest son.” But should the verb asah really be translated in this manner, as Biggs suggests? It is used of God
making (creating) a child in the womb (Job 31:15; BDB). But this occurrence is used of God creating, not man
procreating. TWOT notes that make is used interchangeably in Genesis for create, but create “always connotes what only
God can do and frequently emphasizes the absolute newness of the object created,” but make is “much broader in scope,
connoting primarily the fashioning of the object with little concern for special nuances.” Yet compare the fruit tree
yielding fruit after their kind (Gen 1:11-12), which “is the first recorded account of sexual reproduction” (Biggs, 184),
thus giving the mystical meaning. According to Biggs, “the mystical meaning is established by the Principle of First
Appearances (PFA). The PFA theory asserts that the mystical meaning of a word is defined by the context of the biblical
passages in which the word is first found (Biggs, 32). However, since I personally give little weight to mystical
arguments, this particular argument by Biggs carries little weight for me. The lexical argument above for the word itself
is accordingly very weak.
        On the other hand, the sematic argument for Biggs’ position is even stronger than Biggs’ anticipates. The exact
phrase only occurs five other times. Only one time is the phrase translated had done to him (1Sam 19:18). Three times it
means made for himself (2Chron 32:27,29; SSol 3:9). As Biggs rightly notes, these three occurrences support his
argument: Noah made for himself a son (TM). Nevertheless, Biggs fails to cite the other occurrence: made for it
(Ex 37:27). Even so, this instance supports the made-for translation. Moreover, Biggs does not cite the similar phrases:
made for themselves (Gen 3:7), make for yourself (Jer 2:28; Eze 16:16-17,24). The preponderance of biblical evidence,
therefore, supporting Biggs’ made-for interpretation is even stronger than he has cited. Literally, Noah yielded for himself
a son; he made for himself a son. Less woodenly, he begot a son; or in today’s English, he fathered a son. Consequently,
preference herein will be for this translation of Gen 9:24 and accordingly for Biggs’ interpretation.
        As to extrabiblical support, Biggs appeals to 1En 106:17 as proof that Enoch prophesied that “Noah and his sons
would produce giants once again on the earth after the flood, and that this would usher in yet another round of punishment
on the earth. This is certainly a shocking revelation” (Biggs, 165-167).

              16. And this son who has been born unto you shall be left on the earth, and his three children shall be saved
              with him: when all mankind that are on the earth shall die [he and his sons shall be saved]. 17. And they
              shall produce on the earth giants not according to the spirit, but according to the flesh, and there shall be a
              great punishment on the earth, and the earth shall be cleansed from all impurity. (1En 106:16-17)

      To think that Noah was beyond being seduced, given the track record of many of the OT saints, is unrealistic.
Moses had just written that Noah was a righteous man and did not feel compelled to elaborate on the details regarding
Noah’s seduction by Ham’s wife. Yet Moses did drop enough clues to let us figure out what happened for ourselves.
                                              Parallels Between Noah and Lot
        The sexually aggressive roles of certain women in the OT, such as Lot’s daughters, have been discussed already.
(See Lot’s Daughters, 68). The symmetry between that event and this event has been perceived, in various aspects, by
other interpreters as well. Nephologists have perceived Jesus as giving a clue in Lk 17:26-30 that just as it was in the
days of Noah (when the flood destroyed the Nephilim by water) and in the days of Lot (when fire destroyed Nephilim by
fire), so it will be when the Lord returns and destroys the returning Nephilim at the conclusion of the age. The destruction
of the world by flood and by fire has been anticipated since the days of Enoch. In addition to the symmetry between these
motifs of Nephilim and judgment, we also have the post-judgment parallels in which the principle male figure who
survives the judgement is seduced by female post-judgment survivors in a surprising fashion, leading to the postulation
that just as the female encompassed the male on those post-judgment occasions so it will be in the final post-judgement
aftermath, as anticipated by Jer 31:22. That the actions of the unrighteous—in this case Naamah and Lot’s daughters—
could be used to picture the righteous actions of an eschatological Shulamith should not occasion too much surprise in
that the actions of the righteous—such as the case of Moses striking the rock the second time—can be used to picture the
unrighteous actions of apostates. Likewise, the serpent on the pole is used to picture Christ on the cross. We cannot be
so restrictive in our typology so as to fail to see the plausible connection between the post-flood results.
        Bergsma and Hahn (pp. 4-5), along with many others, have seen a sexual parallel between Noah and Lot:

                When Gen 9:20-27 is understood as a case of parent-child incest, literary links with other pericopes
         in Genesis and the rest of the Pentateuch suddenly become apparent. For example, several narrative critics
         have suggested that Gen 9:20-27 is chiastically linked to Gen 6:1-4, the story of the intercourse of the “sons
         of God” with the “daughters of men.” One story introduces the flood narrative, and the other concludes it;
         Gen 5:32 continues in Gen 9:28-29, forming an inclusio around the two stories. When Gen 9:22 is
         understood as paternal incest, it becomes clear that the two stories are united by the theme of illicit sexual
         intercourse as well.
                Likewise, Niditch, Steinmetz, Kunin, and many others see thematic links between Gen 9:20-27 and

       Gen 19:30-38, the story of Lot’s daughters and the procreation of Moab and Ammon. The similarities
       between the two pericopes are numerous: in the aftermath of a calamitous divine judgment, instigated by
       the wickedness of men—particularly sexual wickedness (cf. Gen 6:4; 19:5), which destroys the earth or a
       large part of it—an aged patriarch gets drunk, facilitating intercourse between parent and child, giving rise
       to one or more of the traditional enemies of Israel (Canaan, Moab, and Ammon). The parallels hardly seem
       coincidental. Steinmetz points out that “the parallel between the Lot story and the vineyard story supports
       the implication of a sexual violation of Noah by his son.”

       The point of departure that Bergsma and Hahn take with Steinmetz is that Bergsma and Hahn contend that it was
a sexual violation of Noah’s wife by his son. Much more likely, however, it was a sexual violation of Noah by Ham’s
wife—Naamah—just as Biggs has argued at length. Just as Lot’s daughters made him drink wine and get drunk so that
they might have sex with him, Naamah got Noah drunk in her tent and seduced him so that he disrobed himself and had
sex with her. Noah fathered Canaan just as Lot fathered Moab and Ammon. These conclusions have been drawn rightfully
by others. That both Noah and Lot were subjected to incapacitated heterosexual rape in the post-judgment aftermath is a
reasonable postulation that has been made by others. I am only noting that, per Jesus, we should anticipate that just as it
was in the days of Noah and Lot so it will be again when the Lord returns and sets up His kingdom. Then, as before, the
female will encompass the male, just as Jeremiah anticipates.
                                                       Conclusion
       Building upon the observations by others, the present book has hypothesized that just as it was in the days of Noah
and Lot sexually, so it will be when the Lord returns. Sexually, Nephilim were produced, and righteous men were
seduced.272 That much has been anticipated by others. What I am adding is the possibility that, when the old things pass
away and all things become new, the incestuous sexual encompassing by Naamah and Lot’s daughters will be replaced
by the righteous sexual encompassing by the Shulamith. Unrighteous encompassing will be replaced by righteous
encompassing. Lot offered his virgin daughters to the Sodomites to be raped by them (Gen 19:7-8). Instead, his virgin
daughters raped him. Noah likewise was virtually raped by Naamah. Although he disrobed himself, one might argue that
what actually occurred was incapacitated rape. Such unrighteous rape will be replaced by righteous rape—if we call it
that—when the female takes charge and has her way with her lover by intoxicating him with her new wine. She will have
the right to use the wine of her mouth, breasts, and vulva to seduce her heavenly soulmate.

                                                      Introduction
       In Part Two of his “The Seven Mountains of Prophecy,” Gilbert mentioned that the Ubaid culture made serpentine
figurines that included female serpentine figures carrying babies, which would have been a mammal rather than
serpentine association, in a preflood location associated with a temple to the god of the abyss.273 Gilbert concluded that
presentation by noting that the Greek word huios in Heb 2:10, which is normally translated as sons, actually “means sons
and daughters” (1:23:47).
                             Illustration 44. Snake Goddess and Suckling Serpentine Child




        Gilbert’s statements were tantalizing. So I inquired if he might have made a connection in this regard between the
sons and daughters of God: Might human daughters of God replace fallen angelic daughters of God, for example, when
the faithful human sons and daughters of God replace fallen angels as the rulers of this world? As to the snake goddess
figurine with the suckling child, I stated: “My working hypothesis is that she is a goddess (a fallen angel of the serpentine
variety) who has given birth to a Nephilim.” He found my suggestion intriguing, but he was still fleshing out his
presentation for his book, which is the reason he had not ventured his own hypothesis as to the import of the serpentine
figurines in his presentation. He replied, “My sense is that you’re right, but we can only speculate because the Ubaids
didn’t leave written records.” Even so, he added, “I have no doubt goddesses manifested themselves to the ancient
world.”274 I will look forwarded to Gilbert fleshing out this material in his own book. For now, I will simply summarize
why, in the light of the present book, I have adopted my working hypothesis stated above.
                                               Sons and Daughters of God
Greek
        Let us begin with the biblical record and the standard Greek lexicon of our day. According to BDAG, sons of men
= humans (Mk 3:28; Eph 3:5). Thus sonship is not limited to males. Sons of Abraham = believers (Gal 3:7). Likewise,
in that Galatian context, all believers, not just male believers, are sons of God (Gal 3:26; 4:6-7). Furthermore, as BDAG
also notes, being sons of God can refer to a special status among devout believers and therefore is not applied to all
believers indiscriminately (Mt 5:9,45; Lk 6:35; Rom 8:14,19).275 However, such demarcation is not based on sexual

Page 166                                                                                        Mongamous Sex in Heaven!
orientation but practical sanctification. Even in the OT, being sons of the Lord refers in a special sense to devout believers
(Dt 14:1), a reference to holy people, not just males (cp. Dt 14:2.) Being God’s sons and daughters in terms of this special
status is conditioned upon personal holiness (2Cor 6:18). As BDAG surmises, these devout believers will have “a status
akin to that of angels” (Lk 20:36).
        What about believers who lack this personal holiness and thus fail to attain this misthological status? Unfaithful
sons of the kingdom have been dealt with admirably by Chuck Missler in his book, The Kingdom, Power, & Glory (pp.
61ff). I have dealt with such issues in even much greater depth in my book, The Outer Darkness. Joseph Dillow’s book,
Final Destiny, should be consulted as well.
        Suffice it to say that God is endeavoring to bring His sons to experience the glory of kingdom rulership (Heb 2:10).
BDAG appropriately cites this verse in the lexical range pertaining to special status of sonship. Not all potential heirs of
the kingdom will inherit the kingdom, as Paul notes even in Galatians (see Gal 5:21). Such rulership is anticipated for
those believers who share the status as sons of the King in the kingdom because they have been faithful. Granted, some
translations render huios in Heb 2:10 as sons and daughters (GWN; 2011 NIV). Others render it as children (DRA; GNV;
NAB; NLT; NRS). The word sons, here, is not referring to sexuality, as such, but to status. Lexically, the writer of
Hebrews was not referring to sexuality but to regality in such statements. Believer’s retaining their misthological (and
thus regal) status as sons (i.e., kingdom heirs) is contingent upon their submission to the Lord’s discipline (Heb 12:5-8).
Experiential overcomers will be God’s sons (Rev 21:7), that is, kingdom rulers. Such rulership is certainly not limited to
male believers. Huios is used inclusively in regards to regality in such instances, as BDAG rightly delineates by not
putting these references in its lexical section where huios means a male. Notwithstanding, children is not the best
translation because, although it correctly denotes generic familial inclusiveness, it fails to convey the regal maturity
necessary for this special status. Such references are best translated as sons but interpreted as sons and daughters, with
the explanation that reference to sons is being used in the translation to point to status and maturity rather than sexuality.

       Dillow summarizes well: “The phrase ‘I will be his God and he will be My son’ is defined elsewhere as a statement
of special honor, not of regeneration. The Davidic Covenant promised David’s Son Solomon, ‘I will be a Father to him
and he will be a son to Me’ (2 Samuel 7:14). The intent of the phrase was to signify installation as the king” (Destiny,

in 2Cor 6:18. Regarding the NT verse, Barrett (BNTC) comments show that it is not just a double entendre but a triple:

      Actually, these son-to-Me parallels embed a double entendre inside the triple entendre: (1) Solomon—picturing both

       As to the Corinthian context, Lenski states: “This means more than ‘children’ who are dear to me. ‘Sons’ connotes
all the high rights of sonship, and ‘daughters’ does the same” (ISPFSEC). Yet practical sanctification is of extreme
importance for believers because their status as sons and daughters of the King is contingent upon their personal purity,
being separate, being clean. In fact, Garland (NAC) uses Dt 32:16-19 as a key passage to explain Paul’s explicit inclusion
of daughters in 1Cor 6:18. In the OT context, God is angry because His sons and daughters, whom He had begotten,
were sacrificing to new demonic gods, His people had forgotten Him. As a result, God spurned His regenerate OT sons
and daughters.277 In the NT counterpart, Paul is likewise concerned that God may do the same in regard to NT sons and
daughters. Garland thus concludes: “Deuteronomy 32 is therefore clearly associated in Paul’s mind as a source for
combating the problems of idolatry. Again, the quotation from the Old Testament derives from a context that attacks any
connection with idols.” Paul’s concern for the Corinthians is in the realm of misthology, not soteriology. Their regal
status and inheritance rights were at stake, not their regeneration. If they are unrighteous in their behavior, they will not
inherit the kingdom (1Cor 6:9-10; cp. Gal 5:21; Eph 5:5; 1Chron 28:6-9). They will enter the kingdom, of course, since
they are regenerate, but to inherit the kingdom requires personal holiness.
       Sons (in Dt 32:20) is a summary term for sons and daughters in (Dt 32:19). Sons is a synecdoche in which a part
is used for the whole—sons and daughters. The emphasis in the synecdoche is not on sexuality but status. All of God’s
regenerate children—females included—have the potential to qualify for inheriting the kingdom, if they live in a worthy
manner. Thus Peter urges husbands to live with their wives in an understanding way and grant them honor since their
wives are co-heirs (1Pet 3:7). In terms of regeneration, and thus potential misthological status, Paul says that believers
are “all sons of God through faith….there is neither male nor female….heirs according to promise” (Gal 3:26-29).
       For brevity’s sake, since Dillow and I address soteriological and misthological sonship at length in our writings
and are in substantial agreement regarding the basics, a list of some special-status sonship passages will suffice here:
                                       Illustration 46. Misthological Sons of God
•   Believers are to be holy people because they are sons of God (Dt 14:1-2).278
•   Believers who are peacemakers will be called sons of God (Mt 5:9).
•   Believers who love and forgive will be sons of their Father (Mt 5:44-45).
•   Believers who are led by the Spirit are sons of God (Rom 8:14).
•   Believers who suffer with Christ will be revealed in glory as sons of God (Rom 8:17-19).

•   Believers who trust the Lord will be brought to glory as sons (Heb 2:10).
•   Believers who submit to the Lord’s discipline will be God’s sons rather than illegitimate children (Heb 12:5-8).
•   Believers who overcome will inherit the rewards and be God’s sons (Rev 21:7).

       Since the term sons of God is an expression that denotes special status in the NT and is not intended to be limited
to male sexuality and since the NT builds upon the OT in making this association, we should infer that the same is true
of the OT. Sons of God, when used of special status, should not be limited to male sexuality. Heiser (Realm) touches
upon this facet of the discussion at times, such as when he says that glorified believers who rule with Christ (Rev 3:21)
are “God’s sons, his children” and that these faithful human sons of God (i.e., overcomers) will “displace the corrupted
divine sons of God” (pp. 156, 158; cp. 311-312). Yet he fails to make the obvious connection. If the expression sons of
God refers to a special status associated with regality and is not limited to masculinity when applied to humanity, then
the expression sons of God should not be limited to males when applied to angelic divinity. When the term sons of God
is used regally, it includes sons and daughters sexually. This is true at the human level. Why not at the angelic level?
After all, Heiser himself states that human imagers were to be a “mirror-council on earth” of the heavenly council
composed of angelic entities (p. 155). If we truly are a mirror image of the heavenly realm, then the term sons of God,
when used of the divine council members, and thus high ranking angels who have that special status, would include both
sons and daughters of God—both male and female angels. Faithful sons and daughters of God will replace unfaithful
sons and daughters of God in the divine council.
       As noted at length in Realm, Heiser does not like the NT translation of saints (hagioi) and would prefer that it be
translated as holy ones so that the continuity between the testaments might be more apparent and that believers might be

(a) unconditional security (2Sam 7:14-15; cp. 1Kgs 11:11-12) and (b) conditional regality (1Chron 28:6-9)—(2) Christ
(Heb 1:5), and (3) believers (2Cor 6:16-18).

that human sons and daughters will become divine sons and daughters, like the angels, is well received herein. If God’s
daughters are to become divine like angels, what is to preclude us from acknowledging the existence of female angels?
        Heiser notes that the word angel means messenger: “Fundamentally, the term describes a task performed by a
divine being, not what that a divine being is.” In a footnote he adds, “The difference between ontology (what a being is)
and function (what a being does) is easily illustrated. The word ‘human’ is an ontological term. Humans (regardless of
gender) can be doctors, lawyers, mechanics, and messengers. All those terms describe functions or tasks. The word
‘angel’ belongs to the latter classification” (Realm, 324). Might I suggest, in accordance with the above analysis, that the
same argument can be made regarding gods (elohim) and sons of God (ben elohim). The terms gods and sons of God are
not ontological terms. Rather, they are functional terms, describing roles pertaining to an elevated status regardless of
gender. In normal discourse, if a male doctor is intended, the context in which the word doctor occurs would have to
clarify the gender. Likewise, in the biblical context, if gods or sons of God refer to male angles, it would have to be made
clear by the biblical context. Angels and humans (regardless of gender) can be elohim and ben elohim. In certain biblical
contexts, I am free, even compelled, to propose that female angels and goddess are included in the terms.
                                                   Snake Goddesses
       Given (1) that the Bible uses the term elohim to refer generically to supernatural gods and goddesses (Realm, 30)
and (2) that ben elohim can refer to God’s human sons and daughters (Realm, 160, 308, 381) and (3) that at least some
of these supernatural male beings came down to mate with human females, what might we postulate regarding the ancient
figurines of snake god and goddess?
                             Illustration 47. Male and Female Snake Gods and Goddesses




      Some of these ancient figures are definitely male—lizard men. Some are just as clearly female—lizard women.
Speculations about these reptilian Annunaki abound. The male holding the scepter appears to be a ruler. This would be a
Excursus on Reptilian Goddesses                                                                                    Page 169
common, observable activity. The female breastfeeding her infant likewise would suggest a common, observable activity.
The infant also has lizard-like features and thus is assuredly her offspring. Breastfeeding is not an activity that one would
normally associate with serpentine figures, however, for this presumably observable activity. Therefore, the postulation
that these statues represent genuine flesh-and-bone creatures, not some mere Sumerian fertility symbol, is most plausible.
A ruling class of serpentine-like humanoids is a popular interpretation, in which the preflood Ubaid culture in
Mesopotamia saw lizard-like beings walking among them, ruling among them, and reproducing among them.
        To reconcile this popular speculation with the biblical data, I would hypothesize that some of the male watchers
who came to that area in the preflood era were serpentine in appearance, perhaps fallen seraphim. Since heavenly angels
cannot reproduce with one another, we may infer that fallen angels cannot reproduce with one another either, which is
why they took human mates according to Gen 6:1-4. Thus serpentine infants would not be a product of male and female
fallen angels. My rather tame proposal, comparatively speaking, is that the fallen male reptilian angels mated with human
women to produce offspring through them.279 Their fallen female counterparts mated with human men to produce
offspring through them. Before their fall, these male and female seraphim were heavenly monogamous soulmates. After
the fall, they procreated with humans in order to be able to create offspring in their own likeness. Apparently, these fallen
angels may have more than five fingers. Count the fingers in the picture for yourself and then include the thumbs. If so,
the six-figured giants in Scripture may have retained something of this genetic trait (2Sam 21:20; 1Chron 20:6).
        Even some of the more fanciful aspects of these legends are not beyond the realm of possibility. If fallen angels
had the technology to build the pyramids, then it is reasonable to conclude that they also had the technology to build
tunnels. The technology necessary to build the great pyramids and other monolithic structures appears to be beyond
anything we have even today. Yet even today we have suterrene drilling machines that can create tunnels by melting
rock. If we can do so today, then what is to prevent us from concluding that fallen angels would have been able to do so
in the past. Perhaps, instead of building an ark to escape the flood, some of them built tunnels. But one can easily read of
such underground reptilian tunnels and cites on the internet if one is interested in such speculations.280 Comparatively
speaking, my conjecture is rather modest: In the preflood era when male angels abandoned their heavenly soulmates to
mate with human women, their female soulmates also left the unseen realm to mate with human males. Both male and
female angels fell for the Luciferian temptation to become like God by creating image bearers in their own likeness.

when he postulated that some earthbound fallen angels survived the flood. See his video for his convincing documentation
of these antediluvian tunnels: True Legends: The Unholy See.

reptilian angels in Heaven. Forton’s proposal sounds reasonable.

                                                  Inclusive Sons of God
       Why are the angels called sons of God in Gen 6:1-4? Quayle gives two reasons: (1) because they “bear a family
relationship in that they were created by God and, therefore, can be viewed in a sense as being his sons,” and (2) secondly
because “angels are always referred to as being males” (Giants, 160). His first answer is correct. He second answer
provides a simple explanation as to why only male angels were involved in the sexual incursion described by Gen 6:1-4.
Occam’s Razor would dictate that we give preference to this simplistic explanation if it is able to account for all relevant
data. Unfortunately for Quayle, it does not. In fact, just a few pages later, Quayle gives a very commendable discussion
in a section entitled, “Male or Female Angels?” He quotes Mt 10:29-30 and then explains:

               On the surface this passage suggests that angels are not sexual beings. However, a closer look at it
       shows it can be interpreted in a variety of ways—with disastrous results in some cases. Some cults in the
       US and elsewhere have misused this passage to justify group sex; they claim that the verse indicates that
       angels don’t marry but do have sex with a variety of partners. Worse, it has even been employed as an
       argument that homosexual relationships will be justified in Heaven (a rather odd supposition given that
       God declared homosexual behavior punishable by death).
               At the other extreme are those that maintain the verse indicates angels are sexless. Those making
       this claim also maintain that human beings will be sexless following their resurrection.
               However, Jesus didn’t really say anything to support either of these ideas. All he said was that none
       of the angels married or were given in marriage, and that human beings would be in the same state following
       their resurrection.
               Since the sons of God were angels, and those who rebelled against God and took women as their
       wives had offspring, it is obvious that angels can have sex. Therefore, it can’t be assumed that they were
       always sexless—or at—least that they cannot transform themselves into beings that can breed with earthly
       women.
               Some have suggested that angels do not marry among themselves because they are all males.
       However, this makes the idea that human beings will be like angels after the resurrection an odd
       circumstance, unless one is willing to assume that women will be resurrected as men—something
       never hinted at in the scripture. In fact, Paul goes to great length, explaining that each person will be
       resurrected with their own body, transformed and incorruptible, but still recognizable.
               So what did Jesus mean when he said this?
               What makes the most sense is that since celestial beings are deathless, there is no need for
Excursus on Reptilian Goddesses                                                                                     Page 171
       procreation. Thus, there is no need for a marriage and children. Following the resurrection, the same will
       be true of mankind as it is now for the angels. Thus, Jesus did not say that the angels could not have sex,
       only that they had no need for it (and most likely were forbidden from it). (Italics his, 166-167).

       Quayle spends the first part of his discussion refuting the notion that angels are sexless by making several keen
observations: (1) This passage can be interpreted to mean that angels in Heaven have sex, just not the type of sex being
described in the passages. Some have twisted this to mean that monogamous heterosexual sex is ruled out in Heaven, so
they argue that other types of sex, such as homosexuality, are practiced there. I share Quayle’s distain for this misuse of
the passage and refute this misuse in my Excursus on Polygamous Sex in Heaven (p. 177). The debate among authors,
such as myself, who interpret the passage as permitting certain types of sex, pertains primarily with what type of sex is
being prohibited. In any case, Quayle is correct that the passage can be interpreted sexually rather than asexually.
(2) Quayle also rightly notes that the claim that angels are sexless is refuted by the fact that such a position would lead
to the erroneous conclusion that humans will be sexless in the resurrected state. But if humans are not sexless in the
eternal state, then neither are angels since we will be like angels in terms of sexuality. (3) Quayle next points out that the
notion of sexless angels is virtually senseless since angels had sex with human women. (4). His forth argument pertaining
to Mt 10:29-30 is highlighted in yellow because it offsets his previous explanation concerning Gen 6:1-4 highlighted in
blue. Contrary to his blue comment, angels are not always males because, according to his yellow deduction, if all angels
are males then this would imply, contrary to Scripture, that all humans will be males in the resurrected state. His yellow
comment regarding Mt 10:29-30 is correct; therefore, his blue comment pertaining to Gen 6:1-4 is incorrect.
       Even so, although Quayle reasons rightly in these four responses, in refuting erroneous interpretations of Mt 10:29-
30, his own explanation as to what Jesus actually means in this passage has weaknesses of its own. First, we may deduce
from the flow of Quayle’s argument that the most natural interpretation of Jesus’ words implies that resurrected humans
will not be sexless and that human women will not become males. Rather, resurrected women will be recognizable as
having the same sexuality in their resurrected state that they did in their physical bodies. Women will be women, in other
words. Consequently, since resurrected male and female believers will retain their masculinity and femininity in eternity,
and will be like angels in doing so, the angels whom they will be like must not be sexless or all males either. In short,
anthropomorphic angels—the angels who are most humanoid in appearance and whom we will be most like in the
resurrected state—must be male and female. We will be like such angels in being both male and female; such angels
must be both male and female. Though Quayle did not explicitly state this conclusion, it is the logical implication of his
discussion. His deductive reasoning is excellent to this point. Furthermore, Quayle’s presumption that these angels would
be forbidden to have sex most naturally suggests that they are not only capable of having sex but heterosexual sex in
particular. For homosexual sex would be a perversion against the Designer’s design for sex and thus not open for
consideration.
       At this juncture, regrettably, Quayle overstates his argument and simply assumes that angels are prohibited from
having sex. Not so! All he has demonstrated is that because angels are deathless and do not need to procreate, they will
not have procreative sex. He has not given any reason to assume that angels will not be able to have heterosexual sex
with one another. To the contrary, since he has deduced that deathless does not mean sexless and that humanlike angels
are like humans in being both male and female, he should have concluded these anthropomorphic angels are designed
like humans to have heterosexual sex, the only difference being that sex for mortal humans was designed to be
procreative. Conversely, immortal humans will be like angels in having heterosexual sex that is not procreative. Their
copulation will not result in procreation. Sexual intercourse for heterosexual immortal couples is a copulation that does
not create children and therefore does not constitute marriage. Further, since monogamy was the original design, we have
grounds for inferring that angels were similarly designed for monogamous heterosexual sex. Copulation is for couples.
       Erroneously, Quayle reasons that the angels will not have sex because they do not need for it. Wrong! Angels need
sex. How do we know? Because, per his own arguments, they were designed like humans. Humans need sex. Angels are
like humans. Therefore, angels need sex. Unlike mortal humans, however, angels do not need procreative sex. The only
way to escape this conclusion would be to assert that the only reason humans need sex is for procreation. Nonsense. Sex
was designed to do much more than meet the need for procreation.
       Quayle’s error leads to the monastic reasoning that limits the need for sex to procreation. Paul rebukes such
reasoning when he tells married couples to “stop depriving one another” sexually (1Cor 7:5). This command against
sexual deprivation is not limited to the need for sexual procreation! For that matter, it has absolutely nothing to do with
procreation. Paul’s command has everything to do with meeting one another’s sexual needs—needs not linked to
procreative sex. If we are designed as males and females to have sexual needs that have nothing to do with procreation
and if we are designed like angels, then it does not take a rocket scientist to figure out that angels were also designed
with sexual needs that have nothing to do with procreation. After the resurrection we will be like angels in that regard.
We will have sexual needs that have nothing to do with procreation. How can Quayle conclude that angels are forbidden
Page 172                                                                                       Mongamous Sex in Heaven!
from sex, when his own argument leads to the conclusion that they were designed for sex, including the desire and need
for sex? The desire of angels for sex is easily proven in Gen 6:1-4 (cp. 1Cor 11:10). Their corresponding need for sex is
reasonably inferred. Just as we desire sex because we need it (Mt 19:10-12), so we may presume that angels do so as well
because they are like us in terms of their sexuality (Mt 22:30). Angels do not have the gift of celibacy. They are not
eunuchs for the sake of the kingdom as is proven by the fact that their sex drive is so strong that some of them are willing
to risk eternal damnation because of their sex drive. Perhaps the sex drive of male angles is stronger than the sex drive
of female angels. If so, this might explain why the male angels are the ones who take the initiative in Gen 6:1-4. After
all, as just demonstrated from Quayle’s own analysis, they are not called sons because they are males. Instead, we may
deduce that they are called sons of God because they were created directly by Him to bear His image in a high position
within a hierarchal familial relationship. Evidently, the difference between angels and resurrected humans in the sexual
arena, the “new thing” (Jer 31:32), will be that the resurrected female will have a stronger sex drive than her resurrected
male counterpart. She will thus aggressively seek to encompass him sexually.
        To reiterate, a verity of terms that superficially seem to refer exclusively to masculinity are in reality understood
contextually as examples of sexual inclusivity. 281 The following examples demonstrate that an otherwise masculine word
or phrase can be used inclusively—to include both male and females in the Bible. Sons of God is a sexually inclusive
term when used of mortal humans (created in the image of angels) and immortal humans (who will be like angels sexually
in the resurrected state).

        Unless context specifies otherwise, we should not assume that sons of God is sexually exclusive when speaking
of angels. Let us reverse engineer Quayle’s argument, so to speak, by posing a hypothetical objector who says, “We will
not have sex in Heaven because we will be like angels in Heaven.” We could simply request the challenger to fill in the
blank: “Being like angels in Heaven precludes us from having sex in Heaven because angels are _____________
(asexual, manful, immortal).” As Quayle has demonstrated, challengers may find it challenging to fill in the underlying
unspoken assumption of their objection. (1) Filling in the blank with asexual will not work because we will not be sexless
in our resurrected bodies due to the continuity with our physical bodies. Plus, angels are not sexless, as is proven by male
angels having sex with earthly women. (2) Filling in the blank with manful will not work because resurrection continuity
dictates that earthly males will be resurrected males and earthly females will be resurrected females. That some angels
are male does not prove that all angels are male. Anthropomorphic angelic continuity dictates that since resurrected males
and females will be like angels sexually, angels must be male and female as well. (3) Filling in the bank with immortal
is the only option. Yet being immortal does not mean that one cannot have sex or that one does not desire sex, only that
sex is not needed for procreation. Therefore, the unspoken premise only rules out procreational sex, not recreational sex.

        In Dt 32:20, sons is obviously used inclusively of sons and daughters in Dt 32:19. Similarly, in Dt 32:17 God’s
Jewish sons and daughters were not only worshipping male elohim but also female elohim. We know this because the
idols of these false deities (referred to in Dt 32:21) were both female and male, as confirmed by archeology and other
biblical passages. Therefore, Dt 32:17 should be translated inclusively as referencing to new gods and goddesses. Given
the natural inference that these new elohim included both gods and goddesses in Dt 32:17, the reference to these elohim
in Dt 32:8, among whom the nations were divided, should be taken as sexually inclusive also. But if the reference to sons
of God in Dt 32:8 is taken as being sexually inclusive, then Ps 82:6 should be as well, and translated accordingly: “I said
‘You are gods and goddesses. And all of you are sons of the Most High. Nevertheless, you will die like humans. And fall
like any of the rulers” (Ps 82:6-7; TM). Arguments in favor of this inclusivity would include observing that holy ones, as
applied to NT believers, includes male and female overcomers. The OT affirms that when the Lord returns in judgment,
He will return with “all the holy ones” (Zech 14:5), pictured in Rev 19:14 as the heavenly armies wearing white garments
and wearing white ropes. Victorious humans will be rewarded with white garments so that they can ride in victorious
radiance with and like angels. If all means all, then it means that human-and-divine, male-and-female holy ones will
come with the Lord. Female angels would thus be included in the council of the holy ones of Ps 89:7. After all, if there
are female angels, then, per Heiser, they are part of the council in at least some capacity: “All spiritual beings are members
of the heavenly host, the divine council (1 Kgs 22:19-23), in the sense they all have some role to play” (Realm, 33, n. 8).
Some translations render holy ones as saints in Ps 89:5,7. Just as all believers, including females, are saints (holy ones),
so also all angels, including females, are saints (holy ones). But if female angels are part of the angelic council in Ps 89:7,
then they would be included in the sons of God (El) in Ps 89:6 (and thus in Ps 29:1 also). For that matter, when Job says
that God “puts no trust in His holy ones,” are we to limit God’s lack of complete trust to male angels, so as to assume
that female angels, in contrast, are completely trustworthy and hence infallible? Of course not. Female angels are just as
fallible as male angels. The reference to God charging His angels with error in Job 4:18 is likewise using masculine
language generically. Female angels are not excluded from being charged with error in Job 4:18. Yet if this is the case,
female angels should not be excluded from the holy ones in Job 5:1 or the sons of God in Job 1:6; 2:1; 38:7. Similarly,
the holy ones in Dan 4:17 could include female council members. If so, the “angelic watchers” include female angels.
Watchers, as holy ones, would be presumed to be sexually inclusive. Nothing prevents us from concluding that these
secondary passages concur with the primary passages in inferring that we will be like angels in terms of sexuality.282

                                                      Human Angels
       The overlap between humans and angels is evidenced in other ways as well. Both God’s divine and human
messengers are called angelos. John the Baptist was a human angel (Mal 3:1; Mt 11:10; Mk 1:2; Lk 7:27). Other OT
examples of human angels/messengers also occur (Hag 3:1; Mal 2:7; Is 42:19). The divine versus human nature of the
“angels of the seven churches,” depicted as stars in Rev 1:20, is highly debatable (cf. Rev 2:1,8,12,18; 3:1,5,7,14). The
approximately sixty other references to angels in Revelation are to divine beings, however. Yet divine angels do not die,
so how can these angels of the churches be exhorted to be faithful until death (Rev 2:8-10)? Commentators and translators
are divided on whether to interpret these church angels as human or supernatural beings. Understandably, some
commentators, like Govett, believe that Dan 12:3 forms the OT backdrop for describing these human messengers as stars.
His remarks are particularly adept: “Those in Daniel, however, take that place eternally: these, probationally only.”283 In
other words, this OT passage pictures rewarded overcomers “shining like the stars,” and thus like angels, a provisional
anticipation of angelification in which human angels will be in a state of glorification with misthological ramifications.
Revelation appears to be drawing on this OT background to create a human-angel composite. These believers are being
addressed like angels and exhorted to overcome so that they will shine like angels, presuming they are faithful. Both male
and female believers have the potential to overcome and thus qualify for this angelic splendor. But if such human
anthropomorphic angels are not sexless or limited to the male sex, why think that supernatural anthropomorphic angels
are sexless or limited to the male sex? Surely both types of anthropomorphic angels are comprised of males and females.
                                                     Church of Angels
        Each of the seven letters of Rev 2-3 are written to the angel of the church, and therefore to the seven angels held
accountable in the Lord’s right hand. But as you read the letters the letters, the exhortation becomes to listen to what the
Spirit says to the churches. What is written to the angels is spoken to the churches. The imagery of angelification is being
used to address the people of the church who have the potential to overcome and earn the status of being sons of God in
the end (Rev 21:7). This is the NT human counterpart of the OT divine assembly. Some of these human angels are being
faithful. Some are not. Some are fallen angels (Rev 2:5). If they do not repent of their morally fallen state, they will be
removed misthologically from this divine assembly (Rev 2:5; 3:16). Just as the OT gods were subject to death, so their
human counterparts are warned of death also (Rev 2:11,23).284 Naturally, the fact that these seven NT churches are
addressed as angels includes female believers. These human female angels are part of this NT assembly of angels and
have the potential to rule with Christ at the highest level of the divine council along with their male counterparts, which
is again indirect evidence that female angels are also part of the OT heavenly council.285

Excursus on Reptilian Goddesses                                                                                  Page 175
                                                         Conclusion
        From biblical evidence we know for certain that the expression sons of God can be used to refer to an elevated
status of human beings who will be like angels in the resurrection. Not all sons of God will have the same status, however.
At the human level, some sons of God will be put in charge varying amounts of cites: ten, five, or zero cities (Lk 19:17-
23). We may further deduce that those human sons of God who rule cities will outrank angelic sons of God. The Father
anoints the Son with gladness above the Son’s angelic companions (metochoi). Contrastively, believers have become and
remain Christ’s co-companions if they hold fast (Heb 3:14; ETM). Status in ranking for believers is dependent upon their
faithfulness, not their gender.286 Those believers who are faithful will outrank angels, and rightfully so since human
believers will be a higher order of being and compose the Bride.287
        As it applies to humans, the term sons of God is sexually inclusive of both male and female overcomers. Biblically,
we also know that physical reality is a shadow of heavenly reality. Indeed, some interpreters would contend, with
complete justification, that on many occasions earthly reality is a mirror image of the heavenly reality. Nothing precludes
us from deducing, therefore, that on some occasions the expression sons of God might be inclusive of both male and
female angels who have an elevated status, thereby affirming the existence of female archangels. Early humanity
worshipped both gods and goddesses. If we conclude that the worship of gods points to the existence of fallen male
angels, then we should be consistent and acknowledge that the worship of goddesses points to the existence of fallen
female angels.
        The archeological evidence of preflood reptilian gods and goddesses is compatible with the biblical record if we
allow that, when the male angelic gods procreated with human females in order to create offspring in their own image,
their female counterparts (angelic goddesses) procreated with human males in order to create offspring in their own image
as well.288 The figurine of a humanoid snake goddess breastfeeding an infant in her own image gives tangible evidence
that this is indeed what happened. Plus, the legends that these reptilian entities built technologically advanced tunnels
underground to escape a meteor shower is compatible with the popular opinion that God may have used a large meteor
to precipitate the flood. At the very least, such legends show that these serpentine entities were mortal, which is again
consistent with the written records that contend that the fallen watchers feared the flood and were subject to death by it.
My theory of Incarnated Sexual Compatibility and Mortality (ISCM) allows that even fallen female angels would be able
to produce offspring and thus finds support in the archeological evidence and legends supporting the existence of
goddesses.
        My rather modest conjecture is that in the preflood era when male angels left their heavenly state and estate to
mate with human women, their female soulmates also left the heavenly realm to mate with human males. Both male and
female angels fell for the Luciferian temptation to become like God by creating image bearers in their own likeness. In
the resurrection, human overcomers become like angels in the heavenly realm in that they will have heavenly soulmates.
Angels have angelic soulmates. Glorified humans will have glorified human soulmates. If the earthly is a shadow of the
heavenly reality, then it is not good for man to be alone sexually (Gen 2:18)—either on Earth or in Heaven.

the NT council counterpart and will be excluded from the marriage supper! However, since overcoming females can have

council is clearly wrongheaded. Therefore, the sexuality of these 70 elders should not be unduly pressed. Their
masculinity severs the typology to represent the sons of God. It cannot be used to prove that the sons of God are
exclusively male. Their gender serves the purpose of the typology to represent the sons of God. It does not prove that the
sons of God are necessarily masculine.

                                                       Introduction
        As I was finishing these excurses, a missionary friend who was patiently waiting for me to finish this book asked
if I had read the Sex in Heaven by Coleman.289 I had not. It had just come out at the beginning of the year. So, as a result
of the inquiry, I ordered the book to see if Coleman had anything useful to add to what I had already written. He did not.
Nevertheless, I did change the title of my book as a result. Until that time, I had entitled my rough draft as Sex in Heaven!
After reading Coleman’s book, I changed my title to Monogamous Sex in Heaven! in order to clearly distinguish my view
from that of Coleman and other writers (such as Kreeft and Ranganathan) and groups (such as Mormons and Islamists).
They advocate polygamous sex in Heaven. My arguments for monogamous sex in Heaven were already interwoven at
various places in my manuscript. Coleman’s book was particularly offensive in its advocacy of polygamous sex in
Heaven, in conjunction with other deviant forms of sexuality. Therefore, my title change was polemical in nature.
                                                Attack Against Monogamy
        Coleman finds the idea of monogamous sex in Heaven to be very offensive: “Fortunately, dishonesty, poverty,
nor monogamy will ever exist in heaven (Matthew 22:30; Mark 12:25; Luke 20:35; Revelation 21:27; 22:15)” (KL 162-
169). In contrast, I have written my book as an encouragement for those who, like myself, seek their sexual satisfaction
in the exclusivity of a monogamous relationship. Consequently, if I found Coleman’s argument persuasive, I would find
his book very discouraging. Thankfully, his arguments are so weak that taking time to refute them at length is not really
necessary. For starters, the verses he cites above do not rule out monogamous sex in Heaven. Coleman assumes that Jesus
is ruling out monogamous sex in Heaven for those who are resurrected. I contend instead that Jesus is ruling out
reproductive sex for resurrected overcomers. They will be like angels in engaging in non-reproductive sex (in a
monogamous relationship). My assessment has the advantage of being consistent with Enoch’s statement that angels
were not given wives because, as immortal beings, angels do not need to reproduce. Additionally, my model has the
advantage of explaining why in Gen 6:1-4 male angels left their heavenly soulmates to mate with human women. It was
not because female angels were ugly or less attractive than human females! Rather, it was so that they could procreate
and thus create their own image-bearers. Angels were created to mate not procreate. Johnson explains:

               According to the books of Enoch and Jubilees, in the days of Enoch’s father, Jared, the angel Azazel
         descended to earth. He wanted marriage, children, and possibly to create an empire of his own. After
         some years of success, a band of two hundred angels, led by an angel named Semyaza, descended on Mount
         Hermon intent on doing the same thing. (Angels, 23)
                                                Pragmatic Polygamy
       Coleman notes that some theologians believe that polygamy in certain areas, like Africa, is not ideal but legitimate.
For example, a man already married to multiple wives should not be expected to divorce them when he converts to
Christianity (KL 1065). Fine. Coleman is writing from Africa and about Africa, and the law of the land in Africa permits
polygamy in many of its countries. And Christians are to abide by the law of the land unless it clearly contradicts Scripture
(Rom 13:1-5).
                                             Illustration 51. Legal Polygamy




289
      Arnold David Coleman, Sex in Heaven: Boundless, Joyful Celebration!! (2016).
Page 178                                                                                       Mongamous Sex in Heaven!
        My argument for synthetic absolutism would allow me to make pragmatic concessions to polygamy in such
situations and countries. Sometimes polygamy is justified. After all, sometimes lying is justified. But this does not mean
that lying will be justified in Heaven! Therefore, it is fallacious to think that polygamy will be justified in Heaven just
because there are situations in which it is currently justified on this fallen Earth. The Bible clearly forbids polygamy for
Israel’s kings (Dt 17:17). However, as Copan (pp. 112-113) demonstrates, the OT also prohibited polygamy for the
common man as well: “Do not take a rival wife in a polygamous relation to uncover her nakedness while your wife is
living” (Lev 18:18; TM). In the NT, church leaders were to be the husbands of only one wife (1Tim 3:2,12; Tit 1:6).
Monogamy is the ideal because it goes back to the original creation model in which God made a monogamous couple.
Jesus likewise acknowledges that in certain situations the OT allowed divorce, but divorce was less than ideal because it
violated the original creation model (Mt 19:3-9; Mk 10:2-9). Nonetheless, God hates divorce (Mal 2:16). We have little
reason to suppose that He is any happier with polygamy. Both violate the original design of the Designer. We have no
more reason to think that polygamy will exist in Heaven than to think that divorce will exist in Heaven.
        I am no more inclined to trust Coleman’s arguments regarding polygamy than I am to trust his extrapolations
regarding pornography. He takes Rom 14:14 to mean that since nothing is unclean in itself, porn is not necessarily unclean
(KL 1931). I strongly disagree. Christian authors who use pencil art to illustrate sexual positions are not engaging in
Christian porn (KL 3026). Such graphic illustrations are not pornographic. Thus their artwork cannot be used as a
conceptual justification for Christian porn. Coleman only gives one restriction about porn: “The only caution about
viewing others, not knowing if the female is married or not is that one should never seek to learn the name or address of
the married woman in hopes of arranging to actually experience physical intimacy with her, (the actual definition of
lusting after another man’s wife as in the tenth commandment and in Matthew 5:28)” (KL 3067-3070). Granted, the verse
can reasonably be interpreted as dealing with intentional lust. Nevertheless, Jesus does not say that you have to intend to
get her into bed before you can be charged with adultery with her in your heart. Rather, to look on a woman in order to
intentionally produce the illicit desires to bed her condemns you as committing adultery in your heart. But enough about
porn. Much of Coleman’s book pertains to such auxiliary matters.290
        As to his fourth chapter, where Coleman actually deals with sex in Heaven, like myself he finds encouragement
in Paul’s statement: “Things which eye has not seen and ear has not heard, and which have not entered the heart of man,
all that God has prepared for those who love Him” (1Cor 2:9). In short, Heaven is going to be better than anything we
can imagine. Regrettably, the major, if not singular, component of Coleman’s argument is that this verse justifies his
assumption that Heaven will include sex. In and of itself, this argument is extremely weak. I have labored diligently in
the present book to use multiple arguments to collaborate my conclusion that sex will be enjoyed in Heaven. Not finding
anything much more than this imagination-based argument from 1Cor 2:9 in Coleman’s book to defend this thesis was
very disappointing. As to our joint anticipation regarding 1Cor 2:9, where we differ is that I do not think that just because
I can imagine it, it must be a viable option. My imagination is circumscribed by what I find to be biblically and logically
possible and permissible. His imagination is not. He entertains the possibility that we might be able to switch back and
forth between genders, or be both genders at the same time, engage in bestiality with any creature we want, and thus
procreate with animals so as to produce human-animal chimeras in Heaven! His imagined possibilities include polygamy,
homosexuality, bisexuality, and bestiality as being perfectly permissible in Heaven. My abhorrence for his imaginative
speculations caused me to retitle my book to clearly differentiate my position from his.
                                                  Perpetual Orgasms
       My imagination is much more restrained than Coleman’s. He thinks that sex in Heaven “will likely be billions of
times better” than anything on Earth (KL 2373-2374). My calculations have been much more modest. I have projected
that the maximum male orgasmic level would be a level four and the female maximum orgasmic level might be a
corresponding level twelve. Even with my comparatively conservative estimations, though, my calculations can match
some of the positive aspects of his speculations.
       Coleman poses that multiple deep throat orgasms might be possible (KL 2363). By my calculations, multiple deep
throat orgasms would not only be possible but probable. In fact, my model gives the means by which to explain how and
why. If a heavenly couple were performing mutual oral sex, then, as the male consumes her vaginal honey, his state of
arousal would be increased, allowing him to experience a level-two orgasm, which would result in her drinking a double
dose of his ambrosia, which is multiplied by her oral factor of 2, causing her to have a level-four orgasm (2 x 2 = 4).291

        As a result of eating her honey, the male would have a 30-seconds-level-two-orgasm. She, however, would have
a four-minute-level-four-orgasm as a result of drinking his level-two output. Presumably, her orgasm would not start
until after he has completed his orgasm. After all, she is busy drinking his ambrosia rather than having her own orgasm
during that time, and the drinking serves as a pleasurable aphrodisiac, increasing her desire and orgasmic response. She
would thus have her four-minute orgasm after he completes his 30-second orgasm. During the heat of the passion, if he

have her second orgasm immediately upon finishing her first orgasm, without any break between her orgasms. Her
soulmate could keep this chain of events going perpetually so that she would have nonstop, level-four orgasms
indefinitely.

                                                        Pornography
        Pornography is highly destructive and addictive. Shortly after the movie Fireproof came out in 2008, in which
Kirk Cameron depicted this destructive addiction, a Christian lawyer I knew shared with me that pornography had
destroyed his marriage. For a sense of how prevalent it is, see an interview on SkyWatchTV with Brandon Schwin that
aired as I was finishing this final excurses. The interview deals with the struggle that many Christian ministers have with
pornography.294 Coleman is a Christian minster who endorses pornography to a considerable degree. He thinks that if
he is wrong in promoting pornography, then the most that is at stake for him is his being least in the kingdom (Mt 5:19).295
He is correct that being in the kingdom is not at stake. Our presence in the kingdom is conditioned on our being a believer,
not on our behavior (Jn 3:3,16). He is wrong on two accounts, however. First, pornography is highly addictive and
destructive even in the present, and thus very dangerous for the Christian in terms of temporal consequences. Play with
fire and you may get burned. It may burn up your marriage and burn out your ability to function sexually with your
monogamous mate.
        Secondly, if I am correct and Coleman is wrong, then he is in danger of being in the outer darkness, which is a
metaphorical and parabolic way of saying, as Coleman allows, that he will be least in the kingdom. The sexual
consequence, though, according to the thesis I am presenting in this book and in accordance with my research in TOD,
is that Coleman will miss out on sexual fulfillment throughout eternity. On the other hand, if he is correct and I am wrong,
then I will have polygamous sexual fulfillment in Heaven throughout eternity. In that case, I would not have the
monogamous relationship with my soulmate that I desire, but at least I would still have a sexual relationship with her to
the degree we both mutually desire at that future point in time. Granted, this implementation of Pascal’s Wager does not
prove my position is superior, but it certainly underscores the prudence of considering the consequences of your actions
carefully. My position is the much safer course of action for both the present and future. Be sexually pure and reap
temporal and eternal benefits is my advice. Exegetically, of course, I believe my position is far superior. But if you are
struggling with pornography and are having trouble finding the means to break free, and are thus tempted to shortchange
my exegetical arguments, then consider the risk factor and Pascal’s Wager. Are you really willing to risk losing out on
eternal sexual pleasure for the sake of temporal sexual impurity?
                                                         Androgyny
      In his fictional retelling of the story of Noah in his Chronicles of the Nephilim, Godawa portrays the fallen angels
posing as the god Anu and goddess Inanna to be sexually androgynous, though dressing in gender distinctive manners:

              Despite their androgynous appearance, Inanna dressed the part of a goddess. They had elongated
       heads, which the head-binding of their servants sought to mimic. Anu and Inanna would tolerate nothing
       less than human attendants molded into their likeness. They both wore the horned headdress of deity
       common throughout the region. Both wore royal robes created from the feathers of vultures.
              Inanna cultivated a flamboyance that set her apart from Anu. She wore heavy makeup and pierced
       her body all over with rings, studs, spikes and other garish ornaments. Her nose, eyebrows, down her arms,
       and even her intimate parts often hosted these symbols of the forced pain that she pleasured in. She also
       gloried in outrageous outfits of opulence and ostentation as a display of her ironic status as goddess of sex
       and war. This day, she was more restrained with her red leather and chains of bondage and domination.
              The skin of the gods appeared smooth, but Lugalanu knew that close up fine subtle serpentine
       scales that sparkled in the light covered them, producing a visible aura of constant radiant luminescence.
       Many described this radiance in terms of beryl, crystal or shining bronze. When their passions flared for
       good or bad, their shining would increase in brilliance, giving the impression of flashes of lightning.
       Because of this, they were called Shining Ones. (p. 24)

       This “sanctifying myth,” to use the term employed by Heiser in his endorsement of Godawa’s book, has many
positive aspects. It affirms the existence of fallen angels existing in the form of both goddess and goddesses, a matter I
have proven with collaboration from a variety of sources herein. Also, Godawa at least provides some explanation for
the goddess form. Even though I cannot accept his explanation as being exhaustive, I do find it attractive to a limited
degree in light of the historical data and contemporary situation. For Gilbert makes a plausible correlation between the
transgender spirit of the age in which we live and that of Inanna, the goddess of sex and war, who was androgynous,

that accompany this sacrificial other-focused act” (p. 206).

         Notwithstanding my appreciation for such positive aspects of Godawa’s fictional retelling, the data does not allow

creature jumped out of the rocks and ran straight at Noah. It looked humanoid in shape, but had lost its distinctive identity
as human. It was androgynous, without genitals, eyes or hair” (p. 156).
         Godawa portrays the fallen angels as androgynous in their fallen form, apparently in the sense of lacking genitals.
But the fact that Godawa depicts the male god, Anu, as impregnating human women sexually in order to produce
Nephilim strains his fictional recounting. Does this male fallen angel not have male genitals in Godawa’s fictional
portrayal? After all, even he admits that these angels “left heaven, came to earth, and violated God’s separation of those
domains by having intercourse with human women” (p. 316). Sexual intercourse certainly suggests the presence of
male sexual genitals! So even though he asserts that Anu has an androgynous appearance, his discussion leads one to
conclude that Anu actually had a penis and used it to impregnate human females. How is this fallen male angel truly
androgynous in Godawa’s fictitious account? As to the seemingly female fallen angel, who Godawa also presents as
being androgynous, he asserts, “The goddesses are all males in female disguise....They are all Sons of God” (p. 147).
Really? Is asserting transvestism the best he can do for goddesses? Such position is very presumptuous and is refuted by
numerous stands of evidence. Moreover, Godawa did not need to take such a strained position. He already had laid the
framework for a very workable solution, when he said, “Along with those two hundred, a number of lesser angels or
mal’akim, the lower messengers of Elohim, also came into the world” (p. 103). He simply could have stated that these
lower messenger angels had a number of female angels in their group and that some of these female angels were acting
like goddesses. Yet, as it is, Godawa tries to pass off the reptilian gods and goddesses as being androgynous, apparently
in the sense of lacking genitals, and is refuted not only by his own fictional retelling but by archeology, as we saw in the
last excurses with pictures of snake gods and goddesses. The Ubaid culture made serpentine figurines that included male
and female serpentine figures that were clearly not androgynous in terms of anatomy. Some figurines were clearly
masculine. Others were clearly feminine. Such archeology refutes androgyny. A more robust theory of androgyny, with
better explanatory power than the simplistic androgyny portrayed by Godawa, is needed to accord for all the data.
         Various forms of androgyny are possible: (1) being neither masculine or feminine in appearance, or (2) having
both masculine and feminine characteristics, or (3) being both male and female as in the case of a hermaphroditic, or
(4) having an ambiguous sexual identity.297
         Humans born with both male and female genitalia (i.e., hermaphrodites) have been discussed and perceived to
have sexual abnormities in the physical arena that fail to express the individual’s metaphysical sex accurately. This
physical breakdown of the machine is due to the moral breakdown associated with the fall and curse. In the eternal state,
though, physical bodies will clearly show the true metaphysical gender. Hermaphroditism will be a thing of the past.
         In conjunction with other corollaries of the present study, more robust hypotheses may be formulated to account
for androgyny among some fallen angels than that posited by Godawa. When humanity suppressed the truth, God, as an
expression of His wrath, gave men and women over to unnatural sexuality, which includes homosexuality (Rom 1:18-
27). We also know from Scripture that what happens in the earthly arena is a shadow of the supernatural realm. Further,
God is not arbitrary. We have reason to suspect that angels and humans who reject Him are dealt with similarly by God.
Indeed, God will consign both fallen angels and unregenerate humans to the same eternal fate in the Lake of Fire.
Furthermore, humans have been created in the image of angels. Therefore, we have strong grounds for suspecting that
since God has given rebelling humans over to sexual prevision that results in various forms of unnatural sex, including
androgyny, the same may be true of angels. Fallen angels, like their human counterparts, may be subject to androgyny,
in all its various forms. Accordingly, some fallen angels will be predominantly, if not exclusively, masculine in both their
sexual genitalia and orientation. These gods can mate with human women and produce genetic hybrids. Likewise, some
fallen angels will be predominantly, if not exclusively, feminine in both their sexual genitalia and orientation. These
goddesses can mate with human males and produce genetic hybrids. As for those fallen angels who prefer to be more
fluid in their sexual expression and orientation, some of them might even be able to shapeshift between masculine or
feminine forms. Whether they have incarnated themselves sufficiently to be able reproduce sexually in doing so is a
