                                                        Conclusion
        Coleman recommends Red-Hot Monogamy by Bill and Pam Farrel (KL 3624). Their book is devoted to defending
the thesis that sex is better in a monogamous marriage than in promiscuous relationships. The Farrels also provide data
to defend that position. It is a good book. However, since their book shows that monogamy is superior, Coleman is
undermining his own book in giving a positive recommendation to their book. My book is in harmony with their book in
espousing monogamy. Their book is limited to monogamy on Earth. I am simply taking their argument to the next level
by posing that the monogamy in Heaven will be red hot also.
        My heterosexual-monogamous-perpetual-69-calculations are reasonable anticipations within my model as to just
how red-hot monogamy can and will be. One does not need to fantasize about polygamy or bestiality or bisexuality when
one can reasonably expect red-hot monogamy. If the purpose of the Song of Solomon is to portray red-hot monogamy,
as the Farrels believe and as Coleman has allowed and I have advocated, and if the Song is prophetic of the heavenly
ideal to be realized in the eschatological future as I have avowed, then polygamists are merely fantasying while
monogamists are rightfully anticipating and calculating. The Bible is leaving a trail of bread crumbs leading us to expect
monogamy, not polygamy, among the heavenly autocracy. This point has been proven with a high degree of inductive
certainty in the present book. The kings of Israel were explicitly forbidden from being polygamists. The leaders of the
NT church were explicitly required to be the husband of one wife. Postulating that kingdom rulers will be monogamous
is consistent with both OT and NT foreshadowing.
        As to the popular opinion that heavenly angels are androgynous, it is normally based on two mistaken premises.
On the one hand, many people misconstrue Jesus’s words in Lk 20:35-26 to mean that angels are sexless. On the other
hand, many people mistakenly think that the Bible only portrays male angels. Therefore, for any angel to assume a
feminine guise would be a false disguise, in their opinion. Goddesses are just cross-dressing gods. Female angels are
fake. Goddesses are really nothing more than transvestites. So Godawa. To the contrary, this study has demonstrated on
multiple fronts that angels are not sexless. And while due allowance has been made for the theoretical possibility of some
fallen transvestites, a hypothesis of through-going transvestism has been shown to be woefully inadequate. The data will
not allow either postulation to stand. One must conclude that (A) angels do in fact have gender, and (B) this gender
cannot be limited to male angels. A summary of some of the findings supporting this conclusion is in order.

However, I was unaware of this Viagra-like-vaginal-lubricant claim, reputed to come from Boas, at the time I formulated
my hypothesis about the potential aphrodisiacal nature of vaginal honey. Instead, my hypothesis was built solely upon
Scripture and logic. So if the Boas’ account is deemed to have any credibility, it would be experiential data confirming
my hypothesis. In any case, Marzulli portrays a man being raped by a female alien in his fictional account. Judging from
many reports, his fiction may be based on reality. L. A. Marzulli, The Unholy Deception, 63.

                                   Illustration 53. Problems with Asexual Androgyny
1. Angels are not asexual because humans have been created as male and female in the image of these gods and
    goddesses (Gen 1:26-27; 5:1-2).
2. Angels are not asexual because the angelic sons of God were sexual even before they fell. Their sexual desires led
    to their fall. The fall perverted their pre-existing sexual desires (Gen 6:1-4).
3. The fact that God created male angels is affirmed on multiple fronts. But if God created male angels, then the
    reasonable expectation is that He designed them to have sexual desires befitting their male gender. This design
    argument finds explicit biblical confirmation (Gen 6:14). Yet if God designed male angels with sexual desires, then
    it also stands to reason that He designed a female counterpart to meet the sexual needs of these male angels.
4. Rather than say, “It is not good for man not to have a procreator,” God said, “It is not good for the man to be alone”
    (Gen 2:18). The male need for a female mate is not limited to the need to procreate. The need for a female companion
    is not even tied to the need for procreation in this verse. Jesus is probably alluding to this implication, among others,
    when He says that males and females will be like angels when they are resurrected (Mt 22:30; Mk 12:25; Lk 20:36).
    The fact that male angels do not need to procreate does not prove that they do not need a female soulmate.
    Exegetically, we may infer that male angels are like human males in needing a female soulmate for purposes not
    connected to procreation. We may deduce that just as the human female was created because it was not good for the
    human male “to be alone,” so female angels were created because it is not good for male angels “to be alone” either.
5. From a number of texts, we should conclude that the earthly reality mirrors the heavenly reality. But if the male’s
    need for a female companion mirrors the heavenly reality, the we should deduce that male angels also need female
    companionship. Mirror typology supports the inference that male angels need female angels, but not procreation.
6. We are like angels in various regards, even being called angels and sons of God in a sexually inclusive manner. Thus,
    it stands to reason that they are like us in needing sexual companionship, even apart from the question of procreation.
7. The Bible describes fallen female cherubic angels (Zech 5:9).
8. Sexuality is ontological, not merely functional, as is proven by the presence of sexual desires in the metaphysical
    arena of astral sex.
9. NDErs confirm that sexual distinction between male and female angels is frequently discernable.
10. Even if the sexual gender of some heavenly angels is not as readily discernable, this does not mean that such angels
    are androgynous in function or sexually dysfunctional, as is supported by the fact that sexual activity in the astral
    plane does not require sexual genitals.
11. Androgyny in the form of hermaphroditism is a breakdown in the design that will be rectified in the resurrected state
    when the physical form clearly reflects the metaphysical gender.
12. God is not sexually neuter; neither are His image bearers. As Adam and Eve reflect the image of God through their
    sexuality, so too must angels reflect His image in their sexuality, since they are a reflection of the same image.
13. The cosmic ladder increases in sexual clarity as one ascends the ladder, thus necessitating that angels be
    distinguishable as both male and female.
14. Heiser’s dilemma (Illustration 22) shows the fallacy of not recognizing the existence of female angels.
15. Gabriel is an example of masculine gender, not transgender.
16. The Bible describes various OT goddesses without cloaking them in androgynous ambiguity.
17. Denying the existence of female angels in general is incompatible with acknowledging the existence of female
    cherubim in particular.
18. Seraphim and cherubim cover their genitals with their wings.
19. Biblical sources portray fallen angels and/or their male offspring as having large penises (Jer 5:8; Eze 23:20).
20. Extrabiblical sources portray fallen angels and/or their male offspring as having large penises.
21. Enoch confirms that the male watchers went “into” the human females to mate with them, which is an obvious
    euphemism for sexual intercourse, implying that the male watchers had male penises (1En 7:1).
22. Enoch quite possibly affirms the existence of female watchers (1En 19:1-2).
23. Using the pantheons of surrounding cultures to affirm that the gods were fallen male angels should lead one to
    conclude that the goddesses of those same pantheons were fallen female angels.
24. Archeology confirms that both the reptilian gods and goddesses were clearly pictured in sexually distinct roles with
    corresponding sexual genitals.
25. Given the results of their fall and their not following the design of the Designer, it is not surprising that some fallen
    male and female angels would act in homosexual and/or transsexual capacities. Their deviant behavior does not
    detract from the original heterosexual design, however, as being the standard of original angelic functional behavior
    and ontological identity.
26. Some of the alleged asexuality asserted regarding extradimensional beings might actually be mistakenly attributable
    to the clothing or suite they are wearing.

        As is observable in the list above, I have used cherubim to refute the opinion of some who say that angels are
sexless or wingless or always male. For instance, in my section entitled Winged Female Angels (p. 49), I refuted the
opinion of Judkins and McDaniel—that angels in Scripture are always wingless males—by pointing out that Judkins and
McDaniel classify cherubim as 4-winged angels and seraphim as 6-winged angles and acknowledge that the sphinx was
actually a symbolic depiction of a female angelic cherub pictured as a Lion Lady, a goddess.
        During the course of this study, I also have interacted with the scholarly presentation by Heiser in his book, The
Unseen Realm. After submitting the initial draft of my manuscript for initial proofreading, I decided to also read his less-
detailed book, Supernatural. Therein Heiser claims, “Angels don’t have wings. (Cherubim don’t count because they are
never called angels and are creaturely. Angels are always in human form.)”299 Opponents of my argument, accordingly,
might try to use such reasoning to offset my use of cherubim to prove that angels are both male and female. Therefore, I
will conclude by demonstrating that pressing Heiser’s statement to such an extent would be ill-advised.
        To assert that Satan was a fallen cherub but not a fallen angel probably draws a finer distinction than is warranted
by the biblical data or even by Heiser’s own discussion. His statements that cherubim are creaturely and therefore not
angelic pose a false dichotomy in assuming that one must choose between regarding cherubim as angels or creatures.
Alternatively, one may synthetically assert that cherubim are angelic creatures. This synthesis is more in accord with the
facts. Satan was a cherub elohim (divine being). Heiser immediately goes on to say that elohim “refers to any inhabitant
of the unseen spiritual world” (KL 183). In his more-detailed book, Heiser places angelic elohim last in his elohim list
and in his three-tiered hierarchy (Realm, 23-24, 30, 46). I have amended his list below to provide, among other things,
the hierarchal list of elohim suggested by his discussion.300


299
    Michael S. Heiser, Supernatural: What the Bible teaches about the unseen world and why it matters, Kindle Edition
(Bellingham, WA: Lexham Press, 2015), KL 168-169.
300
    I have broken Heiser’s sixth category into two categories in order to distinguish the Angel of the Lord from angels of
the Lord, and I have supplied alternate scriptural references since Heiser merged these two groups under one entry and
used Gen 35:7 as a singular reference for both. After all, both Heiser and I believe that the Angel of the Lord refers to
Jesus, not to angels in general. In my list, I have also noted that Jesus is the unique Son of Elohim, a perspective I also
share with Heiser. I also call particular attention to his inclusion of goddesses in his list of elohim: “They have forsaken
me and worshiped Ashtoreth the goddess [elohim] of the Sidonians, [and] Chemosh the god [elohim] of Moab”
(1Kgs 11:33; ESV).
     Heiser is inclined to distinguish the satan in Job 1:6-7 from Satan and place the satan in a lower status than the sons
of God (Realm, 56-57). I am not so inclined. Regardless, Satan was a council member (pp. 83-91).
     Additionally, Heiser’s acknowledging that elohim council members can be referred to as both sons of God or gods
should lead one to conclude that the gods and goddesses that humans worship are part of that council since Heiser
elsewhere assumes that the elohim who are so worshipped are indeed council members.
     Plus, he later states that in classical Greek a demon “can be a god or goddesss [sic], some lesser divine power, or the
spirit of the departed human dead. As such, it is akin to Hebrew elohim in its generic meaning” (p. 325). Consequently,
if demon is used of a god or goddess in classical Greek, it would be equivalent to the OT elohim, whether good or bad.
However, the LXX and intertestamental Judaism were probable factors that led to the NT adopting a negative view of
demons, possibly connecting demon possession with disembodied spirits of Nephilim. Most importantly, Paul quotes
Dt 32:17 in 1Cor 10:20-21 so that the demonic gods of these two passages refer to “high-ranking spiritual beings who
had authority both in pantheons and geographical domains on earth” (p. 328). These demons are gods in the sense of
being high-ranking fallen angels, conceptually overlapping with the sons of God in the divine council who were placed
over the nations. This portion of Heiser’s discussion is highly recommended insofar as it goes.
     What he fails to do is connect the dots and explicitly acknowledge that the elohim goddesses likewise conceptually
overlap this same lexical domain. Not only are these female goddesses elohim, they are high-ranking angelic goddesses,
when seen through a NT lexical lens. Whether the female goddesses are co-equal with the male gods in the hierarchy or
one step down in the angelic hierarchy is difficult to determine. In any event, “in the spiritual world, just as in the human
world, while divine beings (save for the unique Yahweh) are all of the same ‘species,’ some have higher rank than others”
(p. 332). My takeaway is that cherubim are part of this same angelic-elohim species, a type of angel for which we have
scriptural affirmation that some of them are females. Judkins and McDaniel were correct in this part of their deduction.
Consequently, not all angels are wingless males. Some angels have wings; some angels are female; some angels are
winged females. Heiser was wrong to remove cherubim from consideration in these areas. Judkins and McDaniel were
correct to include them but inconsistent in not following through on the logical implication of that inclusion.

        As Heiser will go on to explain, as inhabitants of the spiritual world, all spiritual beings are elohim. As to humanity,
in our spiritual post-resurrection state, “we will outrank angels” (Realm, emphasis his, 158). Yet, in that particular
context, Heiser only implies that we will outrank the lowly messenger angels. In other places, however, his discussion
correctly places us higher and even puts us in the divine council. Still, even this clarification fails to do full justice to the
fuller revelation that resurrected overcomers will be co-rulers with Christ over the new creation. So I would further
elucidate that we will be seated with Christ in the highest seats of the heavenly council, even above the angelic members
of that council—something that even Heiser seems to insinuate (see his ch. 36). A more forthright affirmation is therefore
in order: Overcomers will outrank all angels, even angels on the divine council.
        Heiser acknowledges and demonstrates that the NT uses the term angels as an “umbrella term” for the divine
council (p. 164). “Angelos [angel] had become a word deemed appropriate to generally describe a member of the
supernatural realm, just as elohim is used in the Old Testament” (p. 324). In this generic capacity, NT angel = OT elohim.
Splendid!301 What Heiser fails to fully elucidate, however, is that his concession places glorified humanity above all
members of the angelic council.302
        More importantly for the present discussion of non-human council members, Heiser’s acknowledgment that the
NT uses angels as an “umbrella term” for the divine council leads to the conclusion that cherubim are appropriately
considered angels since cherubim are members of the council (just as Satan was). Heiser unwittingly has placed himself
in the same predicament as Judkins and McDaniel. This dilemma might be stated syllogistically.

       1. All non-human divine council members are some type of angel.
       2. Some non-human divine council members are cherubim.
       3. Therefore, cherubim are some type of angel.

As a corollary, we must deduce that both male and female angels exist:

       1. Some cherubim are male, and some are female.
       2. Cherubim are some type of angel.
       3. Therefore, some angels are male, and some are female.

       Additionally, we may reasonably infer that some of these female angels may be council members, especially since
they were worshipped as goddesses. Scripture and logic, therefore, dictate that the angelic council is composed of both
gods and goddesses. Give a scholar enough rope, and he can hang himself! Heiser seems to have done just that in seeking
to remove extrapolations regarding cherubim as being applicable to angels and vice versa.
       While we cannot use cherubim to prove that resurrected humans will be like cherubim in having wings, a more
carefully nuanced articulation would clarify that the reason we cannot make the deduction from that limited range of data

301
    Heiser even quotes David E. Aune (WBC) approvingly in regarding the divine council depicted in Revelation 4-6:

sufficient for me to make my case that we are created as male and female in the image of male and female council
members since cherubim are male and female council members.

    As a result, Heiser’s understanding of the OT hierarchy should be adjusted. Namely, the rulership of the kingdom in

design was to put the material universe under the subjection of mankind, not under the rule of angelic council members:

is because cherubim are not the only types of angels. Since those types of angels that appear to be more humanoid in
appearance in the Bible are presumably presented as wingless males, we might question whether glorified humans will
have wings. Glorified humanity might be more like wingless angels in that regard. For myself, though, I would suppose
that if glorified humans want to have wings on occasion, they may do so. For example, to assume that all glorified
humans will be males simply because the most humanoid appearing angels in Scripture are male would be erroneous, a
weak argument from silence refuted by multiple strands of evidence. Likewise, the assumption that all glorified humans
will be wingless is subject to the same shortsightedness. Just because no humanlike angels presented in Scripture are said
to have wings does not mean that all anthropomorphic angels are wingless. We already know for certain, in the case of
cherubim, that some types of angels exist in male and female form. Furthermore, we have extremely strong grounds for
concluding that all types of angels have male and female counterparts. One might reasonably wonder, accordingly, if the
female counterparts of these humanlike angels have wings. Or one might pose that there are other types of
anthropomorphic angels that have wings. Or one might postulate that these male humanlike angels might sometimes have
wings and sometimes appear without wings.303 Such speculations would be in much better accord with the NDE and
OBE experiential data, which sometimes records anthropomorphic angels as having wings. Whatever eventually may
prove to be the case regarding wings, those trying to impose a wingless-male limitation on angels stumble over their own
concessions. Cherubim prove that some angels are winged females.
         Collaboration is possible by approaching the discussion from a different direction. Since Satan was a council
member, he was one of the sons of God, which is a commonly conceded conclusion.304 Since mankind (1) was created
in the likeness of the sons of God who serve on the divine council and (2) was created as male and female, the proper
deduction is that (3) the sons of God on the council were comprised of both male and female angels. This conclusion
harmonizes with our observations regarding Satan. As a cherub he would have had a female counterpart ruling with him.
We were created in the image of God by being created in the image of such male and female entities, and we mirror these
heavenly entities. If human male has to have female counterpart to rule, it stands to reason that the angelic entities they
mirror would as well. Being part of the physical dimension, humans were just created further down the hierarchal scale.
Nevertheless, since mankind was created as part of the material universe and originally as a single couple, this first human
male-and-female couple were given the command to copulate so that they might populate the physical dimension and
thereby expand their dominion.
         Angels were lacking this procreative ability, as Jesus points out. Enoch concurs by explaining that angels do not
need to procreate since they are immortal. Heiser likewise correctly points out that “in the spiritual world, the realm of
divine beings, there is no need for procreation. Procreation is part of the embodied world and is necessary to maintain
the physical population,” but he wrongly goes on to conclude: “Consequently, there is no need for sex in the resurrection,
just as there is no need for it in the nonhuman spiritual realm” (p. 186). Not true! The need for sex is not limited to
procreation! What Heiser should have concluded is that those in resurrected bodies will have no need for procreative sex.
Nevertheless, procreative sex will be needed in the eternal state by mode-one humanity so that humanity as a species can
fulfil the original mandate and spread God’s rule throughout the whole cosmos, which we now know to be the multiverse.
Human procreation is necessary to multiply God’s image throughout the multiverse. However, resurrected believers will
not need to engage in this procreative sex since this procreative sex will be carried out by mode-one humanity. Mode-
two humanity (i.e., resurrected overcomers) will still need personal sex, not for procreative reasons but for multiple other
reasons pointed out in the present book, not the least of which is to function as God’s image bearers.
